HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
In the 'I Love New York' campaign, a new kind of Broadway revival.

BYLINE: By Glenn Collins 

 BODY:
NEW YORK STATE [loves] Broadway. Again.
For the first time in more than a decade, the state's tourism promotion, "I Love New York," with its high-recognition "I[love]NY" icon, will focus on Broadway theater as a tourist asset in a $1 million television and radio campaign that begins tomorrow. 
 Today, at a promotional extravaganza in Manhattan's Shubert Theater to be attended by Gov. George E. Pataki and his wife, Libby, the state will introduce the commercial, which depicts the bustle and anticipation at curtain time from the standpoint of a theatergoer.
The original campaign, started in 1977 by what is now Wells Rich Greene BDDP in New York, made heavy use of Broadway stars and shows, including the chorus kids from "A Chorus Line" and Broadway's Dracula, Frank Langella, who purred that he loved New York "especially in the evening."
" 'I Love New York' invented state tourism advertising, and was tremendously influential," said John Farr, a partner at Ogilvy & Mather New York, the unit of the WPP Group that won the account in February. Wells Rich, now a unit of BDDP Worldwide, handled "I Love New York" until 1991; then it went to McCann-Erickson New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, until 1994.
The four-note 'I Love New York' musical refrain is back, but no stars appear in the new commercial, though Matthew Broderick narrates. The marquees of a few shows are visible in atmospheric shots of the Great White Way.
The Broadway component of "I Love New York" was de-emphasized in the 1980's because of budget constraints and complaints by upstaters that New York's other tourist attractions were being slighted.
But New York City tourism officials countered that the campaign had taken on too much of an upstate emphasis. According to the New York City Convention and Visitors Bureau, the city generates $14 billion of the state's annual $25.6 billion in tourism revenue.
A study last year by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey found that Broadway theater contributed $2.3 billion a year to the economy of New York, and generated $142 million annually in taxes.
The new commercial, which cost $400,000 to produce, is the sixth in a series of "I Love New York" ads since June; others were set in locales like Lake George, Cooperstown and West Point, as well as New York City. "We wanted to relaunch 'I Love New York' in a personal way that would speak directly to vacationers," Mr. Farr said.
He said the advertising buy for the summer campaign, which ran from June to July 23, was $3.2 million for television and radio, in local markets as well as in Philadelphia, Washington, Pittsburgh and Cleveland. The new four-week buy for the Broadway campaign will cost $1 million in the same markets, he said.
"There is no state in America that doesn't have a lake or a mountain or a museum, but no other state has Broadway," said Nancy Coyne, chief executive of Serino Coyne Inc., the advertising agency that represents more than a dozen Broadway shows. She worked on the new commercial as a liaison between Ogilvy & Mather New York and Broadway theater executives.
"Rule 1 of advertising is to sell what is unique about your product, and what is unique about New York is Broadway," she added.
Gerald Schoenfeld, chairman of the Shubert Organization, said that according to the State Department of Commerce, "the original 'I Love New York' commercials featuring the Broadway theater earned $22 for every dollar invested."
"We certainly hope that the new investment will be at least as profitable for the state, the city and the theater as the first one was," he added.
The new Broadway campaign "represents a huge commitment on the part of the state," said Charles A. Gargano, Commissioner of the New York State Department of Economic Development, adding that state officials "felt it was a good investment to showcase Broadway again."
Jed Bernstein, the new executive director of the League of American Theaters and Producers, the Broadway trade organization, said the league, with the Theater Development Fund, which operates the TKTS booths for discount-priced theater tickets, had contributed $280,000 toward the making of the commercial. The other $120,000 came from Mr. Gargano's department. " 'I Love New York' has come back to Broadway and we couldn't be more thrilled," Mr. Bernstein said.
As an advertising executive at Wells Rich, Mr. Bernstein pitched its "I Love New York" presentation to New York State last winter. He lost to Ogilvy.
"I think we can work pretty effectively, though," Mr. Bernstein said with a laugh, "since I worked for O & M for 10 years," from 1979 to 1989.
The new commercial offers a toll-free telephone number (800 I-LOVE-NY, what else?) as a tie-in with the theater league's "Destination Broadway" tourism-cum-marketing initiative with Delta Air Lines. It offers trips to Manhattan, including guaranteed premium tickets to Broadway shows.
Because two-thirds of the tourism dollars spent in New York come from within the state and from visitors from New Jersey and Connecticut, the new commercial will also be aimed at the metropolitan market.
"That's all right, we get lots of tourists from New York," said Linda Mysliwy Conlin, director of the New Jersey Division of Travel and Tourism. "Broadway is special, but they don't have our Paper Mill Playhouse."

GRAPHIC: Photo: New York State's tourism promotion campaign is refocusing on Broadway. A new spot shows the Shubert Theater in Manhattan. (Ogilvy & Mather)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long-Term Treasuries Rise Despite Gains in Housing

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities gained for the first time in three sessions yesterday, despite an increase in housing starts. Talk of a Japanese economic-stimulus package helped the dollar overnight and, in turn, lifted bonds at the opening.
Investor demand for corporate and global issues also worked favorably for bonds. Also helping the market was the expectation among some participants of more foreign buyers. 
 August housing starts rose six-tenths of 1 percent, to a rate of 1.398 million units annually. Economists surveyed by Bloomberg Business News had expected starts to slip 1.4 percent, to an annual rate of 1.36 million units after surging by 7.1 percent in July, revised upward from 6.7 percent.
The 30-year bond rose 21/32, to a price of 105 5/32 to yield 6.48 percent, down from 6.53 percent on Monday.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, said the bond market improved yesterday on the heels of Monday's losses, virtually ignoring the slight increase in August housing starts.
"Housing will most certainly contribute to an improved rate of gross domestic product growth in the third quarter," he said, "as compared to the second quarter, but at the same time it should also be noted that the August level of starts is still nearly 4.5 percent below a year ago."
Mr. Fine added that "Although bond yields for nearly three weeks have gyrated upon the release of virtually every important economic statistic," movements in the Treasury's current 30-year issue have revolved "around a yield of 6.50 percent for this entire period."
Many traders said the market's focus was mainly on the Federal Reserve and its chairman, Alan Greenspan, who is scheduled to testify on Friday before the Senate Banking Committee. The central bank's monetary policy arm, the Federal Open Market Committee, will meet on Tuesday.
"If Mr. Greenspan follows form, he will cleverly veil F.O.M.C. thinking and intentions in a barrage of econo-babble," Mr. Fine said. "My own thinking, of course, is that the F.O.M.C. will choose to leave policy unchanged at its Sept. 26 meeting, and very likely ease by a quarter of a point at the Nov. 15 meeting once data are available for at least part of the fourth quarter showing continued benign inflation with only moderate economic growth."
Another factor in yesterday's rise in prices, James Hale, a fixed- income analyst with MMS International in San Francisco, said, was the Japanese economic-stimulus plan.
"The fiscal-stimulus package of over 14 trillion yen bode well for U.S. fixed-income markets, at least in the short and intermediate term," Mr. Hale said. "The aggressive package should temper some anxiety about Japan's banking system woes, and more importantly for Treasuries, it will help sustain the recently favorable capital flows out of Japan."
Until recently, Mr. Hale said, "Japanese institutions were handcuffed by massive losses in domestic assets, even forced to repatriate overseas investments like U.S. Treasury securities to cover these losses."
"But with the Nikkei and dollar both rebounding now and the threat of a banking crisis easing a bit," he added, "Japanese investors should be able to sustain the pace of recent Treasury purchases."
In the corporate bond market, where people are yield-hungry, investors snapped up bonds issued by Dresdner Bank New York, a subsidiary of the big German bank Dresdner Bank A.G. The offering, through underwriters led by J. P. Morgan Securities, was increased by 25 percent, to $1 billion.
Investors are eager for dollar-denominated bonds of Dresdner and other foreign issuers because they typically offer higher yields than United States corporate issuers with similarly rated debt. This compensates buyers for a number of risk factors, from political instability or currency risks to solvency of the issuer or just lack of familiarity with the issuer.
Dresdner sold $500 million of 10-year notes at 53 basis points more than a similar-maturity Treasury issue, or about 10 basis points more than investors can get from the same double-A rated bonds from American companies, according to Bloomberg Analytics. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
For $500 million of 20-year notes, the German bank offered a yield of 64 basis points more than comparable Treasury securities.

HEADLINE: Regla Journal;
Helpless Cuban Wives, Marooned by U.S. Policy

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: REGLA, Cuba

 BODY:
In a dark, Spartan room that resembles more a jail cell than a living room, Sonia Fonseca brought out a stack of 53 letters from a husband in a prison of his own.
"You suffer but I suffer twice as much because my hands are tied," he wrote. "We must continue resisting so that we can fulfill our dreams." 
 Her husband, Tomas Espiau, 45, is among the 10,000 or so Cuban detainees who remain at the United States naval base at Guantanamo Bay, 500 miles away on the eastern end of the island, more than a year after they set out in boats and rafts for Florida.
Held in refugee camps after more than 30,000 Cubans sought entry into the United States last summer by taking to the seas, the detainees are being released gradually. Mr. Espiau is scheduled to reach American soil before March, when the camps are expected to close.
But if the wait has been difficult for Mr. Espiau, it is hardly bearable for his wife, one of scores of Cuban women who counted on the financial help of husbands and boyfriends who were expected to reach the United States but who ended up in worse misery because of the men's long detention at Guantanamo. Many said they encouraged the men to leave for the benefit of their families, only to be left to fend for themselves in times of increasing hardship.
Mr. Espiau, who like many of the detainees was searching for a job and the ability to send money, left a 6-year-old daughter, who started school in September short of underwear, and a 14-year-old stepson with one pair of socks. His wife, 43, spends her days cooking for neighbors, selling homemade sweets, washing the family's meager supply of clothes almost daily for wear the next day and exchanging frustrations with her husband by mail.
"He knows it's not easy," she said, in a phrase echoed everywhere these days during Cuba's "special period," the years of economic crisis brought on by the collapse of trade and aid from the Soviet bloc.
Similar stories are heard everywhere in Regla, a town by Havana Bay where neighbors vividly remember the frenzy at the height of the exodus in August and September 1994, when crowds hoisted rafts, Regla ferries were hijacked and relatives swamped the Nuestra Senora de Regla Church, checking the migrants' fate on posted lists.
When it was over, neighbors said, the town seemed robbed of its youth.
From Ms. Fonseca's block, 15 left. Many women had to seek jobs for the first time, including Sara Lemus, whose husband, an electrician, is still on the base. Left with a son, 7, she recently found work as a receptionist. But like most Cubans, she complained about being paid in pesos while increasingly only dollars buy clothes, meat and other essentials.
Like many other women, she had counted on dollar remittances from the United States. Although banned by American restrictions on aid to Cuba, millions of dollars get to the island from relatives through third countries, American and Cuban officials say.
Her sister next door, Rosa, 32, was luckier. Her husband was allowed to leave Guantanamo for the United States three months ago and has already sent $50 after finding work in a Tampa bodega. Rosa Lemus, who has a son, 11, and a daughter, 7, said she bought shoes for her children, soap, cooking oil, rice and meat.
The sisters say they live for the day their when husbands pluck them out of Cuba after they gain their own legal residency, a sponsorship process that can take four to five years. "The situation has gotten worse and worse," Sara said.
Not all the women wait. Limay Galvez, 20, said she resented that her husband, 22, left abruptly, not promising a future together. But he had a change of heart in Guantanamo, she said, and the love letters began.
"He said he missed me, that he was going to send for me," she said.
Unmoved, Ms. Galvez told her father-in-law that she was breaking off the year-old marriage and moved back with her family. She is now dating her neighbor, who was her first boyfriend.
More than 32,000 Cubans were held in refugee camps in Guantanamo and Panama before the Clinton Administration selectively began allowing them into the country, starting with the old, the sick and families with children. In May, officials announced that all who remained in Guantanamo would be released but that for the first time Cubans picked up at sea would be turned back.
More than 100 boat people have since been returned, Coast Guard officials said.
Under migration accords reached by Cuban and American officials last year, Cubans must now apply to the United States Interests Section in Havana for one of 20,000 visas given annually. The agreements for the first time allowed those with no sponsoring relatives or political reasons a chance to gain entry.
Sonia Fonseca's hope is her husband of eight years, who she said had spent three years in prison for previous escape attempts.
From Guantanamo, Mr. Espiau sends pictures of the tent he shares with other refugees and of his more robust self. In the first two months at the camp, he gained 25 pounds.
In Regla, Ms. Fonseca waits in a shack in a narrow alley, with bare floors and one window. Already thin, she sometimes goes to bed hungry.
Her husband has told her he will be out in November. "If I've resisted one year," she said, "a few more months are nothing."

GRAPHIC: Photo: With her husband detained at Guantanamo, Sonia Fonseca and her children, Mirelyis and Carlos, are having a hard time in Regla, Cuba. They stood in front of their home, a shack with bare floors and one window. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Giuliani, at U.N. Opening Ceremony, Assails New Isolationist Mood in Congress

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 19

 BODY:
In a strongly-worded attack on the isolationist mood swelling in a Congress dominated by his fellow Republicans, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani helped kick off the 50th session of the United Nations General Assembly today, criticizing the "potent strain of isolationism that once again is infecting our political discourse."
The Mayor did not mention the Republican Party by name and said in an interview later that he was not singling out his party or fellow politicians. Still, his defense of the United Nations' achievements and of immigrants' contribution to the nation marked the latest in a series of attempts by Mr. Giuliani to set himself apart from the newly dominant conservative wing of the Republican majority. Many of those Republicans want to end or cut back financing to the U.N. and favor severe immigration restrictions. 
 "Sometimes, leadership means taking unpopular positions, rejecting harmful political fads," Mr. Giuliani said today. "Sometimes, leadership requires challenging myths. That's the kind of leadership we need in defining our relationship with the U.N. and also on the issue of immigration."
Mayor Giuliani's speech echoed his criticism last month of immigration restrictions proposed by a panel named by the Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich, which recommended cracking down on benefits for illegal aliens. At the time, Mr. Giuliani said such restrictions not only violated basic decency but could also have "catastrophic social effects" on New York and other large cities.
Today's speech marked the first such appearance by a mayor of New York City in nearly half a century. The last mayor to address the General Assembly was William O'Dwyer, who welcomed the delegates at their temporary quarters in Flushing Meadows Park in 1947.
Mr. Giuliani spoke to delegates from 185 member states who convened in the General Assembly chamber for the opening of three months of speeches and debate.
While the United Nations invited Mr. Giuliani to attend the Assembly's opening session, the United States representative, Madeleine K. Albright, gave her spot on the list of speakers to the Mayor.
The Mayor's kind words about the United Nations came at a time when it is beset by an array of problems, ranging from a rocky peacekeeping mission in the Balkans to a financial crisis caused by the failure of member states like the United States to pay their full assessments.
"The U.N. provides a crucial forum for international debate and cooperation," the Mayor said.
Mayor Giuliani described the drive on Capitol Hill to cut back support and funds for the United Nations as "an ill-conceived proposition that would achieve only symbolic savings in the Federal budget, while greatly impeding the operations of the United Nations and hurting the economy of the United Nations' host country, the United States," as well as that of New York City.
The case he made for immigration was even more spirited. "You can't be a New Yorker -- you can't be part of this city -- and deny the contributions of immigrants," said Mr. Giuliani, whose grandparents immigrated from Italy.
"Our nation owes its existence to the hard work, determination and vision of immigrants," he said, "and in the end I am confident that support for immigration will prevail over this latest advent of suspicion."
The Mayor hailed New York as "not only the world's most diverse city but also the world's most cosmopolitan and tolerant city."
The Mayor also has an economic incentive to be supportive of the U.N. A recent study for the city's Commission for the United Nations, Consular Corps and International Business found that the United Nations, its agencies and accredited diplomatic missions spend $3.3 billion a year in New York City and create 30,000 local jobs, according to Jane R. Steiner, a deputy commissioner. She said this includes $10 million for parking tickets.
Mr. Giuliani joked that he wanted the delegates to visit every part of the city "and spend money." But he also stressed that New Yorkers welcomed their presence.
"We want to say to all of you that wherever you come from and however long you are here, you are New Yorkers," Mr. Giuliani said.
The General Assembly will open its general debate next Monday and wind up in mid-December. More than 150 foreign leaders are expected to attend a special session commemorating the U.N.'s 50th anniversary, which will take place from Oct. 22 to 24.

HEADLINE: Senator Proposes to Charge Colleges for Student Loans

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, chairwoman of the Committee on Labor and Human Resources, today called for cutting spending on Federal student loans by $10.1 billion, in large part by adding a 2 percent charge to colleges and universities on all Federal loans their students receive.
Thus New York University, for example, whose students received about $150 million in new student loans in the 1994-95 academic year, would have to pay a charge of about $3 million. 
 The new charge, which angry Democrats labeled a "tax," would raise $4.4 billion of the $10.1 billion the Kansas Republican's committee is required to save over seven years as part of the effort to balance the budget.
The proposal is almost certain to be approved by the committee on Wednesday. But it will be challenged on the Senate floor when it comes up as part of the budget reconciliation bill. Last spring the Senate voted to limit cuts in the loan program to $4.4 billion, but after negotiations with the House, the cut on the program of $25 billion a year was raised to $10.1 billion.
Ed Elmendorf, vice president for government relations of the American Association of State Colleges and Universities, described the proposal as "stupid," and likely to be favored only by the student loan industry as a way of avoiding higher charges to banks and other lenders.
Senator Kassebaum said she had received complaints from colleges and universities in her state, but insisted that she had no alternative way to raise the money required by the budget resolution.
Her bill would forbid colleges and universities to raise tuition or fees to pay for the new charge. But Terry Hartle, vice president of governmental relations of the American Council on Education, said the requirement was an effort to "repeal the laws of economics." He said students would pay directly or indirectly, or else colleges would reduce other forms of financial aid.
The other plans to save on loans in Senator Kassebaum's proposal are these:
*Decreasing to four months from six months in the interest-free grace period students enjoy after graduation, saving $850 million.
*Increasing the interest rate on loans taken out by parents by nine-tenths of 1 percent, saving $1.4 billion.
*Reducing Federal payments to lenders and guarantee agencies, saving $2.3 billion, or about 7 percent of the $30 billion in projected Federal spending for the industry's expenses and profits.
*Reducing Federal spending to supervise student loans, saving $700 million.
*Halting the growth of the direct loan program, under which money is lent directly to students by the Federal Government, a new program enacted in 1993 to compete with and perhaps replace the old program under which the Government guaranteed loans made by banks. That change, according to new accounting rules established by Republicans this year, would save $450 million.
The House Committee on Economic and Educational Opportunities will not meet on this issue until next week. That committee wants to abolish the direct loans outright.
The opportunities for the committees are rather limited. An earlier scheme of reducing or eliminating the interest subsidies and raising other direct charges to students stirred complaints over the summer. This proposal from Senator Kassebaum has come forward with much less time for debate.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, the senior Democrat on the committee, denounced the Kassebaum plan. He called the 2 percent charge a tax, and, alluding to Republican plans to cut taxes as part of this year's budget, said, "The Republican Congress has no business picking the pockets of students and working families to pay for tax cuts for the rich."
Opponents plan to propose an amendment on the Senate floor, calling for a much smaller cut and identifying some business tax benefit that could be eliminated to save the same amount of money. That was the approach the Senate adopted, 67 to 32, when it passed a proposal by Senators Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, and Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, on May 25.
But it may be more difficult to get time to debate the proposal when the reconciliation bills comes to the floor, and so the May vote is not a comfortable predictor of Senate action this time.
Still, the higher education community is cranking up opposition to the proposal.
Robert H. Atwell, president of the American Council on Education, wrote Senator Kassebaum to remind her that the University of Kansas would face a $700,000 charge. And he wrote that it was wrong to penalize colleges for admitting needy students:
"It's hard to imagine the Department of Agriculture imposing a tax on grocery stores based on the number of food stamps the store accepts. That, however, is exactly what your plan would do to colleges."

HEADLINE: Cab Fleet Coalition Seeks Increase of 27% in Fares

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
A coalition of yellow cab fleets petitioned City Hall yesterday for an average 27 percent increase in taxi fares, the first increase in almost six years, and the group's leader said the city should require that some of the increase go to drivers.
Officials in the industry and at the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission, whose approval is needed for any increase, suggested that the success of the proposal could turn on drivers' income, which the commission says has remained almost unchanged for a decade. 
 Last year, the commission rejected a proposed fare increase, concluding that owners were exploiting drivers and would hoard the profits from any increase. The new commission chairman, Christopher Lynn, has set a goal of increasing drivers' income by $20 a day.
Mr. Lynn declined to comment on the proposal directly. But he said, "I would like to see the profession of taxi driver be the serious, esteemed job it used to be, and that's not going to happen on minimum wage."
Under the new proposal, the charge for the first fifth of a mile would rise from $1.50, to $2. For each additional fifth of a mile in free-flowing traffic, the fare would increase from 25 cents, to 30 cents, and for time spent stuck in traffic, the charge would go from 20 cents per minute to 25 cents. Over all, for a typical cab ride of 2.47 miles, the fare would climb from $5.70, to $7.10, a 25 percent increase.
The rise was proposed by the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade, a coalition of 22 fleets that accounts for 19 percent of the city's nearly 12,000 medallion cabs. Its latest contract with the Taxi Drivers and Allied Workers Union requires that half the money from a fare increase go to drivers. "The city should require a similar arrangement from the other owners," said the group's president, Ronald Stoppelmann.
Most of the city's cabbies lease taxis from their owners, either for a 12-hour shift or a week. Fares have not risen since January 1990, but industry officials and drivers say cab lease rates have increased to about $85 a shift. Drivers keep all the fares and tips they collect, but because they must pay the lease cost and buy gasoline, they must make more than $100 a day to break even.
Several drivers said the taxi commission should cap lease rates to prevent owners from using an increase in the lease rate to get some of the profits from a fare increase.
Mr. Lynn said he shared that concern and noted that in recent years the mere rumor of a fare increase would push up lease rates.
The taxi commission will hold public hearings and then vote on the proposal, which could go into effect in December at the earliest.
The idea of a fare increase with some protections for drivers was quickly hailed by drivers as a needed boost for an industry that has never regained much of the business it lost as the region's economy slumped in the late 1980's and early 1990's. "We need it, and even with this deal, we still would not get paid adequately for what we have to go through," said Herbert Vartabedian, 54, who has been a cabdriver for 19 years.
Riders were less enthusiastic about the plan, though some said they agreed an increase was called for. "The subway fare's going up and everything else is going up, and it's been a long time since this went up, so I guess it's time," said Anne-Marie Smith, 43, a secretary who stood yesterday on 57th Street in Manhattan, trying to hail a cab.
Jack Carr, 36, an office manager who rode a cab from Wall Street to Times Square, called it "crazy" to increase fares. "It's already way too much," he said.
Yellow cabs are an essential part of the city's transportation network, carrying more than 500,000 people a day, mostly in the lower half of Manhattan and to and from the airports. They are licensed by the city, which has limited their numbers to 11,787 since 1937, though the city plans to sell the rights to 400 more medallions over the next three years.
Without an increase, the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade fleets will not be able to turn a profit next year, Mr. Stoppelmann said. "Since 1990, the single biggest cost, the cost of the vehicle, went out of control," he said. "The most common cab, the Chevy Caprice, went from $12,000, to $18,860, this year."

HEADLINE: Kerkorian's Point Man Has Chrysler Guessing

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Jerome B. York, the new point man in Kirk Kerkorian's effort to coax the Chrysler Corporation's shares higher, met with three Chrysler executives for two hours today. But the meeting, somewhere in Westchester County outside New York, amounted to little more than a ritual, polite dance performed against a backdrop of rising tension between the two skirmishing sides.
"We didn't tell Tracinda anything we didn't tell any of our other large investors," said Arthur C. Liebler, Chrysler's vice president for marketing and communications, referring to Mr. Kerkorian's investment company. "We listened to whatever Mr. York and Tracinda had to say, and didn't hear anything new there either." 
 In fact, what is most interesting about Mr. Kerkorian's new strategy is how little he is publicly proposing, so far. That approach is shaping up to be far more vexing to Chrysler than the failed buyout bid by Mr. Kerkorian last spring.
Mr. York says that increasing the stock price, not running Chrysler, is his goal. He praises Chrysler's products and managers. But Chrysler should be passing more of its cash on to shareholders, he says. His record suggests he would favor a big stock buyback over higher dividends.
But Chrysler insiders believe that Mr. Kerkorian just wants to save face. "This has nothing to do with boosting shareholder value any more," said one Chrysler executive who insisted on anonymity. "It's become an ego thing."
That dismissive attitude aside, Chrysler has seemed off balance since Mr. York's hiring two weeks ago, in a way it never was during the spring and summer.
Wall Street is buzzing with rumors of uncertain origin about Mr. York's real plans -- some of which have grown so pervasive that Chrysler has felt it necessary to respond to them.
One such rumor holds that Mr. York hopes to take the place of Robert J. Eaton, Chrysler's chairman and chief executive, while retaining Robert A. Lutz, Chrysler's president, past his mandatory retirement at age 65 in 1997. Chrysler's board is already considering a way to retain Mr. Lutz, who is popular within the company and on Wall Street, Chrysler executives said.
In an interview today, Mr. Lutz anticipated a question and declared: "There is a greater degree of harmony in top management here, including between Bob Eaton and myself -- you know, just to pre-empt the next question -- than I've ever experienced in any company I've ever served in." Asked if he would remain past retirement age, if so requested by the board, Mr. Lutz said today, "sure I would."
Other rumors, seemingly unrelated to Tracinda, have gained credence simply because of the threat from Mr. Kerkorian. Today, Volvo shares climbed in Stockholm and New York on speculation in Europe and the United States that Chrysler was seeking to buy the company, a possibility dismissed by Chrysler executives. Stock analysts said that Volvo would make sense as a purchase only if Chrysler was seeking to use up excess cash to fend off Mr. Kerkorian.
In fact, Mr. Lutz suggested that Chrysler might not keep so much cash on the books, despite its stated goal of setting aside $7.5 billion to tide it over the next sales recession. "It's not like it's excessive," Mr. Lutz said of the automotive cash reserve, which was $6.9 billion at the end of the second quarter. "But will it always be exactly seven? I can't guarantee that."
He said, "It might be possible at some point to find a different mix of elements that gives us the same degree of financial stability."
Mr. Eaton is scheduled to address the Council of Institutional Investors at a meeting in New York in early October. The speech may provide an opportunity for Mr. Eaton to solidify his support among leading investors, but a spokesman said his speech had not been written yet.
In tightly controlled interviews with journalists, Mr. York has so far issued none of the slipshod pronouncements that leaped like popping corn out of Mr. Kerkorian's camp last fall, scaring some institutional investors: there has been no talk of slashing Chrysler's cash reserve by more than 70 percent; of an immediate, sharp rise in the dividend; of an alliance with a foreign auto maker; of the poor quality of Chrysler vehicles.
Gone, too, at least from the public eye, is Lee A. Iacocca, the source of the comments on quality, which irritated many investors and enraged Chrysler executives who recalled major quality problems when Mr. Iacocca was in charge. Mr. York said Mr. Iacocca remained a consultant to Mr. Kerkorian's company, Tracinda, and that Mr. York talks to him by telephone "a couple of times a week," particularly about sales and marketing issues.
Friends of Mr. York have said that he would have signed on with Tracinda only if he believed he would wind up running Chrysler. Passed over in favor of Mr. Eaton in 1992, Mr. York was Chrysler's chief financial officer and a member of its board until spring 1993, when he left to become chief financial officer at the International Business Machines Corporation
But in an interview, Mr. York said that when he wrote down the pros and cons of joining Tracinda as he started seriously considering the offer in mid-August, "The possibility of become C.E.O. of Chrysler was not on the list."
"The thing I like in life is working on sizable projects where I'm sufficiently influential to where I can affect the outcome," he said. "Helping Tracinda manage its investments to maximize their value was of high interest to me."
Rather than another buyout bid, Tracinda appears to be gearing up for some form of proxy fight to maximize that investment. But Mr. York declined to discuss what actions Tracinda might take. He is urging Chrysler to sell off some nonautomotive assets, as Chrysler has said it plans to do. And he has zeroed in on Chrysler's cash hoard.
Mr. York said that while Eaton's stated target of $7.5 billion was too high, he had not determined how much cash Chrysler needed to see it through the next downturn. He said he believes that while Chrysler might be larger now than during the last recession -- when it burned through more than $4 billion to survive -- it is also more efficient. He pointed out that it now had better credit ratings and a stronger balance sheet, sells more popular cars and trucks and has fully financed its pension fund. "It's a whole different ballgame there now," he said.
Further, he said, if Chrysler expects the economy to remain strong in coming quarters, there is no reason it needs to keep so much cash sitting around now.
Mr. York appears to favor stock buybacks over dividend increases. He said institutional investors tended to prefer buybacks, which enhance the value of their shares, rather than increases in dividends, which are taxable. In trading today on the New York Stock Exchange, Chrysler shares closed at $56.625 a share, up 62.5 cents.
During Mr. York's tenure at I.B.M., the company announced no dividend increases but two buybacks of $2.5 billion apiece.

HEADLINE: Goldman Reworks Rockefeller Center Bid

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
Goldman, Sachs & Company offered yesterday to return a $33 million loan payment to Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., the real estate investment trust that is poised to take control of Rockefeller Center.
The offer appeared to be an effort to sweeten Goldman's bid to buy a controlling interest in the property. But Sam Zell, the Chicago financier who is leading an investor group competing for control of the center, called Goldman's offer an attempt to paper over a loophole in loans it made to the real estate investment trust, or REIT, last December -- loans that could weaken the investment bank's hand in the fight over Rockefeller Center. 
 A spokesman for Goldman and its Whitehall Street Real Estate L.P., an investment fund acting on behalf of Goldman, denied there were loopholes in the loans.
In documents filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Whitehall answered questions from the REIT's board about its bid. The board may vote at a meeting on Friday on whether to accept Whitehall's offer to invest up to $200 million in the REIT in exchange for almost doubling its stake in the company.
The REIT's board has already signed a deal with a group led by Mr. Zell that includes the Walt Disney Company, the General Electric Company and Merrill Lynch & Company That group plans to invest $250 million for a 50 percent stake.
The Goldman proposal, which is largely an attempt to undo the Zell deal, was made after the board had signed the Zell agreement, but the board has a fiduciary responsibility to consider any bids that might give the REIT's shareholders a better return. Whitehall contends that its proposal would dilute the existing shareholders' stake in the REIT less than the Zell deal would, and that Whitehall would pay more for its stake. But it would leave the REIT with more debt.
Whitehall said it would consider adjusting the terms attached to $75 million of $225 million in loans that it and the Goldman, Sachs Mortgage Company extended to the REIT in December. Those loans, which carry unusually high interest rates, and the attached warrants and shareholder appreciation rights give Whitehall tremendous influence over the REIT.
The investment fund also assured the REIT that it had no plans to sell the buildings of Rockefeller Center, though it had previously suggested to those involved in negotiations for the property that greater value could be realized by selling the individual buildings.
Mr. Zell contended that the offer to return the $33 million was really an attempt by Goldman to close a loophole in the loan documents that allows the REIT to prepay the loans, even though the $75 million Whitehall loan specifically prohibits prepayment.
The $33 million payment the REIT made to Goldman on Sept. 1 resulted from a provision in the loan documents called a "cash flow sweep." It requires the REIT, which holds a $1.3 billion mortgage on Rockefeller Center, to hand over to Goldman all its cash flow not needed to cover operating and interest expenses if the center's owners default on their mortgage payments.
The owners, two partnerships controlled by the Mitsubishi Estate Company, filed for bankruptcy protection in May and stopped making mortgage payments. The REIT had expected Whitehall to waive the sweep, but it did not. Mr. Zell stepped in last month with $10 million that gave the REIT money to operate after it paid Goldman, and on Aug. 28 -- two days before the REIT faced a severe financial squeeze -- Goldman offered to waive the requirement.
The Zell group's plans for buying a 50 percent stake in the REIT require the use of the cash flow sweep to pay all of Goldman's debt, thus eliminating Goldman's influence.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Caterpillar disappoints, and everyone nearby is punished.

BYLINE: By Barnaby J. Feder 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
CATERPILLAR INC.'S brief warning Monday evening that it had cut production and that third-quarter earnings would be down from a year ago could be a harbinger of a coming recession. On the other hand, sales are continuing to set records and the earnings decline may be largely a result of an accounting hiccup based on swings in the tax rates paid by the giant manufacturer of heavy equipment.
With scant guidance from Caterpillar, which is based in Peoria, Ill., Wall Street pondered a variety of possible explanations for the earnings disappointment yesterday while handing out the usual punishment for unwelcomed mysteries. Caterpillar's shares plunged more than $6 in heavy early trading on the Big Board and finished with a loss of $6.50 at $58.875. 
 Investor interest in Caterpillar is understandable. Not only is it one of the 30 companies that make up the Dow Jones industrial average, but as the world's largest construction equipment company and one of the United States' largest exporters, Caterpillar is viewed as a barometer of both the domestic and global economy.
Caterpillar's plunge dragged down the Dow but the biggest impact was on other makers of capital equipment. Major competitors like Deere and Case, component suppliers like Parker-Hannifin and Trinova, and companies whose equipment is often used alongside Caterpillar's, like Ingersoll- Rand, all declined. Even Agco, a highflying maker of farm equipment that competes with Deere and Case but not Caterpillar, was caught in the downdraft, falling $2.125 to $50.875.
"We all seem to be dragged into this," said Bryan Kneeland, head of investor relations for Case, which is based in Racine, Wis. Case and others said they had seen no change in the general economic outlook that would justify the declines. If anything, the domestic construction market shows signs of a modest rebound after a brief slowdown and most overseas markets are growing as projected at double-digit rates.
Analysts were uncertain what to make of the announcement in part because it provided less "Cat speak" than usual. Typically, the company uses adverbs, like "slightly," by which it means zero to 5 percent, or "very significantly," which stands for 20 to 30 percent, to indicate how far up or down earnings are headed.
All that analysts were told about Monday's news -- and even that was expressed privately -- was that the decline would not be catastrophic, meaning 50 percent or more. As a result, most now expect per-share earnings in the range of 80 cents to $1, compared with $1.20 a year ago. But the prevailing long-term view is hardly gloomy.
"I reduced it to a hold this morning but after talking to them put it back on our 'buy' list," said Thomas Burns, who follows heavy equipment for the NatWest Securities Corporation. "They told me they could restore production in the fourth quarter if sales projections hold up."
Only one of Caterpillar's markets is clearly headed for trouble. August was the first month in three years in which new orders were lower than actual output for the diesel engines that several manufacturers, including Caterpillar, supply to truck makers. But that decline is not expected to affect the current quarter's performance.
Another factor is that earnings are likely to drop about 15 cents a share because the company tax rate is projected to be as high as 35 percent instead of 24 percent.
Alexander Blanton, who follows the company for Ingalls & Snyder in New York, speculated that part of the decline could also come from special charges related to eventual settlement of the company's 14-month labor dispute with the United Automobile Workers or be related to a spreading of profit-based incentive payments over the year's last two quarters instead of putting them all in the fourth quarter.
Most analysts say earnings are tumbling because of a decision to cut output to reduce dealer inventories of construction equipment.
"Caterpillar wants to get its hands around the problem now before it escalates," said Tobias Levkovich, an analyst with Smith Barney, who noted that part of the pay package for Caterpillar managers is based on their avoiding a buildup of unsold products.

HEADLINE: The Stampede to Harsh Welfare

 BODY:
Overwhelming bipartisan support for historic reform is ordinarily cause for celebration. But not in the case of the welfare "reform" approved by the Senate yesterday. With 35 Democrats joining 52 Republicans, the Senate passed an extreme welfare bill that will inevitably harm poor children. The bipartisan vote reflects the G.O.P.'s ideological blinders and the Democrats' weakness. The Democrats, including the President, preferred to swallow a bill they know is wrong rather than lose on principle.
Last year, before the Republicans took control, the President proposed a serious reform designed to put welfare enrollees to work within two years. But he, unlike the Republicans who made similar pledges, acknowledged the cost -- about $9 billion over five years for training, administration, child care and cash assistance. In contrast, the Republican bill just approved by the Senate pretends that the states can supervise a massive flight from welfare to work -- for a group that is uneducated, unskilled and saddled with miserable employment records -- for $8 billion less than the Government now spends on the welfare programs. 
 The Senate bill, like an even harsher version passed by the House, would tear up the 60-year-old Federal guarantee that turns over as much money as needed to the states to provide poor families cash and other temporary assistance. Instead, Washington will turn over fixed amounts of money, called block grants, to states to use as they please.
The plan provides states almost no additional money when recession hits and welfare rolls soar -- forcing states either to raise taxes at the worst possible time or cut benefits, their more likely course. The Republican plan also promises to employ half the able-bodied enrollees but provides no additional money to accomplish this expensive task. It typically costs about $6,000 more to move enrollees into jobs rather than keep them on welfare.
True, the Senate bill promises to punish states that fall short of its employment goal. But the financial penalty is so low it invites massive non-compliance. The bill also cuts food stamp programs sharply and removes the ironclad guarantees that protect nearly everyone from starvation. The bill would also make some naturalized citizens ineligible for welfare.
The House bill is even worse because it would allow states to eliminate completely their spending on the poor. It would also require states to withdraw cash assistance from unwed teen-age mothers and deny more aid to mothers who have additional children while on welfare. That makes the less punitive Senate plan look better. But it is neither humane nor reasonable.

HEADLINE: IN THE STUDIO WITH: Tony Brown;
Empowerment On the Air

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT 

 BODY:
FORTY-ONE stories above midtown Manhattan, bathed in a radio studio's low-lighted, high-tech glow, an elegantly dressed man with a strong chin and weak eyes bellies up to a microphone. After a moment of concentration, he clears his throat, watches for a cue from his engineer and hurls himself like a cliff diver into the foamy churn of public opinion below.
"This is Tony Brown on W-L-I-B," he proclaims, his practiced, trademark baritone becoming charged with 10,000 watts and reverberating from the studio monitors overhead. He teases out the day's topic. His switchboard flickers with callers eager to wade in. And aided by a legal pad, a few newspaper clippings and a head bubbling with hard-boiled ideas, Mr. Brown goes to work. 
 For hundreds of thousands of regular listeners of WLIB-AM, one of New York's black talk radio stations, Mr. Brown's name alone has become a mantra for meditations on self-help, economic empowerment, computer literacy -- and controversy. And no matter whether his words draw callers' praise or ire (he's been called an Uncle Tom and worse), Mr. Brown, always the stone-faced professional, ends each exchange with "I thank you so much for calling."
Since April, when Mr. Brown, a television broadcaster for 25 years, started as host of the program, he has become one of WLIB's brightest stars. The show, named for him, is broadcast Monday through Thursday from 2 to 5 P.M. Recent Arbitron figures showed him tied for first place with Bob Grant, the caustic ratings champ at WABC, among those who listen most to New York radio during afternoon drive time.
Part of Mr. Brown's charm is his on-air passion for his assignment. His enthusiasm is so great that his words often spill out in splashy streams of consciousness. Last week, when the topic of whether a President Colin Powell would be good for black America was raised, Mr. Brown, in typical fashion, fired from the hip.
"Colin Powell would do as much or more for us, given the limitations of what he could do, as anybody else in this country who is seriously being considered for President," he said. Then still in classic form, Mr. Brown added a cautionary caveat: "You can get only so much out of the political process. We are not going to get anybody in office -- black, white or otherwise -- who is going to solve all of our problems." In short, he warned, "Powell is not going to save us."
The do-for-yourself, take-charge theme is a central principle of Mr. Brown's philosophy, and of much of his work. It is liberally disseminated not only on his radio program these days, but also in his syndicated newspaper column, on the lecture circuit and on his long-running PBS television program, "Tony Brown's Journal." An average of five million viewers, many of them white, tune in each week to the nationally syndicated public affairs program.
"Tony is predictably unpredictable," said Maurice Cox, the vice president for corporate development and diversity for the Pepsi-Cola Company, for 19 years a prime sponsor of Mr. Brown's television show. "You know he is always going to have some interesting guests."
Last week, the television program explored the claims of melatonin, the media drug du jour that Mr. Brown takes and that is said to aid the immune system and to retard aging. The week before, he posed the question "Can you make money on the Internet?" Mr. Cox said the television program's themes appeal to black and white audiences. But, he added, "I don't think Tony does that for some political reason."
Mr. Brown, who refused to give his age (but is 62), plans to extend his reach in November with publication of "Black Lies, White Lies: The Truth According to Tony Brown" (William Morrow & Company), his first book, a 361-page recipe to rebuild America -- all of America. In the same month, Mr. Brown is scheduled to enter cyberspace with "Tony Brown Online," a black-oriented subscription computer service.
Mr. Brown, a former Detroit psychiatric social worker and the founding dean of Howard University's School of Communication, is manic for results. Long before Nike, Mr. Brown was preaching "Just do it." Along the way, though, he lost his tolerance for excuses. Karen Smith, his assistant for the last 12 years, says Mr. Brown demands from everyone what he demands most from himself: excellence. And he does not hesitate to kick a sacred cow or two if they block his way to imploring black Americans to turn to their own imaginations and energies to achieve.
"A mentality of affirmative action and civil rights is not going to get you anywhere in the 21st century," he said in a recent interview, minutes after finishing his radio show. "If you only believe that you're going to be a leader in the world if white people are going to have a preference program for you, brother, you just get out your cotton-picking clothes, because that's what you're going to be doing."
But in Tony Brown's world, if blacks had to pick cotton it would be in fields they owned and controlled. Blacks would also design, produce and market their own high-quality cotton wares. And whites would be happy to do business with them because they would realize that their welfare was "inextricably tied to whatever happens to the least among us," he said.
Mr. Brown's prescriptions for advancement are so firmly tied to the free enterprise system that he often sounds like a capitalist activist. And that's fine with him as the very self-employed president of Tony Brown Productions, the umbrella organization for all his projects.
But for blacks, he says, solutions will come only from independence. "I don't want to be in a community where our fate is in the hands of another community," he said.
A "dependent mentality," he said, has left much of black America "staging areas for permanently poor people who, generation after generation, reproduce their poverty."
It is precisely that sort of blunt (he prefers "honest") and heartfelt candor that has earned him legions of fans -- including the Rev. Al Sharpton and House Speaker Newt Gingrich -- and critics. In fact, when it was announced last spring that Mr. Brown, a black centrist Republican, was joining WLIB, an Afrocentric left-of-center station, a roar of protest greeted the news.
At the time, Sonny Carson, one of New York City's perennial protesters, considered setting up picket lines in front of the station's offices at 34th Street and Park Avenue to denounce Mr. Brown's appointment. Mr. Carson told The New York Amsterdam News in April that "Brown is counterproductive to what we want our community to move toward."
But Mr. Brown, a small-framed man with a bigger-than-life persona, brushes aside his critics. "Let me tell you something," he said, leaning in close as if about to reveal a family secret. "It hurts when I read or hear that someone said something about me. But God bless them. There's nothing I can do about it."
Yet, privately, he encourages the notion that work -- and lots of it -- is the best revenge. "I've got to write a column," he said. "I've got to go on the air from 2 to 5. I owe those people intelligence. I owe them preparation. I owe them respect." He noted, however, that his 5 A.M. to 11 P.M. workdays have not come without costs. He blames his schedule for the recent losses of a girlfriend and a housekeeper fed up with his paper-cluttered Central Park West apartment.
Sonja Gyimah, a listener, is not surprised by Mr. Brown's radio success. "I wasn't an avid listener of WLIB until I heard Tony Brown had a show," she said. She added that she was particularly drawn to "Tony Brown's Cyberspace Club," his Thursday program devoted to computing. While some have characterized the program as little more than an infomercial for Mr. Brown's forthcoming computer service, it is wildly popular with listeners, judging from the phone calls.
Last week, a caller trying to get her 11-year-old son's computer up to speed for the Internet called Mr. Brown's show. Almost instantly, he linked the woman -- over the air -- with computer experts he likes to call "cyberleaders." In minutes, the caller, her son and the listeners got the answers.
The information superhighway is a long way from the muddy back roads of Charleston, W.Va., where William Anthony Brown grew up in the 1930's and 40's. He does not usually talk about his private life, but he said that before he was born, his father had run away and that when he was an infant, poverty had conspired to remove him from his mother. But he was lucky, he continued: two women, domestic workers, came to his mother's door one day and announced, "We are here for the boy." Mr. Brown, who is a divorced father of a grown son, added that they raised him with love until both had died by the time he was 12.
He returned to his biological mother, but he never forgot them. Recently, after work, over a dinner of veal and pasta at Patsy's Italian Restaurant in midtown Manhattan, Mr. Brown, his voice breaking with emotion, recited his book's dedication: "To the two angels, Elizabeth 'Mamma' Sanford, and her daughter, Mabel Holmes, who gave me life when I was 2 months old."
A moment later, the public Tony Brown was back, talking up a storm about race, work, dollars and common sense to save America.

HEADLINE: THE 104TH CONGRESS: SHIRINKING BUREAUCRACY;
G.O.P. Finds Commerce Dept. Is Hard to Uproot

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Just a few months ago the Commerce Department was in danger of becoming road kill along Pennsylvania Avenue in the Republican drive to dismantle, consolidate and privatize a bloated Washington bureaucracy.
The Senate majority leader and other Republican Presidential aspirants declared that Commerce was an example of everything wrong with Washington: a bottomless barrel of pork for cities seeking economic development money; a shameless source of corporate welfare for companies looking for Federal money to pursue risky technologies, and a redundant morass of 100 separate trade programs. 
 Now, Republicans are suddenly discovering that the agency, which has been a mainstay of the Federal Government since it was created by Theodore Roosevelt, is not as easy to rip down as it first appeared.
Over the past week, as more than a dozen committees responsible for overseeing parts of the department's vast domain have sent their "dismantlement" proposals to the Republican leaders, it has become clear that the only parts of the department at greatest risk of extinction are the sign outside the giant Commerce building and about $400 million in initiatives to promote risky but promising technology.
Though the initial Republican instinct was to wipe the department off the map, creating savings optimistically estimated at $7.76 billion over five years, what has emerged from the committees are recommendations for a raft of new independent agencies plucked from the Commerce carcass. Among them would be a United States Science and Technology Administration, a United States Trade Administration, a National Marine Resources Administration and an Economic Development Regional Commission.
And that is before anyone has figured out what to do with the Weather Service, the Patent and Trademark Office and the Census Bureau, though there is talk of a new Federal Statistical Agency, which would tally things like the gross domestic product and unemployment.
"When you look at it, the buildings don't change, the offices don't change, the people don't change," said Vice President Al Gore, who has led the Administration's effort to streamline the Government. Mr. Gore, in an interview on Friday, clearly relished listing new agencies that would be created under the Republican proposals. "In the end, you get a different name plate on the door and some extra expense for changing the stationery," he said.
Republicans say the process is not over, and starting this week the Congressional leaders will sort through the proposals voted out of committee, each of which, naturally, seeks to save the part of the department it oversees.
"I think that the Department of Commerce is gone," said Representative Robert S. Walker, a Republican from Pennsylvania who heads the House committee on science and is the leading proponent of Science and Technology Administration. "But clearly many of its functions must remain."
Other Republicans say the early enthusiasm for mass destruction is clearly waning. Proposals to wipe out the International Trade Administration, which has expertise on virtually every facet of industry and serves as the war room that seeks to track American efforts to get big foreign contracts, have disappeared. Representatives and senators from coastal states rallied to protect the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, which accounts for a bit less than half of the Commerce Department's budget -- though they have vowed to wipe out its tiny navy.
"This talk of wholesale dismantlement has become a joke," said Commerce Secretary Ron Brown, who has spent the past three months denouncing the effort to dismember his department as a "trophy hunt" long on symbolism and short on any real cost savings. "We're headed toward creating even more agencies -- each with its own Inspector General, each with its own public affairs office, each with its own personnel office. Where's the savings in that?"
In the Senate, there is already a proposal afoot to set the fate of the Commerce Department aside and to create a commission that would draw up a list of departments and agencies throughout the Government to be wiped out. President Clinton has vowed to veto any bill that eliminates the Commerce Department.
Eager to zero out something, the Republicans in the House have focused on President Clinton's biggest foray into Japanese-style industrial policy: the Advanced Technology Program, which provides grants to companies and consortia of firms to develop high-risk technologies that seem too risky for venture-capitalists to underwrite.
The whole idea of Government involvement in civilian technology -- as opposed to military technologies -- has never sat well in the Republican Party, however, and on Capitol Hill such programs are regularly denounced as "industrial policy." Last week former Commerce Secretary Barbara H. Franklin, who served in the last year of the Bush Administration, testified that the $400 million Advanced Technology Program was "a large pork barrel." When it was pointed out that she had sought an increase in money for the program when she served in office, she replied, "Times change."
What has changed is the perception of the short-term competitive threat to American industry, which has grown stronger recently. But the debate over the Government's proper role in commercial technological research has made virtually no intellectual progress in Congress since the mid-1980's, despite a vast body of studies over what kind of programs have worked here and in Japan and what kind have failed.
"Obviously, in high-risk research a lot of projects do not work out," Energy Secretary Hazel O'Leary said recently. "But you can't go up to the Hill and defend a program with a 20 or 30 percent success rate."
Mr. Brown argued in an interview earlier this week that "the confluence of trade and technology policy was a big part of making us competitive" and that Congressional efforts to separate them would undermine the country's attempts to increase its strength in global markets. "It is unilateral disarmament," he said. Mr. Brown has declined to counter the Republican effort, though, with his own proposal for reorganizing trade and commerce functions.
Others point out the the United States Trade Representative's office, now part of the President's office, works precisely because it is small. Combining it with thousands of trade officials in Commerce may consolidate resources, but it may not make it any more lithe.
But the Republicans are also in a box: they have vowed to wipe out a Cabinet department, and Commerce is their only hope for this budget year. If it fails, or results in a plethora of new departments, they will be perceived as having failed in a primary mission to rein in Washington.
 
PROPOSED REPLACEMENTS
 
U.S. Science and Technology Administration would incorporate technology areas of commerce and parts of other agencies like the Energy Department.
 
National Marine Resources Administration would be drawn from parts of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration that deal with fisheries and other marine operations.
 
Federal Statistical Agency would combine the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis with the Census Bureau and statistics areas of the Labor Department.
 
U.S. Trade Administration would consolidate Commerce's trade functions with other trade-related agencies, but would leave the U.S Trade Representative as a separate cabinet-level post

HEADLINE: Book Notes

BYLINE: By Mary B. W. Tabor 

 BODY:

 
 
The Scoop
 With only a proposal in hand, publishers were crawling all over each other last week, hoping to snatch up what is expected to be an unusually scrappy behind-the-scenes political book by Ed Rollins, the outspoken Republican campaign consultant.
Seven publishing houses, including Simon & Schuster, St. Martin's Press and Avon Books, entered the auction on Thursday to bid for "Bare Knuckles and Back Rooms." And by the end of the day, Broadway Books, a new division of Bantam Doubleday Dell, had agreed to pay more than $1 million for the book, which will be published in the fall of 1996. 
 Mr. Rollins, who retired from politics last year, spent 30 years managing or consulting for high-level political campaigns, including Ronald Reagan's first run for the White House in 1980, Ross Perot's 1992 bid, Christine Todd Whitman's New Jersey gubernatorial campaign in 1992 and Michael Huffington's failure to become a Senator last year.
The book, whose coauthor is Tom DeFrank, a White House correspondent for Newsweek, is "quite candid," said Thomas L. Dunne, an editor at St. Martin's who read the proposal.
"What I found remarkable is that Rollins doesn't just pass out bouquets to Republicans and brickbats to Democrats. He has plenty of tasty stories about fellow Republicans, too, including a much darker view than you'd expect of Baker, Bush, Dan Quayle, even the Huffingtons."
At one point in the tart proposal, Mr. Rollins, who had a take-no-prisoners style in politics, too, said he was glad Mr. Perot and Mr. Huffington lost. "The country is better off without them in office," he wrote.
In an interview yesterday from his cabin in Front Royal, Va., Mr. Rollins, 52, elaborated. On Mr. Perot: "Any kook could come up to him and tell him something and he would give it the same credibility as a high-level Government source."
On Ms. Whitman: "I took a lot of abuse in that campaign from her husband and her brother."
On James Baker: "Baker was a guy who obviously was the master spinner with the press and to a certain extent did an awful lot to undercut a lot of the Reagan people. That's a story that's never been told. He wiped out Ed Meese and Bill Clark."
On George Bush: "George Bush and Jim Baker were good people but they did more to damage the Reagan revolution than anyone."
On Michael Huffington: "He disappeared for six weeks in the middle of the campaign, and nobody really missed him. He could have been elected Senator if he had been honest about his nanny situation."
On Ronald Reagan: "He was the nicest man you ever wanted to meet."
 
Undoing Melville
 In January 1852, Herman Melville delivered his newest novel, "Pierre, or the Ambiguities" to his publisher, Harper & Brothers. His timing could not have been worse.
Reviews of "Moby-Dick" were just coming out and many were devastating. ("The Judgment Day will hold him liable for not turning his talents to better account," said the Independent, a New York weekly. And it was selling slowly.
The publisher thought the new book even odder than "Moby-Dick" and offered Melville less than half his usual royalties, only 20 percent of the sales revenue after costs. Already $695 in debt to his publishers, Melville accepted, but took revenge.
According to Hershel Parker, a noted Melville scholar who has edited a new edition of "Pierre" to be published by HarperCollins in November, Melville held onto his manuscript and began adding to it.
The original story, Mr. Parker believes, was simply a psychological novel that dealt with incestuous ties between Pierre, a young man of leisure, and his half-sister, Isabel.
But what Melville ultimately turned in was a much longer book, about 130 pages more than Harper expected. Though no copies of the original exist, Mr. Parker suggests that Melville added two chapters and other inserts.
"This was really a suicidal, autobiographical account of his own career, his own aspirations," Mr. Parker said in an interview. "He knew his career was over."
While the original plot remained, Mr. Parker said, the author now painted a dark portrait of American literary life and publishing.
In the two new chapters he abruptly tells the reader that Pierre had once been an author and then heaps scorn on critics who praised the young Pierre, depicting them as low-lifes.
In HarperCollins' new edition, which has been illustrated by Maurice Sendak, Mr. Parker removes all text that deals with Pierre's life as a writer.
Michael di Capua, who oversaw publication of the book for HarperCollins, said the added sections "are so beside the point that when you take them out, they simply are not missed." After "Pierre," Melville saw his career disintegrate.
He wrote another book, "The Isle of the Cross," but Harpers rejected it in June 1853. "Billy Budd," published in the 1920's, was found in an old suitcase.
Melville published one last major work, "Clarel," an 18,000-line poem, in 1876. But he spent the last 40 years of his life unemployed or as a customs inspector in Manhattan.
 
Season for Prizes
 Ten writers have been given $50,000 Lannan Literary Awards for 1995. They are Hayden Carruth (poetry), Carol Ann Duffy (poetry) Li-Young Lee (poetry), Arthur Sze (poetry), Louis de Bernieres (fiction), Mary Morrissy (fiction), Alice Munro (fiction) Thomas Berry (nonfiction), Richard K. Nelson (nonfiction) and Scott Russell Sanders (nonfiction).
James Tate has been awarded the Tanning Prize, the largest annual literary prize in this country. The $100,000 award is to recognize outstanding and proven mastery in the art of poetry.
And Francisco Rebolledo of Mexico has won the Pegasus Prize for Literature, which is given to fiction authors from abroad. Mr. Rebolledo won the $7,000 for "Rasero," a book that will be published by Louisiana State University Press this fall.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 21, 1995, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Book Notes column yesterday about publishers' vying for a political memoir by Ed Rollins, the Republican campaign consultant, misstated the year of Christine Todd Whitman's campaign for the governorship in New Jersey. It was 1993, not 1992.

HEADLINE: WELFARE IN TRANSITION;
Pinch of Tax Bill To Be Felt by Many, Not Just Businesses

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
The $52 billion tax bill that the House Ways and Means Committee approved late Tuesday was largely advertised as an effort to shut down unwarranted corporate tax breaks and, as the panel's chairman said, "end business as usual" in the Capitol. And it would, in fact, knot many loopholes.
But like tax measures passed by the Democratic regime before it, the Republican bill turns out to do a lot of other things, too. 
 The provisions will be incorporated in a larger spending bill, a reconciliation package, whose own future is uncertain. Nor is it clear whether many of the proposals will survive in a conference with the Senate to resolve differences with its reconciliation bill.
Well over half of the billions of dollars that the measure would raise, for deficit reduction and other purposes, come not from closing business loopholes but from elsewhere. About $19 billion comes from trimming the earned-income tax credit for poor working households. About $10 billion stems from a change in pension law that critics say would actually give corporations a windfall of $20 billion or more.
Many of the remaining changes would end tax breaks that affect uniquely Democratic constituencies. They include trial lawyers, Hollywood movie makers and even a onetime political supporter of President Clinton, Tyson Foods, an Arkansas-based chicken empire.
And while a handful of other provisions would eliminate tax breaks for certain businesses, they have the practical effect of benefiting those businesses' competitors. In particular, the legislation would wipe out tax breaks for several competitors of the petroleum industry.
The artful craftsmanship of the tax measure, which was debated and approved mostly in evening sessions, left Democrats sputtering in anger. Representatives Sam M. Gibbons of Florida and Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan, the panel's two most senior Democrats, charged that the real targets of the bill were middle- and lower-income working Americans, not businesses. And President Clinton said the measure was "inconsistent with those basic, bedrock values this country should be standing for."
But Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who heads the committee, dismissed those accusations during and after hearings on the bill this week. His spokesman, Ari Fleischer, said today that Mr. Archer had drafted the tax provisions with an eye to "updating and modernizing the code," not to political loss or gain. "I'll tell you this," he said. "None of those changes were the result of lobbying. Mr. Archer sprang those by surprise."
He did indeed. When Republicans began writing the legislation earlier this summer, its biggest provision would have pared about $14 billion from the earned-income tax credit for the working poor. When Mr. Archer, a solid defender of corporate tax preferences, announced last week that he had also included 27 tax changes that would raise $30 billion from corporations by the year 2002, it created a minor sensation.
But along the way, the reduction in the earned-income credit grew by $5 billion, to $19 billion, mostly by phasing out the credit more quickly as poor families' incomes grow.
Democrats have focused their attacks on that rise. But Mr. Fleischer said today that Republicans chose to reduce the credit by a greater amount rather than raise money in two other unpleasant ways: requiring spouses to help pay the cost of tracking down fathers who do not pay child support, or reducing unemployment compensation.
In truth, he said, the reduction in the tax credit is not a change in the tax code, but a spending cut, because almost all the credit goes to families in the form of checks, not as breaks on their taxes. The bill's greatest effect on taxes, he said, is in those changes that apply to corporations.
The bill approved by the Ways and Means Committee does attack some breaks that have enjoyed bipartisan support in the past. For instance, it would raise $3.1 billion over seven years by gradually eliminating a credit that benefited pharmaceutical and electronics companies that established plants in Puerto Rico. And it would raise another $7 billion by ending a fiercely defended tax deduction for loans on corporate-owned life-insurance policies.
But Democrats see another method in the committee's actions. Today they noted that the bill would eliminate several tax credits and breaks for ethanol, wind energy, biomass and energy conservation, while leaving untouched the volumes of tax preferences enjoyed by the oil and gas business that is centered in Mr. Archer's home state.
Mr. Fleischer rejected any implication that Mr. Archer had played favorites, arguing that petroleum companies enjoyed no tax credits like the ones Mr. Archer targeted.
Democrats also argued that the measure unduly affected their political allies. The bill would raise some $390 million over seven years by taxing all punitive damages and emotional distress awards in lawsuits, a provision that the Association of Trial Lawyers of America, a bedrock supporter of Democratic causes, labeled an attack on ordinary Americans' legal rights.
It would eliminate the tax credit for construction of low-income housing, a Democratic cause, saving $3.5 billion. It would raise another $204 million by tightening the rules by which some businesses -- many of them entertainment companies -- calculate their depreciation of the costs of products like movies whose profits must be estimated.
And it would gradually eliminate a tax break for "certain large farm corporations," including major poultry producers like Tyson.
The single largest money-raiser, however, does not close a corporate tax break. It would relax rules that allowed corporations to withdraw excess money from employee pension accounts only for specific purposes, and often after paying a 34 percent corporate tax and a penalty of up to 50 percent.
