HEADLINE: THE 104TH CONGRESS: MEDICARE;
HOUSE G.O.P. PLAN DOUBLES PREMIUMS OF MEDICARE USERS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
House Republicans disclosed today that their plan to slow the growth of Federal Medicare costs would gradually double health insurance premiums for the elderly. It would also limit payments to victims of medical malpractice and encourage doctors and hospitals to join together in selling their services to consumers.
While putting forth new details, the Republicans failed to provide the text of any legislation and acknowledged that they were still short of their goal of saving $270 billion over seven years. They left Democrats and elderly people hungry for more specific information about the Republican plan to redesign Medicare. 
 Speaker Newt Gingrich predicted that millions of elderly people would voluntarily enroll in health maintenance organizations, and he said the Government could save $70 billion over seven years as a result.
But representatives of the elderly said it was unrealistic to expect a big increase in H.M.O. enrollment as a result of the Republican bill. And even Mr. Gingrich conceded that his estimate of savings was much more optimistic than that of the Congressional Budget Office, the official scorekeeper, which is analyzing the Republicans' still-incomplete plan.
The new details of the Republican proposal did nothing to end the tumultuous political battle that has erupted over Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for 37 million people who are elderly or disabled. Representative Sam M. Gibbons, a Florida Democrat who has been in Congress for nearly 33 years, dismissed the Republicans' latest summary of their proposal as "pabulum."
He asserted that the Republicans were stalling as part of "a very deliberate plot to put their program over before the American people have any chance to understand how it affects them."
Democrats asserted that the Republicans' strategy was apparent in their decision to hold a single day of hearings on the plan, on Friday. In protest, Democrats were preparing their own hearings on Medicare -- on the Capitol lawn, they said, because Republicans denied them space inside.
Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, said: "We're just dealing with another press release today. We have seen no specifics in terms of numbers. No numbers approved or disapproved by C.B.O."
The House Republicans said they expected to save $110 billion by curbing payments to doctors, hospitals and other providers of health care in the next seven years. And they said beneficiaries would contribute $60 billion to $70 billion, mostly through higher premiums, especially for affluent people.
These savings, together with the $70 billion assumed from greater use of H.M.O.'s and other forms of managed care, would generate $240 billion to $250 billion of savings, which is somewhat less than the Republicans' goal of $270 billion.
The Republicans said their proposals were needed to prevent Medicare's Hospital Insurance Trust Fund from going bankrupt. But they said it was taking longer than they had expected to translate their ideas into legislation and to convince the Congressional Budget Office that their proposals would actually save $270 billion. The Democrats contend that the plan goes far beyond what is needed to keep Medicare solvent.
The Republican problems were illustrated at a news conference today. Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, distributed a statement saying: "With this bill, Medicare is saved. With this bill, Medicare is preserved."
But in reading the statement, Mr. Archer made no reference to "this bill" and spoke instead of "our proposal," because there is still no bill, and Republicans were unable to say when they would have one. Several lawyers drafting the Medicare bill are preoccupied at the moment, working on legislation to repeal the 1965 law that established Medicaid, the Federal-state health program for poor people. The Republicans hope to save $182 billion over seven years from that program, and the House Commerce Committee expects to finish work on the Medicaid legislation on Friday, three days after it was introduced.
Under the Republican plan for Medicare, elderly people would have many more options than they do now; they could enter the rapidly changing private health care market if they wanted. They could, for example, get Federal money to buy private health insurance, set up "medical savings accounts" or enroll in a new type of health plan sponsored by groups of doctors or hospitals.
Medicare premiums would increase, along with the cost of the program. Under the Republican proposal, the monthly Medicare premium, now $46.10, would rise to the range of $90 to $93 in 2002. If there was no change in current law, the premium would rise to $60.80 in 2002. Earlier this year President Clinton proposed changes that would raise the premium to $83 a month in 2002.
The House Republicans would increase premiums even more for Medicare beneficiaries with annual incomes above certain levels: $75,000 for one person and $125,000 for a couple. The premiums would increase most sharply for individuals with incomes of more than $100,000 and for couples with incomes of more than $150,000. Republicans declined to specify the increase, but initial calculations suggested that such people might have to pay premiums of $100 a month in the near future, rising to $195 a month in 2002.
The Republicans proposed other changes to control costs that they said had been imposed on the nation's health care system by malpractice lawsuits, and the threat of such lawsuits. Under the proposal, lawsuits could not be filed more than five years after an injury occurred. Damages for pain and suffering would be limited to $250,000 for each case. The House passed a similar measure earlier this year as part of a bill to make comprehensive changes in the legal system, but the Senate rejected the limits.
House Republicans also propose to relax antitrust laws to make it easier for doctors and hospitals to form networks serving Medicare beneficiaries. Doctors who collaborate in such arrangements would, in many cases, be allowed to set their prices in consultation with one another, a practice often prohibited as price-fixing under current law.
Doctors have sought this type of exemption for years, and Dr. James S. Todd, executive vice president of the American Medical Association, welcomed it today. Commenting on the plan, Dr. Todd said, "Our reaction is basically favorable." He said the antitrust proposals recognized that "physicians have been at a disadvantage in trying to put together our own networks" to compete with H.M.O.'s and insurance companies.
To save money, the Republicans propose myriad changes in the formulas used to pay hospitals, doctors, nursing homes and medical laboratories serving Medicare patients. Hospitals, for example, would receive smaller allowances for inflation in the cost of the goods and services they use.
Special payments to hospitals with large numbers of low-income patients would be cut by 25 percent over the next seven years. Such payments are expected to total at least $3.1 billion this year.
John C. Rother, chief lobbyist at the American Association of Retired Persons, said he was pleased to see that the House Republicans had moved away from earlier proposals that would have sharply increased direct costs to beneficiaries. But he said, "We are extremely concerned about the overall level of proposed savings, which may well reduce access to care and the quality of care."
Mr. Rother said he doubted that there would be "a big acceleration of H.M.O. enrollment as a result of this bill." But he predicted that such enrollment would continue to increase, because H.M.O.'s "do a good job of controlling costs" for their members. About 10 percent of the 37 million Medicare beneficiaries are in H.M.O.'s.
Studies have found that the Government typically loses money on each Medicare beneficiary who joins an H.M.O., because those who enroll in such health plans are healthier than the average beneficiary, and the Government pays the organizations more than it would have paid if those people had remained in the standard Medicare program.
But Republicans today brushed aside such concerns. Mr. Gingrich predicted that sick and healthy people alike would rush to join H.M.O.'s.
In any event, the Republicans would impose strict annual limits on Medicare payments to H.M.O.'s. The limits are intended to guarantee that total Medicare spending does not exceed the targets set in the Republicans' seven-year plan to balance the Federal budget.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1003 words

HEADLINE: Gingrich Threatens U.S. Default If Clinton Won't Bend on Budget

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
House Speaker Newt Gingrich threatened today to send the United States into default on its debt for the first time in the nation's history, to force the Clinton Administration to balance the budget on Republican terms.
His comments, a more extreme version of the hardball stance frequently used in past budget showdowns, raised the specter that the looming standoff may begin to rattle financial markets around the world. Mr. Gingrich's remarks came in the middle of a day in which the dollar plunged as much as 5 percent against major currencies before recovering slightly, sending interest rates up sharply. [Page D13.] The Speaker's statement appeared to be one of several factors that added to the markets' unsettled condition. 
 More broadly, Mr. Gingrich's speech to the Public Securities Association, which represents traders in Government debt, underscored the growing agitation and sense of imminent collision in official Washington as both Democrats and Republicans move toward a confrontation that could shut the Government down this fall.
Throughout the capital, there was a sense that the current had quickened and the rumble of a great waterfall could be heard close ahead. Angry disputes broke out on wildly varying issues. Republicans threatened to block sending American ground troops to enforce the Bosnia peace plan, agreed to vast reductions in the protection for endangered species and Federal lands, and pushed ahead with plans for radical changes in Medicare and Medicaid. Democrats fumed and vowed to do what they could to slow the legislation's breakneck pace.
Clearly part of Mr. Gingrich's autumn end-game strategy is to force the White House to accept much of this agenda -- many parts of which President Clinton has vowed to veto -- by holding an increase in the Federal debt limit hostage. Without an increase in the limit, the Government will be unable to meet many of the payments due in November for Social Security, military pay and interest on the Federal Government's $4.9 trillion in debt.
Such confrontational techniques have been used in the past. But it was highly unusual for a high Government leader to suggest, as Mr. Gingrich did today, that default on Government payments was not beyond the pale.
"I don't care what the price is," he said in his speech. "I don't care if we have no executive offices and no bonds for 60 days -- not this time."
Without concessions from the White House across the board, he said, there will not be any increase in the debt ceiling. "And we'll see how long they will last," he added.
Administration officials were still trying tonight to figure out how seriously to take Mr. Gingrich's comments. A few months ago, the Speaker backed away from his off-the-cuff suggestions that the United States should recognize Taiwan as an independent country, a step that would lead to a breach with China.
But Congress has little direct influence over foreign policy. By contrast, its control of the Government's purse strings gave added force to Mr. Gingrich's remarks. Indeed, the Speaker's comments drew a quick and harshly worded response from Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin. "The President won't be blackmailed by the use of the debt limit as a negotiating lever," he said in a telephone interview from Miami, where he was giving a speech tonight.
"It would be unprecedented and unwise for anyone in a position of authority to dismiss the consequences of default on the debt of the United States of America for the first time in our history," he added. "Even the appearance of a risk of default can have adverse consequences, and a default itself would increase the cost of debt for the United States Government for many, many years to come. A sovereign country's credit-worthiness is a precious asset not to be sacrificed under any circumstances."
Mr. Rubin said he did not expect the United States to default on any debt payment, a step that he has repeatedly called "unthinkable." But even a serious threat of a disruption in payments can move the markets, and may send borrowing costs soaring for the United States.
The Treasury Department estimates that every increase of one percentage point in interest rates would swell the budget deficit by $4.9 billion this year. Republicans, however, argue that interest rates should decline if the ultimate outcome of the dispute between the parties is a big cut in spending. They contend that any short-term blips in the market -- because of conflicts with the White House -- would be washed away by long-term benefits.
Aside from all the Sturm und Drang in Washington, the debt limit debate has not yet had much effect on the markets, traders said. "One of the risks is that foreign investors will not understand what is happening here," said David M. Jones, vice chairman of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, which trades Government bonds. "And if they get nervous, they will just flee until it all sorts out."
The issue will take on added urgency in the first five days of November, when the Government must pay $50 billion in Social Security benefits, Medicare and pay for active-duty members of the military. And on Nov. 15, about $25 billion of interest payments are due.
As Treasury officials concede, a number of financial tricks are available to keep the Government afloat even if the ceiling on debt is not raised. There are temporary debt limits, emergency "cash management sales" to keep money flowing in the coffers as short-term loans, and borrowing against other Government reserves. But all of the steps come with a cost, and none can go on for too long.
The debt limit exists as an institution in Washington because the Constitution mandates that only Congress can authorize borrowings. Before World War I, every bond issued by the United States required separate Congressional approval. Today, the raising of the debt ceiling essentially permits the Treasury Secretary to make the day-to-day decisions required to meet the Government's obligations.

HEADLINE: Rudy Perpich, 67; Led Minnesota for 10 Years

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MINNETONKA, Minn., Sept. 21

 BODY:
Former Gov. Rudy Perpich, a dentist who became Minnesota's longest-serving chief executive, died today at his home here, outside St. Paul. He was 67.
His wife, Lola, said he had died of colon cancer. 
 Mr. Perpich served as Governor for 10 years, from 1976 to 1978, and 1982 to 1990.
He was known for his unconventional ideas, and some critics even called him "Governor Goofy." He once proposed selling the Governor's Mansion. At another time, he erected a billboard in protest when he was not allowed to have a portrait of himself with his wife in the Capitol.
But Mr. Perpich was known as a strong supporter of education, economic development and innovative public policy. He said the highlight of his career had come when the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, had accepted his invitation to visit Minnesota in 1990.
His first stint as Governor came about in an unorthodox manner.
In 1976, Gov. Wendell R. Anderson resigned that post so Mr. Perpich, then the Lieutenant Governor, could succeed him as Governor and then appoint Mr. Anderson to the Senate seat left vacant by Walter F. Mondale, who had left to become Vice President.
In 1978, Mr. Perpich was defeated by Albert Quie in the so-called Minnesota Massacre, when the Democratic Party lost the Governor's office, both Senate seats and control of the Minnesota House. But Mr. Perpich made a comeback in 1982 and remained Governor until he was defeated by Arne Carlson in 1990.
An immigrant Croatian miner's son who did not speak English when he entered school, Mr. Perpich was a product of the rough-and-tumble Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party politics of the Iron Range in the northern part of the state, where his parents, Anton and Mary, still live.
A former dentist, Mr. Perpich began his public career in 1956, when he was elected to the Hibbing School Board. He was elected to the state Senate in 1962 and elected Lieutenant Governor in 1970.
He contemplated another run for Governor in 1994, but he decided that Minnesotans were not ready for his ideas. He said he would put off a run until 1998.
In addition to his wife and parents, Mr. Perpich is survived by a son, Rudy Jr., who is called Nick, of Minnetonka, and a daughter, Mary Sue Bifulk of Plymouth, Minn.

HEADLINE: Encore for Suriname's Ex-Dictator?

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: PARAMARIBO, Suriname

 BODY:
Thirteen years after the United States considered sending marines up the muddy Suriname River to force a left-leaning military dictatorship from power in this small South American country, the dictator who ran that Government is now running for President.
The ex-dictator, Desire Bouterse, a 49-year-old career soldier who helped stage one coup in 1980 and another in 1990, is now chairman of the National Democratic Party. As he heads into national elections scheduled for next spring, his popularity is growing. 
 "You can tell everyone that we're 'coming soon,' just like in the movies," Mr. Bouterse told a rally of about 1,500 supporters who gathered under a large steel shed here in the capital one night recently.
As bats flew over their heads, the people in the audience heard Mr. Bouterse attack his favorite targets -- journalists, human rights campaigners, the current Government and the Netherlands, Suriname's former colonial ruler.
He also tried to explain his concept of decentralized government and how, if elected, he would divide Suriname into local districts that would have far greater self-determination than now. People in the stiff seats yawned.
Political theory is not the reason Surinamese support Mr. Bouterse. The country's economy is in a shambles. The exchange rate, which used to be seven Surinamese guildens to the dollar, is now 450 to the dollar. Taxes are higher, but the streets are filled with potholes.
Mr. Bouterse promises to fix everything, and he freely uses his wealth and influence to buy support.
"He brought us chainsaws and then he buys the timber from us," Herman Joeroeja, a Carib Indian who lives in the forest about 50 miles south of Paramaribo, said of Mr. Bouterse (pronounced BOUGH-ter-seh). "If he does good to me, I have to call his name good."
As he campaigns, Mr. Bouterse tries to put distance between the image of a serious politician he now tries to convey and the dark record of killings, disappearances, arrests and other rights violations that marked his decade in power.
In an interview at his office at his party headquarters, he said it was "a black page in our history" when soldiers under his command rounded up 15 opposition figures and journalists on Dec. 8, 1982, and murdered them at Fort Zeelandia, on the Suriname River.
"But people fail to realize the different coup attempts that took place under those 15 people who were killed," he said. "If the central Government hadn't taken action, we would have had not 15 deaths but 1,500."
While the victims were involved in campaigns to restore democratic government to Suriname, there has never been any evidence that they were plotting to overthrow Mr. Bouterse, although there were at least two attempts to oust him from power in that year.
In 1982, the United States was uneasy about Mr. Bouterse's overtures to Cuba, Libya and the Soviet Union, fearing he would allow another Communist beachhead besides Cuba in the Western Hemisphere.
Within a few weeks of the killings, American officials proposed a joint military operation with the Netherlands in which the Dutch would seize control of Paramaribo while United States warships insured that Cuba did not intervene.
When the Dutch hesitated, the United States considered other options. In his 1993 autobiography, "Turmoil and Triumph," former Secretary of State George P. Shultz described President Reagan as willing to send in American troops without Dutch support.
Later, American policymakers even considered an improbable plan for a force of up to 175 South Korean commandos to stage a raid on Paramaribo and overthrow Mr. Bouterse. In his book, Mr. Shultz called the plan "a hare-brained idea," and said post-Vietnam fears about American troops getting bogged down in a foreign land kept anything from ever happening.
Now, independent polls show Mr. Bouterse's party far more popular than the ragged coalition that has ruled since 1991.
"Bouterse may be in a position to be kingmaker in the next elections or even king himself," said Prof. Gary Brana-Shute, a cultural anthropologist at George Washington University who specializes in Suriname. "Bouterse and his friends no longer need military power. They've built a shadow empire of businesses and investments in Suriname and internationally to make the National Democratic Party one of the richest groups in Suriname."
The Dutch, who had granted Suriname independence only five years before the 1980 coup, were deeply embarrassed by the turmoil there and cut off hundreds of millions of dollars in foreign aid after the deaths of the 15 opposition figures and journalists.
Mr. Bouterse said he tried to line up aid in the United States, Brazil, India and Venezuela and was rebuffed. Only then, he said, did he turn to the Communist countries to seek financial assistance. He denied he was ever a Communist.
"Here in Suriname we have had a very strong aversion against so-called Communism," he said. "Most of the dogs in Suriname were called Castro."
A civil war in the 1980's forced some 10,000 Surinamese to take refuge in neighboring French Guiana and sent an already stumbling economy into a free fall. The Netherlands pressed Mr. Bouterse to give up power, and he allowed elections in 1987. Then, in 1990, he dismissed the Government with a phone call in a bloodless coup.
A coalition Government was elected in 1991, but Mr. Bouterse's party, which took 12 seats, remained in the opposition. He stepped down as commander of the military in 1992 and says he devoted himself to building the party and doing what was necessary to make ends meet.
As it turns out, he made ends meet nicely. His wife drives a white customized Mercedes-Benz, and he is considered one of wealthiest men in Suriname, with interests in oil, timber, gold and real estate.
"All those things give you ample opportunity to drive a Mercedes," he said.
A Western diplomat here said that while Mr. Bouterse has supporters, the chance of his party's winning the three-quarters of the 51-seat Parliament that would be needed to name him President is "practically zero."
"Besides," the diplomat said, "the simple fact is that the United States would oppose it and so would the Dutch."
The issue is no longer Mr. Bouterse's Communist sympathies, although his erratic behavior the last time he was in power makes it impossible to say where he would stand.
This time, the United States' interest is in supporting a fragile democracy in Suriname; any retaliation against a Bouterse presidency would likely involve halting any business investments rather than military intervention.
On Nov. 25, Suriname celebrates the 20th anniversary of independence. Ceremonies are to be held at the presidential palace, which was used by Dutch governors during colonial rule, then by Suriname's first elected officials and by Mr. Bouterse himself before being abandoned because it was so deteriorated that it could no longer be used.
The palace is now being repaired with $1 million in Dutch aid, an example of Suriname's continuing dependence on the Netherlands.
"The condition of the palace is the result of eight years without maintenance," while the elected Government was in power, he said. "If we win the elections, you should return in six months and you will see the difference."

HEADLINE: Bill to Tighten Economic Embargo on Cuba Is Passed With Strong Support in the House

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Despite the Clinton Administration's last-minute threats of a veto, the House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to tighten the trade embargo against Cuba.
By a vote of 294 to 130, the House backed a bill that seeks to step up pressure on Fidel Castro by discouraging foreign investment in Cuba, which the bill's sponsors say provides much-needed hard currency to prop up the Cuban economy. 
 Secretary of State Warren Christopher sent a letter to Speaker Newt Gingrich on Wednesday saying that he would recommend a presidential veto and that the bill would "damage prospects for a peaceful transition in Cuba and jeopardize a number of key U.S. interests around the world."
The bill, which awaits Senate action in the next few days, would require the Federal Government to deny visas to foreigners who own or benefit from the use of property confiscated after the 1959 revolution in Cuba. It would also allow Cuban-Americans to file lawsuits in American courts to seek damages from foreign companies that buy or use expropriated properties, such as rum distilleries.
"Castro is increasingly desperate for foreign currency," said Representative Dan Burton, the Indiana Republican who is sponsoring the bill, said during the floor debate. "That is why he has embarked on a campaign to encourage foreign investment at the expense of Americans who had their property confiscated. Our bill is the tool that will deny him his last hope for keeping his regime in power."
Senate Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who is chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, is sponsoring a nearly identical bill that he hopes to attach to an appropriations bill.
In fighting the measure, Administration officials argue that by tightening the screws on Cuba's economy, it increases the likelihood of a violent explosion rather than a peaceful transition in Cuba. The Administration fears that such an explosion could not only cause many deaths and a flood of refugees, but could also force the United States to send troops into Cuba.
The Administration particularly objects to the bill's provision that would, for the first time, allow Cuban-Americans who were not American citizens at the time of the 1959 revolution to sue foreign investors in Cuba for damages in Federal courts.
The Clinton Administration says this provision will clog American courts, offend American allies and violate international laws by giving American courts jurisdiction over disputes in another country.
"These provisions would create tensions in our relations with our allies," Mr. Christopher said in his letter. "We know that this provision allowing lawsuits is already being used by the Castro regime to play on the fears of ordinary citizens that their homes and work places would be seized by Cuban-Americans if the regime were to fail."
Representative Robert Mendendez, a New Jersey Democrat, defended the bill, saying it "was about standing up for American interests" and would "give American citizens the right to sue for properties that are illegally confiscated."
In Havana, Rafael Dausa, a spokesman for the Cuban Foreign Ministry, told reporters that the bill would not destroy his country's socialist system, but would impede efforts to reduce tensions with the United States.
Mr. Christopher recommended a veto even though congressional Republicans had already deleted a key provision opposed by the Administration: one that would prohibit sugar imports from countries with companies that purchased Cuban sugar.
While praising the bill's objective of bringing democracy to Cuba, Mr. Christopher criticized the measure for tying the President's hands by setting strict requirements on when the United States could resume aid to Cuba once it has a government moving toward democracy. He also attacked the bill for calling on the United States to cut aid to countries that help complete a nuclear power plant in Cuba or provide goods or loans to Cuba at below-market rates.
The bill would also require the United States to reduce its contribution to the World Bank or other international financial institutions if they provide aid to Cuba.
During today's debate, the House rejected in a 283-138 vote an amendment that would loosen the 33-year-old embargo on Cuba by allowing the sale of food and medical supplies.
Representative Lee Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat who led the fight against the bill, said, "The philosophy of this bill is that if you make conditions in Cuba significantly worse, you will prompt the Cuban people to rise up against their Government." He and other opponents argued that the bill would increase the pain for Cubans without speeding Mr. Castro's demise.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Rally in Dollar Stalls; Currency Is Below 100 Yen
The dollar tumbled against leading currencies, dropping to less than 100 Japanese yen, to 99.05, in a retreat fueled by tepid central bank support for the dollar and continued speculation about obstacles to a single European currency.
Traders had expected the Bank of Japan to buy dollars aggressively after the Japanese Government released a new economic stimulus program on Wednesday. When no intervention occurred, currency dealers sold dollars and took profits. The dollar also fell against the German mark, sliding to 1.4235 marks from 1.4613. [Page D13.]
 
The stock market slumped, dragged down by the dollar and fears that foreign investors might retreat from U.S. securities. The Dow industrials closed at 4,767.40, down 25.29. [D6.]
 
The weak dollar and a strong business outlook from the Philadelphia Fed slammed bond prices, lifting the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds to 6.55 percent. [D16.]
 
Gingrich Threatens U.S. Default To Force a Balanced Budget
Newt Gingrich threatened to send the United States into default on its debt to force the Clinton Administration to balance the budget on Republican terms, raising the possibility that the looming standoff may begin to rattle financial markets. Mr. Gingrich's speech to the Public Securities Association underscored the possibility of a confrontation between Democrats and Republicans that could shut the Government down next month. [A1.]
 
Time Warner and Turner Board Meet
The boards of Time Warner and Turner Broadcasting System held marathon meetings to approve Time Warner's proposed acquisition of Turner, but neither board had voted on the deal by late in the evening. [D6.]
 
Olympia & York Unit Agrees to Deal
The board of debt-ridden Olympia & York's U.S. arm agreed to a restructuring that may give control of it to a group of creditors led by the Bronfman family. The group offered $167 million in cash as part of a $323 million bid to control at least 67 percent of the American real estate holdings of the company. [D3.]
 
Canada Kills Ban on Tobacco Ads
The Canadian Supreme Court ruled that a ban on tobacco advertising violated free expression by improperly prohibiting a manufacturer from communicating with customers about a legal product. [A6.]
 
Shanghai Exchange Cited in Scandal
A new report blamed the Shanghai Securities Exchange for lax supervision and accused two securities firms of manipulating the market in February's bond futures scandal. [D3.]
 
JWP Settles S.E.C. Fraud Charges
In a case that seems to show how much fraud a company can get away with, even when an auditing firm is monitoring its books, JWP Inc. agreed to settle civil charges with the S.E.C. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D6.]
 
Smirnoffs Keep Name in Russia
A Russian court has ruled that the American vodka Smirnoff, the world's biggest-selling vodka brand, cannot be sold under that name in Russia. The court ruled that the Smirnoff family had the legal rights to the name there, and Russia's Chamber of Appeals of the Patent Office ruled that Heublein Inc., the American producer of Smirnoff, had no permission to use the name. Heublein said it would appeal the decisions. [D3.]
 
Court Refuses to Lift Magazine Ban
The Supreme Court will not overturn an order prohibiting Business Week from publishing an article that uses information in sealed court documents from a lawsuit between Procter & Gamble and Bankers Trust. [A16.]
 
Meridian Bancorp Considers Sale
The board of Meridian Bancorp will meet next week to review options, including a possible sale of the company, its chairman said. [D2.]
 
Neighborhoods Touched by Merger
Low- and middle-income neighborhoods in New York City will lose seven of their 95 bank branches in the pending merger of Chemical Bank and Chase Manhattan. [B4.]

HEADLINE: A Forbes Is Ready to Spend In Pursuit of the Presidency

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
"Pick a number," said Malcolm S. Forbes Jr. on the eve of his run for the Presidency, genially highlighting his willingness to dip deep into his family fortune in a dark-horse quest for the Republican nomination.
"I've seen everything from 10 to 40 million mentioned," he said of what he might personally spend on a blitz to become a household name and crash the Presidential sweepstakes from an offstage vantage of business power, social privilege and political zeal. 
 "I don't know what it's going to be," Mr. Forbes added, stressing that his bank account was not the crucial factor in his planned announcement here on Friday.
"I need to get the message across," he said tersely, as if money was indeed the simple capitalist tool that his late father celebrated and compounded in the family publishing empire led by Forbes magazine.
The message of this 48-year-old media mogul and electoral novice is that the current crop of contenders is too mesmerized by the budget-cutting debate to seize the opportunity that he sees for driving the American economy forward.
He prophesies a "roar" of record growth and prosperity from new, young entrepreneurs, provided that the nation has the right leadership and laws. He is approaching voters with a demand, more than a call, for slaying the serpentine income tax code with a simple flat-tax payment (17 percent beyond the initial tax-free $33,000 of income for a family of four). He is hiring a cadre of gnarled and knowing veterans of past political wars to see whether his money and message can spark something combustible.
"No human being outside of this town could possibly survive a more complex, corrupt, incomprehensible, frustrating, anti-growth, anti-opportunity monstrosity than the tax code we have today," Mr. Forbes, a rapid-fire, note-free orator, told an audience here earlier this week.
"After all," he said, "the Declaration of Independence runs only 1,300 words. The Bible is 773,000 words. The tax code is 7 million words and rising."
The political pros sense a fresh payday in Mr. Forbes, at a minimum. "He's got one thing that other candidates don't have: $25 million," said Edward J. Rollins, who is not in his employ but knew Mr. Forbes as a "superb" adviser in shaping Christine Todd Whitman's tax-cutting stratagem in New Jersey.
"Steve's a real long shot right now," Mr. Rollins conceded, "but with nobody happy with what's going on in the party process, if he could get a good 20 or 30 days' spotlight, who knows, he might break in with something people are interested in."
Mr. Forbes, a conservative editorialist and world traveler as a Republican appointee to the boards of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, has already been attacking the Republican front-runner, Senator Bob Dole, as a candidate who voted for various tax increases and now makes false claims of being the most fervid tax-cutter in the field.
President Clinton is pitied more than pilloried in Mr. Forbes's view. "He did not rise to the occasion," says the neophyte, "and he's reduced today to portraying himself as a kinder, gentler Republican."
In trying to be a politician, Mr. Forbes talks in terms of needing the "inner compass" of Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher, plus the ability of Jack F. Kemp, the former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, to reach people with a message of supply-side economic growth. It was Mr. Kemp's decision not to run for the Presidency that prompted supply-side Republican strategists to implore Mr. Forbes.
"Steve's whole approach is bottom-up capitalism, as opposed to top-down," said Jude Wanniski, a political writer and close friend.
The candidate's inner sanctum includes John Sears, a former Reagan campaign manager, as principal strategist; William Dal Col, a former aide to Mr. Kemp, as campaign manager; John McLaughlin as pollster and Carter Wrenn and Tom Ellis, conservative veterans from the political operation of Senator Jesse Helms.
"Who but Steve do you hear in American politics today with such an unvarnished, unambiguous, unashamed defense of entrepreneurial capitalism and growth and jobs?" asked Mr. Kemp, an enthusiast who is withholding formal endorsement of any candidate for now. "Steve's music to my ears."

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Power To Punish

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Getting the Federal Government's hands off private institutions is one of the main aims of the new Republican leaders in Congress. So they say. What they do is another matter, as we learn from Representative Robert Livingston of Louisiana, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee.
In July Mr. Livingston wrote to the presidents of three private colleges, Middlebury in Vermont and Bowdoin and Colby in Maine. He complained about their rules on fraternities, for example barring any that are limited to one sex. 
 At a public university, he said, such restrictions would be forbidden by the First Amendment's guarantees of free speech and association. And these private colleges got "significant Federal funding," Mr. Livingston said. He asked for an "assurance" that they would end their "discrimination" against fraternities.
The letter's legal premise was false. Courts, including the Supreme Court, have long held that public universities may exclude fraternities.
But the real message of Mr. Livingston's letter was of course not law but power. The threat that Congress would withhold Federal aid could hardly have been plainer.
That kind of muscled official intervention in the business of private universities is dangerous. Their independence is a vital creative factor in the American economy and culture, and there is a deep national interest in protecting that independence.
The three college presidents, who all turned Mr. Livingston's pressure aside, saw the point. William R. Cotter of Colby said to me: "If one Congress can say you must have fraternities, the next one can say you can't have them. These decisions should be for private colleges."
John M. McCardell Jr. of Middlebury said: "Maybe I've read too much John C. Calhoun, but I really believe the private institutions must battle this at the outposts. It's about holding us hostage to particular chairmen in Congress."
Why was Representative Livingston so exercised? The Chronicle of Higher Education, which disclosed his letters, reported that as a student at Tulane he belonged to Delta Kappa Epsilon. D.K.E. recently sued Middlebury, unsuccessfully, over its rule against single-sex fraternities. And D.K.E. is now using Mr. Livingston's letter in a fund-raising appeal to alumni.
It looks as though Mr. Livingston was using his position as a powerful committee chairman to carry out a private vendetta. So much for the claimed desire to keep the Government's cotton-pickin' hands off private institutions.
A similar threat is present in even more dangerous form in legislation to restrict "political advocacy" by nonprofit groups. Representative Ernest Jim Istook Jr., Republican of Oklahoma, is trying to attach it as a rider to a pending appropriation bill.
The Istook amendment would apply to any organization that gets Federal grants. However small the grant, there would be tight limits on what the organization could spend on "advocacy" from its own, privately raised funds: no more than 5 percent of those funds up to $20 million, 1 percent thereafter.
Moreover the private groups would have to submit reports to the Federal Government on their operations, and the groups would be subject to Federal audits: a heavy bureaucratic burden. They would be barred from doing business with any organization whose budget goes more than 15 percent for advocacy.
Mr. Istook's targets range from the Y.M.C.A. to the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, from foundations to universities. His definition of "advocacy" is so broad that it includes not only lobbying Congress but filing briefs in court.
Hitting out at private organizations is a strange course for a conservative. From Alexis de Tocqueville on, admirers of American society have attributed its success in good part to its multiplicity of private organizations: civic, religious and the like.
It is also odd for conservatives to overlook the danger to the First Amendment. They have been rightly outraged at the idea of "politically correct" speech. Yet under this rider any group that gets the smallest amount of Government money would have to give up its First Amendment rights.
The real reason for the rider appears, again, to be a vendetta. Republican radicals in Congress resent what some nonprofit organizations have advocated. So they are trying to use their power to punish.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
While the Children Sleep

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
He strolled out of his apartment in Manhattan. He knew where to get what he wanted, no problem. He was back soon with his packages, the way some husbands come home with ice cream or flowers.
He took some of the contents, and so did his wife. She died. The two little kids were asleep. They found out in the the morning. 
 Happens all the time -- heroin overdose, dead on arrival. But he was a young magazine publisher and she a stockbroker -- both up and coming and everything to live for. How could they do this to themselves and the kids?
Soon somebody wrote a letter to The Times explaining how it happened. U.S. anti-drug policies are to blame. The "demonization" of drugs prevented people from learning how much heroin at what potency was O.K. for holding good jobs without dropping dead. That failure to acknowledge the enduring appeal of drugs is the "larger tragedy."
This was from a professor. He also is a senior fellow at one of those pro-legalization groups supported by tax-free foundation money.
This column is not directed to people like that. They make their reputations and living by being professional legalization pushers; they are gone, goodbye. It is addressed to other people, in academia, or journalism, some lawyers, who simply believe that making drugs legally available would reduce drug crime and save the billions spent on fighting drugs.
They are worth arguing with because they are people of influence. Their activities, writing, their money to pro-drug foundations, help create a casualness, an acceptance, toward drugs that increases their use.
I ask them to rethink the consequences of what they do. Start by calling the Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse, (212) 841-5227, to get its new report, "Legalization: Panacea or Pandora's Box?"
I have read myself groggy with studies on drugs. This one by the center -- at Columbia University and headed by Joseph A. Califano Jr. -- is one of the most valuable. From now on, the legalizers will have to deal with it.
Briefly, with only a taste of the evidence the report presents, these are some of the points it makes:
The drug war has made substantial progress that would have been impossible without laws and public support. The number of "current" users -- those who used drugs within the last month -- has dropped from 24.8 million in 1979 to 13 million last year, nearly 50 percent -- but not evenly in all cities and neighborhoods. The number of hard addicts has stayed steady at about 6 million. Wrestling with them is the job ahead.
Marijuana is the growing enemy of American youth. It not only weakens them physically and mentally in their growing years, reduces the I.Q. of babies if used by pregnant women, but also is the gateway to harder drugs. Teen-agers who use it are 85 times more likely also to use cocaine than whose who do not, 17 times more likely to use cocaine in their adulthood. Almost all Americans who use drugs begin before they are 21. And youngsters say that the major deterrent to use of marijuana and other drugs is legal penalty.
More access to drugs through legalization or permissiveness will hugely increase consumption and addiction. That will cost far more than the $13 billion spent to fight drugs -- in increased hospital costs, spread of disease, and drop in economic productivity and student learning abilities.
Drug-gang crimes would decrease only if drugs could be bought almost everywhere by grown-ups and kids, wiping out all black markets. Even so crime would increase -- by drug-related crimes not related to the drug trade, like murder, rape and assault.
Foreign experiments in legalization or permissiveness have failed. In the Netherlands, for instance, adolescent marijuana use has increased 250 percent. Registered harder-drug addicts have increased by 22 percent. Italy has the highest rate in Europe of addicts enjoying the "enduring appeal" of heroin.
I'm a little sick of trying to persuade pro-legalizers by statistics and money talk. Leave your pocket calculator home, just go out and look at the shaking people with shaking brains.
But reading this report should be the ticket to talking about legalization. Go argue with it. If you still want more access to drugs, stroll down to buy a few packets for yourself and your wife, while the children sleep. No problem.

HEADLINE: In America;
If Colin Powell Runs

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Julio Rodriguez pointed toward a parking lot on the other side of Kelly Street in the South Bronx and said, "He lived right over there."
The tall fence at the entrance to the lot was topped with coils of razor wire. Several cars, a school bus and a boat were parked in the lot. The Bronx is a motley place. 
 At the far end of the block a subway train rumbled along elevated tracks, its noise unnoticed by the small groups of unemployed men and women, some with small children at their side, who had drifted out of tenement buildings to pass the morning, desultorily, with neighbors.
"If Colin Powell ran for President it would show that someone from around here could be somebody," said Mr. Rodriguez, who is 24. "I would like to see him run and win. Everybody thinks we are nothing.
"If he gets to be President, the best thing he could do is find jobs for people. I've been looking, looking. I've been down to Manhattan looking. But nothing."
Rafael Roldan, a quiet, older friend of Mr. Rodriguez, wondered, "If the general runs, what party would it be?"
Mr. Roldan, 47, is a self-employed contractor from Queens. "Light construction," he explained. "Siding, roofs, masonry. My wife and I own our own home, but business is very bad and we're having trouble making ends meet. People can't afford to do work on their homes anymore."
Mr. Roldan was told that General Powell might run as a Republican, or as an independent. He won't run as a Democrat.
Now there was quiet.
Noel Rosa, who is 18 and who had been sitting off to the side, looked up. "Would he really run as a Republican?" he asked. "They are so prejudiced. They don't care about us. They are more for the rich."
His eyes were a mixture of anger and hurt. For urban dwellers, and especially for the poor, the Republican Party as currently constituted is the enemy -- the source of endless destructive, mean-spirited and racist initiatives that are already taking a terrible toll on communities across the country.
It is difficult to see how the ideologues who control the party could accommodate General Powell, or how he could accommodate them. His expressed views mark the general as a Democrat. It is difficult to imagine how a G.O.P. uniform would fit.
"Maybe as an independent," said Mr. Roldan. "I could see that. But not as a Republican."
The unspoken question on Kelly Street was how, in good conscience, General Powell could serve as the standard-bearer of a party that is waging all-out war against the poor and racial and ethnic minorities (and which is hostile to the interests of the middle class as well).
The general knows there is a problem here. "To some extent," he said in a television interview, "those who are seeking the support of the Republican right occasionally almost go to the point of demonizing some of our fellow Americans who have not benefited fully in the American dream."
The problem is much deeper than that comment would indicate. To take just one example, could the general defend the policies of the Texas tax terrors, House Republicans Dick Armey and Bill Archer, who can't wait to slash the taxes of the very wealthy while cutting back on the earned-income tax credit that has proved helpful to the working poor?
As an independent, General Powell could take his inspirational, value-driven message to the American people unhampered by those kinds of grossly inequitable gambits. (God forbid he favors such inequities.) He could articulate a vision of America's economic future, address the tragic social and cultural deterioration of the inner cities, and he could heal many, many wounds.
As an independent, the general could serve as a trusted bridge between the lower and middle classes. For years, the insidious and blatantly racist strategy of the Republican Party has been to pit the middle classes against the lower classes, while sucking money from both groups up the economic pyramid to the smiling faces at the top.
There is a hunger among many Americans for a Colin Powell run at the Presidency. The folks who need effective new leadership are in the lower and middle classes. The ultimate irony will be if the general presents himself to these voters as the candidate of the party that has done so very much to harm them.

HEADLINE: Artists Need Some Affordable Space for Work

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As executive director of the Lower East Side Printshop, a not-for-profit organization providing work space for artists, I read with interest your Sept. 19 news article on the plan for an artists condominium in Peekskill, N.Y. I congratulate the developers for recognizing the economic power that artists bring to declining or abandoned neighborhoods. 
 I was shocked, however, to learn that rents of $1,400 and condominium prices of $125,000 were considered affordable.
While a world in which sipping wine with like-minded others after a productive day in the studio is lovely, the reality is that most artists cannot afford such rents -- the Lower East Side Printshop's monthly fee of $60 is often a stretch for members.
Work space at a reasonable price for artists is a rare commodity, and one that is diminishing steadily as city, state and Federal funding for the arts diminishes. In the last five years, the Printshop has seen support for its work-space programs from the New York State Council on the Arts fall from more than $24,000 to $5,000 this year, and we are grateful to receive that amount.
But the demand from artists for a place to work has not likewise declined.
The partnership of public and private investment that the Peekskill project represents is exciting and is the wave of the future. Perhaps there is an ambitious developer somewhere willing to create a plan truly within the means of artists. I know a few thousand people who might be interested.
 
ROBYN LOVE
New York, Sept. 19, 1995

HEADLINE: Inside Art

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:

Till Death Do Us Part
Some works of art are so important to a corporation's image that no matter what the circumstance, the art and the company stay together.
In Manhattan, at the Equitable Life Assurance Society of America, that means moving Thomas Hart Benton's 10-panel mural, "America Today," one block east from the Equitable Tower at 787 Seventh Avenue to its new location, 1290 Avenue of the Americas, between 51st and 52d Streets. 
 The 1930 mural, which depicts the country's economic and social life at the beginning of the Great Depression, has adorned the lobby of the Equitable Tower since the building's completion in 1986. Equitable bought the mural for $3.4 million from the New School for Social Research 11 years ago.
"Since it wasn't part of the original architecture, we feel comfortable moving it," said Pari Stave, the Equitable's curator.
The owner of the Avenue of the Americas building, Olympia & York, has worked with its new tenant to make the Benton work more visible from the street than it was in the Equitable Tower. "Originally there were plans for planting trees and for a flagpole at the entrance to the building, but these were done away with so the mural could be seen through the building's glass facade," Ms. Stave said. She added that increased security and proper lighting had also been considerations in planning the work's installation.
Consolidation is the reason for the Equitable's move, which is to take place next summer. "We have six locations in Manhattan, and we wanted to put everyone together," a spokeswoman for the company said.
But the Equitable will still sponsor shows in its gallery in the Tower, Ms. Stave said, although most of the company's 600 works of art, which range from drawings and photographs to paintings and prints, predominantly by American artists, will move to the new offices. "If we keep our dining rooms in the Tower, some of the art will stay there, but that hasn't been decided yet," Ms. Stave said.
In Los Angeles, Michael Ovitz's departure as chairman and co-founder of Creative Artists Agency to become the president of the Walt Disney Company has caused many in the art world to wonder about the fate of Roy Lichtenstein's "Bauhaus Stairway: The Large Version," a 27-foot-high mural that hangs in the atrium of Creative Artists Agency's I. M. Pei building in Beverly Hills. The work, which is based on Oskar Shlemmer's "Bauhaus Stair," at the Museum of Modern Art, was commissioned specifically for the 1989 building and bought by Mr. Ovitz.
A Creative Artists spokeswoman, Anna Perez, said the mural was owned by W&S Properties. Mr. Ovitz is a partner in W&S. Ms. Perez declined to comment on whether the company would be buying him out of his share of the artwork. "This is a privately held company, and such financial matters are never made public," she said.
At Mr. Ovitz's new office, a Disney spokeswoman said that Creative Artists would speak for Mr. Ovitz until he began work at Disney on Oct. 1, and deferred all matters to Ms. Perez.
 
Farewell, 57th Street
 Two veteran 57th Street dealers in Manhattan, Alan Frumkin and Grace Borgenicht, are calling it quits. "I'm retiring from the gallery after 43 years, but I will still be active as a private dealer," Mr. Frumkin said this week. "I will be dealing in drawings by contemporary and European masters." The gallery, which is at 50 West 57th Street and shows predominantly contemporary artists, has been run by Mr. Frumkin and George Adams for 15 years. Mr. Adams will continue at the same address, changing the name to the George Adams Gallery.
Grace Borgenicht, who has shown the work of American artists for 44 years, is also retiring. "Since I passed my 80th birthday, I decided it was time to call a halt to the gallery," she said. The gallery, at 724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, will close at the end of October.
 
Moving Uptown
 For the first time in 10 years, Mary Boone will show a new artist. In January, Ellen Gallagher, a 24-year-old abstract painter whose work was included in this year's Whitney Biennial, will have her first New York solo show at Ms. Boone's SoHo gallery.
Ms. Boone, meanwhile, is looking at spaces on 57th Street. "It's time to move uptown," she said. "The atmosphere in SoHo has become unbearable. It's no longer art-oriented. Galleries first came to SoHo with the understanding that collectors like to see art in the context of where artists work, but artists haven't worked here for over 20 years. Now SoHo has become mostly low-end retail stores."
One space Ms. Boone has her eye on is Blum-Hellman's, at 20 West 57th Street. But Irving Blum and Joseph Hellman are involved in a lawsuit to dissolve their partnership, and at this point the future of the gallery is uncertain.
 
1997 Whitney Biennial
 The Whitney Museum of American Art has had a big week. Besides announcing a $35 million capital campaign drive and the New York City Landmarks approval of its expansion plan, the museum had news about its 1997 Biennial.
Lisa Phillips, a 20-year veteran of the Whitney, will be a curator of the show. She selected Louise Neri, the United States editor of Parkett, an international art journal, to be the other curator. Ms. Phillips described Ms. Neri's role as "a meaningful collaboration," but said she would retain veto power. Ms. Phillips is also bringing in consultants from around the country.
The Biennial, which has always been a survey of what is happening in contemporary American art, may be broadening its reach. Since Ms. Neri is Australian and Parkett is a European publication, she brings an international perspective.
"There's a possibility we will include European artists," Ms. Phillips said. "We're still in the process of defining the context of the show."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
In Two Days, the Dollar Loses Most of a Monthlong Advance

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled against other leading currencies yesterday, dropping below 100 Japanese yen in a retreat fueled by tepid central bank support for the dollar and continued speculation about obstacles to a single European currency.
In two days of profit taking, the dollar has largely given up its advance of the last month. Since Tuesday, the dollar has fallen 5 percent against the yen and 4.3 percent against the German mark. 
 However, in afternoon trading today in Tokyo, the dollar climbed above 100 yen.
Yesterday's decline marked an about-face for the dollar, which had been ascendant since hitting a postwar low of 79.75 yen on April 19. It hit 100 yen early this month and passed 104 yen on Tuesday -- a 15-month high -- before starting its fall.
The slide began on Wednesday after the Japanese Government announced a new economic stimulus program. The Bank of Japan had been expected to buy dollars aggressively on the foreign-exchange markets after the release of the package, and when such an intervention failed to materialize, currency dealers sold dollars and took profits.
The profit taking continued yesterday, and as the dollar fell through important technical levels, dealers became cautious that central banks would step in to force it back above those levels. But there was no sign that the Federal Reserve and other central banks were buying dollars, and the selloff accelerated.
In trading in New York, the dollar fell as much as 5 percent against major currencies before recovering slightly. The dollar settled at 99.05 yen, down from 102.70 yen on Wednesday. The dollar fell to 1.4235 marks from 1.4613 marks. The British pound rose to $1.5906 from $1.5503.
"It's the sort of correction you can often get when markets move a long way," said John Ryding, a senior economist at Bear, Stearns & Company.
And analysts attributed part of the dollar's weakness yesterday to a strong surge in the mark and the Swiss franc, which dragged on the dollar as a result.
On Wednesday, two top German monetary officials voiced doubts that France and Italy would be able to become part of a single European currency. Monetary turmoil in Europe typically prompts a flight to the mark and the Swiss franc, which are considered safe-haven currencies.
The dollar fell sharply against the Swiss franc yesterday even though the Swiss central bank unexpectedly cut its discount rate by half a percentage point, to 2 percent, the lowest level in 15 years.
In New York trading, the dollar fell to 1.1408 Swiss francs, from 1.1725 francs on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Dow Retreats by 25.29 As Dollar Falls Sharply

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market slumped yesterday, dragged down by a plunge in the dollar that raised concerns that foreign investors might retreat from American securities.
Shortly before 2 P.M., the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 49.49 points -- just shy of the level that would set off the New York Stock Exchange's 50-point "circuit breaker" rule. It was the second time this week that the Dow fell nearly 50 points in daily trading. 
 Yesterday, the Dow closed at 4,767.40, down 25.29 points.
The broader indicators closed on the downside as well. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 3.77 points, to 583.00 and the Nasdaq composite index fell 6.58 points, to 1,058.51.
"There was continued disappointment that earnings for the third quarter will be less than analysts thought they would be," said Robert Turner, chairman of Turner Investment Partners in Philadelphia. "But we were encouraged to see the market start to build back up."
Bond prices also pulled back from their lows, but were nevertheless sharply down for the day. The bellwether 30-year Treasury bond tumbled 1 9/32 and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.55 percent, from 6.46 percent on Wednesday.
Declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange vastly outnumbered advancers, 1,435 to 828. Volume on the Big Board amounted to 367.1 million shares, off from 400.1 million shares Wednesday.
Financial services stocks were hit by a report from the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia that lowered expectations for an interest rate cut at next week's meeting of the Fed's policy-making committee. Chemical Banking fell 1 3/4, to 58 3/4; Citicorp, 1 5/8, to 69 3/8; BankAmerica, 5/8, to 59 3/4, and Wells Fargo 2 3/4, to 85 1/8. A so-called bad trade on the New York exchange at midday in J. P. Morgan - which dropped 1 3/8, to 76 5/8 -- threw the Dow industrials out of kilter before it was corrected.
Technology issues were down amid widespread anticipation that many companies in this sector will not meet profit expectations. Micron declined 2, to 85 5/8; Cisco Systems, 1 1/2, to 70 5/8; Applied Materials, 2 5/8, to 102, and Advanced Micro Devices, 1 1/4, to 33 1/8.
Some analysts voiced concern after Microsoft said that sales of its new Windows 95 computer operating system have slowed from the introductory pace a month ago. The stock closed at 90 5/8, down 2 1/2.
Wickes Lumber, which slipped 1 3/4, to 11 3/4, noted that it expects third-quarter net income to be below the corresponding period of last year. Professional Sports Care Management, which projected that third-quarter profits would fall short of expectations, fell 1 1/8, to 7 1/2. Food and drug stocks were a general exception to the downward trend, moving higher as the earnings of cyclical stocks weakened. Pfizer gained 1 7/8, to 50 3/4, after it said that sales will jump about 20 percent in 1995, while Eli Lilly rose 1, to 90, after Merrill Lynch raised its medium-term investment opinion. Campbell Soup advanced 3/8, to 49 1/2; Kellogg, 1 1/8, to 71 1/8, and Procter & Gamble, 1/2, to 75 3/4.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Tumble On Big Jump In Fed Survey

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were slammed to the mat yesterday, flipped by a weak dollar and a regional Federal Reserve report showing a strong business outlook. That set back optimism for another rate cut by the central bank this year.
"Both the rise in the Philadelphia Fed survey of regional business activity and the weakness in the dollar tipped the scale," said Tony Crescenzi, head of fixed-income trading at Miller, Tabak, Hirsch & Company, a New York brokerage firm. 
 Others also cited technical reasons for the market selloff, in addition to comments by House Speaker Newt Gingrich to the Public Securities Association. To force the Clinton Administration to balance the budget on Republican terms, Mr. Gingrich threatened to send the United States into default on its debt for the first time in its history.
The 30-year bond fell 1 9/32, to a price of 104 6/32 to yield 6.55 percent, up from 6.46 percent on Wednesday. Yields on notes with maturities of less than five years were down even more because they are more sensitive to changes in Fed rate policy. For bondholders, the decline meant a loss of $12.81 for every $1,000 of bonds held.
The Philadelphia Fed's index, a gauge of manufacturing activity in the Mid-Atlantic region, registered a stronger-than-expected 24.4 reading in September, compared with 4.4 in August. That means about 43 percent of the manufacturers surveyed reported higher activity in September, compared with 27 percent that had reported increased activity in August. The report dashed hopes for an interest rate cut soon.
The survey does not necessarily reflect a booming manufacturing sector nationwide, traders said, but it is a piece of information that the Fed's policy-setting committee will consider closely. Economists said the report sent members of that committee a warning ahead of their meeting on Tuesday.
Also released yesterday were the initial weekly unemployment claims figures, which rose by 1,000, to 365,000, for the week that ended on Sept. 16. Some economists said the initial unemployment claims still indicated a tepid labor market.
Hamilton Davis, a vice president of government trading at Kemper Securities in Chicago, said, "It was an interesting day," adding, "We retraced two weeks of gains in the dollar, in just two days."
"For this one day at least," he said, "the negatives have overpowered the long-term positives of the market." Among other things, the Commodity Research Bureau index, a portent of inflation, rose 2 points to levels "we have not seen since May 1990 in the index," he said.
Mr. Davis added, "Recently, dealers have been rewarded by buying nearby support levels in bond prices, but today the selling overwhelmed the buyers at the first support level and drove us down about one-half point in price on the long bond before anybody could recover."
The Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, is scheduled to appear before the Senate Banking Committee today to testify on the economy, and the market is eager to hear what he has to say.
The Philadelphia Fed survey said manufacturers might no longer be trying to cut inventories, which some market participants took to mean production cycles would have to pick up to match demand again, meaning more hiring, more income and more consumer spending.
Carl Palash, chief economist of MCM Money Watch in New York, a market research and analysis firm, said, "One important point is that the index is close to levels of the 1994 fourth quarter, when the manufacturing sector and economy were both strong." That, he said, put "a damper on expectations that Fed will ease next Tuesday."
Looking ahead, Mr. Palash predicted a rise in September durable goods orders of 3.5 percent, "and I think the risk is that the purchasing managers report will jump to 55 percent."
Mr. Palash said that since the Fed put so much weight on the health of the manufacturing sector, strong numbers like those released yesterday would weigh on the Treasury market. The Fed report's price components also suggested that inflation was not as benign as many had thought.
In when-issued trading in advance of next week's Treasury auctions, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.78 percent, while the five-year note was offered at a price to yield 6 percent. Both suffered from the market's sharp drop, with yields up 10 basis points from the previous day as dealers sought to generate interest in the issues.

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Hold at a High Level

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
The number of Americans applying for unemployment benefits for the first time held at the highest level in nearly two months last week, the Labor Department said today.
Initial claims for state jobless pay were little changed at a seasonally adjusted 365,000 in the week that ended last Saturday, after unexpectedly shooting up by 22,000 the week before to 364,000 claims, the department said. the number of first-time jobless claims was the highest since 372,000 applications in the week that ended on July 22.
The closely tracked four-week moving average of claims, viewed as a more reliable gauge of labor market conditions than the more volatile weekly figure, jumped to 354,750 in the latest week, from 350,500, the department said.
The number of people already receiving state jobless benefits in the week ended Sept. 9, the latest week for which those data are available, declined by 33,000, to 2,623,000 from 2,656,000 a week earlier, it said.

HEADLINE: A Fever, Once in Retreat, Surges in Latin America

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 22

 BODY:
After being virtually eradicated in the Western Hemisphere, dengue fever, a debilitating tropical disease transmitted by mosquitoes, is re-emerging with such force that it has now reached epidemic proportions in Central America and is bearing down on the United States.
The resurgence, health experts say, is largely the result of rapid urban population growth in Latin America and the Caribbean, which has led to lax sanitation procedures, overcrowding and poverty. While dengue fever does not pose as large a threat to the United States, experts at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention warn that states like Texas and Florida face the risk of an outbreak. 
 More than 35,000 people have contracted the disease in Central America in recent months, and El Salvador and Guatemala have declared states of "national urgency," allowing them to deal with the epidemic as a natural disaster. At an emergency meeting in Guatemala this week, health officials from Central American and Caribbean countries met to coordinate their responses and to plead for foreign economic aid to help control the epidemic.
"If control measures are not implemented immediately, the rates will be tremendous for at least the next three months or so," said Dr. Gabriel Schmunis, an Argentine physician who is director of the communicable disease program of the Pan American Health Organization in Washington. "This is the rainy season in Central America."
The disease has also reappeared in other places, including Mexico, where an eightfold increase in the number of cases has been reported this year, and among American troops in Haiti and hurricane relief workers in the Caribbean.
Brazil has identified more than 88,000 cases this year, and in Venezuela more than 15,000 people have been afflicted, leading the Pan American Health Organization to warn in a recent statement of "the growing threat of a full-fledged epidemic" throughout the Western Hemisphere.
Experts say dengue (pronounced DEN-ghee or DEN-gay) is transmitted by the Aedes aegypti mosquito and is characterized by the sudden onset of a high fever, rash, severe headaches, nausea and vomiting. In English-speaking countries, the disease is known as breakbone fever because of the excruciating pain in the joints and muscles that usually accompanies it.
Four basic strains of so-called classic dengue have been identified. There is no vaccine or specific treatment for the disease, but in its classic form dengue is rarely fatal.
But health experts say they are now concerned about the emergence of a more virulent and potentially lethal form of the disease known as dengue hemorrhagic fever, which is caused by the same strains as classic dengue. Beyond their enhanced virulence, the greater severity of the strains also seems related to the genetic susceptibility of the victims, according to the American Public Health Association.
As its name implies, hemorrhagic dengue causes increased permeability of blood vessels, which leads to plasma leakage, shock and death in about 10 percent of reported cases.
Doctors say that falling victim to one variety of dengue does not confer immunity to the others. In fact, experts say that people who have been infected with one or more strains of classic dengue seem more vulnerable to the more severe form of the disease. Antibodies acquired in the earlier infection, they say, may overstimulate the body's immune cells and make them more susceptible.
With all four strains of the disease now having been observed in Central America, the experts warn, conditions for the spread of the hemorrhagic form are ideal.
Statistics on the number of hemorrhagic cases and deaths in the current epidemic are fragmentary and difficult to obtain. Health workers in several countries say they suspected that there has been underreporting of the extent of the epidemic, in part because governments do not want to scare off tourists.
Dengue has long been endemic to the tropics, but after World War II, governments throughout the Western Hemisphere started a coordinated effort to wipe out Aedes aegypti, which also transmits yellow fever. By the 1970's, the campaign had largely eliminated the mosquito and the dengue threat, and governments, ignoring experts' warnings, began to relax their vigilance.
But small pockets of the insect were left in Venezuela and some Caribbean islands, providing Aedes aegypti with the toehold it needed for a comeback.
"The eradication effort was stopped too soon, and when it was stopped, efforts to keep the mosquito from reinvading also were not continued," said Dr. Duane Gubler, a dengue expert at the Centers for Disease Control.
Then in 1981, a severe epidemic struck Cuba, infecting more than 300,000 people. President Fidel Castro initially accused the United States of introducing the virus as a form of biological warfare, but researchers later determined that the disease had actually been imported from Vietnam by Cubans returning from jobs there.
At the same time, a new and hardier species of dengue-bearing mosquito, Aedes albopictus, known as the Asian tiger mosquito, was introduced into the Western Hemisphere and became entrenched in the United States. The tiger mosquito, which ranges as far north as Chicago, has not been identified as a transmitting the current Central American epidemic, but is regarded as a potential carrier.
Over the last decade, there have been periodic eruptions of dengue in the Caribbean and Latin America, though on a scale smaller than this year's epidemic. Such outbreaks can be avoided, experts say, if governments and citizens follow simple and low-cost sanitation measures that eliminate mosquito-breeding sites.
"This is an urban mosquito, and the population of the cities has increased, so more people are exposed," said Dr. Schmunis of the Pan American Health Organization. "That is especially the case where there is no running water and the larvae of the mosquito can grow in places where water collects, such as barrels and tires."
Facing growing pressure from alarmed citizens, several Central American and Caribbean governments have begun extensive spraying campaigns. But health experts say such efforts are largely ineffective, since fumigation kills only adult mosquitoes outdoors and spares both their larvae and those adults that are indoors.
But as a result of this week's meeting in Guatemala, the affected countries have said they will step up their education programs. In several Central American countries, soldiers and health workers have already been deployed to clean up breeding sites and explain to residents the relationship between the disease and their sanitation practices.
To assist in that effort, Britain has already approved a small special aid package, and Norway is expected to follow suit. Although representatives of the United States Government attended the Guatemala meeting and Washington has expressed concern that the disease may soon spread to southern and border states, the United States has not contributed to the emergency fund.
On the average, about 75 cases of dengue are reported in the United States each year, brought back from abroad by Americans visiting the tropics. Dr. Gubler of the C.D.C. cautioned that an outbreak of dengue "along the entire Gulf Coast, from Texas to Florida" is possible, but said a full fledged epidemic is extremely unlikely.
In the United States, "mosquito densities are lower, local mosquito control districts do good work, and the life style of humans is not really conducive to an urban mosquito-borne disease like this," he said.

HEADLINE: Forbes Makes Official Entry Into '96 Race

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
The publishing executive Malcolm S. Forbes Jr. formally declared his intention today to seek the Republican Presidential nomination, promising lower taxes to free the economy from "political repression."
Surveying the already crowded Republican field, Mr. Forbes said that there was "an empty feeling in the campaign so far" and that other candidates were limited by a "narrow, cramped and constricted" view of what the nation could accomplish. 
 Mr. Forbes, 48, the chief executive of Forbes Inc., also announced at the National Press Club here that he would take a leave of absence and hand over the reins of the family's publishing company, which includes Forbes and American Heritage magazines, to his brother, Timothy, while he campaigned. He plans to largely finance his undertaking from his personal fortune.
Mr. Forbes, known as Steve, took over the helm of the company after his father's death in 1990. He said he would continue to write a column for Forbes magazine.
Mr. Forbes said his candidacy, which is widely seen as a long shot, would focus on his optimistic view of the country's growth potential. Emphasizing tax cuts over deficit reduction, Mr. Forbes predicted that an economic boom would flow from his proposals for a flat income tax and for using a type of gold standard to stabilize the dollar.
"I see an American economy that is the most innovative and productive and technologically advanced in the world, hamstrung by high taxes and counterproductive regulations," he said.
Mr. Forbes has no political experience beyond a stint as chairman of the Government's Board for International Broadcasting and his service as an informal adviser to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey. His campaign will have its headquarters in Bedminster, N.J.
What he lacks in political capital, Mr. Forbes believes he can make up in money. He has said he is willing spend millions of dollars of his fortune, free of the spending limits that constrain candidates who accept Federal matching funds.
