HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Time Warner and Turner Finally Agree to Merger
 Ending a tumultuous five-week courtship, Time Warner and Turner Broadcasting said they would merge, reinforcing Time Warner's position as the world's largest communications company. 
 Time Warner said it would buy the 82 percent of Turner it did not already own in a stock deal worth about $7.5 billion. But the transaction ran into immediate problems because of thorny management issues and a conflict between Time Warner and another partner, U. S. West. The structure of the deal also drew a sharp protest from two other major shareholders in Turner Broadcasting: Comcast and Continental Cablevision. [Page 1.]
 
For more than 30 years, if Ted Turner was on board, he was the captain, but not any more. Mr. Turner is becoming vice chairman of the merged companies. [38.]
 
Mitsubishi Bank Sells Bonds
 Morgan Stanley managed the sale of $2 billion of convertible bonds for Mitsubishi Bank, the largest international convertible bond offering on record, which comes despite a crisis in much of Japanese banking. [43.]
 
Hanover Sterling in Stock Charges
 The S.E.C. filed administrative proceedings against the former president and two traders of Hanover Sterling. The men were accused of manipulating the stock price of All-Pro Products, the company owned by Lawrence Taylor, formerly of the New York Giants, who apparently had big losses in the deal. [39.]
 
Investment Spending Rises 9.4%
 American businesses plan to raise investment spending by 9.4 percent this year, to $600.7 billion, the fourth straight increase. [39.]
 
Rubin Suggests Bank Compromise
 Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said the Administration continued to favor allowing banks to merge with insurance companies as well as securities firms, but might be willing to accept a less extensive plan that would allow mergers only with securities firms. [38.]
 
Currency Turmoil Hits Markets
 Turmoil in the currency markets spilled over into stocks and bonds in Europe, sending prices down sharply. In Frankfurt, the DAX index of 30 shares fell 75.53 points, to 2,211.79; the CAC-40 index in Paris fell 63.23 points, to 1,790.69, and in London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index closed at 3,514.8, down 43.1 points. [42.]
 
Stocks Fall in Erratic Trading
 Stocks slipped in the same kind of erratic trading that the market had endured for much of the week. The Dow industrials fell 3.25 points to 4,764.15, the S.& P. index declined 1.27 points to 581.73, and the Nasdaq composite index dropped 5.12 points to 1,053.39. For the week, the Dow lost 33.42 points. [43.]
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.58 percent, from 6.55 percent on Thursday, as Alan Greenspan described a rosy economic outlook in his semiannual report to the Senate Banking Committee. [51.]
 
Controversy Over Implant Book
 In a forthcoming book, a former Dow Corning executive describes what he sees as his company's unethical and reckless handling of the silicone breast implant issue. But the company contends that two years ago the executive, John E. Swanson, suggested that it pay him for the rights to a book he was hoping to write on the implant issue. [10.]
 
Forbes Declares for Presidency
 Malcolm S. Forbes Jr. formally declared his intention to seek the Republican Presidential nomination. Mr. Forbes, the chief executive of Forbes Inc., said he would turn over the reins of the company to his brother Timothy. [10.]
 
Soybeans Fall on Upbeat Reports
Soybean prices tumbled on the Chicago Board of Trade after an early frost in the Midwest appeared to do less damage to crops than had been expected. Soybeans for November delivery fell 18.75 cents, to $6.45 a bushel. [36.]
 
Farm Subsidies Survive Vote
 A vote by the House Agriculture Committee this week stymied efforts to scrap the system of farm subsidies that thousands of growers of cotton, rice and sugar say is not only a safety net in their risky business but also a way to stabilize prices and supply. [6.]

HEADLINE: Bright Prospects on Georgia Farm

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: EDISON, Ga., Sept. 22

 BODY:
Bob McLendon is in high cotton at the moment, literally and figuratively.
For one thing, the price of cotton is nearly twice its value as loan collateral. For another, a vote by the House Agriculture Committee this week stymied efforts to scrap the system of farm subsidies that Mr. McLendon and thousands of other growers of cotton, rice, and sugar say not only provides a safety net in their risky business but also stabilizes prices and supply. 
 Earlier this year, as he was planting his 1,900 acres of cotton in this rural corner of southwest Georgia, Mr. McLendon's ears were ringing with the promises by deficit-hawks in Washington to squeeze savings of more than $10 billion a year from the Government's farm subsidies and to throw farmers like himself to the mercies of the free-market system. Such talk was about as welcome as a boll weevil infestation to farmers like Mr. McLendon, 54.
But on Wednesday, supporters of the subsidies on the House Agriculture Committee voted down a measure that would have begun phasing them out over seven years as farmers adjusted their production and crop selection to market realities.
The plan, called the Freedom-to-Farm Act and sponsored by the committee's chairman, Representative Pat Roberts, Republican of Kansas, would have cut $13.4 billion from farm subsidies over the seven years. It would have meant a major philosophical shift from the way Government farm policy has evolved over the last five decades.
As he walked his lush green fields near here, brushing against the cotton plants weighed down with unopened bolls, Mr. McLendon compared the subsidies to his irrigation system. "I like them for the same reason that I like the irrigation system," he said. "It takes some of the gamble out of farming."
But Mr. McLendon, who has been farming for a long time, says he refuses "to get too high or too low" over a rise in cotton prices or in winning a battle in the long-term war over Government subsidies.
While lawmakers in Washington talked of efforts to end welfare as we know it, legislators like Representative Saxby Chambliss, a Republican from this section of south Georgia, headed back home this weekend with news releases trumpeting their roles in beating back a measure that would have "ended farm programs as we know them."
Mr. Chambliss and others said that during the August recess, shortly after Mr. Roberts's measure was introduced, he and other lawmakers started receiving calls from groups like the National Cotton Council of America. The group, Mr. Chambliss said, sought "to educate all 103 of the newly elected members of Congress" on the importance of the system of Federal crop subsidies to their members.
Daniel A. Sumner, an agricultural economist at the University of California at Davis, said: "There is a conflict for the Republicans with their free-market zeal and their traditional dependence on the farm vote. It is not uncommon to find rural members running on contradictory platforms of cutting Government while supporting subsidies."
But even Mr. Chambliss conceded that Mr. Roberts's proposal is not dead. At the very least, the defeat of a measure sponsored by a powerful committee chairman and embraced by Speaker Newt Gingrich has altered the debate and pointed the way toward some possible compromises. Mr. Chambliss and others are hoping for a measure that would allow some farmers and crops to stay in a reduced subsidy program while other farmers could opt out.
"We have a Republican conference meeting next Wednesday," Mr. Chambliss, a freshman lawmaker, said in an interview, "and I would like to see the Agriculture Committee staff talk with the cotton industry between now and then to reach some accommodation. Going against the chairman was the most difficult vote I had to make, but my constituents are the ones I have to listen to."
The developments have angered some consumer groups, who had hoped for major change in the program, which come up for renewal every five years.
"But we're in agri-business-as-usual land here," said Kenneth Cook, head of the Environmental Working Group, a private organization that contends the current program lines the pockets of millionaire farmers and corporations. "The big boasts of the Republicans of the last election are all gone now that the politics of it all has hit them."
Mr. Roberts's bill would have allowed farmers to keep the payments on subsidized crops on an annually declining basis. The payments would be made to those with a five-year record of growing the subsidized crop whether they grew anything or not. The idea was to stabilize the farmers' incomes while they experimented with new crops or increased and decreased their old crops to meet market demands.
At the same time it would have removed rules governing how much of a commodity farmers could grow and eliminated the subsidy program that pays farmers the difference between what a crop sells for and the Government-set target price.
The main alternative to the proposal is the Agricultural Competitiveness Act introduced by Senator Thad Cochran, Republican of Mississippi. In the House, there is a nearly identical measure, which Mr. Chambliss is supporting and which he says would save the same $13.4 billion over seven years as Mr. Roberts's measure.
Mr. Cochran conceded in an interview that his approach represented a push for "minimal changes" in the programs. It would keep the system of target prices but freeze them at current levels. The plan's main savings would come from a 10 percent reduction in acreage on which farmers would be eligible for crop subsidies. The proposal also retains a host of loan programs to assist United States commodities in a world market where crops from many countries are heavily subsidized by government.
According to the Congressional Budget Office, the Roberts bill would, in the first year, have actually increased total subsidies to cotton growers by $443 million. That is because the levels from which the payments would decline would be pegged to a five-year average of benefits, and that would take into account the disastrous 1992 experience of cotton growers when there was a world glut.
But that does not sway Mr. McLendon. For one thing he believes the Freedom-to-Farm bill would suffer politically because it would make aid to farmers look more like a welfare program. While Government subsidies are now aimed at controlling prices and supplies of commodities, Mr. Roberts's proposal would leave the decision over whether to grow to farmers. If they chose not to grow, they could still collect a Government check.
While Mr. McLendon is likely to do well this year, and not receive any Government subsidies because of the high price of cotton on the open market, that was not always the case. Last year, market price of cotton dipped below the target price of 72.8 cents a pound by about one cent, and Mr. McLendon collected $12,000 from the Government.
In 1992, the cotton-glut year, he collected $100,000 from the Government -- the maximum that he was allowed under the program of target prices. His wife, Barbara, under whose name another farm operates, also collected $100,000 in 1992.
Without such a program, he said, he and other farmers would probably not take the risk of growing cotton.
"There's no such thing out there as a free market and we need strong programs in order to compete," Mr. McLendon said. "The real winner in all of this is the consumer because prices are stable as well as supplies."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I like them for the same reason that I like the irrigation system," Bob McLendon, a Georgia cotton farmer, said of Government farm subsidies. HEADLINE: THE 104TH CONGRESS: STUDENT LOANS;
Democrats Stall G.O.P. Effort To Curb Aid for College Loans

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Accusing Republicans of catering to bankers and ignoring needy college students, Senate Democrats today stalled proposals to curb direct Government loans to students and to charge colleges a fee for every loan their students receive.
With senators eager to leave town by early afternoon, Democratic speechmaking in the Labor and Human Resources Committee delayed a vote until Tuesday to give educational institutions and their lobbyists more time to plead for votes. 
 Responding to earlier alarms from colleges, Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, the Kansas Republican who heads the committee, scaled back a proposal she made on Tuesday from a charge of 2 percent of all Federal loans issued to students at a college, to .85 percent.
According to Democrats, the change in Senator Kassebaum's proposal would mean, for example, that the City University of New York, with $60 million in loans each year, would pay $510,000. Under the earlier plan, it would have been charged $1.2 million.
"It's a tax, and it's a regressive tax on those schools that educate the neediest students in our country," bellowed Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, whose daylong passionate debating volume led Senator Kassebaum to ask him, mildly, to "stop shouting in my ear."
The fee is intended to raise $2 billion over seven years, down from $4.4 billion in Mrs. Kassebaum's first effort to find $10.8 billion in savings to meet the Congressional target for a balanced budget. The other elements in today's budget plan would do these things:
*Require $4 billion in additional charges and reduced payments to lenders and loan-guarantee agencies.
*Eliminate the six-month post-graduation grace period in which no interest is charged on loans, saving $2.7 billion.
*Raise interest charges on the PLUS program of subsidized loans to parents, saving $694 million.
*Limit direct Government loans to the colleges and universities now using them, or about 20 percent of all institutions nationally. Under new accounting rules adopted this year at Republican insistence, $1.5 billion would be saved.
Today's debate, singularly substantive for a Senate argument carried on in the absence of television cameras, concentrated on the charge to colleges. But Senator Kassebaum defended it, saying that colleges "were a major beneficiary of Federal student loans."
Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, disagreed, saying, "This is a tax on students.".
Mrs. Kassebaum shot back: "This is not a tax. It's an origination fee. The Congressional Budget Office scored it and says it is not a tax."
Mr. Harkin replied, "I don't care what you call it, it's a tax."
At that point, Mr. Kennedy intervened, saying: "If it looks like a duck and quacks like a duck, it's a duck. This is a tax."
Indeed, two Republicans, Senators John Ashcroft of Missouri and Slade Gorton of Washington, also called the proposal a "tax." They were supporting an alternative proposed by Senator Daniel R. Coats, Republican of Indiana, that would have eliminated the charge, ended all direct lending and raised other fees. It was defeated, 9 to 7.
The House Educational and Economic Opportunities Committee plans to meet next Thursday to vote on its version of the plan, which would also eliminate direct lending.
Then the budget committees in each house will package the proposals from the committees that deal with education into the omnibus reconciliation bill. In the House, specific amendments to change that bill will be prohibited, but they will be allowed in the Senate.
The basic Democratic argument, joined briefly by Senator James M. Jeffords, Republican of Vermont, was that cutting spending for education was bad for the nation's future. "You're hanging a dollar sign on the door of every college in America, saying 'No Entry Unless You're Wealthy,' " Mr. Kennedy said.
The Republican response was twofold, first to contend that there was little real pain for students in any of their proposals. Mrs. Kassebaum said her origination fee would cost students at the University of Kansas only $13.26 a year.
And the Republicans argued, as Mr. Coats put it, "The very best thing we could do for students, present and future, is to embark on a course of fiscal responsibility."
On Tuesday, the Democrats will try to reduce the savings to $4.4 billion, all of it coming from lenders and loan-guarantee agencies. The Senate voted for that approach in May, but a House-Senate conference raised the figure to $10.8 billion. Mr. Jeffords has said he will vote "present," so that if all other Republicans stick with Mrs. Kassebaum, her proposal will prevail.

HEADLINE: THE 104TH CONGRESS;
Medicare Prognosis for New York Is Grim

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
With far-reaching cuts in payments to providers, the House Republicans' proposal to redesign Medicare would deepen the financial crisis that New York hospitals are already facing, forcing some institutions to close wards and others to close their doors or eliminate services, particularly in areas that serve the poor and the uninsured, health care officials warned yesterday.
The plan would eliminate or curtail many Medicare payments that subsidize doctor training and that compensate hospitals serving disproportionate numbers of indigent patients -- a move that would be especially painful in New York, which has more academic hospitals and poor residents than most other cities. 
 Health industry analysts estimate that the proposals would cost city hospitals close to $6 billion over the next seven years.
"If these proposals are enacted, they will result in a severe fiscal threat to many hospitals in New York," said Dr. John Rowe, president of the Mount Sinai Medical Center.
Hospitals in the New York metropolitan area, particularly in New York City, are still reeling from drastic budget cuts they have made over the last few years in response to the growth of managed care programs and cuts in Medicaid reimbursments.
In the last year alone, New York hospitals have laid off thousands of employees -- including doctors, nurses, lab technicians and housekeepers -- in the biggest cutback of the local hospital work force in decades.
Hospitals here have been trying to improve their financial health through a number of strategies, including consolidating departments, affiliating with doctors groups, clinics and suburban hospitals to increase their market share, and cutting the time patients stay in the hospital.
But while those and other cost-cutting measures have led to leaner, more solvent hospitals, executives at city hospitals and industry analysts said yesterday that they will be hard-pressed to absorb the latest proposed cuts.
"This is especially critical because of all the other changes going on simultaneously," said James R. Tallon, president of the United Hospital Fund, a philanthropic organization. "New York has a demonstrably higher problem and will be much more devastatingly hit because of the concentration of medical education activity and a huge share of the most needy."
New York hospitals train 15 percent of the nation's doctors and depend heavily on the educational reimbursements from Medicare to cover their salaries.
These young doctors, in turn, provide much of the front-line care in the hospitals at a cheaper rate, making the Medicare educational payments a kind of indirect subsidy to institutions caring for the poor and uninsured.
Half of the roughly 12,000 medical residents in New York hospitals are not United States citizens. These residents work, predominantly, in the less prestigious hospitals -- in the 11 public hospitals run by the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, for example.
Under the new proposals, salaries of doctors who are not United States citizens would no longer be reimbursed by Medicare, leaving many inner-city hospitals here and across the country with huge, unexpected holes in their budgets.
The proposals also call for ending reimbursement for the salaries of residents who have been certified in one area of medicine and are training in subspecialties, like gastroenterology or dermatology. The only subspecialty exempted from this provision would be geriatrics.
In addition to cutting some payments for medical education, the proposal calls for cutting by 22 percent payments for some of the indirect costs of training new doctors, such as extra lab tests that are ordered and the longer hours needed to make up for the slower pace of teaching.
The Republican plan also seeks a 25 percent cut in the disproportionate share adjustment for hospitals, a premium paid to hospitals that care for large numbers of needy and uninsured patients.
To compensate for some of these revenue losses, the plan calls for establishing a new Graduate Medical Education and Teaching Hospitals Trust Funds. But the proposal does not specify how much money would be placed in the trust and exactly how it would operate.
What is more, local hospital executives noted, the plan contains a so-called look-back provision, which means that if the government fails to meet its projected savings, it could retroactively reduce its reimbursement rates and assess hospitals.
"We figure that at best, these cuts will cause a $35 to $40 million annual hole in our budget," said Dr. Spencer Foreman, president of the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. "On top of which, the look-back provides a substantial unknown and a lot of exposure. There's no question, hospitals will suffer."
Already Presbyterian Hospital, one of the city's leading academic hospitals, is actively seeking to merge with another medical center in the city, convinced that it is the only way it can survive government budget cuts and the increased competition spurred by managed care.
"The cut in indirect medical education and the disproportionate share will be a big hit for us, very big," said Harold Hogstrom, the chief financial officer for Presbyterian, where 65 percent of the patients are on Medicaid or Medicare. "We don't want to change the nature of our institution, but there is a real danger in the industry that the quality of education and research and clinical care will diminish if the pace of cuts keep up like this."

HEADLINE: Clinton Acts to Save Los Angeles Clinics

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22

 BODY:
President Clinton today announced a $364 million Federal bailout of the beleaguered Los Angeles public health system, a move that will save one of the largest medical complexes in the country and could enhance Mr. Clinton's chances of winning re-election.
During his 20th Presidential visit to the nation's most politically important state, Mr. Clinton said at a news conference here this morning that last-minute "critical consultations" on Thursday in Washington with California officials had produced a rescue package that would prevent the financial collapse of the huge county care system. The county system mainly serves the poor but has been hard squeezed to provide services in recent years because of soaring costs and major cutbacks in Federal, state and local aid. 
 A county-ordered shutdown in services was to begin in slightly more than a week, on Oct. 1, with the most dramatic closing taking place at the sprawling Los Angeles County-University of Southern California Medical Center, a familiar stage backdrop for millions of fans of televised medical dramas.
Critics of the proposed shutdown have charged that it was grandstanding brinkmanship deliberately designed to win aid concessions. Whatever the case, the concessions were won in timely fashion -- and without all that much resistance from the White House.
"It would have been criminal to allow all those clinics to close," said Mr. Clinton, who on earlier visits to California announced multimillion Federal money packages to help the state deal with military base closings and numerous natural disasters.
Those aid grants, according to political experts, have significantly boosted the President's standing in the state, especially in the Los Angeles area, the biggest population center. In 1992, it was this area that gave Mr. Clinton the edge he needed to carry California and win the Presidency.
In return for the aid package announced today, the county agreed to make its three dozen heavily unionized and bureaucratically bound hospitals and clinics more cost-efficient. Among other things, the county, at Federal insistence, will fully embrace the growing national trend toward greater use of economical outpatient treatment as opposed to high-cost hospitalization, the latter favored by many of the county's medical care managers and many members of the heavily unionized hospital workforce.
"It puts the onus on us to change," said one County Supervisor, Gloria Molina, who added that Mr. Clinton had come to the rescue with a plan that could become "a model for the entire country."
The medical care crisis here reached a crucial juncture earlier this year when county officials added up their budget books for 1995 and found a $1.6 billion deficit, a good third of it caused by rising medical care costs. They decided that one way to help balance the books would be to close most of the county's public hospitals and clinics, which provide free health care to the 2.5 million Los Angeles residents -- out of a total population of 9 million -- who are too poor to afford medical insurance.
Efforts to obtain extra money from the state Government in Sacramento were to no avail. The state itself is strapped for funds because of various strict tax caps and because it is lagging in recovering from the recent national recession.
And in any event, Gov. Pete Wilson, a candidate for the 1996 Republican Presidential nomination, has steadfastly opposed any monetary state bailout of Los Angeles, much as he opposed any monetary state bailout of adjacent, bankrupt Orange County. However, he approved the details of the bailout announced today, pointing out that it would cost California nothing.
Had the shutdown of the county's hospitals and clinics begun on Oct. 1, the expectation was that thereafter private medical facilities or facilities run by nonprofit organizations would begin to pick up the slack, however onerous that burden might turn out to be.
Many social welfare exerts called that shutdown approach too Draconian and characterized it as brinkmanship and a deliberate political squeeze play in a highly sensitive area. As layoff notices began to go out, some hospital workers, many unionized, began conducting "sickouts," with one beginning this morning before the President spoke.
Other critics of the move asked how the rest of the budget gap would be closed, only to be told that a way would be found. Thus far, a few modest cuts and layoffs have been made here and there, but nothing on the scale proposed for the health care system.
In previous years when the county budget got out of balance, the county typically took out short term loans, sometimes putting up public buildings for collateral, a practice that has been sharply criticized.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

CITY: LOS ANGELES, CA, USA (94%);

HEADLINE: Robert G. Dunlop, 86, Executive Who Led Expansion of Sun Oil

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Robert G. Dunlop, a retired chairman of the Sun Company Inc. whose 23-year tenure as president led to a rapid growth of the Philadelphia-based energy company and its expansion overseas, died at the hospital of the University of Pennsylvania on Wednesday. He was 86 and lived in Bryn Mawr, Pa.
The cause was complications from a stroke he suffered last week, a Sun spokesman said. 
 Mr. Dunlop, who was named president of the company in 1947 at the age of 37, was a self-effacing man who often said he was "only a bean counter," referring to his early years with the company where he started as an accountant in 1933. He usually remembered an employee's name after the first meeting and would surprise them by addressing them by their name the next time he met them.
He expanded the company's interests in petroleum refining and marketing by acquiring the Sunray DX Oil Company of Oklahoma in 1968, which brought with it large reserves and production capacity. Sun markets gasoline under the Sunoco brand name.
Born in Boston, Mr. Dunlop graduated with honors with a degree in economics from the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce at the University of Pennsylvania in 1931. After serving as the president of Sun until 1970, he was promoted to chairman and chief executive. He retired in 1974 but continued to serve on the board until 1991.
Mr. Dunlop was elected president of the American Petroleum Institute, the industry trade group, in 1965, and held the post for two years.
He was also closely associated with the Boy Scouts of America. In 1972 he was awarded the Silver Beaver Award for distinguished service to the Boy Scouts, and in 1974 he won the Roger S. Firestone Distinguished Citizen Award from the same group.
He is survived by his wife, Emma; a son, Richard, of Salt Lake City; a daughter, Barbara Hauptfuhrer, of Strafford, Pa., five grandchildren and a great-grandchild.

HEADLINE: Pataki Is Off to Europe, Recalling Roots to Voters at Home

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Sept. 22

 BODY:
For decades, New York politicians have made a tradition of traveling overseas, ostensibly to encourage tourism and trade. But there has often been a less openly acknowledged goal: old-fashioned appeals to ethnic voters.
Today, Gov. George E. Pataki -- a suburban Republican who remains best known for having unseated the state's three-term Italian Governor -- followed firmly in his predecessors' footsteps by embarking on a one-week, privately financed trip to Hungary and Italy. 
 Though the trip has been billed as part trade mission, part sightseeing tour and part search for ancestral roots, it is less officially viewed as a pitch to the Eastern European and Italian immigrants and their children who still dominate New York's electorate.
"For people in New York in particular, you are expected to remember your roots," said Edward I. Koch, who during three terms as Mayor traveled overseas at least 18 times on what he called working vacations. "The mayor is a representative of every racial and ethnic community in the city. And the governor is the same for the state."
Between visits with business leaders and government officials in Budapest and Rome, Mr. Pataki will visit the birthplaces of three of his grandparents: two from villages in eastern Hungary and one from southern Italy. Before now, he never visited any of these places.
"It's going to be just a very moving personal experience," Mr. Pataki said.
But it is likely to be politically useful as well. Italians are the largest ethnic group and the largest ethnic voting bloc in New York State, and Mr. Pataki's visit to his grandmother's birthplace in Reggio Calabria, where he hopes to meet cousins for the first time, is expected to generate warm stories in the Italian and Italian-American press.
"It's good politics," said Assemblyman Dov Hikind, a Democrat of Brooklyn and an ally of the Governor. "It gets a lot of attention in the media in the foreign country and in this country."
Hungarians are much less of an electoral factor here, representing about 2 percent of the state's population, or about 262,000 people. But identifying strongly with his roots will help Mr. Pataki broaden what many political analysts consider the public's narrow view of him: an upper-middle class, Ivy League-educated Republican from the suburbs. In a state whose electorate is still dominated by immigrants and their children, the Governor's trip could appeal to many of them, Hungarian or not.
"For a guy who went to Yale and came from Westchester, to establish immigrant roots in a state that is still tribal in its politics is important," said Gerald Benjamin, a professor of political science at the State University at New Paltz. "It's building out the base. He's trying to make connections to more people."
Mr. Pataki's aides say there is little political calculation behind the trip. "That his grandparents come from these countries, that may help a little," said the State Commissioner of Economic Development, Charles A. Gargano, who is accompanying Mr. Pataki. "But not much."
Mr. Gargano said Mr. Pataki would be addressing groups of corporate leaders and investors in both countries, bringing the message that New York is more business-friendly. "I think it is important that they hear it from the Governor," he said.
Among American states, New York is the largest exporter to Hungary and second largest to Italy. Last year, the state sent $42 million in goods to Hungary and $700 million to Italy -- a relatively small part of the state's total economic output, estimated at $413 billion by the Federal Commerce Department.
Still, many trade analysts seriously doubt whether trips by a governor can affect foreign investment, since most important trade issues, like tariffs, are controlled in Washington.
"Low-level attempts at facilitation like this probably fall in the feel-good category," said Gary Hufbauer, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. Mr. Hufbauer said that if Mr. Pataki truly wanted to spur foreign commerce in New York, he should focus on the state's largest trading partner: Canada.
But, he added, "It doesn't get any political kudos for the Governor to visit the Prime Minister in Ottawa."
Moreover, Hungary is not in much shape to expand its commerce or investments overseas, since it is still struggling to raise capital for its own, budding free-market economy. If any business ties are developed, they are likely to lead to New York money flowing to Hungary, and not vice versa.
Pat Choate, an author and former commissioner of economic development in Tennessee and Oklahoma, said trips by governors can help close deals with individual investors. "But to do broad-based, cold calls -- that says vacation trip to me," he said.
Government watchdog groups have also raised questions about the financing of Mr. Pataki's trip. The Hungarian American Chamber of Commerce of New York and New Jersey, and the Hungarian Government, are paying for the Hungarian part of the trip for the Governor and his group. Italy-Italy magazine and Alitalia, the airline, are helping to pay for the Italian part.
Accompanying Mr. Pataki are his wife, Libby; their eldest son, Theodore; Mr. Pataki's half-Italian mother, Margaret; Mr. Gargano, three aides and two state police officers. The administration has not disclosed the cost of the trip, but hotel and airfare for the group are estimated at more than $30,000. Mr. Pataki's campaign fund is also paying for incidentals, including some meals and transportation costs.
Andrew Greenblatt, executive director of Common Cause, called the trip a "big gift" from business people who might have dealings with the state. "It's not just that they're sending the Governor to inspect a factory," he said. "They're sending his family on a tour of Europe."
Mr. Pataki replied: "I think having the Hungarian American Chamber of Commerce pay for the trip makes perfectly good sense. We could justify it as a government expense, but I wouldn't do that. And I think this is a better way for taxpayers."
The Governor is certainly not doing anything out of the ordinary. His predecessor, Mario M. Cuomo, traveled to Israel, the former Soviet Union and Japan on trips that were billed as either economic development missions or personal pilgrimages. Each time, private interests helped pay.
Similarly, former Mayor David N. Dinkins accepted private donations for trips to Europe and South Africa, and encountered criticism as a result. Though he said he was no fan of Mr. Pataki, Mr. Dinkins defended the Governor's trip.
"If he's making a trip to promote the State of New York, I think that's a good and positive thing," Mr. Dinkins said.

HEADLINE: Comments By Fed Chief Hurt Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of longer-term Treasury securities fell in choppy trading yesterday, as the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, making his twice-a-year report to the Senate Banking Committee, described a rosy economic outlook.
There was some initial buying as a number of market participants interpreted his comments to mean there might still be room for further interest rate cuts somewhere down the road, but then the market pulled back. 
 The price of the 30-year bond fell 12/32 of a percentage point, to 10326/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.58 percent, from 6.55 percent on Thursday, when there was also heavy selling. About the only sector that saw substantial demand was the three-month bill, which outperformed all other maturities, as the rate fell four basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 5.17 percent.
"On the whole, the near-term prospects for the U.S. economy have improved in recent months," Mr. Greenspan said, adding that there was no evidence that relatively high short-term interest rates were slowing growth. Analysts said those comments seemed to suggest that the central bank would not rush to ease interest rates next week at the meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee on Tuesday, but would wait at least until November.
"As for the prospects of an immediate rate cut," said Anthony Chan, chief economist for Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio, "Mr. Greenspan dashed those hopes." But, he added, "Mr. Greenspan's comments on the budget assured financial markets that his main carrot-stick was intact, indicating that the Fed would continue to take fiscal policy into account when formulating policy."
This suggested that the Fed remained open to the possibility of lowering short-term interest rates again in exchange for the passage of a credible multiyear deficit reduction plan, Mr. Chan said.
With the chances for interest cuts on Tuesday now remote, Mr. Chan sees next week's committee meeting as a nonevent. Still, traders were reluctant to make any big moves at the end of the week.
"Perhaps the most important piece of data to be released next week will be Friday's Chicago purchasing managers index," Mr. Chan said, as the market will be looking for a confirmation or refutation of the Philadelphia Fed's robust report.
Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst for Thomson Research, in Portland, Ore., said, looking into the next quarter, that the uptrend in prices "is shifting into a consolidation mode and "looking more negative going into October and early November." She sees "a target price on the long bond going as low as 10821/32 , but at a minimum of 11023/32 ."
Ms. Mesch said that with a resistance price of 11411/32 , the uptrend of the last few months was not likely to continue. The market "shows no evidence that the selling has been shut off," she said.
In the municipal market, a trade group representing bond dealers criticized a proposal by a self-regulatory agency on Thursday to levy a fee on municipal bond trades to pay for that agency's operations.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Is Optimistic On Economy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, today painted an optimistic picture of the economy. His statements suggested to investors that the central bank would not lower interest rates anytime soon.
Indeed, Mr. Greenspan, speaking before the Senate Banking Committee, said there was no evidence that relatively high short-term interest rates were slowing growth. His testimony came just a few days ahead of the Fed's policy-making committee meeting on Tuesday and dashed any remaining hopes in the bond market for a rate cut at that time, dragging down Treasury prices. [Page 51.] 
 "On the whole, the near-term prospects for the U.S. economy have improved in recent months," Mr. Greenspan said, though he warned that the economies of leading trading partners -- meaning Japan and Europe -- could still impede growth in the United States "The inflation picture is looking more favorable than it did in early 1995."
Mr. Greenspan's comments came at the end of a tumuluous week for the dollar, which surged past 104 yen on Tuesday before falling 5 percent, to well below 100 yen. In late New York trading today, the dollar settled at 100.10 yen, up from 99.05 yen on Thursday -- leaving traders saying that at least for now the currency seemed hemmed in.
Some of the dollar's recent weakness can be attributed to the turmoil in European currency markets, which pushed European stock markets down sharply. The mark has surged against other European currencies -- as well as the dollar -- amid mounting uncertainty over Europe's goal of monetary union. [Page 42.]
And investors are leery of buying yen, for fear of another aggressive round of dollar buying by Japan and the United States to support the dollar -- just the fear that monetary authorities in both countries are trying to instill.
But the sharp drop earlier this week has also made investors nervous about bidding up the dollar, especially at a time of continued high trade deficits and uncertainty over whether Congress and the Administration will touch off the much-talked-about "train wreck" over the failure to reach a budget agreement.
A shutdown of the Federal Government, which the Republicans have threatened, would likely scare foreign investors.
As always, Mr. Greenspan went to great lengths today to say very little. He repeatedly sidestepped efforts to draw him into the argument, touched off by House Speaker Newt Gingrich, over the potential ramificiations if Congress refused to raise the national debt limit in an effort to force Mr. Clinton to accept Republican budget-cutting plans.
Mr. Greenspan warned against any conflict that would lead the Government to the brink of default on its debt, a step that he said, dripping with understatement, would have "adverse effects on the economy."
But he declined to say just how adverse, despite suggestions by Democrats that Mr. Gingrich was playing with fire, and could so scare foreign and domestic investors that interest rates in the United States would have to rise to make its bonds more attractive.
The Federal Reserve chairman repeatedly expressed confidence that despite the bickering on Captitol Hill, a budget pact would be reached in the next few months.
"I'm more optimistic at this particular point about actually pulling this off," Mr. Greenspan said. "I have no doubt that the net result of moving the budget into balance will be a more efficient, more productive U.S. economy in the long run."

Japan Buys Dollars
 By Bloomberg Business News
 The dollar edged up against the Japanese yen and the German mark in New York trading yesterday, bolstered by intervention by the Bank of Japan and comments by American Treasury officials.
In Tokyo trading, the Bank of Japan bought between $2.5 billion and $5 billion for yen, traders estimated. Although the Federal Reserve apparently did not join in, "wariness of central bank intervention is supporting the dollar," said Ken Nixon, currency adviser at the Bank of Montreal/Harris Bank in New York.
Later in the day, Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers said the Administration supported a strong dollar. And Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said the Group of Seven leading industrial powers were prepared to cooperate on currency matters.
In New York, the dollar fell as low as 1.4081 marks -- the lowest since Aug. 10 -- before recovering to 1.4247 marks, up from 1.4235 marks. The dollar rose to 100.10 yen from 99.05 yen, and to 1.1471 Swiss francs from 1.1408 Swiss francs. The British pound fell to $1.5685 from $1.5906.

HEADLINE: Capital Spending Plans Increase For 4th Year, U.S. Survey Says

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
American businesses plan to raise spending on plants and equipment by 9.4 percent this year, the fourth yearly increase in capital spending plans.
The Commerce Department said today that a recent survey indicated businesses planned to spend $600.7 billion on new plants and equipment, up from $549 billion in 1994. 
 The survey of 22,500 companies completed earlier this month shows spending increases were planned in every business segment except the services industry. And there, the decline was smaller than first estimated.
The overall capital spending plans are larger than the $592.9 billion projected in an earlier survey last winter, when businesses indicated a 6.6 percent increase. Still, the increase would be smaller than the 12.1 percent increase in outlays in 1994.
Capital spending has not declined since 1991, when the last recession was ending. The strong pace of investments since then has been a major factor driving the economic recovery.
"There are two main reasons for the ongoing investment boom," saidGordon Richards, an economist at the National Association of Manufacturers.
"First, the price of computers is declining, which amounts to a fall in the cost of capital," he explained. "Second, businesses have been trying to restore profit margins -- chronically depressed since the late 1980's -- by raising efficiency and cutting costs."
Manufacturing companies said they planned a 26.1 percent increase in spending, to $181.8 billion, much larger than the 20.2 percent advance in the earlier survey.
Businesses producing durable goods said they planned a 32.2 percent increase, to $100.6 billion. Nondurable-goods producers projected a 19.4 percent advance, to $81.2 billion.
Cold Metal Products Inc., a steel processing company with headquarters in Youngstown, Ohio, is among the industrial companies that plan to expand this year. It recently announced that it would increase the capacity of its Ottawa, Ohio, plant by 40 percent in a bid to gain market share.
"Clearly, the manufacturing segment of the economy is trying to raise productivity by employing more technology and machines," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis.
Although the service industry projected a 1 percent decline in investment, to $117.3 billion, the drop would be less than the 2.6 percent decrease forecast last winter.
But companies in other areas said they planned increased spending: finance, insurance and real estate industry, up 27.7 percent, to $47.1 billion; transportation, up 14.5 percent, to $37 billion; wholesale and retail trade, up 11.1 percent, to $75.7 billion; communications, up 10.4 percent, to $49.3 billion, and utilities, up 10.2 percent, to $41.8 billion.

HEADLINE: Observer;
The Fun Doctor Calls

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
What fun it's been. The Newt Revolution, that was fun. Nobody has been more fun than Newt himself, although Rush has run him a close second. Those bumper stickers saying "Rush Is Right" are fun bumper stickers, and listening to grouchy people phoning their grumps to Rush and to Rush shooting ideas from the hip like a kid with the latest water pistol -- that's been fun.
Bill Clinton, he's been fun. Not as much fun maybe as Newt with his sci-fi vision of the future and his dalliance on the primrose path with Rupert Murdoch. Still, you don't get that many Presidents who spend their whole first term trying to figure out why they wanted to be President in the first place. 
 It's been fun watching Bill try to work it out. Reminds you of the lady in the Gilbert and Sullivan song who "doesn't think she dances, but would rather like to try." Now Bill's working like an ant colony for a second term. Give him another four years, goes the pitch, so he can find out why he wants to be President.
Is that fun? You bet your sweet patootie it's fun. And fun, sweetheart, is what it's all about. It's fun calling these statesmen by their first names. But, hey! -- what's that with the statesmen number? These are guys, not statesmen. Just guys. Great, human, ordinary, plain-as-the-wart-on-your-nose, all-American, mud-between-the-toes -- guys.
Guys are fun, always saying "Let's drink some brewskis" and flicking towels at each other's rumps in the locker room. Guys have nicknames. Bill and Newt are fun names to say. Bob is a fun name, and Phil, and Pete, and Pat.
When you say, "Newt, Bill, Bob, Phil, Pete and Pat," you double your fun the way people used to do by chewing Doublemint gum. Now there's the fun of saying those fun guy names, then there's the fun of knowing they think we wouldn't make them President if we had to say, "Newton, William, Robert, Philip, Peter and Patrick."
It's fun knowing what they think of us -- that we're that kind of saps.
O.K., the fun has been great fun for so long that it's hard to remember it was just one of those things, just one of those crazy things, a trip to Newtsville on Limbaughish zingers, a trip to Billsburg where you meet real people who actually believe that gutting the welfare system is going to:
1. Make ignorant, hopeless, bored, hedonistic teen-agers quit producing illegitimate children;
2. Help millions of uneducated, socially incompetent people find jobs in an economy whose official economic goal is to keep 6 percent of the work force unemployed;
3. Smite all 50 legislatures with such kindliness for the old and the helpless that they will raise state taxes to save these wretches from being kicked out of nursing homes.
4. Make the liver bile flow at the rate of eight pints a day.
Sure this last is a joke, but we are talking fun here. If those guys in Billsburg and Newtsville really believe gutting welfare will result in Points 1, 2 and 3, they'll believe anything.
It would be fun to go on and on about the fun: the fun it's been committing character defamation against the Clintons, the nutty sport of Newt's best-selling literary career, the fun of turning off your brain and lapping up the sound bites.
Now, though, fun time is over, and we are finally seeing where it's been carrying us from the first. Dr. Kevorkian is now waiting in the parlor. He's about to be shown upstairs to finish off the government we have known for 60 years.
Is this what we wanted all along when the fun was so intense? Do we know what we're about to get in its place? Do the designers of the post-government age know what they're doing?
In a matter of days they have been dismantling and redesigning structures that took years to put up. Who knows what is in these hastily sketched plans? The sound-bite artists will fill the air with reassuring bushwah about it, but who really has the vaguest idea what the results will be? Best bet: nobody.
The architects of the new age are not really fun guys. They are hard-eyed white men with the high-rise-Texas view of the world. This holds that the world would be a paradise if government would just drop dead and let business folks do what's best for themselves.
The fun is over. Dr. Kevorkian is with the patient.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 514 words

HEADLINE: Diluting the Quality of Life

 BODY:
The latest state budget makes a tiny change in court procedure that is expected to save the state $1 million. In the process, it threatens New York City's ability to combat littering, urinating on the sidewalk, public drinking and other quality-of-life offenses.
The city's interests have fallen victim to Albany budget cutters before, but seldom has it lost so much for so little. 
 The $1 million amendment relieves the state courts of responsibility for violations of the city's Administrative Code, which prohibits a long list of offenses to urban civility, from fishing off bridges to carrying an assault weapon. Disobeying the code is not a crime, but people fined for violations have always been processed through the criminal courts. The system gave offenders a sobering reminder that the city takes quality-of-life rules seriously.
Not surprisingly, the judges have always wanted to be free of this extra workload, which involves tens of thousands of cases a year. The State Legislature always resisted their pleas. But when Gov. George E. Pataki demanded suggestions for saving money, the Office of Court Administration happily proposed that taking the Administrative Code violations out of criminal court would be an excellent economy move.
The projected saving was only $1 million. Still, the Legislature complied. The unspoken plan was obviously to pass the expense of handling the cases down to the city. But the city has no administrative courts to handle the quality-of-life offenses. As a result, more than 50,000 citations for acts like littering and urinating on sidewalks may become void.
This sort of debacle is not unusual in Albany, and the city's lobbying office seems too weak or disorganized to head off such disasters. The State Legislature has the power to do the city endless mischief, and the Giuliani administration needs to be much more vigilant.
But the more immediate problem is what to do about the city's popular quality-of-life enforcement program. The City Council has moved to upgrade some of the Administrative Code offenses to criminal misdemeanors that can be processed in the courts. It is astonishing to realize that possession of a rifle, sale of a switch-blade and illegal disposal of medical wastes have not previously been crimes in New York City. Now, thanks to last week's Council action, a citizen caught strolling around with an AK-47 or grenade launcher can at least be punished by a whopping 16 days in jail.
The Office of Court Administration says the bans on public drinking and sidewalk urination can be prosecuted under other laws. For instance, it says about 85 percent of the 20,000 public drinking offenders the court sees each year could be charged with disorderly conduct. But it is hard to see how the court is going to save time or money by trading 20,000 simple administrative hearings for 17,000 criminal prosecutions.
Either fewer quality-of-life cases will be prosecuted, or the court will not get any savings. In seeking to pass the buck, the Governor and Legislature have created a no-win muddle.

HEADLINE: Exploiting Young Workers

BYLINE: By Patricia Cohen; Patricia Cohen is the political editor of Rolling Stone magazine.

 BODY:
The debate over raising the minimum wage is still stuck in summer reruns.
Worried that most Americans think of minimum-wage earners as affluent suburban kids saving up for nose rings and Nikes, Democrats insist that these workers are adults, hoping to evoke middle-aged mothers and fathers rather than young people. Yet what supporters of a wage increase should be arguing is that it is precisely because most of the lowest-paid workers are young that the minimum should be raised. 
 "A popular misconception is that the minimum wage is basically paid to teen-agers who flip burgers in their spare time," Senator Paul Wellstone, a Democrat, said recently on the Senate floor, expressing a typical comment. "But less than one in three minimum- wage workers are teen-agers." True enough. Yet more than half of those who earn the lowest wages -- the 4.1 million who earn $4.25 an hour or less -- are under 25; nearly two-thirds are under 30. Those proportions are similar for the 8.5 million or so who earn less than $5.15 an hour and clearly could use the 90-cent rise in the minimum wage proposed by President Clinton.
Many of these young workers are unskilled, with few prospects for higher-paying jobs. Young high school-educated men have been hardest hit; those under 25 earn 27 percent less today than they would have 15 years ago, according to the Economic Policy Institute. High school-educated women earn 17 percent less.
Other young people who are only temporarily in low-paying positions are often saving for college or covering the cost of tuition, room and board and books, which has soared to $19,000 a year on average at private institutions. The average college student works 25 hours a week, earning the minimum wage or close to it. Ken Redd, a research analyst for the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities, says there's no question that 18- to 24-year-olds "are working more than they would otherwise because of costs."
That burden will increase as Republicans chip away at student aid programs. Already, Congress has cut $10 billion from Stafford Loans, the largest program, over the next seven years, affecting five million students each year. On average undergraduates will have to come up with an extra $3,100 and graduate students an extra $9,400 each year if that cut is maintained, according to the Office of Management and Budget.
Smaller student programs are also at risk. House Republicans have cut off all Pell Grants to as many as 360,000 students from families with annual incomes between $20,000 and $30,000. Cuts to the Perkins Loan program would eliminate money for 150,000 students, while reduced Federal aid to State Student Incentive Grants for state scholarship funds would affect an additional 212,000 students. All this means that working students need a living wage more than ever.
Critics of an increase in the minimum wage argue that it would throw some people out of work. But a growing body of research has shown that raising the minimum wage did not increase unemployment in the past.
Reversing the declining prospects of young workers should be a national priority. But even Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who has promised to force a vote before the end of this Congressional session on the President's proposed increase, avoids connecting the dots. The last time he raised the issue on the Senate floor, he and other Democratic supporters barely mentioned that raising the minimum wage would help Americans in their late teens and 20's. Instead, the talk was mostly about the poor -- the constituency the Republicans have demonstrated the least interest in helping.
A Times Mirror poll found that Americans in every age group surveyed overwhelmingly supported raising the minimum wage, but the highest approval numbers -- 81 percent -- came from 18- to 29-year-olds.
The minimum wage is just the latest in a long line of issues in which the interests of young people have been obscured. Medicare and Social Security are perceived as issues of the elderly, but it is young workers who are paying for those programs and who are likely to end up with sharply reduced benefits themselves.
Is it any coincidence that disaffection from the political process among young voters is at an all-time high?

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
The Boss's Last Exit From Bronx

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN 

 BODY:
HEAVY morning rains didn't dampen the pace around 161st Street and River Avenue. A handful of joggers ran in Joe Yancey Park as the owners of tiny tobacco stores and variety shops lifted rickety security gates and elevated trains rumbled overhead.
Presiding like the regal nerve center was Yankee Stadium, the crown jewel of the beleaguered South Bronx. 
 On Thursday the Yankees completed a sweep of Toronto to keep pace with Seattle in a mad chase for a wild-card berth. Virtually one game stands between the Yankees and their first post-season appearance since 1981.
The area around the stadium is bursting with activity, but it is not bristling with the excitement of a chase. The Toronto series was slow. The entire season has been slow.
Only 17,766 tickets were sold for Thursday's game, an average of about 17,300 for the series and less than 24,000 this season.
George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' owner, blames the low numbers on the reluctance of fans to visit the South Bronx.
Earlier this week Steinbrenner, who had already rejected a $500 million package from New York City, escalated his threats to move to New Jersey. Responding to a proposal for a 50,000-seat stadium in the Meadowlands, Steinbrenner said he was excited about the offer.
I was stuck in traffic as details of the New Jersey offer and Steinbrenner's reaction came over the radio. The 155th Street exit off the Major Deegan Expressway was blocked to reroute traffic from the game.
My immediate reaction was that Steinbrenner could take his team -- and his traffic snarls -- to Jersey.
A day later the feelings hardened: I have grown weary of the man's threats. He's like a fickle lover who threatens to leave, to stay, to leave again, to stay again. There comes a point when you open the door and say, "Leave."
Unfortunately, things are not that cut and dried.
The Yankees have been in the Bronx since 1923 and have become a central part of the area's economic structure.
"If the Yankees were to go, the area would fall down; we'd have to close down," said Mike DelPrete, who manages the Stadium Tennis Center. DelPrete's clients come primarily from the Upper West and Upper East Sides of Manhattan. Like Yankees fans, few of his clients come from the immediate area.
"When we tell the parents that we're in the South Bronx, next to Yankee Stadium, they feel safe because there's more activity here because of the Stadium being here," DelPrete said.
The perception that crime and safety are problems at Yankees games is one of the central issues in the Yankees' continuing status in the Bronx.
George Suarez, manager of the McDonald's directly across the street from the Stadium, said he gets plenty of business on game days, but always before the game. "We get a lot of people coming in before, but almost nobody when they go out," he said. "They just want to get out of here."
Steinbrenner encourages the fear. He repeats unsubstantiated, tired concerns about safety and the uneasiness of fans as they come to and from the game.
George Bush had Willie Horton; George Steinbrenner has the South Bronx, whose residents are largely black and Hispanic. In an effort to ring out the best possible deal, Steinbrenner is using urban decay -- not the erosion of his marketing department -- to justify the team's low numbers.
The so-called Boss is playing the race game.
Let him play it in New Jersey.
I'll miss the Yankees, the cool diffuse lights that envelope the stadium at night like a halo; Bob Sheppard's voice floating over the Bronx, Harlem and Washington Heights with word of lineup and pitching changes.
And the stadium does serve as a buffer.
"When a game is going on I feel safe," said Anthony Hilton, a station clerk at the 161st Street elevated subway stop. "When you have games you have more police around. No games, not as many police."
The stadium is a security blanket. But is it worth an entire community being vilified by an expeditious owner?
The Yankees' contract with the city expires in 2002; Steinbrenner wants to make a decision next year.
The team and the community are hopelessly estranged. The symbol of their bond is the stadium, and that's all.
Let's part amicably, and get on with our lives.

HEADLINE: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;
Tough Trade Negotiator To Lead Party in Japan

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Trade Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, whose confrontational personality is well known to United States trade negotiators, was elected leader of Japan's biggest party today, putting him in line to be the next Prime Minister.
As president of the conservative Liberal Democratic Party, Mr. Hashimoto becomes a leading candidate for Prime Minister as speculation persists that the Socialist incumbent, Tomiichi Murayama, will soon step aside. 
 United States officials know the 58-year-old Mr. Hashimoto from his hard-line stance in auto trade talks earlier this year, when he faced down American demands that Japan guarantee American cars and car parts a fixed share of the Japanese market.
Although Mr. Hashimoto says he firmly supports good relations between the United States and Japan, his conservative views occasionally stray into right-wing nationalism, such as his refusal to say outright that World War II was a "war of aggression" by Japan.
In his 1993 book, "Vision of Japan," Mr. Hashimoto wrote that the relationship with the United States, while important, "is not something we must maintain by giving up our sovereignty as a state."
Mr. Hashimoto said today that his first priority would be to revitalize the Japanese economy, still ailing from the collapse of stock and real estate prices in the early 1990's.

HEADLINE: Americans Would Never Trade Cars for Trains;
On the Fast Track

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You're on the right track when you suggest that an investment in Amtrak is in the national interest (editorial, Sept. 16). If proof of the efficiency of rail service is needed, one need only look at two of our greatest economic competitors, Germany and Japan, where fast, dependable trains are an integral part of the economy and are taken for granted. 
 With our Federal Government providing research and development and setting standards, each state could develop a network of high-speed railroads (many states have such plans now) that could be connected in the same manner as the interstate highway system. Since trains can go downtown to downtown, new construction for railroads and stations could help provide the urban development needed in so many of our cities.
 
TED SCHULTE
Lake Forest, Ill., Sept. 18, 1995

LENGTH: 2072 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Carol Burnett Comes Round To Where She Started From

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

 BODY:
IT IS A RAINY SUNDAY MORNING IN early August, and Carol Burnett is fighting a cold. She is gamely attacking a Belgian waffle, popping vitamins C, B and E with calcium and beta carotene and talking about her return to Broadway after 30 years and several lifetimes of laughter.
She is trim and elegant in workout clothes, her surprisingly delicate fingers fondling the flatware. She looks younger than her 62 years and greets a stranger with a big hug and a kiss. But she is tired and bruised from 12-hour rehearsals, including bouts of fencing, and she hides her eyes behind smoky sunglasses even in this summer gloom. 
 She is living in a Boston hotel room, far from the newly built Santa Fe, N.M., home she has occupied for only 10 days. She is risking her neck in Ken Ludwig's latest boisterous physical farce, "Moon Over Buffalo," a fond look back at the world of mid-1950's live theater, which she cut her teeth on even as it was fading.
She doesn't have to do this.
"You know what, I do have to do this," she says in the friendly, matter-of-fact voice that warmed nearly 600 nights on CBS from 1967 to 1978. "Because I think it's very important to keep on trucking, to keep on doing. I don't mean trying to do parts younger than you are. It's not Norma Desmond time. It's doing what you can do, within a believable age range, and having fun. Getting back in the sandbox."
When, in response to some question or other, she bursts into that patented goony, gurgling giggle, you have to believe her. And when, on the stage, the long-suffering wife she plays is moved in the midst of lunacy to sudden, unforced tears of love, so are those people out there in the dark.
In "Buffalo," which opens next Sunday at the Martin Beck Theater after several weeks of previews, Ms. Burnett and her co-star, Philip Bosco, play George and Charlotte Hay, an oversize pair of second-rate Lunts touring the tank towns in repertory productions of "Cyrano de Bergerac" and "Private Lives." When Ronald Colman breaks his leg during the filming of "The Scarlet Pimpernel," the great Frank Capra threatens to descend on Buffalo to cast George in Colman's place. All manner of mistaken identity, marital discord and drunken chaos ensue.
Charlotte is a diva, and dizzy enough, but compared with George, a bibulous, adulterous, hopelessly insecure ham, she's solid and sane. As the play began its out-of-town tryout, that imbalance left Ms. Burnett, who created such madcap madwomen as Nora Desmond, in her television parody of "Sunset Boulevard," playing something like her old straight man, Harvey Korman, to Mr. Bosco's Carol Burnett.
"I knew when I read it that the story is George's in a way," Ms. Burnett said last month at the beginning of the Boston run, before changes were made to beef up her role. "I'm sure that will be, might be, talked about -- or thought about, or whatever. But that's not why I'm in this. I'm in it because I think it's a funny show, and I love the people in it, and I like playing with a better tennis player. It makes my game better."
That a star of Ms. Burnett's age and reputation would return to the New York theater in a vehicle in which she is less than the cynosure is a testament to her restlessness, to the paucity of new commercial plays, to her dissatisfaction with the current corporate climate of network television and to the scarcity of good roles in any medium for women over 40. Two other veteran Broadway stars, Carol Channing and Julie Andrews, are returning in vehicles tailored for them.
Since her CBS variety show went off the air, Ms. Burnett has worked selectively. She won praise for dramatic roles in theatrical films like "A Wedding" (1978) by Robert Altman and television movies like "Friendly Fire" (1979). She has also made comedy and musical specials for television, but two subsequent attempts at a sketch-comedy series in the early 1990's fizzled amid the changing tastes and economics of television comedy. And she has kept her hand in the live theater, whose discipline she never really left, most recently in California at the Long Beach Civic Light Opera in limited runs of "Company" and a Berlin-Gershwin-Porter revue.
"I haven't been away from the stage; I just haven't been in New York," she said. "And I just had such a good time in Long Beach that I said, 'You know, I'd love to do -- I don't care if it's Off Broadway, Off Off Off Broadway, it could be in somebody's living room -- but let's, you know, see.' "
Elizabeth Williams, the producer of "Buffalo," who had worked with Ms. Burnett on a Los Angeles production of A. R. Gurney's "Love Letters," sent her a script last year. "She was very game, and very excited about it and wanting to move forward," Ms. Williams said.
But early in rehearsal, Ms. Burnett's presence swiftly posed a challenge for Mr. Ludwig and the director of "Buffalo," Tom Moore. In the last month, they have frantically rewritten and reshaped the play to add one-liners, deeper characterization and bits of comic business to make Charlotte a more equal foil for George. So much new dialogue was added daily that at one point, a stage manager left a two-foot-high stack of paper in Ms. Burnett's dressing room, with a gag note informing her that it was her latest lines.
"Once Carol was cast, there was going to be that balance problem," Mr. Ludwig said. "I'd always intended it to be a story about the two of them, but as the story evolved, George goes off and gets drunk and does all the things that make him the center of the action, and it was less about both of them than it was about him. We've tried to adjust that balance to show more of what their aspirations have been, and where they're both going."
Ms. Burnett was so concerned that an early performance and her own candid discussion of her role might have left a reporter with adverse impressions that she telephoned just before the Broadway previews to express her delight at the revisions and to assure audiences that they would find plenty of her to laugh at. "There is much more lunacy for both of us," she said.
Snippets of Ms. Burnett's greatest hits do crop up in Charlotte: a baleful 25-second double take, those full-throated yells. But a smidgen of her old "Shirley Dimple" takeoff on Shirley Temple was dropped as unnecessary, and her performance is no waxworks. Still, whatever she does, her fellow actors say, audiences tend to respond to her as if she were the same wacky presence who was beamed into their living rooms 25 years ago.
"They don't see her as an actress; they see her as this great comedienne, and that poses a different set of circumstances over which no one has any control," said Mr. Bosco, a veteran farceur who won a Tony Award for his starring role in Mr. Ludwig's "Lend Me a Tenor" in 1989. "The audience sometimes reacts to her as Carol Burnett, this larger-than-life figure, rather than as an actress doing what she does."
Ms. Burnett is well aware of the limitations of her familiarity. Having made mincemeat of the Billy Wilder classic on her old show, she half-jokingly proposed that she be a substitute in the Los Angeles production of "Sunset Boulevard" during a planned hiatus after Glenn Close left for Broadway.
"I said I would learn that whole part just to play it for three weeks, and the challenge would be to see if and when I could get the audience to stop laughing," she said. "They wouldn't go for it; they were too frightened." Similarly, when she appeared as a presenter at this year's Tony Awards show, the higher-ups, fearful of offending the musical's producers, nixed her notion of entering down John Napier's Gothic staircase on the "Sunset" set.
But she insists that she doesn't feel confined by the public affection. "Confined?" she says. "I'm grateful for anybody that says I really like your work. The difficult thing about being a performer -- and you just have to realize it and go with it -- is that it's not like being an artist or a painter or a writer. Because someone will walk by a painting and say, 'I hate that painting,' or 'I hated that book.' But they say about a performer, 'I hate her.'
"So I'm always pleasantly surprised when somebody might come up and say, 'I really enjoyed your work in such and such,' as opposed to 'I really enjoy you.' I mean, I'm flattered, but the flip side of that is 'I hate you.' "
Hardly anyone seems to hate Ms. Burnett. In a world known for temperament and tantrums, she stands out. Mr. Bosco praises her as "the loveliest star one can imagine; no pretensions, very down to earth, very professional, works like the dickens, always prepared." Mr. Moore, the director, said: "I've worked with a lot of stars, and for the most part, it's not my favorite thing, simply because one has to spend so much time thinking about what one says, and you don't have to do that with her. It's an enormous gift."
 MS. BURNETT IS USED to looking out for other people's feelings, and has been for a long time. She grew up the daughter of mostly absentee alcoholic parents: a mother who dreamed of writing for the fan magazines and a father who was a door-to-door salesman when he was able. She was raised in a one-room flat in Hollywood by an eccentric grandmother, the "Nanny" for whom she began tugging her ear in greeting. Hers is a classic stage-struck story: $50 from an anonymous angel to pay her first semester tuition at U.C.L.A., where she fell in love with performing; a $1,000 loan to finance her first foray to New York from a sponsor who insisted that she keep his identity secret.
She burst onto network television three times in one week in 1957, performing a nightclub comedy song, "I Made a Fool of Myself Over John Foster Dulles," a heartsick paean to the pickle-pussed Secretary of State. Two years later, she fulfilled her dream of acting in a George Abbott show, making a successful Broadway debut as Winnifred the Woebegone, the "terribly timid and horribly shy" heroine of "Once Upon a Mattress," Mary Rodgers's musical version of "The Princess and the Pea." (In 1964, she was to be a hit in another Abbott show, "Fade Out -- Fade In," although that success was shadowed by a feud she had with the show's producers.) Soon, she had a regular gig on "The Garry Moore Show," and the rest is history.
The world -- and comedy -- has changed since then, and she lets out a long hoot when asked if any young performer today could make a splash singing "I Made a Fool of Myself Over Warren Christopher." Does she still laugh at what America laughs at, and what does it laugh at, anyway?
"I don't know," she says. "I laugh at what I laugh at, and you know, if you get 30 percent of the audience laughing, you're successful."
Her offstage life has had its share of tears. There were two divorces, the second from the television producer Joe Hamilton, her husband of 21 years and the father of her three daughters, Carrie, Jody and Erin. Their eldest child, Carrie, had a well-publicized struggle with drugs in high school but put it behind her a dozen years ago. Mr. Hamilton died in 1991, and Ms. Burnett has been on her own since 1984. In recent years, she told interviewers she was content to travel solo, but now she says she's looking.
"I see somebody coming along, and I don't know who," she said. "You can have a family, but they have their life. And you can have a family in the theater, and that lasts a certain amount of time and will always mean something to you as a wonderful period in your life that can never happen again. However, there is something very important about being numero uno to somebody else and I would like that, so I'm sending out the pheromones."
"I don't mind if he's younger," adds Ms. Burnett, whose grandmother's boyfriend when she died at 81 was a 40-year-old jazz musician from Redondo Beach. "Because anybody older, usually, with the exception of people in this business, are curmudgeons, or they're chauvinists."
Is she nervous about returning to the town where she made her dream come true? "I want to take the George Abbott approach," she says. "I've done the best I can, now go home and get some sleep. It's no longer in my hands. I've done my work, and what somebody else thinks about it is certainly their privilege."
"Nothing's scary about it," she adds. "It's just getting out of your own way and not worrying it. Just do it. As my grandmother used to say, 'Leave it lay where Jesus flung it.' "
