HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE;
Remodeling New York For the Bourgeoisie

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
THE RESTORATION OF BRYANT PARK, completed in 1992, is one of the nicest things New York City has done for itself in a long time. And the park's inviting new restaurant, designed by Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer, is a fine place from which to savor the view. With its arcadian, trellised facade, accented by the Mediterranean resort chic of white canvas umbrellas, the restaurant offers a perch from which to enjoy the trees, grass and fountains, the surrounding cityscape and, above all, the cheering prospect of people enjoying a public space without fear that something awful is going to happen. No wonder the restaurant, which opened for business last spring, has been hailed as an urban miracle.
The true miracle, perhaps, is that the restoration has recaptured not only a place but also a time, a period before the park fell into disrepair. When the city was prosperous enough to create parks and New Yorkers were not afraid to use them. And yet the sensation is not purely one of nostalgia, for the restoration and the restaurant are also oddly representative of the present era in the city's history. Though Bryant Park resembles an oasis, its revival is not an exception. It is of a piece with many other projects that also seek to reinscribe secure middle-class values within the urban center. 
 They range in scale from large-scale residential enclaves like Queens West and Riverside South, both loosely modeled after Battery Park City, to the Starbucks-style cafes that have sprouted all over town. Across the city, Business Improvement Districts have been devising design guidelines, as well as providing security and sanitation, once provided by the public sector. In the city's rusting industrial districts, new zoning proposals would encourage the rise of suburban-type "superstores," while chain emporiums like Bed, Bath and Beyond have invaded the city's heart.
The transformation of 42d Street into a family entertainment center; the proliferation of theme restaurants on 57th Street; the renovation of Penn Station and Grand Central Terminal into upscale shopping malls, with trains attached: there's no sweeping master plan coordinating these projects. If anything, they signify the capitulation of the public planning process to private enterprise. That's one reason it's not easy to grasp what these projects portend. Taken individually -- a park here, a chain store there -- the projects are of limited significance. Their meaning arises from the aggregation.
And it's a perplexing meaning, because it contradicts the narrative that has ruled the city throughout much of this century: the departure of the middle class and the city's polarization into extremes of rich and poor. These new urban projects fall between those extremes: too accessible and affordable to hold adequate snob appeal for the rich but beyond the reach of the lower economic echelons, they are pitched to those in the middle. Not the lower middle, not even the middle middle, but white-collar professionals. Bed, Bath and Beyond is not, after all, Porthault, and Starbucks is not Petrossian. Perhaps, in honor of the increasing influence of Business Improvement Districts, we ought to call this new city Business Class.
It is not a new development, nor is it unique to New York. Many older American cities have sought to reverse their economic decline by fostering a kind of hybrid urban-suburban culture, an ethos that fuses suburban security and standardization with urban congestion and pizazz. Festival marketplaces, like those developed by the Rouse Corporation in the 1970's, were among the first manifestations of this genre. The gentrification of old brownstone neighborhoods, the conversion of lofts from manufacturing to residential use, the rise of the gay subculture as a stable force in the urban economy: these, too, have contributed to the impression of an urban revival.
If that image has become more conspicuous in the past few years, that is partly because the extremities of the preceding decade -- the glitz development of the 1980's, the homelessness of the early 1990's -- have receded from the foreground of urban consciousness.
Is that a good thing? Earlier this year, when employees of programs intended to aid homeless people in the Grand Central business district were accused of assaulting them instead, it became apparent that there is something misleading, or at least incomplete, about the Business Class image. Suddenly the difference between a genteel gated suburban community and Business Improvement Districts did not seem so profound. If anything, the Business Improvement District looked more sinister because its gates were invisible. While these districts preserve the city's traditional image as a place of social accessibility, image and reality no longer coincide. Rich and poor are still polarized, but the gap between them is less conspicuous.
It's hard not to be of two minds about this development. On the one hand, those who care about the city's future can only welcome the social and economic stability that a middle class provides. Even if what we're seeing now is in large part image, that isn't necessarily a bad thing. Images can sometimes engender reality: a burnished urban image is far more likely than a tarnished one to attract and maintain businesses, tourism and other forces pivotal to the city's economic well-being.
Even the most favorable trend, however, has its price, and the cost of the Business Class city needs to be much more talked about. There's a moral authority to the city's openness, for example, a democratic interplay between freedom and equality that has long been central to New York's identity. This stands to be eroded if the urban center is remade into a fortress. Of course, moral authority isn't worth much if there is no city left to embody it. But without that authority, what is the difference between a city and a mall?
 POVERTY, RACIAL Prejudice, environmental abuse: a lot of critical issues are dimly concealed by the veneer of middle-class affluence. Compared to them, it may seem the most trivial of pursuits to talk about the look of the veneer itself: about design, about taste, about art. And yet, it's precisely because the veneer has the potential to deceive that talking about it in visual terms takes on social significance. What lies beneath the veneer is significant, but so is the veneer itself. Does it reflect who we are?
The old Barnes & Noble sale annex on lower Fifth Avenue had orange industrial carpet over floorboards that creaked and it felt like a firetrap. The new Barnes & Noble store over on Avenue of the Americas has lush green carpet, classical music noodling softly in the background and a cafe perched on a balcony. It's so pleasant that you want to linger for hours.
It is pleasant to go into those Starbucks-style coffee bars; the coffee is good and the atmosphere is pleasant. Shopping at the World Financial Center in Battery Park City is pleasant. It is particularly pleasant to see those depressing bunion ads on the subways giving way to bold designs boosting upscale products.
When pleasantness begins to pall, one can go in for excitement. The new Chelsea Piers are exciting! The plunging two-story escalator at Sony's Lincoln Square multiplex is exciting! The interior David Rockwell has designed the "Official" All Star Cafe, a sports-theme dining and restaurant going up in Times Square, will be very exciting! Pleasant. Exciting! Pleasant. Exciting! Is this architecture? Or an experiment in mass Pavlovian response? Design? Or a drug?
"Middle class" is often taken as a synonym for the safe, the stodgy, the mediocre. But being middle class in New York is supposed to mean being culturally aware. Yes, you get some material rewards: a decent place to live, nice clothes, a tasty dinner. But you also keep up with movies, painting, theater. You read a book. If Mark Morris or Laurie Anderson is appearing, you try to get in. You care about what that new curator at the Whitney is going to make of the opportunity. Even if you do not take an active interest in these things, you still have the reassuring knowledge that you're living in a place where almost any cultural appetite can be satisfied.
But if your appetite is for contemporary architecture, you're out of luck. If you go to Paris, London, Barcelona, Los Angeles, Tokyo and many other cities, there's usually a new building that you have to see, or you will die. You may hate it, but your life depends on it. But when visitors from abroad come here, what do you show them? There's the skyline, of course, and the street gridiron, two of the greatest architectural spectacles of all time. But when it comes to recent buildings of stature, where do you look?
A few weeks ago I was out walking with the fashion designer Isaac Mizrahi, and at one point we strolled past the Millennium, the new luxury high rise on the Upper West Side. I like the building and was planning to write something favorable about it. But Mizrahi said, "Well, you'll have to tell me what you like about this. Because to me, it's just another eyesore. Maybe a slightly better eyesore."
I wanted to respond, "Well, how would you feel if someone took a look at one of your dresses and said, 'Ugh, another rag on a hook'?" But I had to admit, the man had a point. It's been some time since people could look up and see a building with something fresh or startling to say about the contemporary city and the creativity that drives it.
Thirty years ago, the cityscape found room for works by Mies van der Rohe, Wallace Harrison, Eero Saarinen, Marcel Breuer, Frank Lloyd Wright, Walter Gropius and Gordon Bunshaft. Not all of their buildings were great; some were terrible. But what they contributed was much more than a handful of potential future landmarks. Even the worst of their projects, like the Pan Am Building, helped create a picture of the city as an open-ended, ongoing project, a place that recognized the power of architecture to symbolize a city's willingness to respond to change with fresh ideas. That symbolism went far toward securing New York's reputation as a global cultural center in the postwar decades.
That's what's missing from this emerging picture of a Business Class New York: some show of public awareness that the city remains a dynamic experiment. Yes, we love to shop, and we deserve a comfortable refuge from urban turmoil. But we're also a city that historically recognizes the difference between creating and consuming. Where are the buildings strong enough to carry that tradition forward?
The irony is that the general level of architectural design in New York is higher than it has been in a generation. The firms that garner many of the most prominent commissions -- offices like James Stewart Polshek & Partners, Beyer Blinder Belle, Fox & Fowle, Alexander Cooper & Associates -- do superior work. Their sensitive, urbane designs represent an enormous advance over the days when architects approached a building site as an island unto itself. But it is Business Class architecture, not world-class architecture. It seldom risks greatness.
It should be a source of civic pride that some of the world's most celebrated architects live and work in Manhattan and a matter of shame that many of the most gifted seldom build here. And their few New York projects are distant from the center. Richard Meier hasn't built in New York for 20 years -- his entire mature career to date -- and his last building was in the Bronx. Rafael Vinoly, designer of the most important public building now in construction in Tokyo, built an excellent gymnasium last year, in the Bronx. Peter Eisenman built a little fire station 10 years ago in Brooklyn. I'm not a great fan of the skyscraper Gwathmey Siegel built on Broadway at West 48th Street, but I respect it. It's architecture, and it's centrally located.
 SITE, THE FIRM THAT, ALONG with Frank Gehry, won this year's Chrysler Design Awards, has built nothing here except interiors. Ditto Emilio Ambasz. Michael Graves has designed a shop. John Hejduk has renovated one building. Diana Agrest and Mario Gandelsonas, active in projects from Des Moines to China, have designed, I believe, a townhouse. Aldo Rossi, who has maintained a New York studio for the past decade, has built nothing here. Arata Isozaki, who also maintains a local office, has designed a discotheque and has collaborated with James Stewart Polshek on the Brooklyn Museum expansion.
Among the younger generation -- arguably the most highly educated in history -- it's even worse. While their contemporaries in Los Angeles have built enough to be called the Santa Monica School, Steven Holl, Tod Williams and Billie Tsien, Henry Smith-Miller and Laurie Hawkinson, Hariri & Hariri, have been confined locally to interior renovations.
Then there is the long list of world-class architects whose work one might expect to see in a city that prides itself on being a cultural capital; to name a few: Tadao Ando, Renzo Piano, Frank Gehry, Rem Koolhaas, Richard Rogers, Rafael Moneo, Toyo Ito, Jean Nouvel, Antoine Predock, Zaha Hadid.
Of course, cities have more important things to do than collect trophy buildings by famous designers. And architecture encompasses important things besides esthetics. But it's not as if New York were setting new standards in environmentally or socially responsible design, either. And since we are still putting up buildings, and architects are still designing, why can't at least a few of them be alert to the moment we live in?
Some people might prefer architecture to remain confined to consenting adults in the privacy of their converted lofts. The idea has taken hold that architects are to be regarded as rampaging egos, user-unfriendly, contemptuous of the city and its traditions. Though there may be some truth to this, there is also something profoundly anti-urban about making New York endlessly atone for excesses committed by modern architects in Jane Jacobs's day. Most architects have learned their lesson since then. Some have a lot to teach.

PUB-DATE: September 24, 1995

SECTION: Section 2; Page 4; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1678 words

HEADLINE: SUNDAY VIEW;
90's Obsession Finds a Home in Old Forms

BYLINE: By Margo Jefferson

 BODY:
TRAGEDY Tomorrow, comedy tonight, said Stephen Sondheim, and would that this were true outside the confines of a theater. For most of us, life is melodrama tonight and comedy tomorrow. The wit (and the will) to make fun of our grief is always -- minimally -- a day away.
In "The Food Chain," by Nicky Silver, which is playing at the Westside Theater, melodrama and comedy nearly devour each other. "I'm telling everyone to see this play," said a French friend. "It's like a Feydeau farce." And he's right. 
 In those turn-of-the-century French romps, husbands and wives coupled, uncoupled and cross-coupled in each other's drawing rooms, bedrooms and bachelor flats with mathematically efficient panache. Here in America, almost a full turn of the century later, solitary men and women couple, uncouple and cross-couple with noisy desperation, talking about themselves the whole time.
It isn't really dialogue. Instead, they're hurling monologues at one another: laments, rants and cutting diagnoses of their mothers, fathers and once-and-future lovers; the looks and talent they have or wish they had; their most humiliating moments, in high school or in the SoHo restaurant where they ate alone last night and had to endure the waiter's asking "Are you alone?" in a tone of insolent familiarity.
Amanda (played with high-strung hauteur by Hope Davis) is a rich, thin and conspicuously cultivated poet who, as the play begins, is pacing the floor of her conspicuously dreary New York apartment because her husband has been missing for two of the three weeks they have been married. (The furniture is castoff modern; the color scheme is green and beige with touches of pink, yellow and black.) She picks up the phone and finds herself calling a crisis hot line; soon she is explicating herself to Bea (Phyllis Newman), a relentlessly earthy and practical Jewish widow and mother who once ran a needlepoint store but who now, thanks to her crisis training, does all she can to run the lives of unhappy strangers.
The stage revolves, displaying a lavender bachelor flat with gym equipment in one corner and a large photograph of a perfectly developed male torso dominating the wall behind a bed. Serge (Patrick Fabian), with a body almost as perfect as the one in the photo, sits on the bed listening to headphones, lost in a Mick Jagger reverie, waiting for his new lover to call.
He is interrupted by a knock on the door. "Let me in or I'll kill myself," a voice calls out cheerily. And in bursts Otto (Tom McGowan), the ex-lover from hell, who is fat, funny, foul-mouthed, fast-talking and furious at everything and everybody. He bounces around the apartment wolfing down food and spewing out insults. You may be a model, he reminds Serge, but you're only a runway model: "You're not good-looking enough to be in print." His running gag is "Do you think you could love me if . . .," followed by some improbable condition and finished off with an insult. ("I tattooed your name on my rear end, and now I sit on you all the time.")
The stage revolves again, back to Amanda's apartment, but I will say no more: farce depends on a series of improbable but airtight coincidences and mishaps that link each character (not least the absentee husband and the absent lover) into what Mr. Silver calls the food chain and what Aretha Franklin used to call a chain of fools. "Where's the justice?" asks Ms. Newman's perfectly pitched Bea, the deus ex machina in the guise of meddling mother. Then, uttering a short expletive, she shrugs off justice and settles for comic symmetry.
In Old World farce (not just the light-hearted Feydeau sort but even a radically darkened, complicated one like Jean Cocteau's "Indiscretions"), the plot -- the meetings and schemes, the self-assured calculations -- ruled the emotions. The closed structures that people lived by were social first; the psychological was a byproduct. In this New World farce, emotions (obsessions, really) dictate plot. The maniacal, oddly logical structures that rule us are our own psyches: our needs, traumas, neuroses; our compensations and cover-ups. It's the stuff of melodrama, all right (inner lives usually are). And when private melodramas meet, they explode into farce.
The formal constraints of farce (the fast tempo, the double-dealing plot twists, the artificial symmetries) are good for Mr. Silver, at least for now. His prose strives to be witty, analytic and rhetorically astute at all costs. The price (I am thinking of his previous play "Raised in Captivity") can be emotional incoherence: his people's strenuously expressive lines, combined with their obtuse, even brutish actions, can make you wonder if they aren't just a device -- if he doesn't really want to push them aside, take the stage himself and hold us captive with a series of brilliantly written, artfully autobiographical stories and monologues.
Mr. Silver does still have fits of overwriting and underediting. (When one theatergoer thinks he heard Amanda's tirade about women's handbags in a Christopher Durang play and another thinks she heard it on the Comedy Central cable channel, attention must be paid.) But I felt I was watching a writer find the form that best suits his obsessions, aided by his director, Robert Falls, and by his physically adept, emotionally alert actors. How right George Bernard Shaw was when he called laughter "the natural recognition of destruction, confusion and ruin."
 
'The Island of Lost Shoes'
 That being said, let's consider the kind of divine comedy that outwits destruction, confusion and ruin by inventing its opposite: a world that is half Utopian (perfect order) and half Arcadian (perfect romance). No form is better suited to this than a musical comedy: being able to stop the action with a song or dance is as close to omnipotence as anybody is likely to get. And the more artifice the better: the costumes should be brazenly fake, and glittering; the virtuosity should show and not hide behind naturalism. Everyone has a second self, the alter ego or the imaginary companion from childhood, now onstage where it belongs, performing like a trouper.
Bloolips is a five-man troupe of British drag queens. They sing (Ray Dobbins created the pastiche of clever songs), they dance, they act, they clown and, because they're in drag (English music hall has a venerable drag tradition), they do on the stage what we do in our dreams, which is to play whatever part we need to, in violation of sexual, social or intellectual unities. (Yes, you were Dostoyevsky in your dream. But for reasons that remain unclear, you seemed to be Burt Reynolds as well.)
"The Island of Lost Shoes" is the Bloolips show that is playing at P.S. 122 through tonight (can't they stay longer?), and trying to describe what goes on in it is like trying to describe a dream. Puns and other wordplay abound. Moods and costumes change with dazzling frequency. Times are hard in London and the girls of Bloolips -- especially the leading lady, Bette Bourne, in her billowing bronze top, with bronze-feathered hat and red mules -- are feeling blue. Bette is old ("past the four-dozen mark"), she drinks, she's unemployed at the moment and her sexual charms are faltering.
Let's take a vacation, cry her loyal friends Bella Bechstein, Naughty Nickers, Lavinia Co-op and Harmony. Of course, this is code for that old musical rallying cry, "Let's put on a show!" No sooner are they en route to Greece than one of those utterly benign plane crashes ("We're losing attitude -- I mean altitude," cries Bette) leaves them stranded on what could be the Island of Lost Souls but turns out to be the Island of Lost Shoes. They're stranded in a consumer's Bali Hai, "where you do as you please, and where shoes grow on trees"; where you can go hunting and gathering for clothes each day because the habitat includes steamer trunks filled with frocks.
How to tell of the wonders of the island? Like all fantasy isles, it has a resident monster, an 8-foot-tall transvestite on stilts (played by Lavinia), who looks like a ravaged Neptune until she is pacified with offerings of makeup. Then she turns herself into a haunting blonde in gold, who moves like an ethereal Sally Rand and delivers an exquisitely ghoulish Actors Studio monologue (with "Clair de Lune" playing on an organ) about the perilous pleasures of being Marilyn Monroe.
As for the pleasures of show business, they're all here. Not just in the array of costumes Bloolips wears (maribou trim, brooches and chokers, fringed and beaded dresses, brazen pink and black checks, negligees, picture hats and pith helmets with veils), but also in the array of styles they pirate, parody and embody.
There's the old music-hall shuffle, Jolson-style, that accompanies the raucous "What Did Robinson Crusoe Do With Friday on a Saturday Night?" There are the diligently vivacious, overdressed Busby Berkeley tap numbers ("We're in the Money" done with credit cards instead of gold coins). When Bette wants to emote, she declaims "King Lear" very nicely. And at one point she steps forward to apologize to us for what she calls "the shoddy quality" of a certain gag. We live and work on so little, she explains in a throbbing voice, "gathering puns by day, stitching together sketches by night." "Lord, I'se a-weary, I'se a-weary," she concludes, and the swooping tremolo of the drawing-room poetess gives way to the plantation pieties of a minstrel in blackface.
Musicals season their plots with romance, but they can do without it. What they can't do without is the romance that blossoms between the performers and the audience. Bloolips courts and teases us wonderfully. Bella Bechstein, Naughty Nickers and Harmony are good supporting players. Lavinia Co-op is a wonderfully eccentric comedian and mime. And Bette Bourne? Ms. Bourne is a great performer.
 THE FOOD CHAIN: Contemporary men and women couple and uncouple with noisy desperation.
 THE ISLAND OF LOST SHOES: Drag queens doing on stage what most people do in their dreams.

HEADLINE: Winning Owners Over to the Landmarking System

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
BUYERS have begun moving into nine formerly derelict houses in the Bronx that have been restored with city financing under the eye of the Landmarks Preservation Commission to something like their original glory.
The buyers are presumably pleased, and so are the supporters of the Longwood Historic District, in which these buildings on Hewitt Place and Beck, Kelly and Dawson Streets are now handsome architectural specimens. 
 "To see the first families move into these brownstones after 15 years of effort gives us quite a sense of accomplishment," said the Rev. John W. Redic 2d, chairman of the Longwood Historic District Community Association. "We are just tickled to death."
Less tickled are the three small contractors who were responsible for the work. They had no easy time satisfying the Landmarks Commission's supervisors with the quality of their efforts. Which leads to the question, what level of excellence does restoration work have to reach to pass muster? Are the standards reasonable?
Perhaps the answers will always be subjective, but indirectly, at least, the issue is addressed in a report issued last May by the Citizens Housing and Planning Council of New York, a civic organization that deals with housing and development issues. The report is called "Landmarks Preservation in New York City: An Affirmative Approach." It was prepared by a committee headed by William R. Ginsberg, a former Parks commissioner, and it has the tone of a friend and supporter offering suggestions. The J.M. Kaplan Fund financed the study.
Its underlying assumption is that to become a success as a tool for historic preservation in New York City, the Landmarks system should encourage confidence, not fear, in property owners. And as landmark designation has turned toward low- and moderate-income areas of the city, the report says, the need to confront the cost implications of maintaining landmark structures has become more acute.
Negative attitudes among owners toward landmarking arise, the report says, from "exacting maintenance and repair standards and the time, cost and uncertainty associated with navigating a rigorous regulatory process."
On the question of standards, the report favors the application of principles established in the United States Department of the Interior's "Standards for Historic Rehabilitation." They are guidelines on methods and materials, to be applied "in a reasonable manner, taking into consideration economic and technical feasibility."
One recommendation of the council is that owners be allowed to present cost information to the Landmarks Commission. Under the policy that long prevailed, applicants could not inform the commission about the cost of using original materials or possible substitutes. The reasoning was that the law barred commissioners from making decisions on economic grounds. That policy has been dropped by the current chairwoman, Jennifer J. Raab. Doing so has given the commission greater flexibility to work with owners to fashion acceptable solutions to preservation problems, she said.
The planning council has much to say on tax policy: Stop overassessing, and hence overtaxing, landmarked properties with unrestored buildings, it advises. One suggested way to do this would be to tax only the landmarked structure, and not the land beneath, particularly when the unredeveloped structure is in a high-density, high-value area. Another approach is to make the landmark status of a property clear on Finance Department records, which may prompt lower assessments on buildings for which designation is detrimental to resale value.
The report notes that small residential buildings and low-density commercial buildings in historic districts, or very small landmarks in high-density zones, may well be overassessed under current practices.
Another recommendation is to make all landmarked properties eligible for the J-51 program, which frees older residential property for many years from most of the taxes attributable to the rehabilitation work. Currently, properties south of 110th Street in Manhattan that have an assessed value of $38,000 or more per apartment are ineligible for J-51 benefits.
The council also advises that the panoply of city loans and grants for lower-income housing should be made available to landmarked or historic-district properties. Some of those incentives, now either unavailable or available only on a restricted basis in most of Manhattan, should be expanded to include certain excluded Manhattan areas, the report advises.
BUT whatever happens at the policy level, there may still be problems at the construction site. Contractors without long experience in landmarks work may be in for a rude awakening.
The turn-of-the-century houses in the Longwood Historic District were in the city's tax-foreclosed housing inventory for years. Most have stoops, double doors of framed glass, bay windows and decorative brownstone trim around windows and doors. Those on Hewitt Place are part of a strip of houses with wooden porches, galvanized shingles on the roof and a metal cornice.
"All three of the contractors had a great deal of difficulty meeting the Landmarks standards," said Aaron Lewit, director of construction for the Enterprise Foundation, a nonprofit producer of low-income housing, who monitored the job on behalf of the city. "All three had a lot to do over after they had done it once." The Community Preservation Corporation, a bank consortium that supports moderate-income housing, financed the project and helped select contractors.
At one point, the Landmarks Commission's inspector declined to approve pointing work on the side facade of a Dawson Street house on the ground that the mortar was too wide in the joints between bricks. In another case, the contractor on Hewitt Place was obliged to refabricate an odd-sized cellar window that he had had custom made to the preservation architect's standard. The first window turned out to be too small when it arrived. The contractor wanted to correct matters with wood trim.
On Kelly Street the contractor had to redo much of the masonry work on the front stoop. On another occasion, on Dawson Street, a change order obliged a contractor to replace the rear portion of a roof with new slate, although it is invisible from the street. The same contractor said he had to wait out a whole winter to do the brick pointing on Dawson Street because it took so long to select the color. Forty color samples were prepared for selection, he said.
The Landmarks Commission provided $12,500 a house under its facade improvement program, or $112,500, for the Longwood work. When the contractors "costed out" the job based on the specifications from the preservation architect, Judith Saltzman, the anticipated cost came to $277,000. A larger subsidy from the Department of Housing Preservation and Development made up the difference.
But the need to redo completed work caused the restoration to be far more costly to contractors than the cost figures imply. In construction, profitability depends not only upon staying within budget but also upon completing on time.
Four buildings, on Hewitt Place and Dawson Street, were ready for occupancy six months before the Landmarks Commission would permit the issuance of even a temporary certificate of occupancy. The five other buildings, on Kelly and Beck Streets, had no sign-off either, but the contractor had other construction-related problems.
The Kelly Street buildings are now ready to be occupied, Mr. Lewit said, but the contractor has had to leave $30,000 in escrow pending a Landmarks sign-off.
The three contractors were J.H. Loewy of Queens, L&L Construction of Manhattan, and Brender-Hecht Associates of Brooklyn.
All nine houses have been sold, the two two-families at $110,000, the five three-families at $125,000 and the two four-families at $150,000. The housing agency provided $1.23 million for the job, about $45,500 per apartment. Four houses are occupied and the rest should be by mid-October, the Enterprise Foundation said.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Contingency Auditors and Leases;
Tenants Using Specialists to Check Up on Landlords

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
ALAN J. POMERANTZ, the real-estate specialist at the law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges, has a client who wants to renegotiate his lease. Mr. Pomerantz hired a lease auditor to scour the lease and the rent bills for discrepancies.
While the tenant would, of course, welcome a refund, money is not the audit's raison d'etre. "The more we find, the more leverage we have with the landlord," Mr. Pomerantz said. "And if the problems affect other tenants, he has even more incentive to settle with us before our claim becomes public." 
 Landlords had best get used to such stories. Lease audits are increasing in frequency, scope and acrimony.
The current crop of auditors do not just check whether bills conform to the lease. They challenge the way rentable space is calculated and common-area charges assessed. They question whether the landlord's method of charging for electricity constitutes illegal "reselling" of power rather than distribution of same. They charge that landlords overpay for cleaning services and building managers.
Tenants rarely discuss their audits, and auditors insist they are simply protecting tenants' rights. But some landlords and lawyers say something more insidious is going on. They say too many auditors are charging on a contingency basis -- no payment up front, but a big chunk of savings that result -- and thus are motivated to pick apart all but the most precisely worded lease clauses.
"To the landlords, they come across as bounty hunters," said Lawrence F. Reilly, a real estate partner at the Morristown, N.J., law firm Pitney, Hardin, Kipp & Szuch.
"It's like they throw everything they can find against a wall, and see what will stick," said Anthony E. Malkin, president of W&M Properties, which is undergoing a nasty audit battle at a building in Stamford, Conn.
Landlords and management firms readily trot out examples. Bruce Mosler, vice chairman of the Galbreath Company, says one auditor recently questioned the amount that Galbreath was paying in taxes and service fees at one building, not the formula it applied to apportion those costs.
"The tenant wanted to break its lease and figured we'd settle," Mr. Mosler said. "We told them to take a hike."
The Durst Organization is fighting with a major tenant whose contingency auditor spotted fuzzy lease language regarding rent escalations. According to Douglas Durst, when the lease was negotiated 15 years ago, both sides agreed that the rent would go up by 4 cents a square foot for every one percent increase in the porter's wage. The auditor construed the lease to mean the rent would go up a tiny fraction of a cent.
"They are telling us that we agreed to a $200 annual increase," said Mr. Durst. "An accounting firm wouldn't do this."
The contingency auditors counter that tenants hire them expressly because they scrutinize leases closely and will chase longshots. They say that tenants who employ hourly auditors find it unaffordable to pursue small claims. They defend the hefty percentages they charge by noting that they can go through a dozen leases before they find an overcharge.
And they say landlords look for lease loopholes, too. They cite landlords who dismiss their property management agency and then charge double in fees to manage the property themselves; landlords who characterize a new cooling tower as an operating expense, which can be passed along to tenants, rather than a capital expense, which cannot; landlords who get around leases that forbid them from passing along promotional costs by inviting their staff to parties for brokers, and calling it training.
"Leases contain tons of ambiguities, and interpretation depends on how aggressive the landlord is," said Marc E. Betesh, president of Kislak Lease Services, a lease auditing firm in Woodbridge, N.J.
Other auditors say that corporate financial staffs and fixed-fee auditors have no incentive to chase down gray-area charges.
"If we audited on a fixed-fee basis, we'd simply report to our clients, and that could be the end of it," said Joel I. Binstock, president of York Consulting Group, a Manhattan-based lease audit firm.
ON one thing, everyone is unanimous: Audits have become a common, and probably permanent, part of the real estate landscape. During the last recession corporations caught on to the huge dent that occupancy costs made in their budget, and worked at getting those costs down. In the process, many realized that their rent bills were processed by accounts-payable people who knew little about real estate clauses.
"People who hadn't seen the lease were approving sizable payments," said Joel G. Shapiro, managing director of the accounting firm BDO Seidman's real estate group.
Landlords, meanwhile, faced a slashed income stream, and often pared their own administrative staffs, upping the chance for billing errors. Brokerage firms faced fierce competition for a dwindling number of deals, and used audit services to build relationships with new clients. And individual brokers, building managers and others who were downsized out of jobs, or whose mainstay businesses dried up, used contingency auditing to replace evaporated incomes.
Landlords say it is that latter group that has turned lease auditing into an acrimonious exercise. They say that the contingency auditors knowingly raise specious issues, hoping that the landlord will settle to avoid the legal fees, time and general ill will that fighting back could entail.
"They disrupt tenant relationships and besmirch reputations," Mr. Malkin said.
Landlords are trying to fight back through air-tight clauses in new leases. They are saying that tenants can only question a bill within 60 days after the bill is issued ("That's ridiculous -- it can take 30 days for the bill to get to accounts payable!" Mr. Binstock said). Instead of granting blanket access to expense ledgers, they now say tenants can only have information they reasonably need to explore an area in dispute. And many insist that only accountants charging flat or hourly fees do audits.
"Large tenants may negotiate better access to the books, but I will never agree to show those books to anyone but a C.P.A.," said Arthur L. Bocchi, who handles leasing at 666 Fifth Avenue, at 52d Street.
Actually, the fee issue is not so cut and dried. Many accounting firms use "value added billing" for lease audits; they charge a retainer, with a bonus that reflects a percentage of the savings their audit yields.
"In that sense, even accountants are contingency auditors," Mr. Shapiro said.
Still, the accounting firms are likely to be more restrained than the contingency audit firms. Many are in the business just to prevent competitors from establishing relationships with their clients. And many want to capture landlords as accounting clients.
Brokerage firms also tread a fine line when they do lease audits. The business gives them entree to tenants. But it also puts them in an adversarial position with owners -- one reason that few brokerage firms will audit leases in buildings they manage.
In fact, many brokers have soured on the business. "It is just not good business for a brokerage to antagonize owners," said Dan Gronich, the head of Grubb & Ellis New York, who says he will check whether a tenant's bills reflect the deal he negotiated, but never charges a fee for that service.
OTHERS have strongly limited the types of audits they will do. Julien J. Studley and Cushman & Wakefield pretty much limit their audit business to their own tenant-clients, and often do the audits for free.
"You do so many to find one that makesmoney, it doesn't make sense to pursue this as a business," said Kurt Handschumacher, Studley's corporate managing director.
Of course, such firms occasionally do miss windfalls. John Santora, a Cushman & Wakefield senior managing director, says that a free audit he did for a 200,000-square-foot tenant in Newark yielded a $200,000 rebate in taxes, as well as a $300,000 annual reduction in electricity charges.
"Sure, it hurt not to participate in the savings, but they are a good client," he said.
Those brokerages that remain in the audit business are generally less aggressive than the full-time contingency audit firms.
"We don't look for every last nickel, we just want to see that tenants get the deal they were promised," said Robert A. Sass, executive managing director of Williams Real Estate, which will lower or even waive its one-third-of-savings fee for a tenant that gives Williams its leasing business.
Of course, many audits do end amicably, with both sides trying to follow the spirit of a lease, not just its letter.
Mr. Betesh did an audit for one client who rented space in a building that was not yet completed, and whose lease specified he would pay 50 percent of operating expenses over $500,000. The first year of the lease, the operating expenses jumped to $650,000.
It turned out that the negotiations had been predicated on the client paying half of costs in excess of $5 a square foot for a 100,000-square-foot building, and the completed building was 130,000 square feet.
"It was an honest mistake," Mr. Betesh said. "The landlord readily resolved it."

LENGTH: 2887 words

HEADLINE: Wanted: Large Condos In the Premier Buildings

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
AS the Manhattan housing market sputters along, coughing, starting and stalling like an old tin lizzie, at least one segment seems to be moving steadily: large condominiums in prime buildings.
Like a mantra, one real estate broker after another cites the apparent success of Millennium Tower, at 101 West 67th Street, where the top 12 stories of the 56-story rental/retail/condominium complex are for sale. The tower's 93 condominium apartments command prices that average $675 a square foot, and go as high as $890 a square foot -- over $1 million for a two-bedroom apartment. After a year of sales, the building is 90 percent sold, with the majority of the apartments sold in pairs, and combined for even bigger spaces. 
 Real estate brokers and even rival developers also cite the progress of Donald Trump's latest condominium complex, the Trump International Hotel and Condominium, which was once the Gulf and Western Building at 15 Columbus Circle but is now being rebuilt, and given a new address: One Central Park West.
Judy Banham, the sales representative of the Sunshine Group, the building's marketing agents, said that contracts have been signed for 28 of the 166 units, at a total of $38 million since sales began in early summer. Nevertheless, agents involved in some of the sales emphasize that the units that went first are those with the best views of Central Park and the Hudson River, and they say there has been some hard bargaining going on, a fact Mr. Trump does not deny.
Demand, agents say, is strong -- but buyers are choosy. There is "a two-tier market in condominium sales," according to Alan Rogers, managing director of Douglas Elliman Real Estate, "the high end and the low end."
"With only a few exceptions," he said, "there's no new construction, and the old inventory is not suitable for many of the new buyers." In many cases, he said, "We're stuck with essentially a poor-quality inventory: smaller apartments in 'off' locations."
According to Barbara Corcoran, head of the Corcoran Group, a Manhattan real estate firm: "The greatest demand for apartments today is for grand condominiums in premium buildings with spectacular views -- it's outpacing every other sector of the marketplace. There's too little to select from and too many buyers."
Ms. Corcoran estimated there were "three times as many buyers for condos than for co-ops, with only one-fifth the product." In 1993, she said, 459 two-bedroom condominiums sold for more than $400,000; last year that figure climbed to 638. Douglas Elliman, in its midyear 1995 report, concludes that both the price and the volume of luxury condominium sales have risen.
MANY brokers report that their clients are showing an increased desire for the "flexibility" offered by the condominium form of ownership compared to a co-op's restrictions. Condominium boards do not have the same broad powers to reject applicants as co-op boards, and generally allow owners to rent out their units at will.
As a result, developers who are beginning to build apartments to sell after the long recession are building only condominiums. The Jack Parker Organization has broken ground for its "mid-level" ($400,000 and up) condominium at 72d Street and Second Avenue, and the Brodsky group will break ground next month for a 250-unit luxury condo tower on East 76th Street in back of the St. Jean Baptiste Church. A small new condominium building at 205 East 76th Street, developed by Robert Ezrapour, has been built and one model apartment is finished; there will be only six full-floor, three-bedroom, three-bath apartments available, priced from $595,000 to $725,000.
In addition to the new construction, at least one building's owners are attempting to shift from rental to condominium status: At the Allegro, constructed in 1989 at 62 West 62d Street, 26 apartments have been put up for sale; if 18 of the apartments are under contract of sale -- representing 15 percent of the building's 120 units -- the building can be converted to a condominium, according to state regulations.
Dolly Lenz, Sotheby's top-selling condominium broker, said the building's sponsor has already turned down offers close to the asking prices -- between $405,000 and $470,000 -- for two of the 1,100-square-foot two-bedroom units, "so that's how strong a position they feel they're in." Last Wednesday night, Rose Associates, the sponsor, held a cocktail party for brokers -- and more than 300 showed up.
High-end condominiums have always been attractive to foreigners -- many of whom prefer not to deal with co-op admission committees, who in turn are more comfortable with people who view their New York building as a primary residence. And while the frenzy of foreign buyers -- particularly the Japanese, has certainly abated since the mid-80's, there are still plenty of such sales.
Half of the contracts signed for the Trump International were for foreign buyers, according to the project's marketing agent -- and Mr. Trump said he was surprised it was not more. Another surprise, according to the agent, is that a substantial number of sales have been to Californians. About a third of the units at the Millennium Tower went to foreigners, according to a sales agent there who stressed that the building also attracted New Yorkers, including many families.
Brokers say the success of the Millennium is due to two key factors, and they say both must be present in a project to insure success: an exciting or chic location, preferably with spectacular views, and oversize, well-constructed apartments.
William L. Zeckendorf, president of Zeckendorf Realty, said that he launched the Millennium Tower when "there was nothing but doom and gloom and the market was going nowhere -- we knew we needed to get high prices to make it work."
Mr. Zeckendorf ordered apartments 50 percent bigger than was common in the 80's and, he said, paid three times as much to design his lobby and his corridors: $30,000 for each corridor, compared to the average $10,000. His one-bedroom apartments total 1,000 square feet; his two-bedrooms, 1,500.
The developers who will be successful in the new market, brokers say, have learned from the past: the shoddily constructed cookie-cutter studios and tiny one- and two-bedroom apartments in glitzy towers built in the 80's now sell poorly. Many either languish on the market or are withdrawn after a few months or years, and rented out -- sometimes at surprisingly good rentals.
Adding to the potential problems of owners of some less-desirable condominiums, especially if they bought their apartments a decade or more ago, is a financial consideration that lawyers and developers say will only loom larger as their buildings age.
Because of the way condominium ownership is structured, there can be no underlying mortgage on the building -- and there is virtually no way to put one on, since each apartment is a separate piece of real estate, with its own title and deed.
So when condominiums need major repairs -- like roofs or repointing -- there is only one way to raise the money if the condominium's reserve fund, traditionally smaller than a co-op's, does not cover the cost: assessments.
Although board presidents and managing agents in buildings who have had these problems decline to have their buildings' addresses published, because of a possible effect on resale values, several spoke with great emotion about the importance to condominium boards of immediately putting aside money for such contingencies.
David Kuperberg of Cooper Square Realty, which is primarily a management company, is sending a newsletter to all its buildings stressing the importance of long-term planning, which Mr. Kuperberg said was missing from most condominiums. "Most exist on what we call a 'one and pray' basis," he said. "They plan for one year and pray that no major problems will occur."
The board members and managing agents also spoke of another problem inherent in condominiums: when an individual unit owner defaults on both his carrying charges and his mortgage, the condo board must take a back seat to the bank in recovering any money (in a co-op, the board has the first position). As bank foreclosures grind on, the common charges accrue, easily totaling thousands of dollars. When the unit is ultimately sold at a foreclosure sale, the price often may not equal the mortgage amount owed. The bank takes what it can -- and nothing is left over for the condo board.
ONE former president said one owner who did not pay his carrying charges ran up a bill of $65,000; in a counterclaim, the owner said the building owed him $45,000. The building agreed to call things equal. "We gave him a credit of $20,000 just to get rid of him," the former board president said.
Stuart Saft, a real estate lawyer who is chairman of the Council of New York Cooperatives, is proposing state legislation that would hasten the foreclosure process. The legislation does not attempt to reverse the banks' and the boards' position on who has first call on funds from foreclosure sales. "It just attempts to stop the bleeding, to stop the hemorrhage," said Mr. Saft, adding that if passed, the new law might cut the time of a contested foreclosure from four years to four months.
Meanwhile, a number of managing agents have recently begun to push condominium boards to add a line item to their annual budgets for the reserve fund.
"We are trying to get the condominiums we manage to focus on this issue -- it's becoming a more serious issue every day," said Oskar Brecher, president of American Landmark Management, which manages about 20 condominiums. Two buildings his company sponsored -- 923 Fifth Avenue and 58 West 58th Street -- historically took different approaches to the problem.
At 58 West 58th Street, a more "middle-of-the road" condominium in terms of the affluence of its apartment owners, he said, the reserve fund must be large enough to handle most common expenses. Right now, the condominium's goal is to have no less than $250,000 at any one time.
At 923 Fifth Avenue, one of the many white-brick apartment houses converted to condominiums in the 80's after it was built in the 50's for rental tenants, there has been a different approach.
"These owners are the types that would rather have the money to use as working capital -- when we needed money, we'd just ask them," said Mr. Brecher. But now, he said, there is a new sense that there should be a reserve fund. "Now we have started salting away money," he said.
No. 923 Fifth Avenue is a good example of an older condominium building that, despite its undistinguished exterior, still manages to sell well, according to sales agents. A major reason is its location: at 73d Street. There are only a handful of condominiums on Fifth Avenue on the Upper East Side, and the apartments that face Central Park are considered blue-chip. A six-room, 1,500-square-foot apartment with a park view at 923 Fifth sold in January 1995 for $1.5 million, or $1,000 a square foot.
"A condo on Fifth Avenue is generally more valuable than a co-op on Fifth Avenue," said Frederick W. Peters, president of Ashforth-Warburg Associates. "They're simply more scarce, and the buyers who want them have very few alternatives."
When the apartment hunter moves away from the poshest neighborhoods, brokers say, the gap narrows. At a nondescript postwar brick condominium at 141 East 55th Street, a 595-square-foot one-bedroom is for sale for $185,000, with total monthly charges of $715; a comparable co-op might be priced between $140,000 and $150,000.
For the more ordinary condominiums that languish on the sales market, renting is a definite option, and brokers say that in today's hot rental market, an apartment in a so-so building rents for almost as much as a comparable one in a luxury building. At the Savoy, a condominium at 200 East 61st Street built in 1986, a one-bedroom with great views rents for $2,400; one is on the market for $369,000. At The Monarch, a 1984 building in a less desirable location -- 200 East 89th Street -- a one-bedroom is currently for sale for $229,000, yet the rental income is pretty much the same, according to brokers' listings of both sales and rentals.
Roger Erickson, senior vice president of William B. May Real Estate, said there is only one rule: "A brand new building in a great location with big apartments will sell."
"It's like buying a new car," he said. "Some people won't do anything else. They love the new car smell, the feeling that they're the first to live there." Other than that, he said, the condo market is "spotty" and goes building by building. He gave as an example the condominium building at 45 West 67th Street -- right across the street from the Millennium Tower.
Mr. Erickson currently has the actor Kevin Kline's apartment for sale. "It's a 2,200-square-foot duplex with spectacular views for $1.05 million," the broker said. "And I can't understand why it hasn't sold. That's less than $500 a square foot."
IN addition to the Millennium and the Trump International, real estate agents familiar with Manhattan's condominiums listed the following buildings as among those significant within the market:
* Trump Tower: In the height of the market, the best apartments here were trading for $1,500 a square foot. Agents say that the pace -- and the price -- have fallen off since its heyday and that the apartments are not distinctive. But the Trump Organization disputes those comments, arguing that the best apartments fetch more than ever. The 2,500-square-foot apartment 57L, which faces Central Park, sold in August for $3.2 million, $1,280 a square foot. Meanwhile, apartment 63H, a 1,076-square-foot apartment without a park view, sold in July for $650,000, or about $600 a square foot.
* 1049 Fifth Avenue: With its entrance on 86th Street, this former hotel that was gutted and expensively rebuilt features large apartments with prewar finishes. Though apartments here have taken a while to sell, the building is now 92 percent sold, according to a spokeswoman for the developer. This year, apartment 17A, a seven-room, two-bedroom apartment with a paneled library and city and park views, sold with a maid's room and a storage room for $2.1 million; subtracting the value of the extra rooms, the price was over $1,000 a square foot.
* 817 Fifth Avenue: Unusual for a condominium because it is a prewar building, this tower at 63d Street has elegant, single-floor apartments the owners sometimes rent for more than $20,000 a month. Steve Wynne, the Las Vegas casino owner, recently signed a contract for $4.5 million for an apartment.
IN Greenwich Village, at the four prewar condominiums known as the Bing & Bing buildings after the company that once operated them, including 45 Christopher Street and 302 West 12th Street, brokers' listings indicate a sharp rise in sales prices. Apartment 14B, a two-bedroom at 45 Christopher, sold in March of 1992 for $385,000; by last May the same apartment six floors lower brought $440,000.
The Galleria, built in 1975 at 117 East 57th, suffered in the pit of the market from a slightly worn-looking lobby. Now, according to Roberta Title, head of condominiums at Gumley-Haft Real Estate, whose company also manages the building, it has a new board of managers composed of tenant owners. The new board has put in plantings and completely redone the rooftop gathering room and terraces, and acted to stabilize rising carrying charges.
In December 1991, when the market was at bottom, apartment 39H in the Galleria sold for $267,000 in a foreclosure sale, according to transfer records. The same apartment, 1,208-square-foot "convertible two-bedroom" -- one bedroom plus dining room -- is back on the market, priced at $539,000. Ms. Title said she did not think the price was high for today's market; Apartment 37D, also a "convertible two," is under contract for $509,000. Apartment 45A, the biggest apartment in the building, a two-bedroom with dining room, sold two months ago for $925,000, or more than $500 a square foot.
Yale Robbins, a company that gathers statistics on condominium sales, confirms the trend: In January 1994, the average per-square-foot sales price at the Galleria was $450; by this July, it had shot up to almost $600.
Olympic Tower, at 641 Fifth Avenue, at 51st Street, has its detractors among agents, who grumble that it is not being properly maintained. Others say that the rooms, if not spacious, are not tiny and that the building remains popular with Europeans, who still insist on a Fifth Avenue location. Again, location within the building makes all the difference: an outstanding view is considered readily salable, according to brokers; other units may languish.
All in all, brokers say it is the prime condos that are selling the quickest. "Big, family-sized condos are so hot you can feel the heat right down to the bottom of your feet," said Clark Halstead, head of the brokerage that bears his name. In the 80's, he continued, "developers -- in their wisdom -- built teeny-weeny chicken coops, because the conventional wisdom was that they'd get more per square foot.
"In fact, it's proved the opposite -- the bigger apartments and the best views bring the most money."

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/Public Housing;
In the Beginning, New York Created First Houses

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
THEY demolished another high-rise housing project last month, the six giant buildings of the Lafayette Courts complex in Baltimore, providing additional evidence to support the belief of many people that the public housing vision has gone awry. So how are things at New York's first housing project, built in 1935? Fine thank you -- and not just because First Houses, at the southwest corner of Third Street and Avenue A, is no taller than the trees that shade its cozy courtyard.
In the 1930's the idea of government-built housing was dangerously close to socialism, almost a cuss word at the time. But reformers drew on generations of disgust with the growing urban slums and the more recent Depression to mobilize for a new approach. Mayor Fiorello H. LaGuardia appointed Langdon Post, a housing activist, to head the city's new Housing Authority. Post had been head of the Tenement House Department, a city agency. 
 Post found Washington impossibly slow in using its large relief funds for slum improvements, and he wangled $300,000 and free Works Progress Administration labor to attack a dozen mid-19th century tenements on the Lower East Side.
At the time there were two competing views of how to remake the older sections of the city: the visionary one, clearcutting to create a completely modern landscape, and the nuts-and-bolts one, emphasizing rehabilitating buildings in small clumps. This second method was the one the Housing Authority tried out first, planning a renovation of the old buildings and demolishing every third building to reduce housing density and increase light and air. The resulting 122 apartments opened in December 1935.
The architect, Frederick Ackerman, put the entrances to the buildings in a rear courtyard with benches and plantings, and gave them new skins of industrial-style brick.
The Housing Authority received 3,800 applications for the 3- and 4-room apartments, which rented for $6.05 per room, about two-thirds of what similar apartments in surrounding slums cost. Interviewers carefully screened out those families who they felt were too poor, too rich, too big, too small, too lazy and too dirty. May Lumsden, who was in charge of the screening, wrote in the magazine Survey Graphic in 1936 that she got only "the very finest types" for tenants.
Of the 122 families selected, 81 had had no private toilets, and 20 had had some rooms with no windows. So they were properly grateful: "I never knew what color my furniture was before; I never saw it before except by electric light," Mrs. Lumsden quoted one of her happy new tenants as saying. At the end of a year there were no delinquencies and no family was on relief: the first tenants of First Houses were barbers, taxi drivers, garment workers and the like.
Over the years First Houses has changed little, in part because of landmark designation in 1974. There are new windows, and a gate to keep the homeless out of the central courtyard at night. The tenements to the south have been demolished, flooding the rear courtyard with sun underneath giant London plane trees. Tenants now congregate in a protected courtyard with light and air so luxurious it makes some apartment houses on Park or Fifth Avenues look like, well, tenements.
Andrew Hladeck, who moved in in 1946 after serving as Gen. Douglas MacArthur's personal cook, says that in recent decades the Housing Authority has been lax on supervision of the maintenance staff and the tenants, and he knows that some tenants illegally sublet or share their apartments. Mr. Hladeck, who was a cook at Child's for many years and is now retired, pays $424 a month for a two-bedroom apartment.
John Hamill, acting director of the Housing Authority, said that no complaints had been received about illegal subletting at First Houses but that any future complaints would be investigated. He said that in terms of supervision, "we have done our best with limited resources."
IF public housing nationwide is generally so problematic, and if so many cities have demolished developments, why hasn't New York torn down any, high-rise or low-rise? "While other Housing Authorities solve their problems with dynamite," Mr. Hamill said, "the New York City Housing Authority has persevered and currently maintains the largest and most viable housing stock in the nation."
Roger Starr, a former New York City housing administrator and a contributing editor at the magazine The City Journal, said that compared to other cities, the Housing Authority, with its 184,000 units, had been very careful in tenant selection. "They got lax in recent years," He said, "but they've reverted to a strict policy in the last 8 or 10 months."
Albert Davila, a spokesman for the Housing Authority, said that evictions citywide were up: 912 this year through July, against 384 for all of last year. There are 150,000 families on the waiting list, he said.
Elsie Griesbacker, the president of the First Houses tenants association, said she waited 16 years to get into the development and has been a tenant for 12 years. She said she also wants greater supervision. After 60 years, she said, the interiors need a major overhaul.
She is hoping that First Houses will get a $4.5 million Federal grant to pay for new plumbing, bathrooms and electrical improvements. But neither she nor her neighbors wants to move. "Most people, walking by, don't even know it's a project," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Looking north on Avenue A from East Second Street in December 1935 at First Houses, above, a year after the former mid-19th-century tenements had been renovated and turned into New York City's first public housing project. (New York City Housing Authority); The Housing Authority received 3,800 applications for the 3- and 4-room apartments, which rented for $6.05 per room. Above right, First Houses today, and below right, the courtyard at the rear of the houses. (Photographs by Frances Roberts for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
A Distressed Town's Famous Son Sends Investment Money Home

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER 

DATELINE: PENNS GROVE

 BODY:
Mystery swirled around this Delaware River community for months: who was the secret buyer of 12 waterfront acres in the depressed heart of town?
No one had been interested in Penns Grove real estate since the sprawling Du Pont chemical works next door in Carneys Point, once a cornerstone of the local economy, began laying off blue-collar workers decades ago. Statistically, if not emotionally, this town of 5,200 is the state's second most economically distressed municipality, after Newark. 
 When papers were filed naming the corporate entity Screwball Inc. as the purchaser, a thrill of hope and expectation surged through the town. The man who controls Screwball is the area's most famous son, the actor Bruce Willis.
Soon tourists, the first in memory, were taking pictures of the vacant 12 acres, a stone house and a shuttered bank building that Mr. Willis had bought for $750,000. They entered one of the few remaining businesses on Main Street, Willis Hardware, to ask if it was owned by the star, who became famous from the television series "Moonlighting" and his "Die Hard" films, and now commands more than $10 million a picture. "No relation," they were told.
And they wanted to know if Mr. Willis's equally famous (and rich) wife, the actress Demi Moore, had been spotted this summer talking to contractors hired to renovate the stone house the couple planned to occupy on visits with their three young daughters.
But mostly, everyone wanted to know what plans the couple had for the property.
"So far, all we know is he owns a house with a very large backyard," said H. Donald Stewart Jr., a local real estate broker whose office handled the purchase.
Mr. Willis's press agent in Los Angeles said the actor would not comment on his plans for Penns Grove. But some of the locals have reached what they figure is the only logical conclusion: riverboat gambling.
Philadelphia is trying to win approval from Pennsylvania voters to license floating gambling halls. If that happens, many people think New Jersey will follow.
"I think we'll have riverboat gambling one day," ventured Paul Morris, Penns Grove's Mayor. "If Bruce Willis knows someone who knows someone who knows there will be gambling on the river, then he has picked a location that is strategically located to serve the riverboats."
Penns Grove was settled by Quakers three centuries ago. During World War I, when the Du Pont gunpowder plant turned into a round-the-clock operation for 25,000 workers, the town's night life turned rowdy as the population went from 2,000 to 10,000 almost overnight. Contemporary accounts tell of "staggering" crime rates, bands of thugs blowing safes, bordellos above taverns, gambling and murder.
Besides Du Pont, the river was the economic heartbeat of Penns Grove. Ferries carried travelers back and forth to Wilmington, Del., directly west. Excursion boats, traveling between the 300-foot pier in Penns Grove and the Philadelphia docks, gave revelers a day's outing. Meat and eggs from sturgeon pulled from the river were canned in a factory near the pier, reportedly the largest caviar producer in the United States. World War II and the postwar boom brought petrochemical plants to the banks of the Delaware north of Penns Grove.
Then two things happened from which the town never recovered. The New Jersey Turnpike was built, and the Delaware Memorial Bridge opened to carry north-south traffic between New Jersey and Delaware. Penns Grove became a backwater for interstate travel, and residents were soon driving across the bridge in 15 minutes to shop in Delaware, which has no sales tax. Sweet shops and haberdashers that had once done a bustling commerce on Main Street were closed, leaving only a few merchants.
Mr. Willis was born in Germany in 1955. Soon after, his family settled in Carneys Point, where his father and uncles worked at Du Pont and other plants. Industrial employment was already in a slide as blue-collar workers lost jobs to technology, and expectations about future jobs were low when Mr. Willis graduated from Penns Grove Regional High School in 1973.
"I grew up here and saw it all go downhill terrible," said Debbie Pruette, who was a junior the year Mr. Willis left to start hunting for work as an actor in New York City. She and others remember him as a wisecracking, popular guy not much different from the roles he has created. He was student government president and was voted by his class to be the student with "the most school spirit."
Mr. Willis has come back to Penns Grove for high school reunions, most recently in 1993. But there was no hint that the local boy who had made good was destined to return as a prominent investor.
"I give him credit for actually bringing some of his good fortune back here," said Adele M. Stalcup, 43, the only lawyer in town. She has been struggling to restore Leap House, a sagging three-story Victorian pile across from Mr. Willis's land. "But I'm not sure if I am going to like Bruce as a neighbor if he turns this place into a little Las Vegas."
Others were more optimistic. "I'm not sure Bruce Willis even knows what he wants to do with the property," said Rose Maurice, head of the local Neighborhood Preservation Program. "But he brings excitement to a town that needs some cheering up after more than two decades of decline."

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

FUN AT THE JAYS'
Friends of the 64-acre John Jay Homestead in Katonah are holding their third yearly Old-Fashioned Country Fair today from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. with dozens of attractions for children and adults.
The $10-a-car admission will be used to support the historic site's educational programs. 
 Of special interest to animal lovers is a 4-month-old, 40-pound Siberian tiger cub -- one of several nonpettable animals to be admired. Its handler, Andrew Simmons, will also bring along an 8-month-old bear cub, an alligator snapping turtle, a python, a European eagle owl and a peregrine falcon.
While children will have to observe the creatures from a distance, they will be able to pet the goats, sheep, geese and a donkey in the homestead's farm-animal compound.
There will be pony rides, rides on wagons drawn by Belgian draft horses, three-legged races, egg tosses, demonstrations by artisans, an antique car and tractor display, storytelling, numerous games, music by the New York Blue Grass Authority, lots of food and many door prizes rounding out the agenda.
In addition, anyone with a home-baked apple pie may submit it for judging. The winner will get a free dinner for two at the Monkey Bar in Manhattan.
The Homestead is on Route 22. For more information call 232-5651.
 
ARMONK ART OUTDOORS
 Nearly 170 artists representing 17 states from coast to coast will take part in the 34th Annual Armonk Outdoor Art Show on Saturday and Sunday from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. It will be held at the American Legion Field behind the North Castle town offices on Bedford Road. Admission will be free, but a donation will be appreciated to support projects at the North Castle Library.
It was the Friends of the library that started the show years ago, bringing it to a stage where it is now rated among the top 200 exhibitions of its kind in the country by the professional artists publication Sunshine Artist Magazine.
Judged in six categories, the entrants are well known in their fields of oil, watercolor and acrylic painting, sculpture, mixed media, graphics, and handcrafts. Prices range from $35 to $9,000, and six works -- one in each category -- will be distributed as prizes in a raffle for visitors.
Among the artists represented are Michael Patterson, Peter Bramhall, Laura Breitman, Albert Drogin, Guenther Riess, Sue Phalieros and Carol Turentine.
For more information, call 666-7544.
 
A SMITHY AT MUSCOOT
 William Fitzgerald is a seventh-generation blacksmith, the first of his family to be born here or anywhere outside of County Limerick in Ireland.
He will lead four blacksmithing workshops at Muscoot Farm in Somers for anyone who wants to learn the craft.
The first of the five-hour sessions will take place next Saturday from 9 A.M. to 2 P.M.; the others are scheduled on Oct. 7 and 28 and Nov. 4 during the same hours. Each session costs $65 and is limited to five students.
"We have five forges, five anvils and five sets of tools for them to work with," Mr. Fitzgerald said. "And this is not a situation where people come and watch me demonstrate. They do all the work, I just guide them through it."
In addition to running his own ironworks where he makes horseshoes, ornamental objects, gates, fireplace tools, and provides decorative items for churches and building contractors, he has held the classes at Muscoot for a dozen years.
Many of his students come back for increasingly advanced instruction. The most popular items for first-time students are fireplace pokers and nails, but each student can make whatever he or she likes.
"Making a nail is very difficult because it's so small," he said. "The iron heats up and cools down quickly, before you have a chance to draw the point or make the head." Fires are stoked with soft coal and the forges are hand cranked the old-fashioned way.
Hard-soled shoes, not sneakers, are to be worn, with jeans, sweatshirts or other sturdy clothing. Leather aprons are provided for protection.
To register or obtain more information, call 232-7118.
 
BIG POWER BREAKFAST
 The first suburban breakfast to be held by the 240,000-member National Association for Female Executives will have as its theme "The Big News in 'Big' Business -- Thinking Small."
It is scheduled on Tuesday from 8 to 10 A.M. at the Nestle Building, 100 Manhattanville Road in Purchase, and registration is $30.
Planned in conjunction with the Entrepreneurial Center of Purchase, the event will be attended by members of the two organizations and the public from Fairfield, Rockland and Bergen Counties as well as Westchester.
Marge Lovero, president of the Entrepreneurial Center, will moderate a panel discussion by Maurice Cox, vice president of Pepsico in Somers; Dee DelBello, publisher of Westfair Communications and the wife of Alfred DelBello, a former Westchester County Executive, and Joanne Reilly, senior vice president of National Westminster Bank.
Billed as a "not for women only" event, the program is aimed at executives and owners of small businesses, focusing on the demand by big businesses for outside entrepreneurial ideas and services.
Call (212) 477- 2200, extension 334, to register or obtain more information.
 
BUSINESS AND ASIA
 Sharon Russell FitzSimmons, international finance and treasury executive for Philip Morris International, will be the speaker at the Westchester County Association lunch on Wednesday at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook.
Her topic will be "Is the Time Right for You to Be Doing Business in Southeast Asia?"
She will outline opportunities in the markets of Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam, where a population of 425 million generates a gross domestic product worth $570 billion and the per capita income is $1,400 a year. As a result, those markets are beginning to compete strenuously with the developed economies of Japan, Taiwan, South Korea and Hong Kong.
Ms. FitzSimmons is a graduate of the Harvard Business School who spent four years in management positions at Philip Morris's Australian operations before becoming involved in the company's Asian expansion.
A reception will begin at 11:30 A.M., followed by the lunch and presentation at 12:15. Reservations at $50 may be made by calling 948-6444. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Getting Around With a CD-ROM

 BODY:
Two CD-ROM's packed with information of use to travelers are becoming available in computer stores around the nation.
Precision Mapping 2.0 for Windows features a detailed map of the entire continental United States. It includes more than 17 million streets and roads -- virtually every street in the country -- and almost 3 million miles of rivers and streams. 
 Users can search by city name, street name, address, ZIP code, area code, and latitude and longitude. The program will even search down to the level of a street block, or a cross street or intersection.
Once a location has been found, Precision Mapping 2.0 can be used to create a custom color map that can be exported for use in a word processing program or spreadsheet. The program, produced by Just Softworks of Lemont, Ill., can be used with most printers, so that within seconds the custom map can be ready to use.
Available at Software Etc., Barnes & Noble, Computer City and Comp U.S.A., Precision Mapping 2.0 has a street price of $79 (the full recommended retail price is $119). As a bonus, buyers can choose between two free CD-ROM's: American Business Information's 11 Million Yellow Pages or 70 Million White Page Listings.
To run the program, users will need Microsoft Windows 3.1 or higher (including Windows 95), a 386 or higher I.B.M.-compatible computer, four megabytes of memory, a CD-ROM drive and a mouse.
Almost a companion program is the 1995 Wayzata World Factbook, a multimedia gazetteer compiled from information supplied by the Central Intelligence Agency, the State Department, the Defense Intelligence Agency and other official sources.
It provides cultural, governmental, economic and demographic profiles of 264 countries, regions and territories. The profiles are enhanced by maps, sound effects, color flags and more than 200 photographs of world landmarks, from the pyramids to the Great Wall of China.
Also included are entry requirements for travel, State Department travel advisories and terrorist group profiles. The 1995 edition, the fifth since 1991, contains eight megabytes of updated data, as well as new photographs and charts.
The program has a street price of about $20 ($25 recommended retail price), operates with any Macintosh, as well as with Windows 3.1 and, according to the manufacturers, Windows 95, and is available from Comp U.S.A. or Computer City, or by mail from Wayzata Technology, 21 Northeast Fourth Street, Grand Rapids, Minn. 55744; (800) 735-7321.
