HEADLINE: Grace Under Pressure

BYLINE: By Moira Hodgson; Moira Hodgson, the restaurant critic for The New York Observer, writes frequently about the arts.

 BODY:

IN AND OUT OF VOGUE
By Grace Mirabella with Judith Warner.
Illustrated. 257 pp. New York:
Doubleday. $25. 
 WHEN Grace Mirabella suddenly replaced Diana Vreeland as editor in chief of Vogue in 1971, the fashion industry was taken by surprise. Vogue was the leading fashion magazine of the growing group of Conde Nast publications. Ms. Mirabella seemed an odd choice for the job. For Vreeland, fashion was about youth, flamboyance and fantasy. Ms. Mirabella, her assistant for nine years, was the opposite: a down-to-earth hard worker with a business and retailing background. She edited the magazine for 17 successful years, the circulation tripled, and then, in a striking replay of events, she was abruptly fired and replaced by Anna Wintour, a glamorous and much younger woman.
Traditionally, most of the editors of Vogue had been from New York society; Grace Mirabella's parents were Italian immigrants who lived in New Jersey (her father was a salesman). She was born, she says in "In and Out of Vogue," in Philip Roth's Newark, "a city of strivers pushing forward from immigrant enclaves." New Jersey, she says, "is more than a place; it's an adjective" -- as illustrated by a recent New Yorker cartoon showing an unfashionable, overweight matron walking on the street wearing a T-shirt marked "DKNJ." The caption: "Donna Karan's nightmare."
It is hard to imagine Grace Mirabella, a champion of the very sort of chic but wearable clothes that Donna Karan has sold with such success, working for someone like Diana Vreeland. But in the 1960's, the era of the "Beautiful People," she did. Vreeland, who had great style and an extraordinary eye, was given to statements like "Pink is the navy blue of India" and "The bikini is the most important thing since the atom bomb." A typical Vreeland memo, this one about a runway model, reads: "Her outline is splendid. Her proportion unique with the small round head, long throat and legs but she can look as if she was walking toward a strange destiny which I am sure most Swedes are."
When Ms. Mirabella took over at Vogue, a major revolution in women's fashion was under way. As millions of young American women poured into the workplace and into professional careers, the go-go boots, love beads and miniskirts of the 60's were giving way to more practical, wearable clothes. But by the mid-80's, fashion had, predictably, changed again. In the Reagan era there was lots of new money, the cult of celebrity flourished and runway fashion shows became wild spectacles with even wilder clothes.
Even though Ms. Mirabella subsequently started her own magazine, with the backing of Rupert Murdoch (it is now a bimonthly published by Hachette), the blow of her dismissal from Vogue was severe. Ms. Mirabella has a number of scores to settle, and settle she does. She fires volleys at Anna Wintour, describing her as "cold," "suspicious," "autocratic" -- "a vision of skinniness in black sunglasses and Chanel suits" who was "playing the movie version of a fashion editor a la 'Lady in the Dark.' " She also has harsh words for Si Newhouse, the publisher, with his "dull gaze" and "glumly decorated office," and Alexander Liberman, the editorial director of the Conde Nast empire, behind whose "honey-soaked delivery was an iron will, a tin ear for dissension and an ego the size of the Newhouse fortune."
The photographer Richard Avedon is, she says, a "royal pain" who "achieved some of his best effects with girls who were utterly strung out on dope." And in the 60's, Andy Warhol and Viva and the whole crew smelled "like unwashed underwear and pot" as they milled around the Vogue offices with their cameras. She describes the American designer Halston's clammy hands and unfocused gaze when he was high on drugs and says that Yves Saint Laurent was "a rather lost-looking man with a bottle and a glass in his hand, looking like someone who couldn't remember anymore how or where he'd started."
This is strong stuff from the former editor of the publication whose senior staff members once wore hats at their desks and lunched every day at the Colony Club. Vogue was from its start an upper-middle-class magazine, run by society women who wore clothes from Paris and dispensed advice for the well-dressed woman on fashion, society and etiquette. (A member of the staff once tried without success to throw herself under a subway train, and Edna Woolman Chase, the first editor in chief, is reported to have told her when she came back to work: "My dear, we at Vogue don't throw ourselves under subway trains. If we must, we take sleeping pills.")
In the 50's Mary McCarthy had described Vogue as a forbidding monitor enforcing the discipline of Paris. Its sole concession to its provincial subscribers was a pattern department. McCarthy said: "Furs, jewels, sumptuous materials, fine leathers, line, cut, atelier workmanship, were the very fabric of fashion; taste, indeed, was insisted on, but taste without money had a starved and middle-class pathos. The tastefully dressed little woman could not be a woman of style."
Grace Mirabella set out to address this tastefully dressed little woman, who was now someone leading a complex, busy life, more often than not with a full-time job and a family to take care of. She had a no-nonsense approach to fashion: "What I've always cared about, passionately, is style. Style is how a woman carries herself and approaches the world. It's about how she wears her clothes and it's more: an attitude about living. Dressing up in the most expensive thing around has nothing to do with style. Style transcends money, fashion trends, 'prettiness.' "
During the late 80's, Ms. Mirabella had increasing run-ins with Alexander Liberman. "I thought of his favorite line about the women's movement: 'Clearly the women of the future will be bald,' how he dismissed story ideas: 'No, you don't want to do a story on the pro-choice movement. Nobody cares . . .' and how he reacted when we wanted to do a story on the changing roles of women: 'You don't need to do another story about working women. Women are cheap labor and always will be.' "
SHE says her attempts to show clothes that were liberating and to cover relevant issues of the day did not go far in the era that culminated in the bouffant excesses of Christian Lacroix and the appearance in Vogue of sadomasochistic photographs by Helmut Newton. The 80's, she recalls, "was an emperor-has-no-clothes era, start to finish. Clothes were about labels, designers were about being celebrities, and it was all, on a bigger and bigger scale, about money. Until eventually, as the 80's turned into the 90's, fashion came to be about nothing more than itself. It degenerated, like post-modern art, like post-modern architecture, into a self-referential game full of jokes and pastiches that amused the fashion community enormously and did nothing at all for the woman shopping and trying to find something to wear. At the very same time that women were really emerging as a potent economic and political force in America, there were no clothes for them at all."
Ms. Mirabella says Ralph Lauren once told her that he could always count on her to talk straight. "In and Out of Vogue" -- written with Judith Warner, who has also written biographies of Hillary Clinton and Newt Gingrich -- does not have the breathiness of fashion-magazine prose but rather the simple, blunt delivery that Ms. Mirabella prides herself on.
Her story conveys all the immediacy of the front line, and apart from the gossip it is an interesting chronicle of the vicissitudes of American fashion and the successful appearance of clean-cut, wearable clothes from designers she championed -- among them Geoffrey Beene, Ungaro, Halston, Calvin Klein, Ralph Lauren and Giorgio Armani. It leaves you feeling sympathetic toward Grace Mirabella while turning the pages to see who is attacked next. Her book is fascinating, humorous, wry and ultimately rather sad. It offers insight into both the fashion and magazine-publishing businesses, which in the past decade have converged in ways that no one would have predicted when Ms. Mirabella became editor of Vogue.

GRAPHIC: Drawing

HEADLINE: FAULT LINES: The Big One: Washington's Political Earthquake;
The Social Engineers Let Welfare Go Unfixed

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
EIGHTY-SEVEN of the Congress's 100 Senators voted last week to abandon 30 years of Federal welfare policy for an untested and drastically different alternative, a stampede that would be historic enough were it all that happened. It wasn't. Three of every four Democrats, 33 in all, joined in scrapping a system their party had invented, nurtured, expanded -- and declined to reform as recently as last year. That opportunity lost, they have now acceded to what had been unthinkable: the end of the very entitlement that guarantees Federal aid to the poor.
So begins the final journey of the Great Society, with Lyndon Johnson's political progeny clambering aboard a bandwagon they could have steered but chose not to. It is unlikely to be a one-time event.
Republicans will reap the credit or blame 
 for dismantling the Federal social bureaucracy that began with the New Deal. But Democrats, by failing to keep vigil over programs that did not change with the times, let its foundation crack. The new Congress is merely the demolition crew.
In the last week alone, House committees voted to end the Federal entitlement for Medicaid, the Johnson-era health program for the poor, and reduce the earned income tax credit, a Carter Administration anti-poverty venture. Congress is disassembling the Legal Services Corporation, cutting Head Start, reducing funds for public broadcasting and the arts and paring or abolishing other Democratic legacies. In most cases, charges of waste and mismanagement are the pile-drivers sinking the pillars of Republican ideology.
Those charges have been especially damaging for welfare programs whose beneficiaries are not so politically powerful and, to listen to the Republicans in their shrillest moments, not so deserving. But some more popular programs were hardly exempt. Republicans began a major overhaul last week of Medicare, warning that it, too, is riddled with waste and careening toward bankruptcy.
They may be right. Some of these programs are no doubt rotten ideas, poorly executed. Others were good ideas poorly executed, and still others good and reasonably effective government. In a way, it hardly matters. All were part of a guileless effort to remake society that began as a revolution and became the status quo. A transformed economy, cultural upheavals and the Democrats' reluctance to adapt their own shopworn ideology seem to have laid them all bare to counter-revolution.
"We blew it," one icon of the era, Mario M. Cuomo of New York, said in a recent interview. "We were in power for a long period of time. We didn't correct ourselves. We didn't sharpen our agenda. We didn't stay up to date. And we paid the price."
Isabel Sawhill, a scholar at the Urban Institute, suggests that Gresham's Law is at work -- that bad Democratic management has finally driven out basically good policy.
Welfare is the showcase example. The basic subsidy, Aid to Families with Dependent Children, was begun to assist the children of widows and other victims of circumstance in the Depression. As recently as 1960 it remained so, serving only 745,000 families at a cost of about $1 billion a year.
By the 1960's, it had clearly become inadequate. Industry rose; subsistence farming shrank; blacks and other poor streamed to cities. President Kennedy's first Congress let states broaden A.F.D.C. The Supreme Court barred states from denying benefits to classes of recipients, such as families newly moved to another state. Food stamps became easier to get. The welfare rights movement eased the stigma attached to handouts.
And in a way, it worked. As Michael Katz noted in his 1989 analysis of welfare, "The Undeserving Poor," Federal programs lifted about half the poor over the poverty line from 1965 to 1972. Infant mortality plummeted. Few would argue that the average poor family is worse off today than in 1960.
But the costs were huge. A.F.D.C. now costs $23 billion and reaches 14 million households. The dole became the rule for a vast swath of society, the plight of the program's children worsened rather than improved, and the list of ills it was supposed to cure -- crime, illegitimacy, drug use, family breakup -- only got longer.
 
Democrats Against Clinton
 Yet Democratic efforts to overhaul the system were fitful. President Clinton's own proposal to link welfare to work -- and to create jobs -- died last year, largely because the Democrats, who still controlled Congress, refused to embrace it.
Robert Shapiro, vice president of the Progressive Policy Institute, a new-Democratic idea factory, says Congress clung to a notion of giving the poor a share of an endless economic expansion that was in fact ending. "Rather than saying that these programs can't solve these problems and that we need additional emphasis on responsibility, they said 'More aid is the answer,' " he said. "And when those become the terms, these programs have to fail."
There was surely more to it than that. But the basic theme of good intentions, unrestrained and unquestioned, courses through many of the programs Republicans now seek to decimate or abolish.
Many experts call the earned income tax credit -- actually, a Government check that keeps the working poor above the poverty line -- the best antipoverty program of all. It encourages work and is cheap to run.
But its history is instructive. It began in 1975 as a tiny and temporary effort to buffer poor workers from an increase in the Social Security payroll tax. Since then, the credit has been extended, indexed to inflation, made permanent, and finally, in 1993, offered to childless couples. It grew from $252 million to $20 billion and could become most costly welfare program of all.
The new Congress points to studies claiming that a third of the payments have gone to ineligible workers or, sometimes, con artists. The Government cracked down on fraud, but Republicans say some beneficiaries make $50,000 or even $100,000 a year.
Another success story, Head Start, is under assault, too. Head Start has schooled 14 million children in 30 years; Democrats long clamored to expand it. President Bush did so in 1992 to silence election-year criticism. But Edward Zigler, a Yale University psychologist who helped start the program and remains an advocate, says the expansion was disastrous. "They wanted to triple the size of Head Start without any plan, any plan whatsoever. Just throw money out there," he said. The result: wasted funds for hastily trained teachers and staff in catch-as-catch-can surroundings.
There's more. The Legal Services Corporation, intended to give the poor entry into the justice system, faces extinction amid accusations that lawyers clock time for liberal causes rather than clients. Supplemental Security Income, the last resort for the disabled poor, faces cuts, accused of frittering billions on drug addicts, alcoholics and families whose children have questionable behavioral problems. Medicaid now spends much of its money on elderly nursing-home patients, many of them middle class, as well as the younger poor. Even Medicare, which began 28 years ago with a $3.7 billion allotment, now costs $170 billion, grows by 10 percent a year and threatens to eat the entire budget in one gulp.
So was the Great Society wrongheaded? Or just wrongly run? Its basic tenets -- some obligation to the poor, to children and the disabled and the sick -- are probably permanent principles of American society, in one form or another. Democrats chose one form. In a lapse of vigilance, they may have ceded the right to choose another.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROWNSTONE BROOKLYN;
Montague St. Faces Rigors Of Popularity

SERIES: Shoptalk: An occasional look at commercial districts around New York.

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
These days, when the telephone rings at the Brooklyn Heights office of William B. May, the real estate company, it is often a prospective business owner eager to find commercial space on Montague Street, the neighborhood's main shopping thoroughfare.
The company receives about 20 such calls a week, compared with two or three a week several years ago, said its vice president, Christopher Thomas. "Usually, I have to tell them there's nothing available," he said. Until recently there were as many as six vacancies along the four short blocks of Montague Street. Today there are none. "Things have never been so tight," Mr. Thomas said. 
 But not everything is rosy on Montague Street, which connects downtown Brooklyn to the waterfront promenade of Brooklyn Heights. While the street has captured the attention of national retail chains like Banana Republic, Starbucks and the Gap, many smaller merchants are struggling.
The influx of chain stores has sent rents soaring to $75 to $90 a square foot, comparable to rents in SoHo or the Upper East Side, Mr. Thomas said. The rents have forced out some longtime shopkeepers, and those who remain complain that business has yet to recover from the real estate crash and recession of the late 1980's.
To maintain the area's economic well-being, the Brooklyn Heights Association hired a consultant last week to explore the formation of a business improvement district. The B.I.D., which requires the approval of the majority of the street's 103 merchants, would impose taxes on the businesses and use the money to look after their interests in areas like marketing and street cleaning.
The B.I.D.'s first battle could be against a city plan to allow vendors to set up food carts on Montague Street. Sidewalk vendors are banned from the neighborhood, and most merchants want to keep it that way. "Besides the fact that our sidewalks are too narrow, these vendors don't pay taxes and they leave the street a mess," said Bill Hurcomb, owner of Boro Photo at 146 Montague Street.
A hearing before the Department of Business Services is scheduled for Oct. 2.
The growing competition on Montague Street has been particularly fierce among restaurants, which now make up at least a third of the street's businesses. One local fixture, the Leaf and Bean coffee shop at 136 Montague Street, which sold bulk coffee and tea and also had a small cafe, was forced out in January after the monthly rent was doubled, to $10,000. A more upscale restaurant, the Height Cafe, quickly took its place.
Armando's, an Italian restaurant at 143 Montague Street that opened in 1938, has begun to feel the pinch from the competition. In the last year, six new restaurants have opened within 100 yards of Armando's, five of them Italian.
"We all can't survive," said Armando's owner, Peter Byros. "In order to be healthy, the street has to have more than just restaurants and big chains." ANDREW JACOBS

CORRECTION-DATE: October 1, 1995, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about the commercial district on Montague Street in Brooklyn Heights misidentified the establishment that succeeded the Leaf and Bean. It is Ozzie's Coffee Bar, not the Heights Cafe. The article also misstated the closing date of the Leaf and Bean. It was June 1994, not last January.

HEADLINE: For Part-Time Business Students, Golf Will Have to Wait

BYLINE: By DANIEL McGINN 

DATELINE: PURCHASE

 BODY:
ON a sunny morning late last month, 40 alumni of New York University's Westchester business program met at Sterling Farms Golf Course in Stamford for a day of golf, sun and fun. Of the school's 240 current students, however -- all of whom were invited -- just one attended.
"Time becomes a very precious commodity once you enter the program," said Mary K. Oberhelman, Westchester director of New York University's Stern School of Business. "It's a lot easier to do things like that when you don't have to go to school." 
 For the part-time Stern students, passing up a round of golf is one of the many sacrifices required in pursuit of a master's degree in business administration. They attend classes on the Manhattanville College campus here for three hours a night, two nights a week, for more than three years before receiving their degrees. But the time invested appears to be worth it.
Earlier this year, U.S. News & World Report named Stern's program the best in the United States in the magazine's first ranking of part-time programs. The list is based on a survey of business school deans nationwide. N.Y.U.'s Business School has long been renowned for its part-time program, in part, according to Business Week's most recent guide to M.B.A. programs, because of the school's history as a place where Wall Street executives could take classes after work at nearby Trinity Place, where the school was founded in 1916.
The school's roots in Westchester are more recent. In the mid-1970's, as more corporations fled to the suburbs, Manhattanville College was seeking to put its classrooms to use in the evenings.
In 1977, the Stern School began renting a suite of offices in Brownson Hall and holding sessions in classrooms upstairs. Workers from nearby corporations like International Business Machines, Kraft General Foods and General Electric flocked to the program, which matriculated about 700 graduates in the next 18 years.
Part-time M.B.A. programs often don't get the respect of their full-time counterparts, said Dick Kwartler, editor of The MBA Newsletter in Floral Park, L.I., who estimates that two-thirds of the country's 275,000 students pursuing M.B.A. degrees attend school part-time. "There has always been more prestige attached to the full-time programs -- that's where the glamour is," he said. "There has always been a stigma attached to the part-time programs, but the heads of the schools are aggressively attacking that."
Ronald J. Patten, dean of the business school at DePaul University in Chicago, referred to the phenomenon as "the Rodney Dangerfield complex" in a recent story in The MBA Newsletter.
He said that the increasing number of companies that will pay for employees to pursue the degree on a part-time basis show that corporations value the programs.
At N.Y.U., administrators say their part-time program is every bit as rigorous as full-time study. "It's not watered down in any way," Ms. Oberhelman said. "It's the same requirements as the full-time program, whether you're in the city or here."
Students in the Westchester division can choose to major in finance, general management or a combined finance-international business program. Other majors are available to students who wish to travel to the city for additional courses.
No matter what their major, master's degree candidates complete 60 credits of course work, consisting of 30 to 33 credits in required courses like accounting, economics, marketing and finance, 12 to 18 credits in their major, and an additional 12 to 18 credits of electives. Most students take six credits a semester and take 10 semesters, including summer sessions, to complete the degree.
Tuition and required fees total $5,133 a semester, putting the total price for the degree at more than $50,000. Many students' employers pick up all or part of the cost.
The program, which receives nearly 200 applications a year, admits a class of 80 students each fall. The average student admitted into this year's class is 27, has more than six years' work experience, scored 639 out of a possible 800 on the Graduate Management Aptitude Test and maintained an undergraduate grade point average of 3.3, Ms. Oberhelman said.
The school's primary competitors for applicants are Fordham University, which operates a satellite M.B.A. program in Tarrytown, the University of Connecticut's Stamford campus and Pace University. But for Susan Schiffler, who was accepted by Pace and the University of Connecticut in addition to N.Y.U., the choice was easy.
"I wanted to further my education, and I looked for the best school in the area," said Ms. Schiffler, a Yorktown resident employed at I.B.M. who began classes at Stern this month. "N.Y.U. was it without a doubt."
Ms. Schiffler is taking financial accounting on Monday evenings and microeconomics on Thursdays. After one session of each class, she was impressed.
"The professors are really personal," she said. "They bring a lot of good examples into class."
The examples were apparent in Prof. Robert Schwartz's Foundations of Finance class on a recent Tuesday night. As he led the class of 55 through topics like "The Flow of Funds From Households to Firms" and "The Structure of the Securities Industry," he mixed theory with stories of where he was during the 1987 stock market crash (having his Volvo repaired) and his advice for the best one-word guess on any finance exam ("liquidity"). "How did you know that," he asked as a student answered a question by reading from the notes projected on the overhead screen.
The payoff for the long evenings of staring at overhead projections is the chance for career advancement and the salary increases that go with it. Christine Doria, a 1987 graduate of the program who lives in Rye Brook, began classes in 1983 while working as a process design manager at Union Carbide in Tarrytown. Shortly after graduation she moved to Bankers Trust in Manhattan, then in 1990 moved to Chase Manhattan, where she works as a business manager in the securities lending division.
"If I didn't have the degree, I'd probably still be in a technical position," Ms. Doria said. "Maybe I could have become a business manager, but it certainly would have taken a bit longer."
Stern's downtown division has produced some famous alumni, including Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Ismail Merchant, the film producer. The Westchester program hasn't graduated anyone of comparable status yet, but its director said that it's only a matter of time.
"It takes a while," Ms. Oberhelman said. "Just wait a few years."

HEADLINE: Few Protest Metro-North Fare Hike

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
IF Westchester commuters were upset by the average 9 percent fare hike proposed for Metro-North, they did not turn out to protest. Only 15 people showed up at a hearing held at the public library here recently by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
Of those speakers, four were elected officials and three came to complain about train service in Rockland County. 
 The meeting was in marked contrast to a raucous counterpart in Manhattan several days earlier, where more than 100 speakers unleashed their anger and frustration on the authority's board, which in addition to the Metro-North fare hikes has proposed a 25-cent increase on subways and buses and a rise in bridge and tunnel tolls.
E. Virgil Conway, the authority's chairman, said he saw the low turnout as an acknowledgment of Westchester commuters' happiness with the service and acceptance of the increase.
"I think the light turnout reflects a high level of satisfaction with Metro-North," Mr. Conway said. "Citizens understand that fares have not been raised for many years and that the proposed increase was fair and appropriate."
Indeed, some of those who did speak commented on the improvements that have been made by the railroad in the last decade.
"I remember going to the railroad station to hand out political documents in 1980," said Sandra R. Galef, the Democratic Assemblywoman from Ossining.
"The trains were always late, so we had plenty of time to talk to commuters, and they were really mad. Service has greatly improved, and I think commuters would support a modest increase."
Not everyone was so sanguine about the proposal. Naomi C. Matusow, the Democratic Assemblywoman from White Plains, also said that service was excellent, but she still protested the fare increase.
"It doesn't take a financial genius to figure out what's going on here is a tax shift," Ms. Matusow said. "This fair increase is subsidizing Pataki's income tax cut," she added, referring to Gov. George E. Pataki. "I think the M.T.A. has an obligation to stand up on its hind legs and to say that money is important to commuters. You should be fighting for a restoration of those funds."
Because of city, state and Federal budget cuts to mass transit, the authority faces a budget deficit of $816 million. Just over half of the cost for services is paid through government subsidies; the rest comes from fares.
The fare and toll increases are part of a new phase of the authority's capital-investment plan, which is intended to rebuild the commuter railroads and the subway and bus system. The authority has already spent more than $20 billion on the plan since 1982. Metro-North has seen more than $1.4 billion in capital improvements, much of it spent on replacing deteriorating cars and tracks. On-time rates have improved from about 80 percent in 1983 to its current 96 percent, one of the best records in the country.
Improvements already begun or planned on Metro-North include expanded parking in North White Plains and along the New Haven Line, refurbishing all New Haven Line stations in New York, a new station in Cortlandt and expanded parking in Goldens Bridge and Irvington.
Some critics have questioned how the capital-improvement program can continue with shrinking state aid for day-to-day operations and no new state aid for capital improvements. But Mr. Conway, who was appointed by Governor Pataki five months ago, said he will be able to carry out the authority's plans.
"There are always naysayers," Mr. Conway said. "I agree with the Governor's expressed view that economic growth is needed. We are still heavily subsidized by the government. But this is an era where authorities like ours have to be more and more self-sufficient. The basic assumption in the financial plan is that internal efficiency will do the lion's share of expense reductions."
One of the themes many speakers expressed at the New York City hearing was the belief that Governor Pataki and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority board were favoring the suburbs over the city in its proposed plan. But several speakers in White Plains argued that most suburban commuters will be doubly hit by the fare increases. Not only do they pay for parking at train stations but they will also have to pay increased Metro-North fares and increased transit fares if they take the subway or a bus to get to their offices in New York City.
The fare increases on the Harlem and Hudson Lines and the New York State section of the New Haven line will average 9 percent, with some fares increasing more and others less. For instance, under the proposal, the monthly commutation fare from Rye to Manhattan would rise to $152 from $138, a 10.1 percent increase. The one-way off-peak fare would rise to $5 from $4.75, a 5.3 percent increase. From Peekskill, the monthly fare would increase to $193 from $172, a 12.2 percent increase. The new fares are expected to be instituted on Nov. 1.
Another issue raised at the hearing was commuter safety. Patricia Dolan, who works as a chef and commutes out of North White Plains, said she often felt threatened as she waited for trains.
"My main concern is safety of the stations," Ms. Dolan told the board. "I can't tell you the number of times I've been followed. I won't ever take a local train, especially at night. You feel so scared. Something has to be done. As a woman, I need some protection."
Donald N. Nelson, president of Metro-North, said that the hearings -- which are required by state statute -- were helpful in that they gave people a chance to express their opinion and that the board sometimes comes away with new information. In response to Ms. Dolan's complaint, he said that he would look into lighting the North White Plains station. He added that the railroad has increased the number of Metro-North police officers to 197 from 140.
"Security is important to us and we have several new police programs aimed at what that customer was complaining about," Mr. Nelson said. "But the fact remains that at any one time we have 40 to 60 cops and 160 stations, so it's possible for a person to commute and not see a police officer. Still, the coverage is much better than it used to be."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
A New Life for Old Mills, Silent for a Decade

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

DATELINE: WINDHAM

 BODY:
WHEN the American Thread Company closed its plant here in 1985, it left 1.2 million square feet of vacant mill space on a 40-acre property where 2,000 people once worked.
Now, after a decade of false starts, a project that envisions a mix of offices, light industry, shops, restaurants and a museum in the complex is already attracting tenants to this northeastern Connecticut community about 30 miles east of Hartford. 
 With almost $6 million in public grants, three buildings have been demolished, and four structurally sound ones with a total of 100,000 square feet are being cleaned, repaired and repainted.
"More has been done with that property in the last 10 months than in the previous 10 years," said the town's First Selectman, Walter M. Pawelkiewicz.
The plan is to lease 100,000 square feet a year for five years, which would use up most of the space that can be salvaged and create 1,200 jobs, said Geri W. Langlois, executive director of the nonprofit Windham Mills Development Corporation.
"So far, based on the contacts that we've had, I think it's possible," Mr. Langlois said. "But people have to be patient. It took American Thread 65 years to build this property up to where it is today. To fill it up again in just five years would be a major accomplishment."
As the Windham Mills project moves forward on the east end of Main Street, Windham officials are finding growing enthusiasm for a downtown revitalization effort.
"The mill project is giving the community a sense that something is happening in the downtown, that things are positive," said Irene I. Flaherty, executive director of the Windham Community Redevelopment Agency.
She said the project was already generating more interest in the agency's two major holdings, a five-acre parcel of vacant land near the mills and a turn-of-the-century Greek Revival building on Main Street.
Marguerite P. Reich, executive director of the Windham Regional Planning Agency, said what happens at the mill could affect the economy of the entire northeast corner of the state.
"Windham has always been the economic center of the region," Ms. Reich said. "It's the place where people work and shop."
The chief promise of the mills project is that it could bring to one site some healthy economic diversity -- housing, commercial and retail space and light manufacturing.
The mill project, with its walkways along the Willimantic River and restored blacksmith shops and textile museum, could also become the anchor for a planned heritage corridor park in the region, she said.
THE mill complex is in Willimantic, a hamlet in Windham that once identified itself so closely with the mills that its police cars bore decals that showed a spool of thread. So when American Thread announced it was leaving, the town lost its economic breath.
There followed a succession of developers who promised to restore the mills, but none of them delivered. Then last November, with $5.7 million from the state's Department of Economic Development and almost $200,000 in Federal economic diversification funds, the town took the property by eminent domain and began repairs on its own.
Russell S. Pratt, a contractor who is chairman of the Windham Mills Development Corporation, said he was surprised to see that after years of neglect the mills were in relatively good shape.
"The strength and integrity of these structures is incredible," Mr. Pratt said. "The structure itself is a fortress. You've got two-foot-thick granite walls, and floors built to support industrial equipment of a century ago, which was extremely heavy and vibrated constantly."
Features such as 4- by 16-inch yellow pine roof beams, ornate staircases, 12- to 20-foot ceilings and maple floors will add to the allure of the space, he said.
"No one could afford to replicate what we have here," Mr. Pratt said. "Anything else just becomes vanilla space after you've seen this building."
Mr. Pratt said most of the renovations so far have made the buildings habitable -- the roof replacement, repairing the sprinkler system and replacing wiring.
"Now we're structurally sound, watertight and safe," Mr. Pratt said. "A lot of what's been going on here hasn't been apparent to passers-by, but we've reached a point where it's going to start looking different on the outside as well."
Restoration is planned for 11 buildings totaling 412,000 square feet. Another two buildings with 224,000 feet of space are being evaluated.
Because of the size of the project -- at the height of production, American Thread was filling two 15,000-gallon fuel oil tanks daily to warm the mills -- each job becomes massive. All 2,800 windows in the complex will be removed and replaced by aluminum-framed double-paned windows, each costing $425.
"From the outside," Mr. Langlois said of the windows, "you really can't tell the difference, but they're a lot more efficient."
"Primarily this is a job-creation project, and an industrial property re-use," Mr. Langlois said. "We're going to save as much as we can, but buildings that aren't economic to renovate are going to have to come down, and items such as windows will not be restored."
Mr. Langlois said much of the focus would be on the river views along the back of the building.
"Only a handful of people in Willimantic even know this view exists, so to open it up to public access is one of our top priorities," Mr. Langlois said. Among the accommodations planned are an outdoor stage area to seat 500 people for concerts, a boardwalk, and a restaurant overlooking the river.
EIGHT buildings are in such bad shape they will have to be demolished. And an arson fire June 10 destroyed a 400,000-square-foot building that probably could not have been saved anyway.
Windham Mills, which traces its roots to 1857, offers space at $3 per square foot a year, with minimum spaces of 1,000 square feet available for leasing. Two tenants, Temporaries of New England and Indar's Stair Company, have moved into a total of 3,000 square feet of office space.
While the price is competitive, it's hard to predict how leasing will progress. Because of a glut of space on the market right now -- some real estate brokers estimate the vacancy rate for commercial space to be as high as 50 percent in Windham not including the mill space -- it might be hard to attract tenants even at $3 a square foot.
"People who have a large quantity of space and are looking to fill it are offering it as low as $1 per foot, and even giving the first month free," said Joseph Underwood, a commercial real estate broker in Windham.
But Mr. Langlois said he was confident of his project's future. He is helping to arrange financing for two prospective tenants, and is in contact with several others.
"There's a lot of naysayers in town," Mr. Langlois said. "At first we were told we'd never get the money, then the roofs would never be done before winter, then we'd never get tenants. But slowly, the arguments are eroding. We got the money. The roofs are fixed. The tenants are starting to come in."

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 3; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1489 words

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Eugene C. Gavin;
A Second Tax Amnesty, Tough Love

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
EUGENE C. GAVIN, who was the Republican State Representative from Westport in 1993 and 1994, was appointed Commissioner of the Department of Revenue Services this year, responsible for 900 employees and a $47 million budget.
In his new job, Mr. Gavin is overseeing Connecticut's tax amnesty program, which seeks to raise $31 million in back taxes from people who have not filed returns, or have hidden income. 
 Mr. Gavin, a former director of state and local taxes for the Coopers & Lybrand accounting firm, discussed the tax amnesty program recently at his Hartford office. Following are excerpts from that conversation.
Q. Connecticut had a tax amnesty program five years ago. Is it a good idea to have a second one so soon?
A. I recommended to the Governor to have another tax amnesty program because we didn't have a personal income tax in 1990. We looked at the 34 states that have had a tax amnesty program and most of the applications were from personal, individual filers. Two-thirds of the revenues raised under those programs came in from individual filers.
Connecticut is the first to offer a second, full-blown tax amnesty program. I don't like to say never, but I really would be hard pressed to say when or if we should ever have another amnesty program.
Q. How well did the state do with the first amnesty?
A. We received about 10,000 applications. It was supposed to raise $10 million; it ended up at $55 million.
Q. Should the Federal government offer a tax amnesty?
A. The time is right. They believe 18 percent of the taxpaying public is not paying their fair share. That's a huge gap.
Q. Is there public support for a crackdown on tax cheats?
A. There was a national survey done recently that said the No. 1 priority of taxpayers was to have their state tax agencies go after taxpayers who aren't paying their fair share. People are sick and tired of subsidizing the tax cheats, the tax deadbeats, the tax outlaws. I believe that, too. I have to comply with all the laws you do, and I probably have to comply with them to a higher standard.
I don't want to hammer anybody without giving them a chance. Tax amnesty is going to give everyone the chance to come forward, without penalties, without fear of criminal or civil prosecution, maybe even get a reduced interest rate.
Q. Isn't the interest rate on unpaid taxes set by law?
A. Right now, for tax liabilities before July 1, 1995, you could pay up to 20 percent interest. That's very high. One of the initiatives of the department that was passed by the legislature was to apply a lower rate that is more in line with current interest rates. It's still too high, but it's down to 12 percent beginning July 1, 1995.
If your original liabilities were due in 1991 and 1992, that 12 percent versus 20 percent is a big incentive.
I justified giving that to people because when we have to go out and audit people, that costs money. Out of 900 employees, 300 are in the audit function. That costs taxpayers.
If people come forward, we haven't used one dollar of taxpayer money to find them. And if that person or business has been earning money in the state for three years and not paying taxes, we get a lot of money in 1995. But even more important, we get a continuing tax payment from then on in. It becomes an annuity.
Q. Has anyone studied how much the 1990 amnesty program added to the tax base?
A. The quick answer to that is no. And that's another reason I believe the second tax amnesty program is a good idea. In 1990 they did not keep statistics on the new taxpayers and what it meant on an ongoing basis. Obviously they were very pleased with the results, and maybe they were so ecstatic they overlooked a few things.
Also in 1990, they did not develop the profiles of people who came forward, and try to figure out how we missed them before. We're going to do that in 1995, I guarantee it.
Q. Isn't the campaign a little threatening, particularly the slogan "Make your move before we make ours" that you display in your office?
A. We're not trying to intimidate. We're giving you the opportunity to come forward, whether it's out of fear that we will find you -- and we will -- or out of conscience.
Q. Are people going to be afraid to come in and ask about amnesty?
A. If they're afraid to come to the department for help, there are other sources. Three organizations have agreed to give free advice, tax advice and assistance in completing amnesty applications. They are the Connecticut Society of Certified Public Accountants, the Connecticut Bar Association and the Connecticut Society of Enrolled Agents.
If people want to talk to the Department of Revenue Services, they can get the same advice without any fear of subsequent action by us by calling 800-321-7TAX, a toll-free number that provides answers on a completely confidential basis, and if you want to file an application they will be able to monitor it for you and give you its status at any time.
Q. Are people who are caught cheating on taxes going to be able to file an amnesty application?
A. The only people eligible for amnesty are those who are not under audit, and not under civil or criminal investigation.
Q. Are you relaxing enforcement at all during the amnesty program?
A. It's actually being stepped up a little bit. We've formed a discovery unit with about 25 people who have expertise in all the taxes in Connecticut. One of their first initiatives is they're going after professional athletes and entertainers who might come in for one night and earn $100,000. I estimate that will represent about $16 million for the four years covered by amnesty and about $4.5 million to $6 million a year from now on.
And that's only the first initiative. There are others that we will be starting during amnesty. That should give you more incentive to file for amnesty as soon as possible.
Q. Does a three-month amnesty encourage procrastination?
A. Almost two-thirds of the applications that come in are in the last three weeks of the program. But it's not a good idea to wait. If you think you have a problem in September you should file in September, because if you wait until November you're giving us another 60 or 70 days to contact you for an audit, and then you're not eligible.
Q. Is everyone who comes in going to be audited?
A. No, that would be unlikely. We have made the amnesty application program as simple as possible. We want it to be taxpayer friendly. But it is like any tax document you file. It is subject to audit, and you could be audited, so I encourage people to be as honest as possible.
Q. Will you be coordinating with other states and the Internal Revenue Service?
A. The I.R.S. is mad at Gene Gavin, because it would like Connecticut to turn over all the information we receive under tax amnesty. I said I am not going to do that. None of the information that comes in will go to other states or to the Internal Revenue Service.
The only exception will be if the I.R.S. asks me, "Do you have any information on XYZ Company?" If they identify who they want, I will provide them any information we have.
Q. The Federal government has a program that if you turn in a tax cheat you get a portion of whatever is collected. Would something like that make sense for Connecticut?
A. Amazingly enough, we get the calls for free. I understand it, I'm a human being. If you're paying your taxes, and you know your neighbor down the street is cutting his tax liability in half, maybe because he has a cash business or he's not registered with the state, you're going to want to turn him in.
Our second initiative, is going to target businesses that are paying their fair share of taxes and are upset because they know there are related businesses that are not. I'm going to level the playing field.
The other thing we're going to develop further is sharing information with other state agencies. The Department of Consumer Protection, the Department of Motor Vehicles, the Department of Environment Protection, the Liquor Commission -- every agency that issues any type of license. Some businesses license themselves with consumer protection and not with the tax department because in the past we didn't have the legislation or technical skills to do the matching. But if you register with any state agency, we're going to find you.
Q. Have you taken any steps to make sure your employees don't treat people like deadbeats?
A. During the amnesty program we want people to feel comfortable to come forward. I've instructed every one of my 900 employees to act accordingly, and if anyone has a problem with that, my number is 297-5650, and anyone can call me.
Anyone who comes forward, we're treating with kid gloves. The only caveat I want to add to that is we are stepping up audit activities and arrest activities, so I want you to come forward before that happens to you. Because it will happen.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Eugene C. Gavin, new Commissioner of the Department of Revenue Services. "Make your move before we make ours." (George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Chamber Plan Finances Small Business Loans

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
IN one of the first programs of its kind in the country, the Westchester County Chamber of Commerce this month began a $4.2 million privately capitalized loan program intended to help small businesses with start-up and expansion costs.
Initially, the program is being run in conjunction with seven banks but is expected to expand, said Harold E. Vogt, the chamber's president. He said he was receiving inquiries daily from other interested lending institutions. 
 "For years, the lament of small businesses has been about obtaining financing," Mr. Vogt said, explaining that banks tend to avoid business loans of $50,000 or less because they "require as much attention and paperwork as $5 million loans."
Under the Westchester Regional Small Business Loan Program, as it is being called, loans of $5,000 to $50,000 will be available to eligible small businesses through the banks, but the Chamber of Commerce will perform the administrative paperwork and screening tasks.
"We will cover those expenses instead of the banks," Mr. Vogt said, explaining that his organization will be hiring a loan administrator to help applicants develop business plans and fill out applications.
The County Chamber will work with the State Small Business Development Center to create the business plans, which Richard Feitelson, a spokesman for the center, likened to a road map.
The critical business plan, which is often required in loan application packages, "shows where you are, where you want to go and how you are going to get there," Mr. Feitelson said.
Loans will be be pre-approved and 90 percent guaranteed by the Small Business Administration. In addition, each participating bank will make available $200,000 a year for the program over a three-year period. Participating banks are Chase Manhattan and Chemical Bank, Key Bank, Marine Midland Bank, NatWest Bank, North Fork and Waterhouse Bank.
The Westchester County Chamber of Commerce loan program is being patterned after a pilot program started a year ago in Syracuse. That program has delivered 18 loans to small businesses, said Steven Cohen, president of the Westchester County Bankers Association.
Mr. Cohen observed that many well-known large companies like Federal Express and Microsoft were started with loans from the Small Business Administration.
Start-up consulting firms, financial services and food service companies are among the types of new businesses in the market today, Mr. Cohen said.
Observing that there are "a lot of talented people out on the street these days," he said that many new business owners are former bankers who became unemployed after bank mergers.
The loan program is intended to aid "a whole gamut of businesses," with purchases of equipment, expansions, new campaigns and other expenses, Mr. Vogt said.
Further details on the program are available at 948-2110. ELSA BRENNER

SECTION: Section 7; Page 15; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1454 words

HEADLINE: Why the Rich Get Richer

BYLINE: By Michael Lind; Michael Lind, a senior editor of The New Republic, is the author of "The Next American Nation."

 BODY:

THE WINNER-TAKE-ALL SOCIETY
How More and More Americans
Compete for Ever Fewer and Bigger
Prizes, Encouraging Economic Waste,
Income Inequality, and an
Impoverished Cultural Life.
By Robert H. Frank and Philip J. Cook.
272 pp. New York:
Martin Kessler Books/
The Free Press. $25. 
 WHAT do Boris Becker, Alan Dershowitz, Diane Sawyer, Michael Jordan, Elle Macpherson and John Grisham have in common? According to Robert H. Frank and Philip J. Cook, they are all beneficiaries of "winner-take-all markets," in which the top performers tend to monopolize pay and prestige, leaving little in the way of either gain or glory for the vast numbers of also-rans -- the equivalent of a third world in the professions, with a few wealthy oligarchs and a miserable majority.
The phenomenon is long familiar in industries organized around superstars. Mr. Frank, who teaches economics at Cornell University, and Mr. Cook, who is a professor of public policy at Duke University, contend in "The Winner-Take-All Society" that the star system is becoming common in many fields, at the cost not only of social equality but of long-term efficiency: "In effect, the reward structure common in entertainment and sports -- where thousands compete for a handful of big prizes at the top -- has now permeated many other sectors of the economy." In arguing that efficient markets may produce outcomes harmful to society, the authors challenge the conventional wisdom of both conservatives and neoliberals. It is a challenge that is particularly timely now that income inequality in the United States has reached proportions not seen since the Great Depression. "The incomes of the top 1 percent more than doubled in real terms between 1979 and 1989," they point out, "a period during which the median income was roughly stable and in which the bottom 20 percent of earners saw their incomes actually fall by 10 percent."
Mr. Frank and Mr. Cook reject the argument that inequality is increasing as a result of changes in "human capital," that is, "individual productivity and related qualities, including education, experience, unique talents, temperament, drive and intelligence." Human-capital theorists tend to attribute the growth of inequality to the failure of those at the bottom of the ladder to take advantage of opportunities, because of lack of training (Robert Reich) or genetic inferiority (Charles Murray). Citing Christopher Jencks's analysis in his 1972 book "Inequality," that differences in human capital account for no more than 15 percent of variations in income, Mr. Frank and Mr. Cook argue convincingly that slight changes in the distribution of talent cannot possibly explain the radical growth in inequality: "The winner-take-all perspective urges us to look first to the nature of the positions people hold, rather than to their personal characteristics."
To give only one example, the fact that the pay of a typical chief executive of a large American company is 120 times that of a manufacturing worker today, compared to a mere 35 times in 1974, is the result not of changes in the abilities of bosses and workers, but of the fact that companies now routinely raid one another for executives, thus bidding up their pay. In Germany and Japan, chief executives are promoted almost entirely from within, and have not experienced enormous pay increases. (Among other things, this fact gives the lie to those who excuse the overpayment of American executives by referring to "the globalization of the economy"; the key factor is the unique and peculiar structure of American corporate management.)
Until recently, conservatives have argued that the growth of income inequality is a statistical illusion. Now, intelligent conservatives, like David Frum, are taking a different tack: the increase in inequality is real, but since the main cause is the surge in incomes at the top, why complain? Mr. Frank and Mr. Cook offer an answer. The star system, in fields from law and corporate management to university teaching, is distorting American society by diverting talented young people into competitions that most will lose: "Our claim is that . . . market incentives typically lure too many contestants into winner-take-all markets, and too few into other careers," a point also made by Derek Bok in "The Cost of Talent" (1993). The most compelling example is the diversion of "our most able students" into finance and law in hopes of being the next George Soros or F. Lee Bailey. The free-marketeer's assumption that students will rationally calculate their chances of success in a given field is belied by what one psychologist has called "the Lake Wobegon Effect," after the Garrison Keillor town where "the men are good-looking and all the children are above average." As Mr. Frank and Mr. Cook note, "Winner-take-all markets attract too many contestants in part because of a common human frailty with respect to gambling -- namely, our tendency to overestimate our chances of winning"; they fear that hordes of young actors doomed to failure are being joined by wannabes in law, finance and journalism who might have succeeded and served society in other fields.
The least convincing part of "The Winner-Take-All Society" is the proposal to deter such "overcrowding" by means of higher taxes on superstars: by directing wannabes to alternative pursuits, "the effect of the tax is thus to reduce the cost of the winner-take-all tournament"; society need not worry about discouraging Pavarottis because "the people most likely to drop out would be those whose odds of making it into the winner's circle were smallest to begin with." There would be fewer starving artists and more comfortable engineers.
 IT is not at all clear, however, that "a more progressive tax structure would not reduce but actually increase economic efficiency." By Mr. Frank and Mr. Cook's own account, the greatest gains in winner-take-all markets have gone to top performers in already well-remunerated professions. Higher progressive taxation might make superstar lawyers less common, but as long as the average lawyer makes more than the average engineer, it would not encourage aspiring lawyers to go instead to engineering school (Mr. Frank and Mr. Cook do not discuss the possible effects of a tax on all lawyers).
The case for higher rates will have to rest on arguments more plausible than a deterrent effect on actors, Wall Street wizards and novelists who lack the talent to make it to the top. Another of the book's arguments is more persuasive, and just as likely to outrage the devotees of laissez-faire. It calls for "positional arms races" in professions that without special rules and customary inhibitions will degenerate into winner-take-all melees. Mr. Frank and Mr. Cook cite restraints on cutthroat competition in sports, like team roster limits, revenue sharing and pay caps that "prevent both large- and small-city franchise owners from getting into an all-out bidding war for one another's players." And they lament the destruction of the "positional arms control agreement" in higher education after the Justice Department charged Ivy League schools with antitrust violations because they colluded on their financial aid policies. Now that universities have been not merely allowed but forced to use financial aid to compete with one another for the brightest students, the authors predict, "financial aid will be captured disproportionately not by the students whose families most need it, but by the students with the highest grades and test scores."
Mr. Frank and Mr. Cook tend to make winner-take-all markets a one-size-fits-all explanation, and many readers will find some of their remedies worse than the disease. Nevertheless, "The Winner-Take-All Society" is a major contribution to the debate about the causes and consequences of inequality in America. "As today's young economists look back to the early years of the Great Depression, most are astonished to realize that, less than a lifetime ago, their predecessors thought that the cure for a stagnant economy was to reduce the supply of money," Mr. Frank and Mr. Cook write. "The problem of our time is not depression but the multiple evils of rising inequality, budget deficits and slow growth. Yet the quintessential conservative policy prescription of this era -- tax cuts for middle- and upper-income people -- is no more likely to cure these problems than monetary contraction was likely to cure the Great Depression." Mr. Frank and Mr. Cook have provided a timely reminder that the reward structure of the free market and the optimal incentive structure of an equitable, efficient society may not coincide at all.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 11; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 881 words

HEADLINE: Terminal City

BYLINE: By Paul Theroux; Paul Theroux's travel book "The Pillars of Hercules" will be published next month. He is a native of Medford, Mass.

 BODY:

HUDDLE FEVER
Living in the Immigrant City.
By Jeanne Schinto.
302 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf.
$24. 
 IN the course of this account of life in Lawrence, Mass., the author, Jeanne Schinto, remarks, "When it comes right down to it, where you will be happy living depends on where you are most comfortable; not where you belong according to some 'rule' about work or class, but where you feel you belong -- which is usually the place where you feel free to be yourself."
That rambling, clumsy, good-hearted sentence gives an accurate flavor of the book, which is also chatty, anecdotal to the point of being gossipy and given to the well-intentioned cliche as well as the muddled summary. It is also premature, because things change, places change, people come and go. As for cities, some are hopeless. That is also the subtext of the book. At one time such personal accounts of closely observed residence would be concerned with distant cities: "Rangoon Jottings," "Ten Years in Khartoum," "A Decade in Bangkok." Yet Lawrence is just that sort of city -- a remote, bereft, rotting and blighted place that was once prosperous and proud. Its social structure was complex in an Asian way even before the Vietnamese displaced the Irish.
After years of living on the periphery of middle-class life in Greenwich, Conn., and Washington, Ms. Schinto went to Lawrence because her husband, Bob Frishman, needed to supervise his family's furniture business. But this was much more than a relocation. The move was cultural outreach of a bold kind, for the couple made a deliberate decision to buy an old house in Lawrence and live in this now-decrepit city in the hope that the street and the town would rise again. An alternative would have been to commute the short distance from Andover. But Andover was no challenge at all. Well organized, tidy, prettily painted, a buffed-up and well-appointed antique with a colonial pedigree, and also the site of a distinguished school, Andover is consequently snobbish, preppy, fastidious, racially and culturally monochrome and insufferable. "Known for its urban blight," Lawrence, right next door ("a city of old Italians and young Latinos"), became home for the couple.
"Huddle Fever," the story of Ms. Schinto's 10 years in Lawrence, is an unclassifiable and somewhat garrulous chronicle that deals in sociology, local history and politics, the rise and fall of American manufacturing, the unpredictability of neighbors and the paradoxes of American immigration. It is no help to Lawrence's dignity that Robert Frost was a Lawrence High School grad (valedictorian of the class of 1892), or that Leonard Bernstein grew up there. This is overshadowed by Willie Horton, who committed his 1974 murder there, and by the city's high unemployment and even higher percentage of welfare cases. Once the Irish and Italians went to Lawrence to work in its clothing mills, the city became, by 1911, "the cloth-making capital of the world, easily surpassing two of its early-day rivals -- Manchester, N.H., and Manchester, England -- combined." Latterly, new immigrants have gone to Lawrence from Puerto Rico and Cambodia and Vietnam -- as well as from other cul-de-sacs in Massachusetts -- to sign on for free welfare money.
As the city lost its grip on manufacturing, it went downhill, and the gigantic mills became derelict. Ms. Schinto's history of Lawrence's luminaries and declining fortunes, drawn from earlier, academic scholarship, shows the author's indignation and sadness. She sketches the history of the town fathers, of Billy Wood's famous textile operation, the American Woolen Company, and the important contradictions of Roman Catholicism in Lawrence. But it remains a book that makes up in feeling what it lacks in design or fluency; it would have profited by being more rigorous. Ms. Schinto describes the experiences of her friends and acquaintances, but in sentences like "Terri Kelley says a Vietnamese girl told her" (a story of prejudice), she cannot adequately convey the larger picture of a town of new immigrants with a terminal disease, where it is easier to get on welfare than get a job.
 WHEN a city is viable, as Lawrence was, and offers work to people and a fair day's pay, there is a sense of community in spite of the ethnic differences. Working people learn to rub along together. In the absence of work, there is despair and foolishness and waste. The best intentions cannot change that. But despair is not the thesis of this book, which is, ultimately, not the tale of a ruined city but of the experience of living in it. It is awkwardly, unapologetically personal. This is the story of two good people, Ms. Schinto, a novelist and anthologist, and her husband, who ran unsuccessfully for Lawrence's City Council. Their residence was an altruistic experiment, and like many other altruistic experiments it ended in disappointment, confusion, alarm and flight. The town they hoped would improve just got worse; the street they hoped would rise fell into decay and became the haunt of arsonists and drug dealers. In the end the hopeful couple move the few miles to Andover, and, almost against their will, they quite like it. Perhaps Ms. Schinto will write a similar book about smug little Andover.

GRAPHIC: Drawing

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: The Good Old Days Are Now

BYLINE: By Rebecca Pepper Sinkler; Rebecca Pepper Sinkler, a former editor of The New York Times Book Review, is working on a family memoir set in the early years of the century.

 BODY:

COMING OF AGE
The Story of Our Century by Those Who've Lived It.
By Studs Terkel.
468 pp. New York:
The New Press. $25. 
 LATELY there's been a slew of books on getting old. That figures. We're a nation of narcissists and more of us are living longer. More aging navels, more aged gazers. Studs Terkel, who has made a life's work of chatting with celebrities and plain folks for a Chicago radio program, has also published books of oral history every few years. "Working" (1974) was his first, followed by others on race, World War II, which he labeled "The Good War," the Great Depression and the fate of the American dream. Now in his own 80's, he has conducted and collected interviews with some 70 men and women who have logged their biblical threescore years and ten or more.
But don't let the title "Coming of Age: The Story of Our Century by Those Who've Lived It," or the label "oral history," fool you into expecting some kind of broad, inclusive overview. The people interviewed for "Coming of Age," though diverse in their life histories, are an inordinately like-minded crowd, and the language spoken here is pure Terkel: the voice of the embattled old liberal shaking his stick at the 20th century.
If you don't fancy sitting in on the last meeting of the Norman Thomas fan club, you will probably bypass this book. Mr. Terkel may even expect that: he's been preaching to the choir so long he may not care about the sinners. Even his footnotes, often quoting from his own work, tend to multiply examples and emphasize opinions rather than elucidate obscurities. To be sure, he makes a token stab at including conservatives -- an investment banker here, a once powerful lawyer there, even one self-confessed Republican. But if you had a buck for everyone here who snarls at Ronald Reagan and George Bush, you'd have enough to send a nice contribution to your favorite political action committee.
If many readers are put off by such politics, it will be too bad because these grayheads (as the author calls them) are great fun to listen to and their stories, if not startling, are instructive. For those who have never heard an account of the 1937 strike against General Motors' Fisher Body Division in Flint, Mich., Genora Johnson Dollinger, 80, recalls the event in spirited detail -- company goons, tear gas, bloodied heads. "Our society is set up in such a way that we don't rely on the memory of old people," says Hazel Wolf, 95, whose own vivid memories include growing up as a daughter of a Wobbly, becoming a Communist in the 1930's, being jailed for a day in the McCarthy-era 1950's (accused, absurdly, of attempting to overthrow the Government by force), working as a legal secretary and living happily for the past three decades on Social Security and a rent subsidy. She still has enough juice in her batteries to make speeches and pester politicians on behalf of her favorite causes (labor, the environment, women's issues). To recharge, she camps out: "I have a little tent, a sleeping bag and a little pad," which she takes to the woods, she explains to her no doubt startled interviewer, as if this were the normal run of affairs for nonagenarians.
Not all the interviewees are as inspirational, but most are personally admirable. Almost no one gripes about isolation, pain or the limited resources that are the lot of many very old people. In fact, you have to read this volume in small doses for fear of choking on all the earnest good cheer, courage in the face of adversity, acceptance of mortality balanced with a cussed determination to keep fighting the good fight. (Though most of these folks deplore the competitiveness of American life, they are not about to let anyone get the better of them, including the old man with the scythe.)
For anyone over the age of 70, the minimum age of the interview subjects, there is a risk that these tales will be not inspiring but depressing: compare yourself -- at any age -- to "slim," "perky," "bustling" Alice McGrath, a former labor organizer, who reports that her 75th birthday party gathered "bankers, progressives, Chicanos, old friends, the whole bunch." "The newspapers were saying how wonderful I am," she said.
You can't help agreeing, of course. Who would fault a woman still angered by the world's injustices, still full of spit and vinegar, still ranting at her Jacuzzi-mates about racism, homelessness, poverty, the folly of the Cuban embargo? But by the time you finish reading about this paragon, you wish Mr. Terkel had played her off against a mere mortal, someone like George Jameson, the 102-year-old codger who was interviewed in a British newspaper last month. Old George takes life a little less seriously, reveling in his pint of bitter in the morning, his lunchtime stop at the local for another pint, his jam sponge at teatime, his stiff Scotch before dinner, his favorite sitcoms, "a little cuddle" from his wife at bedtime and the glass of brandy and milk on his bedside table in case he wakes during the night.
Sure, Studs Terkel aims higher than the old-codger interview. All his protagonists have made their marks, whether famously -- like the economist John Kenneth Galbraith, interviewed at 85; the jazz bassist Milt Hinton, 83; the actress Uta Hagen, 75; Marvin Miller, 72, the first head of the baseball players' union -- or more quietly, like the teachers, doctors, nurses, policemen, lawyers, public servants and organizers who labored in obscurity. But though he may aim high, Mr. Terkel's interviews don't soar. He seems to have asked all his subjects a series of unimaginative questions: on their childhoods, mentors, turning points in their lives, regrets (if any), their commitments to their community, feelings about technology, health care, hopes for the next generation, for the future of the race, their religious beliefs, how they would like to be remembered, etc.
Maybe because the questions are so relentlessly pedestrian, they elicit banal answers. Many childhoods were poor but happy. Some of the people were born rich, but most have achieved compassion. Some fear technology, some embrace it, all warn of its dangers. The Depression looms large, though for most it is remembered almost fondly, and for some there's a hint of nostalgia, even a wish for a return to the good old days of unemployment and labor unrest. The powerful drop names, the religious praise God, even the atheists are pious.
The century's wars, the great strikes of the 1930's, the McCarthy era, the corrupting influence of television, the selfishness (or generosity) of the young: all prove springboards, sadly, more for opinion and generalization than for real storytelling. There's little poetry.
But there are notable exceptions. Amid the treacle there's the mean old German lady whose first sentence is "We were very important people in Berlin," and who goes on to vent resentment, bigotry and a mesmerizing rage for seven hard-hearted pages. And then there are the delightful yarns of Robert St. John, 92, who as a young reporter covered the Lindbergh kidnapping, the mob and one of Roosevelt's Presidential campaigns. He "retired" from newspapering at 30; then, by a series of flukes, he got sucked back by World War II into spot reporting and broadcasting, was blacklisted in the 50's, still writes and lectures (and still knows how to tell a great story) and delivers a highly politically incorrect prescription for living to an obstinate old age.
ONE of the longest interviews is also one of the strongest -- a talk with John Gofman, 76, one of the all too few scientists included, considering that this is a century that has been shaped by science. Dr. Gofman, a whistle-blowing chemist, physician and antinuclear activist, is just one of the angry old prophets gathered here who will not go gentle into anyone's night. In fact, his visions of decay and disease are enough to give us all bad dreams.
And occasionally, the language and imagery in other interviews is inspired. Bessie Doenges, 93, a columnist for a Manhattan neighborhood weekly, describes the daily exhaustion of the aged as evening comes on: "Then it's 8 o'clock and I fight sleep, damn it all. I fight it with everything I've got! I don't want to go to bed, life's too short. Actually, I sleep 12 hours or maybe 14. Sleep is my last lover. I don't want it, but there you have it. . . . I accept it with grace. What else can I do?"
What else indeed? These interviews will find an audience, and there will be more such to come. Two of Mr. Terkel's informants are writing their own books: one will be called "Waiting to Die," the other "Aging Well and Dying Well." Until then, "Coming of Age" gives us a glimpse of a stage of life we all look forward to eagerly, considering the alternative.
