LENGTH: 1503 words

HEADLINE: Color-Blind in the Marketplace

BYLINE: By Richard Rorty; Richard Rorty teaches philosophy at the University of Virginia.

 BODY:

THE END OF RACISM
Principles for a Multiracial Society.
By Dinesh D'Souza.
724 pp. New York:
The Free Press. $30 
 DINESH D'SOUZA, a research fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, a leading conservative think tank, believes that one of the biggest obstacles facing African-Americans today is liberalism. Whenever black people do anything wrong, liberals are quick to excuse their behavior. This makes it harder for young blacks to pull up their socks, do their homework and get jobs. "Today the most formidable ideological barrier facing blacks," Mr. D'Souza says, "is not racism but antiracism."
Mr. D'Souza sees liberals as cultural relativists -- people who infer, from the mistaken premise that every culture is as good as every other, that the crime-ridden, drug-infested culture of the ghetto is just as good as that of the white suburbs. "Relativism has now imprisoned liberals in an iron cage that prevents them from acknowledging black pathology," he writes. "This explains the interminable liberal rhetoric about the 'root causes' of poverty, the 'bitter hoax' of the American dream, the mysterious disappearance of 'meaningful' jobs, the prospect of a 'resurgence' of 'hate,' the danger of 'imposing one's morality.' " If it were not for the insidious influence of cultural relativism, defenders of affirmative action (like this reviewer, who is a card-carrying liberal) might give up "the unquestioned assumption of contemporary liberalism" that "racism is responsible for black failure, and that given the persistence of racism in society, there is no alternative to institutionalizing race as the basis of job hiring, voting, law and education."
Having abandoned this assumption, we liberals might then come to agree with Mr. D'Souza that we should never have assumed that "segregation was a system established by white racists for the purpose of oppressing blacks." We might cease to believe that "the civil rights movement represented a triumph of justice and enlightenment over the forces of Southern racism and hate." Such beliefs are largely due, Mr. D'Souza thinks, to the adoption of "Boas ian assumptions." He treats the anthropologist Franz Boas (1858-1942) as the founding guru of cultural relativism, and claims that Boas exerted a bad influence on both W. E. B. Du Bois and Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Black leaders might have understood segregation better had they not held, as Mr. D'Souza says King did, "the Boasian proposition that inequality between whites and blacks is not natural but the conventional product of past and continuing discrimination."
"History shows," Mr. D'Souza tells us, "that the principles of the civil rights movement developed as a direct outgrowth of cultural relativism." This led the movement to misconstrue both the purpose and effects of segregation: "It correctly targeted discrimination, but wrongly construed private individuals and companies, rather than government, as the primary threat to black prospects." Its leaders did not notice the hardship that segregation laws imposed on, for example, the streetcar companies, which were forced to buy extra equipment. So they did not see that segregation "represented a triumph of government regulation over the free market." They also failed to grasp that although there was a "vicious racist backlash" after Reconstruction, this "was over by the 1920's," and that segregation "represented a compromise on the part of the Southern ruling elite seeking, in part, to protect blacks."
The fatal influence of cultural relativism reached right up to the Supreme Court. For in citing social scientists in Brown v. Board of Education on the destructive effects on black children of segregated schools, "the Court's exaltation of the 'feeling' of inequality reflected the subjectivity of Boasian relativism: to be unequal is to be perceived as unequal." As Mr. D'Souza sees it, in holding that separate schools are inherently unequal, the Warren Court took the first step down the road that led from desirable color-blindness to undesirable affirmative action programs.
Mr. D'Souza is cheered that some African-Americans now agree with him that "if blacks can close the civilization gap, the race problem in this country is likely to become insignificant." But, he claims, "the mainstream of black intellectuals simply refuses to criticize African-American pathologies or to seek internal reform." People like William Julius Wilson, who in "The Truly Disadvantaged" traces the ghettos back to black unemployment, are, Mr. D'Souza believes, pretty well unredeemable. "In Wilson's view," Mr. D'Souza says sardonically, "blacks just happened to arrive in the cities around the time that unskilled jobs were leaving"; Mr. Wilson cannot admit that the shortage of jobs is caused by the civilization gap, rather than vice versa.
If Mr. D'Souza's story is right, white Americans can relax. Their ancestors may have treated blacks harshly, but that was a long time ago. Racism is a thing of the past, for (Mr. D'Souza asks) "if white racism controls the destiny of blacks today, how has one segment of the black community prospered so much over the past generation, while the condition of the black underclass has deteriorated?" We liberals are inclined to respond that one reason that one segment of the black community has prospered is that affirmative action worked. Even though we wonder whether affirmative action programs still command enough public support to be viable, we agree with Cornel West that "given the history of this country, it is a virtual certainty that without affirmative action racial and sexual discrimination will return with a vengeance." We accept Mr. Wilson's explanation of why the condition of the black underclass has deteriorated: its members are surplus to the requirements of the national labor market.
 MR. D'SOUZA is right that there is a "civilization gap" between ghetto and suburb, and that distrust of black ghetto teen-agers can be viewed as rational because it's based on culture rather than race. But does he really believe that they will get jobs if they develop better habits? That the "last hired, first fired" pattern of employment had nothing to do with the transformation of our inner cities since World War II? Does he really think that Mr. Wilson's detailed and careful historical account is just cultural relativist mythmaking?
It is hard to say whether he does, because his book contains so little argument, so little genuine debate with his opponents. "The End of Racism" is bloated with quotations and anecdotes, but has virtually no argumentative structure. There is no cumulation of results from chapter to chapter, only an increasingly self-confident reiteration of the same slogans. Writers like Mr. West and Mr. Wilson are quoted only to be waved aside, sneered at as intellectually and morally bankrupt liberals. Mr. D'Souza's contempt for those who disagree with him is so great that he cannot take their concerns seriously.
The only analytic tool Mr. D'Souza uses is his idee fixe, cultural relativism. But Franz Boas was not the simpleton Mr. D'Souza makes him out to be, and few liberals hold the absurd dogma that all cultures are on a moral par. What makes us liberals doubt that it is up to blacks to close the civilization gap is not a philosophical dogma but the plausible, empirical claim that there will always be a civilization gap between people with hope and people without it, people who know they have a chance in life and people who know they do not.
It is, alas, true that liberals who work in multicultural education, and in the "diversity" industry, often do make cultural-relativist noises. Mr. D'Souza, whose previous book was "Illiberal Education," wants to use these noises as evidence for the bankruptcy of all liberal ideas. But he barely tries to defend his startling claim that "the principles of the civil rights movement developed as a direct outgrowth of cultural relativism." The civil rights movement was an expression of naked moral outrage at unnecessary human suffering. It was the great, inspiring moral event of our lifetime: the moment at which our country showed that it was still capable of moral progress and of a national moral identity. The idea that it was somehow based on false philosophical principles is weird. Mr. D'Souza's tone of lofty intellectual condescension toward men like Du Bois and King is very hard to take.
Until conservatives stop talking about philosophical principles and start talking about the causes of suffering, and until they start offering more plausible proposals for relief than "let the blacks civilize themselves" and "end dependency on big government," they will not contribute much to American public life. Conceivably somebody could make a case for the claim that white Americans are now entitled to relax, go color-blind, and let the African-Americans rebuild their culture on their own. Mr. D'Souza has not even begun to make it.

LENGTH: 1168 words

HEADLINE: More Casinos, More Players Who Bet Until They Lose All

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: DAVENPORT, Iowa

 BODY:
Down to her last dollar, Linda Edwards bet it on the slot machine and felt sick to her stomach as it vanished, like the $75,000 that had gone before.
Since the riverboat casino opened here four years ago, Ms. Edwards, a 46-year-old factory worker, has squandered her retirement account, taken out three loans and borrowed to the hilt against two credit cards. "It takes hold of you," said Ms. Edwards, who has a teen-age daughter at home. "I had thoughts of suicide."
Gambling, the fastest-growing industry in America, has spread like prairie fire across Iowa, a state that did not even have a lottery until 1985 and now has 10 big casinos, not counting the horse track in Altoona and the dog track in Council Bluffs, both of which have 24-hour slot machines. 
 No longer does the state impose a maximum loss of $200 a day for each player on the riverboats. Now there are no limits, and some card games are as high as $1,000 a hand. It is an astonishing metamorphosis of Midwestern mores: It was in Dubuque during the 1970's that a Roman Catholic priest went to jail on bingo charges, and now nearly 9 of 10 Iowans say they gamble, a recent survey found.
And in a statistic that has caused some alarm in the state, 5.4 percent of Iowans reported a gambling problem, up from 1.7 percent in 1989.
"You ask around, and just about everyone now knows somebody with a gambling problem," said Tom Fennelly, a state counselor who works with Gamblers Anonymous here, which has twice needed to move into bigger quarters recently.
Among the 24 recovering gamblers who gathered for support in a former law office in downtown Davenport, more than $200,000 had been lost aboard the riverboat casino a few blocks away, where Main Street crosses the Mississippi River. Six of them had gone bankrupt.
Meetings of problem gamblers are springing up here and throughout the nation, especially in the smaller cities and towns that had been isolated from casinos until the last few years.
For some gamblers, the chase for a big jackpot has ruined more than just bank accounts. Jason Berg, a 19-year-old from the little Iowa town of Elkander, ended his life in June after running up a big gambling loss, leaving a note that read simply, "I'm out of control."
Philip Marshall, 51, shot himself in August after losing a bundle at the Catfish Bend riverboat casino in Fort Madison. And in Illinois, a 41-year-old suburban salesman, Howard Russell, shot himself in the parking lot of the Grand Victoria Casino in Elgin last fall, after losing more than $50,000. When the police found him, he had $13 in his pockets.
Gambling is a $40 billion business that draws more customers than baseball parks or movie theaters. Besides providing an estimated 1 million jobs, gambling has also been a politically painless way to raise tax revenue: casinos alone paid $1.4 billion in state and local taxes last year.
The cost in human misery -- the lost homes, the broken marriages, the neglected children -- are difficult to calculate. But with gambling growing at a breakneck pace, experts say, the problems are surely keeping pace.
John Kindt, a professor of commerce at the University of Illinois in Champaign-Urbana, who has studied gambling, estimates that for every dollar that states take in from gambling, they pay three dollars in costs, for social agencies and the criminal justice system.
By the most conservative estimates, he said, a problem gambler costs society an average of $13,000 a year in lost work, incarceration, neglected children and other problems.
Bills have been sponsored in both houses of Congress to establish a commission that would study the impact of gambling. One sponsor, Senator Richard G. Lugar, a Republican who is seeking the Presidential nomination, told the Christian Coalition in a recent speech that gambling was having a corrosive effect on the nation's fabric.
Senator Paul Simon, an Illinois Democrat who is also a sponsor of the bill, told his colleagues recently, "What should not be ignored by Congress and the American people is that we have a problem on our hands."
The move for a commission has been strongly opposed by gambling interests. Frank Fahrenkopf Jr., the former Republican Party chairman who is now the chief lobbyist for the nation's casinos, wrote a letter to Mr. Simon in which he acknowledged problem gambling but said the industry was already "taking aggressive steps to deal with this problem."
Here in the Quad Cities, an area that has been called the "Detroit of the Farm Belt" for the presence of John Deere and other farm machinery companies, gambling was seen as a way to revive an economy devastated by the loss of 20,000 jobs during the collapse of the farm economy in the 1980's. Unemployment had soared into the upper teens, and some idled workers who were unable to pay mortgages simply left town.
Today, unemployment is down around 3 percent, but it is unclear how much of that is attributable to gambling. The riverboat casinos were promoted to voters here, in large part, as a way to bring money in from other regions. At first, busloads of Chicagoans came to the boats to gamble. Later, there was competition from casinos on Indian land.
But now that casino boats have opened in the Chicago suburbs, gamblers there no longer need to come all the way to Iowa, and few do.
The typical gambler now is not a tourist but someone like Sue Jackson, a 50-year-old Davenport housewife, who sat before a $1 slot machine the other day and lamented that she was "not having any darned luck at all."
Mrs. Jackson, who started on the nickel slots and then moved up to the quarter machines before graduating to the dollar slots, said she had initially opposed riverboat gambling because she believed that it would cause problems for some people.
And for her? "Oh yeah," she said, "it sure could."
Mr. Fennelly, the gambling counselor, went to prison in the 1970's for running a sports betting operation. He said most people finally went for help when they did something their conscience could not abide, like stealing or lying to get money. He told of one woman who had resorted to prostitution to get money for gambling.
In some ways, gamblers are even more reluctant to seek help than people with alcohol or drug problems, fearful that they will lose their jobs if they are found out, experts say.
"You can imagine having a job with access to money, say, as an accountant," Mr. Fennelly said, "and the boss finds out you've got a gambling problem."
A decade ago, he said, men outnumbered women at least 20 to 1 among problem gamblers. "Women tend to find the racetracks a bit seedy, and they don't usually get into sports betting with a bookie," he said.
But the emergence of casinos, which tend to be pleasant, upbeat places, has changed all that. Now, women make up about half of the people in the Gamblers Anonymous meetings here.
One of them is Mrs. Edwards, the woman who gambled away $75,000. "I've been clean since March," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Legalized gambling, the nation's fastest-growing industry, has spread quickly through Iowa, where nearly 9 out of 10 people say they gamble, and concern is growing over problem gamblers. People recently flocked to a riverboat casino in Davenport, Iowa, to play 25-cent roulette. (Rick Cinclair for The New York Times) (pg. A10)

HEADLINE: Congressman Heads to Trial In California

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE 

DATELINE: COMPTON, Calif., Sept. 24

 BODY:
In an unusual prelude to the extortion trial of Representative Walter R. Tucker 3d, lawyers asked prospective jurors whether they believed black politicians were targets for "takedown" by the Federal Government more often than their white counterparts.
The question is at the heart of Mr. Tucker's contention that as a black man representing a Congressional district with one of the largest black populations in the nation, he is the victim of overzealous white prosecutors. Jury selection was completed last week, and the trial is expected to begin in earnest on Monday. 
 Prosecutors have said they have thousands of documents and many hours of clandestine videotape and audiotape evidence that show the 38-year-old, second-term Democrat taking $37,500 in bribes and soliciting another $250,000 in kickbacks from two waste disposal companies while he was the Mayor of Compton. Compton is the largest city in Mr. Tucker's district, which encompasses industrial suburbs south of Los Angeles.
If convicted on all counts, he could be sent to prison for up to 246 years and fined as much as $2.7 million.
The often technical financial aspects of the case have been overshadowed by emotionally fraught legal, political and racial issues. Mr. Tucker, a lawyer and Baptist minister trained at Princeton and Georgetown Universities, is the youngest member of a powerful political dynasty, a family that has been described as the "Kennedys of Compton."
From the start, he has said the prosecution was the result of bias.
"Look at the list," Mr. Tucker told reporters recently on the front steps of the Federal courthouse in Los Angeles. "There was Marion Barry before me. There was O. J. Simpson before me. There was Mike Tyson and Mike Jackson. You may as well call me Mike Tucker."
In response to questions suggesting that some people might interpret the Government's efforts as an attempt to bring down a black official, the chief prosecutor in the case, Nora M. Manella, recently told reporters that her office was "an equal opportunity prosecutor."
In any event, Mr. Tucker's statement that black politicians are targets of unfair prosecution resonates powerfully in this predominantly black city of about 92,000, where he and his family have long commanded respect for championing black causes and for building a potent political machine. Mr. Tucker's father was a former school board member and Councilman who served as Mayor until his death in 1990.
The extent of that power was evident earlier this month outside the courthouse, where Tucker supporters, who include local businessmen and ministers, carried placards saying "Stop Racism" and "Witch Hunt."
The case has attracted not only local but also national attention because of what some blacks see as a pattern of the predominantly white Federal law-enforcement establishment spending time and money prosecuting cases against blacks and members of other minority groups that it might not have pursued against white leaders.
Going back to Adam Clayton Powell Jr., the revered Harlem Congressman who was indicted on charges of tax evasion more than three decades ago, there have been 6 blacks among the 70 members of Congress indicted, according to the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a Washington research organization. In other words, about 9 percent of those indicted have been black.
And when Hispanic members of Congress are included, the figure rises to about 15 percent -- in a period when the number of black and Hispanic members of Congress accounted for less than 5 percent of all lawmakers.
Of the black Congressmen, Charles Diggs of Michigan and Mel Reynolds of Chicago were convicted, but the other three, Representatives Harold Ford of Tennessee, Floyd H. Flake of New York and Mr. Powell, were either acquitted or set free after a hung jury.
"Historically, African-Americans have had reason to question the criminal justice system," said Leo Terrell, a black civil rights lawyer in Beverly Hills, Calif. "So it is always reasonable to at least raise the racism issue."
Royce W. Esters, president of the Compton chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, agreed. "They are targeting Compton because there are a lot of black people here," he said. "Every time there is a black person in a high place they try to get them."
Prosecutors will not comment on the evidence they plan to present. But court documents indicate that the investigation videotaped meetings in which Mr. Tucker appeared to take money from an undercover agent with the understanding that he would put certain items on the Compton City Council agenda.
Mr. Tucker and his lawyer have yet to offer any evidence that Federal officials are motivated by racism, except to loudly and repeatedly declare that they know it is true.
"I think that the case will show that I have been targeted, and I am obviously an African-American," Mr. Tucker said in an interview, kneading the air with his fingers. "I can tell you that based on the information I have, the city of Compton, over the years, over the last decade, has been targeted, and the city obviously is one associated with African-American leadership."
He talked at a table in his spacious office in a shopping center here. Hanging on the crowded walls were plaques from civic and political groups praising his community spirit and achievements. Renowned locally as an animated, charismatic speaker, Mr. Tucker was uncharacteristically subdued.
And then, lapsing into the language of the pulpit, Mr. Tucker added: "Even though my enemies have meant this for evil, God has used it for good, and it has strengthened me, it has made me stronger in the Lord. It's made me stronger in my resolve about what my life has meant."
This is not the first time Mr. Tucker has been charged with a crime while in government. An assistant district attorney from 1984 to 1986, he was dismissed after changing the date on a photograph being used as evidence in a narcotics case, reportedly in an attempt to cover up the fact that he had withheld the pictures from the defense. Accused of altering an official document and lying to a judge, he pleaded no contest to misdemeanor charges and did not serve any time in prison.
Despite the tampering charge, Mr. Tucker's political career flourished. In 1991 he was elected Mayor of Compton, succeeding his father. A year later Mr. Tucker survived a bitter Democratic primary fight and was easily elected to Congress. He was re-elected last year.
But Mr. Tucker's rise coincided with a series of scandals. In 1993, Compton became the only school district ever certified by the state as an academic and financial disaster. At about the same time, Patricia Moore, a Tucker family ally and one of the city's most prominent politicians, was indicted on Federal bribery charges.
In recent weeks, the United States Attorney's office appears to have intensified its investigation of city politics. On Aug. 29, Joseph Scraggins, a former owner of a Compton-based construction company, pleaded guilty to conspiring with Mr. Tucker to extort money from a business trying to build a waste-to-energy plant in Compton. Mr. Scraggins also pleaded guilty to filing a false Federal income tax return. Lawyers for Mr. Scraggins have said he would testify at the Tucker trial if subpoenaed.
Three days later, in a potentially even bigger blow to Mr. Tucker's case, Ms. Moore was charged again with bribery. One company from which Ms. Moore is charged with extorting money is Compton Energy Systems, the same business named in Mr. Tucker's case.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST ACCORD: THE OVERVIEW;
ISRAEL AND P.L.O. REACH ACCORD TO TRANSFER WEST BANK AREAS

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Sept. 24

 BODY:
After months of arduous negotiations and a tense last-minute flurry of crises and walkouts, Israel and the Palestinians concluded a major agreement today on transferring control of much of the occupied West Bank to its Arab residents.
With only two and a half hours left before Israel shut down for the celebration of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, the Israeli Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, and the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yasir Arafat, finally initialed the 400-page document. The major obstacle they had ovecome was the security arrangements for Hebron, where Jewish settlers live surrounded by Arab residents. 
 Mr. Peres and Mr. Arafat approved the agreement in a brief ceremony this afternoon in Taba, Egypt, a Red Sea resort where the final negotiations took place.
The initialing cleared the way for the agreement to be approved by the Israeli Cabinet on Wednesday, and to be formally signed in a much-postponed ceremony at the White House on Thursday with President Clinton and the leaders of Egypt and Jordan in attendance.
The accord, which capped marathon and often tempestuous negotiations, spells out in detail, step by step and town by town, the withdrawal of Israeli forces from much of the territory Israel has occupied since the 1967 war and the transfer of extensive governing authority to an elected Palestinian Council until a final separation is negotiated by the turn of the century.
Mr. Peres, his voice breaking at moments, said at the ceremony today: "Ladies and gentlemen, let's face it, what we are doing today is not a normal political or economic enterprise; it is history in the real meaning of the word.
"On our side there are many mothers and fathers and children who suffered tremendously, and on the Palestinian side, too, there are many people who paid with their lives, their fortunes, their freedom, and I really feel the Lord has offered us a real opportunity to change the course of hopelessness and desperation and bloodshed into something more promising, more noble, more humane."
Mr. Arafat was somewhat less conciliatory, saying: "On this occasion and from this place I would like to speak to our prisoners, to those who were injured, with greetings, and I assure them that the dawn of freedom is coming. I also greet the families of our martyrs."
His comments were certain to raise the hackles of the Israeli right, since the people the Palestinians call "martyrs" the Israelis call "terrorists."
But the P.L.O. leader, whose name and trademark head covering were synonymous with terrorism only a scant two years ago, also wished the Israelis a happy New Year in Hebrew, "Shanah Tovah," and expressed the hope that the coming year would be a time of real peace between "people of the area."
The agreement came under almost immediate attack from opposition forces on both sides.
"This is a bad agreement for which Israel will pay a heavy price," the conservative Likud Party bloc said in Israel.
In Hebron, which had caused so much strife for negotiators, the Palestinian Mayor, Mustafa Natshe, said the agreement "does not meet the expectations of the people."
Militant Israeli settlers in Hebron vowed to block the agreement from being put into effect.
Inside Israel, the two-day observance of the High Holy Days precluded mass protests. But after that, warned a longtime political commentator, "fasten your seat belt."
Mr. Peres and Mr. Arafat, however, were obviously elated and even emotional at the 20-minute televised ceremony. They had put in about 80 hours of direct negotiations, and spent almost every night of the last week working together in an atmosphere of crisis and suspense.
Hours before the initialing, Mr. Arafat stormed out, shouting, "We are not slaves!" It was the second time he erupted and walked out, and once again he was enticed back to the bargaining table by telephoned appeals from President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and the chief American mediator, Dennis B. Ross.
The accord is the second stage of the process that began when Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and Mr. Arafat shook hands on the White House lawn on Sept. 13, 1993. The "Declaration of Principles" they issued then ended 26 years of total estrangement and set a timetable for a permanent disengagement of Arabs and Israelis in the Palestinian lands by the end of the century.
The first stage, initiated in May 1994, established Palestinian self-rule in the Gaza Strip and in Jericho in the West Bank. The final stage, which is to begin in May 1996, will be the "permanent-status negotiations" over the fate of Jerusalem, Arab refugees, Jewish settlements and security arrangements.
In many respects, today's agreement was far more complex and politically volatile than the Declaration of Principles, which established only broad and often contradictory guidelines for disengaging two peoples with competing religious, legal and historic claims to the same small patch of land and a history of bloodshed, terror and humiliation.
Immediately after the ceremony, Mr. Arafat departed for Cairo and a tour of Arab capitals, presumably to discuss the agreement, which will not be made public in full until it gets the expected stamp of approval from the Israeli Cabinet.
Within 10 days of the signing, the Israeli Army will begin withdrawing from the population centers of the West Bank -- Jenin, Nablus, Tulkarm, Qalqilya, Ramallah and Bethlehem, as well as 450 towns and villages -- and turning security over to a 12,000-member Palestinian police force.
Arrangements for Hebron, the only West Bank city with Israeli settlements, proved to be the most difficult. The Palestinians demanded that it be treated like all the other cities, while Israel insisted on provisions to protect the 450 Israeli settlers, who believe their presence is biblically ordained.
The compromise was an elaborate plan dividing the city into three zones: one patrolled by Israelis, a second patrolled jointly and the third patrolled by Palestinians, but with Palestinians in overall control of security.
The arrangement also calls for the construction of a special road connecting the Jewish enclaves in the city to a larger settlement outside Hebron.
While the Palestinians will have exclusive control over populated areas, the rest of the West Bank was divided into two more categories: villages and towns where Palestinians will maintain public order and the Israelis will have overall security authority; and Israeli settlements, unpopulated lands and military zones where Israel will have sole control.
According to the agreement, internationally monitored elections for the Palestinian Council will take place 22 days after the Israeli Army finishes withdrawing from populated areas. But since the road in Hebron will take at least six months to build, the elections are not expected until spring.
The Council will have 82 members, but separate elections will be held for the "head of the executive authority," which insures that Mr. Arafat will remain at the head of the interim government.
After the elections, Israeli withdrawal from rural areas would continue at six-month intervals. The Council would remain in power until May 1999, when a final-status agreement is supposed to be ready.
The overlapping security responsibilities and the staged withdrawal enabled both sides to claim major gains. The Palestinians declared that they would gain control over 90 percent of their land within two years, while Mr. Rabin said Israel was immediately surrendering only 30 percent of the territories.
The Israeli right sees the entire process as a surrender of the biblical heritage of the Jews and as a concession to terrorists. Militant West Bank settlers vowed to obstruct the accords at every step, and with Israeli elections now 14 months off, every step of withdrawal is certain to be scrutinized.
Mr. Peres and Mr. Arafat approached the talks with urgency, hoping to secure as much as possible before elections, which could bring a Likud government into power, and presumably halt the process.
Opposition to the peace effort has spread in the last two years because the original agreement in 1993 did not stem terrorist attacks in Israel, as many Israelis had hoped.
Binyamin Netanyahu, the opposition leader, turned on the agreement immediately. "This Government has crossed every red line that it has set for itself and has been blackmailed in a hurried, timid and irresponsible negotiation," he declared. But he stopped short of saying he would not honor the agreements if he came to power, as some colleagues have said.
The National Religious Party accused the Government of "surrendering the land of our forefathers."
Benjamin Begin, a Likud member of Parliament and son of the late Prime Minister Menachem Begin, said: "This is a difficult day for the people of Israel. There's only one word: This is a tragedy."
A statement issued by the "Jewish Community of Hebron" declared that the only armed force it would recognize was the Israeli Army, and that "any foreign armed force within Hebron," Palestinians included, would be regarded "as an enemy force, and will be reacted to accordingly."
In a news conference today, Mr. Rabin seemed more intent on defusing criticism than on hailing the agreement. He reiterated the Labor Party's policy that the final settlement would not return to 1967 boundaries, that Jerusalem would remain united and part of Israel, and that Israel's "security border" would stay at the Jordan River.
"I think we made the right step in the direction of our final goal, which is not 'Greater Israel' as a binational state, but the state of Israel as a Jewish state," he said.
Mr. Arafat also endured considerable pressure during the negotiations, especially from radical Islamic movements and militant Arab opponents.
Within the West Bank, Palestinians feared the effects of the continued presence of settlers and soldiers in Hebron. "No matter how many soldiers are stationed there, they will be seen as a basic injustice and a source of constant friction and violence," said Hanan Ashrawi, one of the early Palestinian negotiators.
In Hebron, Tayfeer Tamimi, a member of the court of sharia or Islamic law, with ties to Hamas, described the settlers as a "time bomb which can explode at any minute."

Chart: "The Peace Accord"
 Main points of the interim Israel-P.L.O. agreement reached yesterday
 
ISRAELI WITHDRAWAL: The West Bank will be divided into three zones: populated areas, from which Israeli troops will withdraw entirely; rural areas, where Palestinians and Israelis will share authority, and exclusively Israeli areas, which include Jewish settlements, military bases and unpopulated areas. Israeli troops are to start withdrawing from populated areas within 10 days of the signing and complete the pullout in about six months.
 
ELECTIONS: The agreement calls for internationally monitored elections to choose an 82-member Palestinian Council from the West Bank and Gaza to be held 22 days after the troops withdraw from populated areas.
 
HEBRON: An Israeli force will remain in the center of Hebron to protect the 450 Israeli settlers there, but the Palestinian police will have overall responsibility for security.
 
PRISONERS: Immediately upon the signing of the agreement, Israel agreed to free all women as well as men who were sick, young, elderly or had completed two-thirds of their sentence. Others would be set free on the eve of elections. Further releases will be discussed later.
 
PALESTINIAN COVENANT: The Palestinians agreed to revoke within two years articles of the Palestinian Covenant calling for the destruction of Israel.
 
NATURAL RESOURCES: Israel pledged to increase the Palestinians' share of West Bank water and to join a search for new resources.
 
SACRED SITES: Jews will be guaranteed freedom of access to Rachel's Tomb in Bethlehem and Joseph's Tomb in Nablus, while the the Tomb of Abraham in Hebron, which is also sacred to Muslims as the Ibrahimi Mosque, will remain as is, with separate times of worship enforced by Israeli forces. (pg. A6)
 
Chronology: Major dates in moves toward Palestinian autonomy:
 
June 5-11, 1967 -- In a war with its Arab neighbors, Israel seizes the West Bank and Gaza Strip, Palestinian-populated areas held by Jordan and Egypt, respectively, since 1948. The Arab sector of Jerusalem is annexed.
 
Sept. 17, 1978 -- Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel, as part of the Camp David peace accords with Egypt, recognizes "the inalienable rights of the Palestinian people" and agrees to the principle of autonomy in the West Bank and Gaza. Israeli-Egyptian talks on autonomy never reach fruition.
 
Dec. 9, 1987 -- Riots erupt in Gaza and quickly spread to the West Bank, sparking a six-year uprising against Israeli rule in which more than 1,100 Palestinians and 150 Israelis are killed.
 
Nov. 15, 1988 -- In Tunis, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yasir Arafat, declares a Palestinian state and implies acceptance of Israel.
 
PUB-DATE: June 23, 1992
 
Sept. 13, 1993 -- After months of secret negotiations in Oslo, Norway, Israel and the P.L.O. sign an accord outlining an interim framework for autonomy in the West Bank and Gaza.
 
PUB-DATE: May 4, 1994
 
Sept. 24, 1995 -- Arafat and the Israeli Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, reach agreement on the second stage of autonomy: self-rule in most Arab-populated areas of the West Bank. (pg. A6)

HEADLINE: Tidy Up a Wilderness, or Leave It in Natural Tatters?

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

DATELINE: WANAKENA, N.Y., Sept. 21

 BODY:
On July 15, the sky fell on a large swatch of the Adirondack Park -- almost literally.
A 20-mile-wide wave of thundering black clouds and hurricane gusts roared from the west. In a few minutes, the freak storm steamrolled a Rhode Island-sized triangle of the vast mosaic of wilderness and private land, focusing its power on the Five Ponds Wilderness Area south of this hamlet. Microbursts like great fists of air punched down forests and houses, killing four campers and a motorist. 
 Two months later, the dead are long buried and houses repaired. But state officials, environmentalists, timber companies and landowners are locked in debate over what to do, or not do, with the tens of millions of toppled or tottering trees across 125,000 acres, an area six times the size of Manhattan.
Do you cut the risk of forest fire by sending in timber companies to harvest the fallen trees and sell them? Or do you leave the logs to rot and nourish new forest growth?
Answering these questions poses a subtle political test for Gov. George E. Pataki, who finds himself caught between Adirondacks environmentalists and members of his own administration.
State officials, with memories of the Long Island wildfire still fresh, fear the fallen timber could fuel another huge forest fire. But forest ecologists counter that bringing chain saws and logging trucks onto public parkland would threaten a century-old, constitutionally guaranteed effort to restore the forest to its primeval splendor.
Whatever the Pataki administration decides, the debate has drawn outsiders' attention to the extraordinary extent of the destruction.
Bernard Siskavich, a state forest ranger based here, saw the wilderness from a helicopter after the storm and was one of the first to grasp the almost supernatural scope of what had happened.
"It went on and on, everything was flattened," he said. In 21 years as a ranger, he said, he'd seen blowdowns in "isolated spots, 30 or 40 yards, once in a while, but I've never seen anything like this."
Since then, it has become clear that the storm's destruction dwarfed anything since Hurricane Hazel swept inland in November 1950, knocking down more than 400,000 acres of Adirondack trees.
The 900,000 acres affected far exceed the scale of the state's more recent -- and widely reported -- natural disaster, the wildfire that scorched 6,000 acres of pitch pine on Long Island.
There are arguments about what to do about the damage on private timber holdings within the park, but the most intense debate is focused on the blowdowns in state-owned forest preserves like the Five Ponds Wilderness.
These tracts were deemed forever wild under the State Constitution a century ago, in the hope they would recover from voracious logging in the 1800's.
As a result, some forest ecologists are saying that any salvage effort would be unconstitutional.
"The state lands were set aside specifically to let the landscape return to primeval forest after the devastating logging of yesteryear," said Dr. Edward Ketchledge, an ecologist who has studied the Adirondack wilderness for 50 years and is on a panel of scientists advising state environmental officials. "This essential concept cannot be lost in the immediacy of our public concern for all this timber that's down."
This week, after several public meetings, the State Department of Environmental Conservation convened a group of environmentalists, scientists, timber industry representatives and spokesmen for private landowners to plan a response to the damage.
In one indication of the passions at work, the gathering was told that the department had just received an anonymous phone call warning that some of the old trees in the Five Ponds region had been spiked -- the radical environmentalists' practice of driving spikes or other material into tree trunks so that chain saws or mill blades biting into them would be destroyed.
Michael D. Zagata, the department's Commissioner, said in an interview that by the end of October the state would have a plan that protects the public from fire and preserves the sanctity of the park. He said that salvage of timber remains an option, and that the fire risk is serious.
But even if state officials decided that timber salvage was warranted, and even if the Attorney General's office determined that such an emergency harvest did not violate the Constitution, some environmentalists said they would challenge it in court.
"If they start up a chain saw, this is a potential nightmare for the administration," said William Cook, a lobbyist in Albany for the Citizens Campaign for the Environment. "This all comes back to Governor Pataki."
The debate over how to handle damaged trees on private land is only slightly less intense. Within the 6 million-acre park, 3.5 million acres, including many commercial timber stands, are privately owned.
After surveying the landowners, the Empire State Forest Products Association estimated that $2.7 million worth of timber was damaged or felled by the storm and should be quickly harvested. Kevin King, executive vice president of the association, a lobbying group, said, "Mother Nature has done quite a bit of clearcutting."
Several environmentalists said they understood the landowners' need to salvage the downed wood before rot, staining or insect damage spoiled its value. What some environmental groups have objected to is a state plan to issue a blanket permit that would allow landowners with damaged forest to clearcut large holdings -- damaged and healthy trees alike -- without any direct oversight.
If approved by the Adirondack Park Agency's commissioners, as environmentalists expect, the permits would sanction what amounts to "mail-order clearcutting," said John F. Sheehan, a spokesman for the Adirondack Council, a private environmental group.
The draft permit says a property owner may harvest "all trees, whether damaged or not," where he finds that one out of three trees is damaged. The owner would be able to start cutting immediately and could send in a map and other paperwork as late as next February. No inspection by state workers would take place unless a damaged area was in wetlands, and then a permit could be issued on the spot.
The 11 commissioners, 3 of whom are new appointees of Gov. George E. Pataki, are to return any final comments to agency staff by Monday.
Mr. Cook, the environmental lobbyist, said that if the commissioners did not make the permit more restrictive, it would be a clear sign that the new appointments had shifted the Park Agency to a markedly pro-development stance.
"The primary goal here is to maintain the integrity of the forest," Mr. Cook said. "We're talking about tens of thousands of acres that are potentially going to go under the saw."
Overall, though, he and other environmentalists agreed, their primary concern remained areas like the Five Ponds Wilderness.
Five Ponds is prized by scientists because its heart, a 50,000-acre melange of beech, sugar maple, white pine, hemlock and red spruce trees, has never felt the bite of ax or saw.
This is thought to be the largest remaining tract of old-growth forest in the Northeast, said Dr. Charles D. Canham, a plant ecologist at the Institute of Ecosystem Studies in Millbrook, N.Y., who has been conducting research in the Five Ponds area for more than a decade.
It is a unique living laboratory, Dr. Canham said. The idea that the state would sanction salvage there, he said, was appalling. "I'm just flabbergasted that we're even having to go through this debate," Dr. Canham said. "It is no less wild a wilderness because some of the trees blew down."
In interviews, several Adirondack residents from various spheres suggested finding a middle course: salvaging some fallen trees to create a buffer against wildfire, but letting the rest lie where it is.
The timber industry appears to be leery of harvesting the windfall on state preserve land because timber prices, already low, would be further depressed by the glut of wood. Addressing the issue, a recent editorial in a logging-industry magazine, Northern Logger and Timber Processor, was simply titled, "Let It Rot."
From a logger's point of view, it is danger, not economics, that would make such a salvage operation unwise. Lawrence Goodyear, a logger for Dumac Forestry Services with 25 years of experience cutting trees, said his main concern in a full-scale salvage operation would be the extreme hazard to workers.
Standing next to a small hill of stumps and shattered trunks that had been hauled out to the roadside from around Star Lake, Mr. Goodyear described how trees that are bent but still rooted can suddenly spring up, flinging a chain saw back at the cutter.
Trees leaning on others never fall where you want them, he said, adding, "Us guys shudder at that kind of stuff. It's just not worth it."
Among state forestry officials, the fear of fire dominates other considerations. Lieut. Daniel Walsh, a spokesman for the Environmental Conservation Department's Bureau of Fire, said the chaotic piles of tree trunks and branches amount to as much as 150 tons of fuel per acre in some places. The Long Island blazes last summer fed on a fifth as much fuel.
Calling the moist woods of the Adirondacks "asbestos forests" for their fire-resistant qualities, several conservationists pointed out that few fires followed the great blowdown of 1950.
But the conservationists ultimately all fall back on the original intent of Article 14 of the State Constitution. "It couldn't be any clearer," said Mr. Sheehan, who recited an excerpt: "The lands of the state... shall be forever kept as wild forest lands... Nor shall the timber thereon be sold, removed or destroyed."
Any interference in the short term would prove to be a mistake in the long run, said Bill McKibben, an Adirondack resident whose new book, "Hope, Human and Wild," describes the recovery of the region after more than a century of clearcutting.
"The forest preserves here are the longest running experiment anywhere in the world in the idea of ecosystem recovery," Mr. McKibben said. "It would be very sad to mess with that experiment, especially since it's working so well."

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (92%);

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Russian Economy May Be On the Verge of Growth
For the first time since the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991, the Russian economy may be on the brink of growing. All the signs point this way: inflation is down, the country's budget deficit is under control -- and its central bank has ceased the practice of printing rubles whenever it needed to prop up factories and farms, meaning that the ruble is for the most part holding its value.
While all these signs are encouraging, the economic and political atmospheres remain volatile, threatening stability -- and economists report a growing gap between the rich and poor. [Page A1.]
 
At NBC, Generation X Generates $
While the president of NBC Entertainment would have you believe that the network wants to appeal to all segments -- read, ages -- of the population, his actions tell otherwise. NBC has annointed three young programmers, including 31-year-old Jamie McDermott, left, to run mini-networks of their own. Shepherding such shows as "Friends," "E.R." and "Hope and Gloria," the programmers have been a blessing to the network, which leads all three networks by a wide margin in ratings among relatively young adults with household incomes greater than $60,000 -- a segment that advertisers are willing to pay a premium to reach. [D7.]
 
A Force to Contend With, Again
Ken Olsen, the founder of the Digital Equipment Corporation, is back. At 69, Mr. Olsen, who was forced to resign from Digital in 1992 after the company suffered heavy losses, is competing with Andersen Consulting, E.D.S., and I.B.M. to help businesses modernize their computer systems. He believes corporations would do well to impose the same discipline on networks of PC's that they reserve for their mainframe and minicomputers. [D5.]
 
Janet Jackson Does the Impossible
Thanks to video technology, the singer finds herself running across the arms of the statue of Christ in Rio de Janeiro and sitting on top of the Easter Island monuments -- even though she never left the airplane hangar in California where she taped the video for her latest single, "Runaway." By imposing Ms. Jackson's image into two-dimensional photographs of the locales, the production studio Hollywood Digital spent one-fourth of what it would have spent traveling to the locations shown in the video. And those savings don't even take into consideration the idea of hoisting the pop rock star to the heavenly heights she appears to roam in Rio. [D7.]
 
San Francisco Examiner in Flux
The Hearst Corporation, which owns the 108-year-old evening paper in San Francisco, is reportedly in talks to close The Examiner and take over management of The San Francisco Chronicle -- the city's bigger, morning newspaper. Since 1965, the papers have operated jointly, sharing printing, distribution and other business operations. But they have maintained separate editorial staffs. They have split profits, or losses, too. For the current year, losses are estimated to be $10 million to $12 million. Both newspapers have been losing circulation, with The Chronicle down to 110,000. [D8.]
 
Former Intel Engineer Arrested
The F.B.I. arrested William Gaede, charging the former Intel software engineer with mail fraud and interstate transportation of stolen property. The Federal crimes of which Mr. Gaede is accused are related to the theft of millions of dollars worth of production secrets for Intel's Pentium microprocessor. [D2.]

HEADLINE: In Hungary,Pataki Gets Treatment Of a Star

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: NYIRBATOR, Hungary, Sept. 24

 BODY:
The 14-car motorcade that raced through the narrow streets of this rural village today, blocking traffic and forcing cars off the road, signaled the arrival of a foreign dignitary. And in this case, the lanky and slightly rumpled man who alighted from the black limousine was indeed a chief of state, namely New York's Gov. George E. Pataki.
Wearing a blue blazer and white pants and looking like a candidate primed for the campaign trail, Mr. Pataki beamed broadly as he strode toward a whitewashed 17th-century church for morning mass, shaking hands and greeting parishioners in his halting Hungarian. 
 Mr. Pataki is perhaps more revered in his ancestor's homeland than in New York State, where to some constituents he remains an elusive and, according to polls, not entirely beloved figure. Today, his first full day in Hungary, showed how popular he had become in parts of this nation of 10 million.
As he watched Mr. Pataki sign prayer books here, one admiring parishioner, Hernadi Istvan, said: "All Hungarian people watched him during the campaign last year. Here, people are very proud. He is Governor, after all, of the biggest state in America."
The official pomp and lavish news coverage that greeted him here contrasts sharply with his low-keyed and often-low-profiled style of Governorship. Often overshadowed at home by New York City's combative Mayor and New Jersey's popular Governor, Mr. Pataki has been accorded all the attention of a rising political and media star in Hungary, where his father's parents were born.
He is scheduled to hold private meetings with the Foreign Minister, the Prime Minister and the President. He will address Parliament. On his first two nights here, he has been the subject of two documentaries shown on national television, was the lead item on Budapest evening newscasts and made the front pages of several major newspapers.
And as he has toured the eastern farming region near the Ukrainian border where many of his relatives still live, an entourage of 20 Hungarian security officers, drivers, Foreign Ministry officials and translators has attended his every need while being trailed by a gaggle of local and American reporters.
All this for someone who has limited power to do the many things that Hungarians want of him, specifically, increase foreign aid, improve trade with the West, spur investment by American companies and help Hungary win a place in NATO.
Asked about the nation's interest in Mr. Pataki, which began during last year's Gubernatorial campaign, Hungarians talk of the Governor as a symbol of emigre political success for a nation that, as Mr. Pataki himself put it, has "lost every single political enterprise they've been involved in" for the last 1,000 years.
Krisztina Wiedemann, a teacher and radio reporter from Budapest, said: "I don't know why it is. Maybe because it's very strange to us that somebody of Hungarian origin can get such good status in America."
Mr. Pataki, 50, is visiting Hungary for four days with his wife, Libby; their eldest son, Theodore; his mother, Margaret, and six aides on a trip financed by the Hungarian Government and Hungarian-American businessmen. Mr. Pataki, who is a quarter Italian, also plans to visit Italy for three days later this week.
Though he will be meeting with Hungarian officials and business leaders to talk about increasing business with New York, Mr. Pataki acknowledged that his main goal was to find the birthplaces of his grandparents and long-lost relatives.
Throughout northeastern Hungary, a poor agricultural region, officials have spent recent weeks poring through archives searching for evidence of the Governor's ancestors, hoping that he would show greater interest in them if they did. In two towns, Debrecen and Kisvarda, the mayors sadly presented Mr. Pataki elaborately researched family trees that came up blank with Pataki ancestors. Both vowed to keep searching.
But in Aranyosapati, a rural village of 2,100 where his father's parents lived, Mr. Pataki hit a gold mine of cousins. Several hundred people lined the streets and climbed fences to get a glimpse of him this morning. And as Mr. Pataki strode into the throng, one after another announced that he or she was a relative.
A man in a lavender shirt said they were second cousins. An old woman with no top teeth proclaimed herself a Pataki. An elegantly dressed 81-year-old man in a black fedora said he was a distant cousin, adding, "We have the same nose." Mr. Pataki bear hugged them all.
After receiving a wooden box containing a vial of water from the Tisza River and soil from a farm, Mr. Pataki told the gathering: "It's just extremely moving to look around at the crowd and see the faces and know so many of you are relatives of mine. I can tell because the women are all beautiful and the men are all handsome."
It was neither the first nor last time the Governor sounded as if he was schmoozing on the stump. When local officials complained he was spending too little time with them, he pledged, as he constantly did on last year's campaign, "I will be back." And when Hungarian reporters asked him what he would specifically do to help the local economy, he artfully dodged the question by saying, "I have some ideas that we'll be talking to Hungarian officials about. But nothing we can discuss now."
Indeed, much of the trip has had a hurly-burly campaign quality to it. He visited a Bosnian refugee camp in Debrecen for all of 15 minutes. Even at his grandparents' village of Aranyosapati, he was scheduled to stay only 35 minutes. When Mr. Pataki insisted on walking along the Tisza River where his grandfather liked to swim, an argument ensued with his time-conscious hosts. Finally, Zenia Mucha, Mr. Pataki's press spokeswoman, shouted, "The Governor wants to go, O.K.?" They drove Mr. Pataki to the river.
Mr. Pataki said the apple orchards of Aranyosapati, the distinctive regional dialect and even the way the farmers piled their hay reminded him of the Peekskill farm where he grew up. "This is where I want to be," he said, looking at sunflower fields. "Budapest is not where I want to be."
Asked whether he would stay in touch with his newly discovered cousins, Mr. Pataki jokingly suggested that some could come to America and work for the state. "We might be able to hire more people in my family than in Joe Bruno's," he said, referring to the Senate majority leader who has put several relatives on the state payroll.
Like their American counterparts, Hungarian reporters have pressed Mr. Pataki to reveal details about his life. One asked how he got to be so tall (he is 6-foot-4). "Magyar blood and good American food," Mr. Pataki replied. Another wondered whether he had favorite Hungarian dishes. Stuffed cabbage, he said. And several asked him to say something in Hungarian.
To one, Mr. Pataki answered in Hungarian, "I can speak only a little in Hungarian, and I'm very sorry about that. I'm quite tired right now and can remember that when I was young I could speak more Hungarian, but it is a big effort to do right now."
Asked to translate, a Hungarian radio reporter said, "I'll have to listen to my tape. His grammar is, um, not perfect."

HEADLINE: Staking Claim in Alternative Software on the Internet

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif.

 BODY:
James Gosling wants to make the computer software world safe for diversity.
In his view, and in the view of many other people in the industry, the software giant Microsoft is close to crowding out all its competition. 
 "As far as the software business goes, Microsoft has become like death and taxes," said Mr. Gosling, the 40-year-old software wizard who is the mastermind behind the Java language. He contends that Sun Microsystems, by distributing Java freely over the Internet, will create an alternative software world that Microsoft will be unable to dominate.
A Canadian who came to the United States to attend graduate school at Carnegie Mellon University in the late 1970's, Mr. Gosling had been a hacker from the days he discovered computers while hanging around at the University of Calgary at age 13.
He had always been an electronics tinkerer. "I was always interested in building things, but in order to build things you have to have parts," he said. Software, whose parts are just digital ones and zeros, liberated him.
The Java programming language is Mr. Gosling's second effort at transforming computing with a software design that permits programs to operate over computer networks. The first project, which he began shortly after arriving at Sun in 1984, was known as NEWS, or Network Extensible Windowing System. The idea -- radical at the time -- was to enable any computer screen on a network to display a program running on any other computer on the network.
While NEWS never caught on as a commercial product, it did demonstrate the potential for distributing computer-processing power across a network. And it helped pave the way for today's so-called client/server computer networks, in which a network of desktop client computers can share programs that run on centrally located server machines.
"He has skills of making code very compact and very fast," said David Rosenthal, a software designer who joined Mr. Gosling's NEWS project after initial skepticism.
Despite its technical success, the commercial failure of NEWS taught Mr. Gosling some valuable lessons. So did the near-failure of Java, which Mr. Gosling began working on as a secret project in 1991. Conceived as a programming language for interactive television and the consumer electronics industry, the Java project was originally called Oak and was at the heart of Sun's attempt to create software for set-top television controllers.
"We got seduced by the dark side of interactive television," he said.
But by mid-1994, as the industry hype over interactive television was deflated by economic realities and a realization that neither the audiences nor the technology was ready for prime time, Sun and Mr. Gosling steered Java toward the Internet's World Wide Web -- where most of the real "information highway" action was starting to take place.
Even if Java takes off and becomes an Internet standard, Sun Microsystems may receive little direct financial benefit, Mr. Gosling acknowledges, since most people will be getting it free. But indirectly, the overall growth of the Internet is a boon for Sun, whose network server computers are the most popular way for companies, agencies and universities to connect to the global computing web. "Anything that contributes to the health of the Internet contributes to Sun's health as well," Mr. Gosling said.

HEADLINE: Argentine Economic Chief Seems Safe in Job, for Now

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 24

 BODY:
After weeks of mounting speculation that dismissal was imminent for Finance Minister Domingo Cavallo, the architect of this country's economic stability, it appears that he is keeping his job, at least for now.
Mr. Cavallo, whose bright star has dimmed lately as Argentina endures a stubborn recession and record unemployment, departed on Friday on a mission to Europe and the United States to convince international investors that he is still at the helm of Argentina's economy, which he maintains is fundamentally strong, despite current hard times. He will be visiting bankers and investors in New York on Wednesday. 
 "I will continue as Finance Minister because the President wants me to stay and because we still have a lot of unfinished work to do in reforming this economy," Mr. Cavallo said in an interview recently. "Those who want to take me out of office want to change the policies that we are pursuing, but the financial markets understand that and have reacted accordingly."
Indeed, there have been widespread calls in recent weeks within the administration of President Carlos Saul Menem and his Peronist party for Mr. Cavallo's ouster, particularly after his public accusation that a "mafia" was working inside and outside the Government to undermine his economic policies.
As rumors spread that Mr. Cavallo was on his way out, financial markets here took a beating, with investors assuming that the Menem Government was shifting away from the policies that have brought growth and stability to an economy once plagued by hyperinflation, corruption and inefficiencies. After several days of silence, Mr. Menem publicly endorsed Mr. Cavallo, saying that there would be no change in finance ministers.
But for many economists and bankers here, the issue is not whether Mr. Cavallo will step down, but rather when he will depart and under what circumstances.
"We do not discard the possibility that Cavallo could resign in the immediate future, but we think that it's very unlikely," said Raul H. Buonuome, an economist for Baring Securities Argentina S.A. "We believe that Cavallo will leave his post in an agreement with Menem sometime before 1997."
Most economists and bankers interviewed here said they doubted that Mr. Cavallo would step down soon because such a move would cause havoc in the financial markets and lead to a flight of foreign capital similar to the one after the Mexican currency crisis in December.
Indeed, Mr. Cavallo, a former economics professor, has a good rapport with foreign investors, and through road shows like the one he began over the weekend, the minister has almost singlehandedly convinced investors that Argentina is not another Mexico.
"The feelings of the market is that it's difficult to find a qualified substitute for Cavallo because you need a very strong and capable person to keep the economic policies on schedule," said Mario Vicens, an economist for Macroeconomica, a firm that advises international investors.
Mr. Vicens said investors were generally pleased with Mr. Cavallo's initial policy moves, including opening markets to foreign competition, privatizing state businesses and instituting a currency exchange system that pegs the peso tightly to the dollar on a one-to-one basis.
These policies have reduced inflation to 4 percent from more than 5,000 percent in 1989, while fostering economic and industrial growth of 6 to 9 percent, until a sudden recession this year after the Mexico crisis.
Despite his introduction of policies that have stabilized the economy, Mr. Cavallo has remained unpopular within the Peronist movement, especially among old-liners, perhaps because he has been mentioned as a presidential candidate in 1999.
Eduardo Duhalde, the Governor of Buenos Aires province and a leading candidate to succeed Mr. Menem, and Jorge Blance Villegas, head of the Argentine Industrial Union, have accused Mr. Cavallo of opening the economy too quickly to international competition and blamed the minister's policies for the country's record 18.6 percent unemployment.
As Mr. Cavallo tries to institute the next round of changes in the banking and health care systems, among provincial governments, in labor laws and in the judiciary, he is encountering broad opposition from Peronists who say he is going too far.
Investors and economists said that the new round of changes isnecessary to continue to attract foreign investment; Argentina desperately needs foreign capital to spur growth and meet its debt payments.
Meanwhile, Argentina continues to suffer through a recession, set off by the Mexico crisis. Many economists expect there will be no growth this year. The Economy Ministry, which initially forecast 3 percent growth for 1995, now says that growth will be about 1 percent, compared with 6.5 percent last year.
The ministry says unemployment is not expected to improve until the second quarter of 1996, after changes that reduce the cost of labor are expected to take effect.
But Argentina's trade balance is improving: in the first seven months of the year there was a surplus of $1.2 billion, compared with a deficit of $3.2 billion in the similar 1994period. Exports were up 42 percent, to $12.5 billion, and imports were down 6 percent, to $11.3 billion.
"If I have to leave for health reasons or because I am tired or sick or have to accept another responsibility, there should be no problem at all with somebody else coming in and taking over my office," Mr. Cavallo said. "But the question is not whether only Cavallo can do these reforms. The question is what is the interpretation in the markets of Cavallo leaving."

HEADLINE: Patents;
An inventor sees a future in which energy will be generated by turbines sitting on the ocean floor.

BYLINE: By Sabra Chartrand 

 BODY:
FOR thousands of years, inventive farmers and merchants have harnessed nature's energy to help ease their workload. Greek poetry from 85 B.C. praised the water wheel for freeing women from grinding corn by hand. Ninth-century Arabic writings described wind-driven grain mills; records referred to similar designs at work in 13th-century China. Those early power plants led to the tower windmills that sprung up across Europe in the 14th and 15th centuries.
Windmills and water wheels eventually gave way to steam engines. But now a New York City inventor says he has patented machinery that will harness currents of a different kind. Bogumil Kumbatovic says flexible turbines submerged offshore will extract cheap, clean energy from ocean waves. 
 Mr. Kumbatovic imagines America's coasts dotted with his design for a turbine mounted on four hydraulic legs embedded in the ocean floor. The hydraulics are used to maneuver the turbine so it can adapt to the waves as they change direction. Each turbine consists of a tank surrounded by paddle boards, belts and rollers. A turning drum at the front of the tank acts as a pulley. A set of belts connects it to an electric generator. Electricity is produced when a wave hits the paddles and rotates the turning drum and the pulleys.
Mr. Kumbatovic believes that flexibility sets his design apart from other water "mills."
"The equipment has a slideable base which moves forward and backward by means of hydraulic cylinders," he said. "This allows the system to keep individual waves circulating within the power generating system for a longer period of time, extracting maximum energy from each wave."
And that, he said, also makes his design more durable than other inventions that used the ocean to generate power.
"Previous attempts failed because they couldn't withstand the ocean's destructive waves," Mr. Kumbatovic added. "This system's hydraulics allow the entire equipment to be moved up and down with the changing tides and the height of oncoming waves."
Though he has not tested his design with a working prototype, Mr. Kumbatovic is convinced that a turbine sitting in waves that are at least three feet high and traveling at 6.6 feet a second would produce 420 kilowatts of power. But huge numbers of his invention would have to be deployed to replace just a part of existing power sources.
"The U.S. utilities currently have 109 nuclear power plants in operation, which supply about 21 percent of the nation's electricity," Mr. Kumbatovic wrote in a report describing his invention's impact on energy use. "To replace this power capacity with ocean-power units would require installation of 129,762 units, and the cost of all of these units would be approximately $73 billion."
That would still be less, Mr. Kumbatovic said, than the total for nuclear plants, which cost several billion dollars each.
"The economical advantage of these ocean-power units could be perfectly utilized on an island such as Maui, Hawaii," Mr. Kumbatovic said. In addition to its coastal uses, he said his machinery could be adapted for installation on the side of a ship, where it could produce energy from waves rolling by. Mr. Kumbatovic received patent 5,311,064.

A Hardware System For Added Security
Hackers, clumsy children or insidious viruses may be stymied by a newly patented security system that uses the idle programming power in a hard-drive controller to limit or deny access to computer files. Owners can program the security system to make files "read only" or inaccessible. The only way to change the security instructions is with a key.
David Reardon, a founder of Kinetic Enterprises in Springfield, Ill., says his invention means parents can allow children to play computer games without worrying that business files will be erased, or colleagues can exchange software without fear of introducing computer viruses into a hard drive.
"Every computer has a main processor," Mr. Reardon said. "One of the present security problems is that all programming and decision-making emanates from there. But there is another programming device, the hard-drive controller. We can use the intelligence of that device and make a separate program for security."
Controllers are programmed by the manufacturer to regulate access to the tracks in a hard drive. Mr. Reardon's invention adds programming that tells the controller to restrict certain tracks -- so that they can be viewed but not manipulated.
"Kids can run games," Mr. Reardon said. But not they cannot "delete, erase or write on the files," he added.
"The security parameters are fixed in the controller and it will ignore commands in the central processing unit which violate the security parameters," he said.
Those security instructions can only be changed after a key or magnetic card has been inserted into a lock on the computer. He admitted that his system might be cumbersome for large companies with numerous computers where someone would have to be responsible for a lot of keys. But he said the key would keep hackers from defeating the controller's programming.
"All software-based security functions that operate through the central processing unit can be defeated by more clever software designers or programmers," Mr. Reardon said. "Software can defeat software. So we created a physical hardware device that cannot be emulated by software or outsmarted.
"This would not replace a security shell," he added, "but would become the bedrock which protects that security shell from being altered, challenged or spied on."
He said the system might also be used to detect viruses, or to determine if someone was trying to break into restricted files.
"If you ran a program with a computer virus on it and the hard drive was instructed to read only, the computer would refuse the program and flag it," he said. "It can also lock up the system completely and refuse to respond to requests to look at the hard drive."
Mr. Reardon hopes to license his patent, 5,434,562, to a computer hardware manufacturer.

HEADLINE: In America;
Don't Call It Welfare Reform

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
I keep wondering who would be helped by the so-called welfare reform legislation that has so much support in Congress and with the public.
I keep coming up with the same answer. No one. 
 The bill that passed the Senate last week (even harsher legislation has been approved by the House) would hurt many people, would kill some and would help no one.
Robin Toner, reporting in The Times on passage of the Senate bill, said that a "shaken and sad" Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the Democratic floor leader during the debate and one of the very few senators to vote against the bill, had "pleaded for order as the voting was under way, but a celebratory atmosphere took hold."
Millionaires celebrating the stomping of the poor.
Joel F. Handler, a professor at the U.C.L.A. School of Law and one of the country's foremost experts on welfare, spoke last week about the potential consequences of "reform."
"You can deny welfare for childless adults, the homeless, people like that. They'll drift around and die slowly under the bridges, out of sight. But if you become too drastic in cutting welfare for families, if you do it too suddenly, then they will begin showing up at shelters, and then you have no choice but to do something about the children."
Believe it or not, that's the good news. At least the homeless and hungry children will be visible. The bad news is that the remedies for destitute families tend to be public shelters, hotels, foster care -- a mix of programs that is more degrading and much more expensive than welfare.
The politicians who are so hot for this "reform" insist that it is all about making people responsible for themselves, making them work. The insufferable Phil Gramm likes to talk about people riding in the wagon while others do all the pulling. I refer the Senator to page 85 of Professor Handler's new book, "The Poverty of Welfare Reform."
Mr. Handler writes: "The evidence over time is both consistent and persuasive that the vast majority of welfare recipients do not lack a work ethic. Empirical work demonstrates, as we have seen, that, against considerable odds, the majority of welfare recipients work while they are on welfare, trying over and over to find and keep jobs, and that, in fact, the majority do leave welfare through work."
He quotes the sociologist Kathleen Harris: "Parents rely on welfare simply because they cannot find jobs that pay enough to support their families."
That is the problem in a nutshell. But year after year, in a chronic denial of reality, legislators insist on attaching meaningless work requirements to welfare bills. The Senate bill passed last week has a provision that requires 50 percent of welfare recipients to be working by the year 2000.
"Well, that's nonsense," said Mr. Handler. "The jobs aren't there."
In his book, he cited a 1989 analysis of job opportunities in New York City that focused on needy people who wanted living-wage jobs. The study found that there were 770,000 economically disadvantaged adults and only 57,000 job vacancies.
The problem is not welfare; it's poverty. It's the absence of work, not the refusal to work. It's the growing inability of this society to provide meaningful employment for those citizens who want to work -- as the middle class is finding out through harsh experience.
That is the problem, and neither the legislators nor the citizens who are so anxious to punish the poor for being poor have a clue as to what to do about it. To get a sense of just how clueless the politicians are, consider that the Republicans in Congress are trying to reverse President Clinton's expansion of the earned-income tax credit for the working poor.
This program helps keep working people off welfare. If President Clinton's expansion of the earned-income tax credit were allowed to remain in place, it would result by 1996 in moving about 1.4 million families -- working families -- above the poverty level.
But no. That would make too much sense. The effort now is to scale it back. The current Congress is loath to resist any effort to whack the poor. It's for their own good, you know. Suffering builds character. And if there's anything politicians know about, it's character.
