HEADLINE: Lessons From California

 BODY:
California, that harbinger of so many fads and fashions, is now a laboratory for the hardship that can result from years of refusing to face up to fiscal realities. Los Angeles County faces enormous cutbacks in health and other services, although the immediate threat that dozens of health clinics would be shut down was eased last week with President Clinton's announcement of an emergency aid package.
Orange County, the wealthy neighbor to the south, is in actual bankruptcy, and is trying to bail itself out by raiding funds vital to preserving its bus system and infrastructure. The state government, itself awash in debt and deficits, is unable to help southern Californians avoid shredding the social safety net. 
 The disastrous economic recession of the last several years has been a major factor in California's troubles. But heedless tax-cutting without corresponding service cuts has greatly magnified the budget problems. Since the tax revolt of the 1970's that led to Proposition 13, which arbitrarily froze real estate tax rates, the state has nurtured the lethal idea that public services could be maintained without anyone paying for them. This mentality plunged the state and many of its local governments into debt, some of it covert, as they borrowed from various government reserve and pension funds or issued bonds, notes, warrants and other debt instruments to pay operating bills.
Like New York and many other states, California and its localities have been strangled in recent years by the soaring costs of health and welfare programs and prisons (as a result of tough new crime laws). Education costs have gone up as well because, in the late 1980's, voters approved an amendment to the state's Constitution requiring the state to spend a fixed portion of its budget on education and protect local school districts from the increased costs of enrollment growth and inflation.
As budget deficits deepened, Gov. Pete Wilson and the Legislature borrowed to meet expenses and raided various reserve funds set aside for special purposes. Since Proposition 13, for instance, the state has taken over the collection of property taxes from all local governments and districts. Pressed to meet the new requirements on school spending, state officials simply siphoned money away from funds that had been earmarked for counties. Such actions have compounded the problems facing Orange and Los Angeles Counties now.
Since declaring bankruptcy earlier this year, Orange County has faced the extraordinary problem of paying off $1.7 billion it lost gambling in the high-risk derivatives market. After county voters rejected a tax increase, the Legislature helped it assemble a package of cuts in bus service and spending to maintain harbors, parks, flood control and other infrastructure. Such steps will produce the money, but at a potentially large cost for repairs down the road.
Los Angeles County asked Sacramento for the right to raise taxes on cigarettes and to be freed from some costly state mandates. But the county is widely seen among Republicans in Sacramento as a den of wasteful spending. Governor Wilson, anxious to cover his conservative flank as he runs for President, rejected the idea of any tax hike, or even authorizing the county to carry out the deed.
At a time when the call in Washington is for cutting budgets, California offers a cautionary tale. No one is denying the need for making economies in government spending. But Californians are entering a new era of reductions in the entire scope of government that poses a genuine peril to public safety and well-being. Harsh limits on government spending will carry consequences that must be documented and debated in the years to come.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. in Michigan Basks In the Spotlight of Success

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., Sept. 24

 BODY:
As he rode the ferry over here shortly after dawn on Saturday, Senator Arlen Specter, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, fumed over rumors that he had been denied a room at the island's Grand Hotel, packed this weekend with Michigan Republicans attending their biennial conference and auditioning five Presidential aspirants.
"We didn't even try," Mr. Specter said, offering an explanation for staying at a mainland Best Western that he would make later in his speech to the Republicans. "We got in too late for the last ferry." 
 That the tale of the stiff-arming of the Pennsylvania Senator was widely and somewhat proudly exchanged by Republicans here testifies to the state party's delighted sense of its surging power.
Seven years ago, Michigan's Republicans were in disarray, with one leader predicting no statewide victories for 20 years. But this weekend, a record number of Republican leaders -- almost 2,000 district chairmen, state legislators, members of Congress and other party faithful -- turned out for the 21st Biennial Republican Leadership Conference on this resort island at the confluence of Lakes Huron and Michigan. They soaked up praise from candidates who fell over one another lauding the state organization and its chief, Gov. John Engler, for showing Washington the way on tax cuts, welfare changes and budgetary prudence.
Michigan Republicans find their organization taking center stage at a time when Republicans nationwide, having increased their majorities in legislatures and statehouses, are determined to win back the White House in 1996. So Michigan was thrilled to take the Presidential candidates, if not the campaign spotlight, away from New Hampshire for a weekend.
"They are pandering, aren't they?" Mark VandenBerge, a Republican from Grand Rapids, said with glee of the visiting candidates. "It's a real courtship thing that's going on." The reason, he said, was clear: with a few exceptions at the top of the state party, "Everyone else is still on the fence."
Many here would prefer Governor Engler to the declared candidates, who repeatedly promised to do little more than what they said he had done. "I want to do for America what John Engler has done for Michigan," Senator Phil Gramm of Texas said in his speech to the conference.
Among the visitors here, Speaker Newt Gingrich drew the most passionate response from the crowd. And though he was not among the announced candidates, the Georgia Congressman enthusiastically joined the hallelujah chorus today. "We really are the Engler Revolution in the U.S. House of Representatives," he said.
In independent polls, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas has a commanding lead in Michigan over his closest rivals, Mr. Gramm and Patrick J. Buchanan, with the others in the crowded field barely registering. And Mr. Dole was acting like a front-runner this weekend. "I've been reading, you know, past inaugural speeches, just to sort of get the feel for them," he told supporters at the Grand Hotel.
But with the primary six months off, support even at the party's core has not firmed up.
As Mr. Dole observed in his speech on Saturday, "I see all these 'Engler '96' stickers." The Governor has said he was not interested in running for President, but he had not ruled out a Vice-Presidential bid, a possibility that has been floated by the front-runner from Kansas.
Besides Mr. Dole, Mr. Gramm and Mr. Specter, the other candidates here were Gov. Pete Wilson of California and Morry Taylor, an auto-parts executive from Grosse Pointe.
Independent polls show President Clinton, who carried Michigan in 1992, narrowly leading Mr. Dole here. Among Republicans who have said they are likely to vote in the primary next year, the survey showed Mr. Dole leading with 43 percent, followed by Mr. Gramm at 9 percent and Mr. Buchanan at 8 percent. The poll was taken late last month by EPIC/MRA, a polling firm based in Lansing.
Mr. Engler's popularity also conceals fissures among Michigan's Republicans, particularly between the party's religious right wing and its moderate core.
"The central theme of Michigan politics now is the religious right," said Robert Andrews, a Republican lawyer from Luddington, as he strolled along the Grand Hotel's 660-foot southern porch. "I've had people, frankly, ask me why I'm involved in Republican politics, and the reason I'm involved is that I want to be a moderating influence."
Last year Michigan's Republicans won control of the Legislature for the first time since 1968, and elected the first Republican Senator, Spencer Abraham, since 1972. With the economy booming along with the auto industry, Governor Engler, who won a second term last year, has approval ratings of more than 60 percent.
But it is far from certain that the popularity of Mr. Engler -- who says he will not endorse a candidate in the primary -- will rub off on the eventual nominee. While Reagan Democrats may be happy with the Governor, deep ties between organized labor and the Democrats may make them reluctant to break with the party. Only slightly more Michigan residents call themselves Republicans than Democrats.
"This is still a toss-up state," said Thomas H. Shields, president of the Marketing Resource Group, a Republican polling firm in Lansing. "It's not a Republican state yet. The Republican Party seems to be the party of choice, not necessarily the party they're wedded to."

HEADLINE: A Small College's Tax-Exempt Status Challenged

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Washington and Jefferson College is a small liberal arts college tucked away in a corner of southwestern Pennsylvania. But it has become the focus of a growing nationwide struggle by governments to tax colleges and other nonprofit institutions.
Founded in 1781, Washington and Jefferson, like other colleges and nonprofit groups, has always been tax exempt. But two years ago, after watching other cities win payments in lieu of taxes from nonprofit organizations, the City of Washington, Pa., where Washington and Jefferson is located, asked the college to make such payments. The college refused, and the case is now in the courts. 
 A smattering of colleges and universities make voluntary payments to their local governments. Harvard gives Boston and Cambridge about $6 million a year, and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology gives Cambridge about $1 million.And in recent years, financially squeezed municipalities across the country have begun to look at nonprofit groups -- especially health and private educational institutions -- as potential sources of revenue.
The tax exemption was grounded in the belief that institutions that benefited the public, rather than private shareholders, should be encouraged and helped to survive. But in an era in which nonprofit groups are under growing scrutiny, the exemption is being called into question.
Cities argue that the nonprofit groups own substantial property that is taken off the tax roles, even as these groups benefit from services like fire and police protection. The groups pay taxes on income that is not directly related to their public mission.
The stakes are high. Although recent data are hard to come by, a United States Treasury commission reported in 1977 that about one-tenth of all property was held by nonprofit groups and was tax exempt. The report estimated that taxing this property would raise $5 billion.
For the most part, municipalities and other government bodies have not changed the laws exempting nonprofit institutions from taxes, but have negotiated voluntary sums at levels lower than taxes would be.
The District of Columbia, for example, has been looking at organizations like the Federal National Mortgage Association, George Washington University and the World Bank, which city officials say could help ease their financial burden. In Pennsylvania, cities like Philadelphia and Pittsburgh have won annual payments from colleges, hospitals and other nonprofit groups.
Washington, Pa., won an agreement for payments from a local hospital and then turned its attention to Washington and Jefferson, which has 1,100 students and 100 faculty members. When a college trustee said Washington and Jefferson would not consider a payment, the city asked the college to provide services to the city, like mowing a nearby park lawn and opening its athletic facilities to the public.
"We just felt that it was time for them to pay their fair share," said Mayor Francis L. King. "They use a lot of our services."
But Howard Burnett, the college president, sees it differently. "The power to tax is the power to destroy, and this would have been the first step toward the government destroying private higher education," he said last week.
The local tax board backed the college. But after the city took the case to court -- and despite briefs from colleges, universities and other nonprofit organizations throughout the country supporting the Washington and Jefferson position -- the Court of Common Pleas ruled last year that Washington and Jefferson must pay local property taxes, saying the college did not meet the state's five tests for a "purely public charity."
Within days, the college, which has an annual budget of $29 million and an endowment of $60 million, received tax bills of almost $500,000, from the city, the county and the local board of education.
On Sept. 15, however, the college won a reprieve. In a 4-to-3 ruling, the state appeals court, the Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania, reversed the decision. The City Council voted last week to appeal.
The roots of the action in Pennsylvania come from a 1985 ruling by the State Supreme Court. The ruling seemed to open the door for challenges to tax exemption by setting five tests for charitable organizations. They are that an institution advances a charitable purpose, gives a substantial portion of its services gratuitously, benefits people who are legitimate subjects of charity, relieves government of some of its burden, and operates free of a private profit motive.
In the meantime, advocates of tax exemption for nonprofit groups hope that the appeals court decision will hold and that it will forestall efforts to tax nonprofit groups.
"There is a need for local tax reform," said Brian Mitchell, president of the Commission for Independent Colleges and Universities in Pennsylvania. "But we don't think they should find short-term solutions on the backs of private colleges and universities and other nonprofits."

HEADLINE: Farm Bill in Congress Offers Kansan Visions of Choice for His Open Fields

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, Kan., Sept. 21

 BODY:
The table-flat fields of wheat on Randal Loder's farm stretch to the horizon, but Mr. Loder believes he could make more money if Washington would allow him to plant that land in corn instead.
Showing that markets move faster than bureaucrats, corn sells at a premium here, largely because the world's largest beef-packing plant operates five miles down the road from Mr. Loder's farm. 
 "I'm locked into wheat because the Government won't let me change," said Mr. Loder, who last year received $32,500 in subsidies, out of a total revenue of $531,000. "The corn could go from my combine here, one mile down the road to the feed lot -- and the manager would love to have it."
If Mr. Loder has his way, Congress will soon approve legislation that will allow him to plant all the corn he wants. By Sept 29, the House Agriculture Committee is expected to vote on what could be the greatest shift in farm policies since subsidy payments started in 1933.
Offering a 1990's style of New Deal to the nation's commodity farmers, the bill held most likely to succeed would give farmers freedom to choose their crops in return for a gradual weaning from Federal subsidy checks.
Representative Pat Roberts, the Kansas Republican who is chairman of the committee, said his bill, the Freedom to Farm Act, has "an excellent chance." And if the bill is approved by the House committee, the Senate Agriculture Committee is likely to pass a similar measure. This week Republicans worked to win to their side the votes of Southern Congressmen opposed to subsidy cuts for cotton farmers.
With Republican support strong for easing away from this American-style central planning, the Roberts bill would cut subsidy payments roughly in half over seven years, counting for inflation. Reducing projected crop payments by $13.4 billion, the bill is intended to help meet a Congressional goal of balancing the national budget by the year 2002.
"Annual set-asides would be eliminated," a bill document said, referring to longstanding farm land reserve policy. "Critics could no longer charge that the Government pays farmers not to farm."
The future of farm subsidies after 2002 would be studied by a new Government committee, the Commission on 21st-Century Production Agriculture.
Hardly the work of urban liberals, the attack on the long sacrosanct farm subsidies is being led by Mr. Roberts, a 59-year-old conservative who for 15 years has represented the state's First Congressional District. Known here as the "Big First," the western Kansas district encompasses 640,000 people scattered over an expanse of the Great Plains that is larger than New York, New Jersey and Connecticut combined.
It is this prosaic landscape of long horizons and endless skies that makes Kansas the nation's largest beef processor and largest producer of wheat and sorghum. Last year the state's highly efficient farmers produced a Missouri River of grain: slightly more than one billion bushels of wheat, corn, sorghum and soy.
Partly because of Mr. Roberts's power in Congress, the Big First is the nation's champion district for crop subsidies, receiving $5.45 billion over the last decade.
And it is here in this farming town of 24,600 people in southwestern Kansas where farmers say they are willing to take smaller subsidy checks as long as they are allowed to pursue market trends in deciding what they want to grow.
"It makes us better farmers to have to sit down and to decide what to grow on our own land," Marc Miller said over coffee today as an early snow sifted over his fields. "A lot of other businesses are not subsidized. On Main Street, it's the battle of the fittest."
Government planning does not keep pace with the local economy's dynamism. Offering mild weather, low wages and abundant supplies of alfalfa and corn, this corner of Kansas is becoming a magnet for dairies, slaughterhouses and hog farms. Potatoes can be harvested here two weeks before the Idaho crop.
But farmers cannot leave and then re-enter the subsidy program from year to year. To remain in the crop subsidy program, Mr. Loder, for example, must surrender his freedom to choose what he can grow on 75 percent of his land. On this land, covered by the subsidy program, the apportioning of crops must be maintained year after year.
Farmers like Mr. Loder, no longer content to follow Washington's crop quotas, say they want the flexibility to pick and choose among high-paying crops.
"I'd rather get my money from the market than from a subsidy," Terry Gigot said at the Agriculture Department office here before hoisting his tall frame into his pickup truck. "When you receive subsidies, you feel like you are taking welfare."
Hardly an isolated opinion. Of nearly 10,000 farmers who responded last year to an Agriculture Department poll, 41 percent wanted to phase out subsidies and 37 percent said they wanted subsidies to continue. In the last month, the Freedom to Farm bill has been endorsed by state and regional newspapers ranging from The Garden City Telegram to The Kansas City Star.
The farmers' confidence that they can make it on their own stems from a variety of factors.
Until 1960, American farm incomes averaged about half that of the nation as a whole. Since 1970, despite some wild fluctuations, farm incomes have roughly kept pace with national levels.
Here in Kansas over the last 40 years, wheat yields have doubled and corn yields have increased sixfold. In the same period, the number of Kansas farms declined by half, and the average size doubled. But in a land of $110,000 harvest combines, profit margins can be razor thin.
"Producers are going to get steadily larger, more sophisticated and more corporate," Ernest A. Yake, executive vice president of Bank IV, predicted of farm life after subsidies. "The individual might get lucky for a few years. But when it goes bad, he's going to be hit right between the eyes."
With farmers in better financial shape, subsidies have already started to fall. Target prices -- the prices that trigger subsidy payments -- have been frozen since 1990 for corn, wheat and sorghum.
Over the last decade, crop payments to Kansas farmers dropped by half, to $467 million last year. Here in Finney County, where 90 percent of the county's 480 farms are in the subsidy program, crop payments last year hit their lowest level in a decade -- $7 million.
"This year, all advance payments for barley, wheat and corn will have to be paid back," predicted Thais E. Frieouf, county director for the Agriculture Department's Farm Service Agency. Wheat is selling here for $4.30 a bushel, well over the $4 subsidy trigger price. Corn is selling for $3.19 a bushel, also over the $2.75 trigger price.
With payments falling, some critics maintain that the new farm bill is merely a ploy to keep subsidies before they vanish.
"Freedom to Farm locks in a lot of spending for commodity programs which wouldn't have to be made," said Kenneth A. Cook, president of the Environmental Working Group, a Washington-based research group that is critical of the program.
Dan Glickman, a former Kansas Congressman who is now Secretary of Agriculture, warned last week in Washington: "Providing yearly payments to producers, regardless of how much they are receiving from the marketplace, is not reform, it's a windfall."
Democrats in the House Agriculture Committee have opposed the Freedom to Farm measure, offering instead a bill to maintain production quotas and to cut subsidies by only $4.2 billion over seven years.
Farmers scalded by previous price cycles fear that a lifting of Government production controls could unleash megaharvests and subsequent price collapses.
"We definitely have the ability to produce more," said Mr. Gigot, a third-generation wheat and corn farmer. "But when we turn it loose, the prices inevitably will crash."
Many farmers, citing their fear of overproduction, said the Freedom to Farm plan would be successful only if it was linked to an aggressive export promotion program and to a Congressional guarantee against export embargoes. This year the nation's farm exports are expected to increase by 12 percent, to $49 billion.
Believing that the world should become one large duty- and subsidy-free supermarket, many Kansas farmers are convinced that a growing world demand can swallow up the nation's growing production. Over the last 15 years, world grain consumption increased by about 20 percent. But with production controls curbing American harvests, most of the new demand was met by plantings outside the United States.
Conjuring up visions of booming Asian markets, several farmers here cited a projection that if each resident of China were to eat two more eggs a week, the grain needed to feed the extra chickens would be equal to Australia's entire harvest.
But Kansas farmers complain that while European governments heavily subsidize food production and exports, the United States cuts subsidies and uses food exports as a foreign policy weapon.
"If we are going to take a hit on the guaranteed income side, then the Government should take a hit on one of its best foreign policy tools," Mr. Loder said. "What difference does it make if we don't sell grain to China, when they can buy grain from the Australians, the Europeans?"
If the State Department were to move to Kansas City, one farmer predicted, American food exports would flow a lot faster.
"It's been years and years since we have sold wheat to Cuba -- and the Canadians love that," complained Vance Ehmke, president of the Kansas Association of Wheat Growers.
Mr. Ehmke, who farms near here, also asserted that farmers wanted freedom from export embargoes. He bitterly recalled an embargo imposed by President Richard M. Nixon after international soy prices rose to record heights in the 1970's.
"We sent a signal to Japan that we were not a reliable soy producer," the wheat farmer recalled. "The Japanese encouraged the Brazilians to plant soy. Now Brazil is the world's largest soy producer."
Indeed, with only 2 percent of the nation's population living on farms, Mr. Ehmke feared that an overwhelmingly urban and suburban Congress would not have the stomach to deal with one possible corollary of free markets: rising food prices for consumers.
Low, stable grain prices contribute to low supermarket prices for milk, meat and bread. Americans spend about 12 percent of their household budgets on food, the lowest percentage of any major industrialized nation in the world.
"In a market-oriented economy, there will be more volatility in food prices," Mr. Ehmke said. "In China and Asia, those economies are going to come on stream and compete with American consumers."
He added: "We are being sold a market economy. American consumers better stay out of it and not whine when it happens."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

BUDGET CUTS IMPERIL MILITARY SCHOOL
The military's prep school at Fort Monmouth, N.J., is the main way for black applicants to reach West Point: half of all black cadets currently at West Point came from the school. But although blacks in the United States Armed Services account for barely 11 percent of the officer corps -- despite making up 30 percent of the enlisted ranks -- Congressional budget cutters may eliminate or severely reduce enrollment at the prep school and those from which the other military branches draw many of their minority officer candidates. [Page A1.]
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
SCHOOLS A MESS, SOLUTIONS ELUSIVE
For years now, it has been widely acknowledged that the governing structure of New York City's schools is a mess. The teachers' union has said so. Mayors and governors have said so. Parents' groups and lawmakers from both parties have said so. But acknowledging that there is a problem and solving it are two vastly different things, particularly when the State Legislature is involved. News analysis. [B3.]
 
Highly sensitive metal detectors, newly deployed at 34 schools this year, are one part of the school system's response to repeated calls for a Police Department takeover of the school system's safety division. [B3.]
 
FARE INCREASE LOOMS, AS DO 'NEW TOKENS'
Once upon a time, there was a Transit Authority that cried, "New Token!" It most recently cried "New Token!" when it planned to raise fares in 1991. But the Transit Authority (heh! heh!) was only fooling. The fares went up, but the tokens did not change. Now subway and bus riders are facing another fare increase. And once again, the Transit Authority is crying, "New Token!" [B3.]
 
PENALTY UPHELD ON OFF-DUTY OFFICERS
A Federal appeals court in Manhattan upheld a lower-court ruling that the Police Department can discipline off-duty officers who blocked traffic during a rowdy demonstration at City Hall in 1992 without violating their First Amendment rights. The ruling ended a two-year legal battle for 57 officers who were docked 10 vacation days for participating in an ugly demonstration at City Hall on Sept. 16, 1992. [B3.]
 
IN NINTH CHESS GAME . . . A WINNER
Viswanathan Anand smashed Gary Kasparov with a powerful queenside attack in Game 9 of the world chess championship. Thus the 25-year-old Indian grandmaster brilliantly seized the lead in the 20-game match, 5 games to 4. It was the first decisive result in the match, breaking a record string of eight draws. [B2.]

PORT AUTHORITY PLANS FACE LIFTS
Port Authority officials promised face lifts for PATH stations and the Lincoln and Holland tunnels over the next two years, prompting Mayor Giuliani to accuse the authority once again of doing more for New Jersey residents than for New Yorkers. [B5.]
 
Long Island Rail Road customers think trains are too few, too late and too dirty, and for the first time in four years, they think the railroad is getting worse, a new survey says. [B5.]

A black Porsche that collided with a minivan on Route 9W in Tenafly, N.J., killing five people, had been modified for racing and was being driven at high speeds, officials said. [B5.]

HEADLINE: New Tactic Is Tested on Illegal Immigrants

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Sept. 25

 BODY:
In the first major sweep of illegal workers in non-border states, Federal immigration officials have arrested or deported 4,044 illegal immigrants and replaced about 2,400 of them with legal workers, the authorities said today.
The raids, termed Operation South P.A.W. (Protecting American Workers), focused on assembly plants, food processing operations, restaurants and construction sites in six Southeastern states in the last three months. 
 This first "interior enforcement" effort -- as opposed to those on the nation's borders -- only skimmed the surface of the problem of illegal immigrant workers in the region, said Thomas P. Fischer, district director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service here. He estimated that the permanent population of illegal workers in the region approached 100,000; they are drawn to the area by the same vibrant economy, jobs and relatively low living costs that attract millions of legal workers every year.
"The illegal-worker problem is no longer a border-state problem only," Mr. Fischer said. "The border states are becoming pass-through areas for immigrants being drawn to jobs in other areas."
In the operation, 20 employers were arrested or investigated for "a willful pattern" of immigration-law violations in their hiring, immigration officials said, and 10 others were fined up to $15,000 each. I.N.S. officials did not provide the names of specific businesses today.
After illegal workers were found, the officials helped legal residents get those jobs, the officials said. The immigration officials got the names of legal residents looking for work from local employment services. After a raid, they met with the employer and offered to use those lists to help fill the gaps in the employer's depleted work force. As a result, some 2,400 legal workers were hired, Mr. Fischer said.
News of the operation caught many advocates for immigrants and immigration reform by surprise. They said such raids were discredited tactics in immigration enforcement because they created more fear in communities than deterrence among employers. The Clinton Administration, said Frank Sharry, executive director of the Immigration Forum, had received high marks for stepping up border enforcement and the monitoring of employers, which his group and others contend are more effective tactics.
"After excellent progress and progress greater than the two previous administrations in immigration enforcement, the Clinton Administration seems to be resorting to methods that have long been discredited," Mr. Sharry said. "Do they have a better way of doing this, or are they just trying to get headlines as we head into an election year?"
But the I.N.S. Commissioner, Doris M. Meissner, defended the effort, saying it was consistent with efforts to keep illegal workers from crossing the borders and to find abusive employers and sweatshops using illegal workers. The raids were not the kind of infamous sweeps in which immigration officials descended upon immigrant neighborhoods and social events to pick up people randomly, generating fear, she said. The raids were based on solid investigative leads and aimed at businesses that appeared to be willfully violating the law, she added.
"This operation was very carefully put together," Ms. Meissner said, "and we believe that such interior enforcement relieves pressure on the border. We are saying, 'If we find you at the border, we will send you home, and if we find you at the workplace in the interior, we will send you home.' "
Of the six states affected, Georgia had the largest number of illegal immigrants arrested and detained or deported: 1,351. David Poythress, the state's Labor Commissioner, suggested that Georgia had a high number of illegal workers because migrant workers from other countries came to the state to plant or pick crops and then remained. With the bustling economy of the state, and as it prepares for the 1996 Summer Olympics, many illegal workers have been attracted to the state to fill jobs that American citizens and other legal residents will not fill, he said.
The immigration service began its sweeps in June, hitting businesses in Alabama, Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, Mississippi and Tennessee. Illegal workers from 45 countries were found, and the operation turned up a range of violations, officials said.
In a Chinese restaurant in Jackson, Miss., officials found a 13-year-old Mexican boy working 12 hours a day, seven days a week for $21 a day. In Atlanta, they found illegal immigrants working for $15 an hour as skilled carpenters at local construction sites.
"Now there is an African-American, who didn't have a job, working on that construction site, making more than $30,000 a year," Mr. Fischer said.
In some places, employers learned of the raids before they were carried out, officials said. At a assembly plant in west Tennessee, the entire work force of 268 was "out sick" when investigators showed up.
Mr. Fischer said the average wage paid to the illegal workers had been $7 an hour. When agency officials factored in the illegal workers who they believe slipped through their net, they projected that they had "redirected to America's workers" about $55 million in gross salaries. The entire cost of the operation was $750,000, Mr. Fischer said.
But the operation was criticized by Gail Hoffman, director of an immigrant assistance program called Bridging The Gap in Atlanta. She said the agency's depiction of its efforts as saving American jobs had the effect of "demonizing" immigrants in general.
"It makes them look like terrible people," she said, "and not mothers and fathers and families, which they are."

HEADLINE: Gambling Fuels Louisiana Voter Anger

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 20

 BODY:
From the days of Huey P. Long through the era of Edwin W. Edwards, the voters of Louisiana have shown a remarkable tolerance for political corruption. This year, they may finally have had enough.
The reason is gambling. Since the last gubernatorial election, four years ago, Louisiana has become a 52,000-square-mile casino. There is gambling on the land, gambling on the rivers, gambling on the lakes, gambling in bars and restaurants, gambling at truck stops, even gambling in doughnut bakeries and barber shops. 
 And, to the surprise of few, with the arrival of slots, craps and video poker has come the enrichment of politicians and their cronies. First it was revealed that Governor Edwards's son Stephen and several of the Governor's closest allies had secured profitable contracts to represent gambling companies regulated by the state. Then last month, the Federal Bureau of Investigation disclosed that it was investigating whether top legislators took all manner of bribes to kill bills that would have allowed Louisianians to vote on repealing video poker in their communities.
The voters' disgust, both with the corruption and with the Legislature's approval of gambling without a referendum, is palpable at any gathering of the men and women now running to succeed Mr. Edwards. Sixteen candidates -- seven of them considered serious contenders -- are on the ballot for the Oct. 21 nonpartisan primary, and their contest has been thoroughly dominated by the need to clean up state government.
While corruption in Louisiana is seemingly on the rise, the state remains at the bottom of almost every ranking of quality of life and government: last in teacher salaries and bond ratings, first in poverty, fourth in unemployment and violent crime. Polls show that voters are furious that their politicians seem to be the greatest beneficiaries of state government, and the gubernatorial campaign has been become a race to tap that anger.
In a recent televised debate, Phil Preis, a 45-year-old Democratic lawyer from Baton Rouge who is running as an outsider, asserted that "the only growth industry we've got in Louisiana right now is the F.B.I."
Reacting to public-opinion polls, all of the major candidates have proposed some restrictions on gambling. Typical proposals have been to allow Louisianians to vote on whether to repeal various forms of gambling or to ban campaign contributions from gambling interests. All of the candidates have sworn off contributions from lobbyists and businesses involved with gambling, although newspapers have discovered that some have accepted them anyway.
The front-runner in the race, former Gov. Buddy Roemer, a Democrat-turned-Republican who lost his re-election bid to Mr. Edwards in 1991, is being attacked by his opponents for signing the 1991 legislation that allowed the state to license 15 riverboat casinos and for failing to veto a bill that allowed video poker at truck stops, restaurants and taverns. Mr. Roemer acknowledges that permitting video poker, the focus of the F.B.I.'s bribery investigation, was a mistake.
Although most of the subjects of the F.B.I.'s investigation are Democratic legislators, Democratic Party officials have blamed Mr. Roemer for the scandal, calling him "the godfather of gambling in Louisiana." Some candidates have even criticized Mr. Roemer for playing host to weekly poker games in the Governor's Mansion.
"Everybody's on television with ads talking about corruption, talking about gambling contributions," said Bernie R. Pinsonat, a Baton Rouge pollster. "As one legislator told me, anything coming over my desk next year with ethics on it, I'm voting for it."
The heightened moral outrage over corruption is only one of the ways this year's race may reflect the end of an era in Louisiana politics.
For only the second time in 24 years, Mr. Edwards is not on the gubernatorial ballot, having chosen not to run for a fifth term. Although all but one of the governors elected this century have been white Democratic men, none of the five leading contenders this year fit that description.
Two of the candidates -- Mr. Roemer, 51, and State Senator Mike Foster, 65 -- have switched to the Republican Party. Two Democrats are women, State Treasurer Mary L. Landrieu, the 39-year-old daughter of former New Orleans Mayor Moon Landrieu, and Lieut. Gov. Melinda Schwegmann, 48, whose family owns New Orleans's largest grocery chain. The company has plastered Ms. Schwegmann's face on the 2.5 million grocery bags, both paper and plastic, that leave its Schwegmann Giant Super Markets each week.
Another top contender is Representative Cleo Fields, 32, a black Democrat from Baton Rouge whose chances improved recently when another black Congressman, William J. Jefferson of New Orleans, withdrew from the race.
If Mr. Fields is able to consolidate his support among black voters, who represent 28 percent of Louisiana's 2.26 million registered voters, he could become the first black candidate to make a statewide runoff, held between the top two candidates if none wins more than 50 percent of the primary vote. But in the scheduled Nov. 18 runoff, Mr. Fields would be considered a heavy underdog against Mr. Roemer, who would win between 25 and 30 percent of the primary vote, according to recent polls.
That dynamic has created a migraine headache for the mayor of New Orleans, Marc H. Morial, a Democrat and perhaps the most popular black elected official in the state. If he endorses Mr. Fields, he could contribute to the victory of a Republican governor. But he may offend his black supporters if he endorses one of the white Democrats, presumably Ms. Landrieu on the theory that she could beat Mr. Roemer.
Mr. Roemer, the Harvard-educated former Governor, once a liberal by Louisiana standards, is running hard to the right. In 1991, Mr. Roemer became a Republican, but was outflanked by the former Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke and finished third. Mr. Duke then took more than half of the white vote in losing the runoff to Governor Edwards.
Recognizing Mr. Duke's appeal, Mr. Roemer is now calling for chain gangs for prisoners, the death penalty for drug dealers, drug testing for welfare recipients, a statewide curfew for juveniles, and term limits for lawmakers.
Opponents have criticized him for acting out of mere expediency.
"I remember him saying four years ago, 'I'll never let anyone get to the right of me again,' " said State Representative Quentin Dastugue, a conservative Republican who dropped out of the race last month. "Roemer will do anything and be anybody you want him to be to be Governor."
But Mr. Roemer and his supporters see his evolution as a matter of maturity.
Like Bill Clinton and Michael S. Dukakis, two other young governors who mounted comebacks after being bounced out of office, Mr. Roemer is using his speeches and advertising to apologize for the arrogance and ineffectiveness that typified his first term. He was known then for his bullheaded fights with the Legislature, his refusal to return telephone calls, even his decision to wear blue jeans to a meeting with the Japanese ambassador.
"I'm older, slower, not nearly as smart as I thought I was, but I might be a little wiser," Mr. Roemer, now graying, says at every turn.
If he can sell his more conservative message in Louisiana, a state won by Mr. Clinton in 1992, it will only reinforce the sense that the President cannot win in the Deep South in 1996.
In the only other gubernatorial races this year, the Governor of Mississippi, Kirk Fordice, a Republican, is favored for re-election, and a conservative lawyer, Larry Forgy, is running a strong race to become the first Republican elected governor of Kentucky in almost 30 years.
Some political analysts do not discount the possibility that Louisiana, where 69 percent of all voters are registered as Democrats, is now conservative enough to put two Republicans -- Mr. Roemer and Mr. Foster -- in the runoff. "That would be bubba heaven," said John Maginnis, editor of the Louisiana Political Review.

HEADLINE: Clerk Is Charged in Killing of 7-Year-Old

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 25

 BODY:
In what may become the first case tried under New York State's new death penalty law, an unemployed grocery clerk was charged today with the kidnapping and murder of a 7-year-old girl who disappeared on Thursday while playing in front of her house here.
The authorities said that after several days of questioning, the 25-year-old clerk, Lawrence Whitehurst, led the police to woods on the outskirts of town before dawn today, to a pile of twigs and debris that covered all but a foot of the girl, Rickel Knox. The Ulster County District Attorney said he won Mr. Whitehurst's cooperation by agreeing to sign a plea bargain that was actually a ruse to find the victim. 
 "We would never have found that child without him leading us to her," the District Attorney, E. Michael Kavanaugh, said.
Mr. Kavanaugh said that he would ask a grand jury, probably this week, to indict Mr. Whitehurst for first-degree murder, a capital offense, and that he would seek the death penalty if he won a conviction.
Rickel, a second grader, had just taken off her roller skates and was expecting her mother home from work on Thursday afternoon when Mr. Whitehurst lured her into his car, the authorities said today.
They said they suspect that she was already dead when the police first interviewed Mr. Whitehurst two and a half hours after she was reported missing. He was questioned because Rickel's baby sitter was Mr. Whitehurst's father, Lawrence Miller, who was also watching Mr. Whitehurst's two children that day.
"This was not a situation where you can warn a child to stay away from strangers," said Chief James K. Riggins of the Kingston police. "The child knew him, she knew her parents knew him, she knew his children. It wasn't unnatural for her to get in his car."
Under the new capital punishment law, which went into effect on Sept. 1, the death penalty may be sought for first-degree murder if a defendant intended to kill the victim while committing another felony crime, like kidnapping or rape.
Mr. Kavanaugh would not say whether Rickel was sexually assaulted until the results of forensic tests were available.
Because of the rigorous court challenge that is likely to meet the state's first capital punishment case, Mr. Kavanaugh said he asked for help from forensics experts from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who came from Boston to work with the New York State Police and the local police to insure that the evidence would withstand scrutiny.
The police first questioned Mr. Whitehurst two and a half hours after Rickel was reported missing because he had been at his father's house and left his children there, Mr. Kavanaugh said. He made some inconsistent statements, he said, but despite more questioning on Friday and Saturday, there was not enough cause to arrest him until early Sunday morning, after the police found a witness who saw Rickel get into Mr. Whitehurst's car.
Mr. Whitehurst, who the authorities said they believe was using crack cocaine on Thursday, was arrested a few years ago on a misdemeanor drug charge. That is his only arrest record, the police said.
Because Mr. Whitehurst indicated that Rickel could still be alive, Mr. Kavanaugh agreed late Sunday night to enter into a plea bargain. The arrangement would have limited Mr. Whitehurst's possible sentence to 10 years to life if Rickel were found alive and 15 years to life if she were found dead.
Mr. Kavanaugh said he might have taken the contract, which both sides signed, into account if Rickel had been found alive but that he knew all along that if the child was dead, he would not honor it.
"By 10 o'clock Sunday night, we were not even close to solving this crime," Mr. Kavanaugh said. "The agreement is not something I'm comfortable with, but I would have done a deal with the devil to get that child back safely to her parents. I would be very surprised if under these circumstances, any court would uphold that contract. It is not an enforceable agreement."
Because Mr. Whitehurst may be charged with a capital murder, he is being represented by Jeremiah Flaherty, a lawyer with the state's Capital Defender Office. Under New York's death penalty law, a lawyer from that office is assigned to every person facing indictment for first-degree murder until a district attorney formally announces that the death penalty will not be sought.
In Kingston, a working-class city of 23,000, people are outraged. Dozens of residents came to court today to hear Mr. Whitehurst mumble a not-guilty plea at his arraignment.
Rickel's parents, Rickie Knox, an automobile detailer at a local car dealership, and Margaret Marable, who works for Family of Woodstock, a community services organization, declined to talk to reporters.
The Rev. Willie Hardin of the Riverview Baptist Church said he was speaking for the family.
"We were holding out all kinds of hope," he said. "But God is on the throne through it all. Rickel sang in the choir at church. She was a little songbird. She was a very happy child."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The body of Rickel Knox, left, who disappeared on Thursday while playing in front of her house, was found yesterday. A suspect, Lawrence Whitehurst, right, was charged with kidnapping and murder.

HEADLINE: 'New Media' Experts Debate Proposals to Reduce Immigration

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
A Congressional proposal for strict new limits on immigration, which critics say would undermine the ability of high technology companies to recruit foreign workers, may not create severe barriers to a growing new entertainment industry in New York City, economists and business executives said yesterday.
The "new media" industry has in recent years grown out of the dense concentration of entertainment companies operating out of Manhattan lofts and inexpensive offices. Hundreds of start-up companies have sprung up to find new markets for software, interactive video programs and other high technology products in publishing, television and advertising. 
 Unlike larger, more mature computer companies, executives say these new media companies haven't recruited many high technology professionals from abroad.
"These companies are so culturally based, I don't think new immigration rules will make a difference," said Gail Kleinberg-Koch, president of C A/S Comsearch, a Manhattan company that recruits workers for new media companies.
Because companies in the field concentrate on entertainment, she said their workers must combine technical expertise with an intimate knowledge of American popular culture -- from Wheel of Fortune to professional wrestling -- that few immigrants can offer.
But her view was not shared uniformly.
"That sounds ethnocentric to me," said Daniel Stechow, 32, the founder and president of Brainstorm Interactive, a Manhattan company that makes interactive video products. "What is American culture if not derivative of other cultures?"
Although Mr. Stechow's products, including a video of the Grateful Dead, are now marketed only to United States companies, he said two of his technical executives are immigrants, a computer artist from Japan and a programmer from India. He said he hoped to sponsor both for American citizenship, enabling them to become permanent employees.
But that might run headlong into immigration bills in Congress. Among other changes, they would cut the annual number of immigrants to 535,000 from 800,000 a year, and the annual number who could obtain citizenship for professional reasons to 75,000 from 140,000.
The Congressional proposal may be welcomed by many people in the New York region who have been laid off from large technology companies, including I.B.M. in Westchester County, Grumman on Long Island and Electric Boat in Connecticut.
"There are several categories of high-tech jobs where foreign recruitment would only add to a surplus of workers in the region," said Emmanuel Tobier, a professor of economics and urban planning at New York University and an expert on immigration.
But some new media companies were critical of the Congressional proposals.
"In my case, these rules would mean one less entrepreneur," said Yee Ping Wu, 40, a classical pianist and computer expert who formed Music Pen, a new media company in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan, in 1988. The company makes CD-ROM's and multimedia programs. It employs 600 people.
Ms. Wu immigrated to New York in the 1970's and stayed on, she said, as an illegal alien until she obtained citizenship under the amnesty program of the late 1980's.
"What makes New York interesting is its cultural diversity," she said. If the rules now proposed in Congress had been enacted a decade ago, she added, "I'd be in trouble."

HEADLINE: Ethics on Vacation

 BODY:
Gov. George Pataki is in Europe this week, searching for his roots. New Yorkers will understand his desire to visit his family homeland. Indeed, many of them have made similar trips themselves. Most of them, however, managed to do it without bringing along their own press spokeswoman. Most also paid their own way.
The Governor and his party, which includes his wife, mother and son as well as four aides and two state troopers, are visiting Hungary as guests of the Hungarian-American Chamber of Commerce. Later they will move on to Italy, where the Italian-American Chamber of Commerce is picking up the tab. 
 Mr. Pataki's staff says the point of the trip is to encourage trade between New York and the two countries from which his family emigrated. Desirable as that goal may be, it is hardly at the top of the state's present list of priorities. If Mr. Pataki is planning his schedule on a business basis, he might be better employed lobbying Washington on the Medicaid formula he has opposed.
The visit to Hungary is clearly a mixture of politics and pleasure, a family vacation plus a chance to remind the voters back home that the Patakis are not far removed from their immigrant heritage. By letting private business groups pay for this outing, the Governor has yet again shown himself tone-deaf to questions of conflict of interest.
Mr. Pataki, who came to office with a mandate to shake up state government, seems more than willing to accept the status quo when it comes to ethical standards. At a time when even Congress is showing a long-overdue interest in lobbying and campaign reform, New York remains a land of opportunity for lobbyists, fund-raisers and influence peddlers. Mr. Pataki has made no attempt to clamp down on gifts from lobbyists, set reasonable limits on campaign contributions or sell a reform agenda to the Republican majority in the State Senate, which seems to make a sport of killing ethics legislation.
Moreover, he has been setting a terrible example. He spent his first months as Governor on a fund-raising binge for a re-election campaign that is still three years away. His Economic Development Commissioner, Charles Gargano, is doing double duty as a key political fund-raiser.
Two senior members of his administration were discovered heading a Saratoga Race Course event that collected contributions from people doing business with their state offices. After that embarrassment, the Governor contended he was cleaning up his fund-raising procedures. But it turns out that his reform policy will still permit officials like Mr. Gargano to raise political contributions from people who do business with the state, provided they do not solicit those who conduct business with their own agencies.
This is mere cosmetics. Mr. Gargano, who this week is one of Mr. Pataki's fellow vacationers in Hungary, has influence within the administration that stretches well beyond the office he heads. The real road to reform is clear: The Governor should tell his officials that as long as they work for the taxpayers, they are out of the political fund-raising business, period.
The Hungarian trip is symptomatic of a much larger problem. Mr. Pataki should be setting a new tone, but he is operating like a champion of business as usual. His aides say he is not the first governor to let private interests underwrite his travel. But if the voters were satisfied with the way things were, they would not have elected him.

HEADLINE: Fall in Mortgage Rates Increased House Resales for August

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
Low mortgage rates drew more buyers into the market in August, raising sales of previously owned homes to a 15-month high, a real estate group said today.
The Mortgage Bankers Association reported today that sales in August of previously owned single-family homes rose to a seasonally adjusted annualzed rate of 4.11 million, the highest since a similar rate in May 1994. 
 August sales were 3 percent above July's 3.99 million rate and 5.1 percent higher than the 3.91 million pace a year ago. Every region contributed to the increase, with the Midwest registering the biggest gain.
Sales in the Northeast gained 3.4 percent, to a 600,000 annual rate. However, the median price for a used home in that region was $142,300, down from $145,000 in August 1994. The median is the midpoint, meaning half the homes cost more and half cost less.
David Lereah, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association, noted that interest rates were dropping again and leading to further shrinkage in housing inventories.
"You take the interest rate environment and combine it with the supply coming down and you have a very favorable backdrop for future housing construction," he said.
Edmund G. Woods Jr., president of the National Association of Realtors, agreed. "Buyers have taken advantage of the low mortgage rates and will continue to do so through the end of the year," he said.
The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation has reported that fixed-rate 30-year mortgages averaged 7.85 percent in August, up from 7.61 percent in July but well below the 9.15 percent in January.
They had fallen back to 7.57 percent last week, representing a considerable saving since the year began. The monthly payment on a $100,000 mortgage with a 7.5 percent interest rate is $699, while the payment on the same loan with a 9 percent rate is $805 -- a difference of $106. The mortgage rate stimulus to sales has shrunk the monthly supply of existing homes on the market to 5.1 months in August, down from 6.7 months in April, according to the real estate survey.
The Government reported earlier that the supply of new homes had fallen to a six-month supply in July, down from 7.2 months in February. It reports August sales on Friday.
"With the monthly supply coming down, it tells me that housing starts for September will be pretty good, that we will be able to sustain a healthy pace of construction and home sales," Mr. Lereah said.
Housing starts totaled 1.398 million at a seasonally adjusted annual rate in August, the highest level so far this year.
But offsetting some of the savings from lower mortgage rates was the national median price of a used home, which rose in every region except the Northeast. Nationally, it was $117,600, up 4.1 percent from $113,000 a year earlier.
Sales in the Midwest advanced 3.9 percent from July to a 1.06 million annual rate. The median price there was $97,600, compared with $89,700 in August 1994. Sales in the West rose 3.4 percent, to a 900,000 rate. The median price was $151,700, up from $149,100 a year earlier.
In the South, sales advanced 1.3 percent, to a 1.54 million rate. The median price was $102,900, compared with $98,100 a year earlier.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
30-Year Bond Up in Price On Light Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices were little changed yesterday in light trading ahead of the Federal Reserve's meeting on interest-rate policy today.
Prices of Treasury securities were generally lower, except for the long bond, which edged up 2/32 , to 10328/32 . Its yield was unchanged from 6.58 percent on Friday. 
 Trading volume was light, with many traders on the sidelines awaiting the Fed meeting or absent because of Rosh ha-Shanah.
Technical factors kept futures trading inside Friday's range, as the December Treasury bond futures contract closed at 113, with the high at 1132/32 and the low at the closing price.
Treasury prices felt pressure after a stronger-than-expected housing report raised inflationary concerns. The National Association of Realtors said yesterday that the number of home resales during August rose by 3 percent, to an annual rate of 4.11 million. Analysts had expected home resales to drop 1.3 percent, to an annual rate of 3.94 million.
Economists noted that the larger number suggested that despite the apparent sluggish pace of the economy, the housing sector was still doing well. Also fresh in traders' minds was last week's report on housing construction, which rose unexpectedly in August to the year's highest level.
William Gamba, senior vice president in charge of the government trading desk at Cowen & Company, said the housing report was a little "on the strong side."
Few market participants expect a change in interest-rate policy to come out of the Fed's policy-making committee meeting today. "But that doesn't mean we can't have another cut in interest rates down the road," Mr. Gamba said. "I think the Fed will wait until it sees something concrete from Washington regarding the budget.'
But a small minority in the market say there is an outside chance of some Fed action today.
Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said a strong case could be made for an easing.
" Although recent data have, on balance, been more upbeat than was evident prior to the July 6 easing," she said, "the data still indicate some significant pockets of weakness and subdued inflation. Since the current 5.75 percent Federal funds rate is seemingly still restrictive, a policy easing at this juncture should be the appropriate course of action."
The Treasury note auctions this week are not likely to present a problem for the market, Mr. Gamba of Cowen said, particularly after watching the backup in yields that have occured in the last three trading sessions.
Today, the Government will sell $17.75 billion of two-year notes, and tomorrow $11.5 billion of notes with a five-year maturity. In when-issued trading ahead of the auctions, the two-year note was selling at a price to yield 5.85 percent and the five-year note at a price to yield 6.06 percent.
At yesterday's auction of new three- and six-month bills, interest rates were mixed as the market awaited the outcome of today's Fed policy meeting. The average rate for a new three-month maturity fell 11 basis points, to 5.14 percent, while the rate on a six-month issue rose 5 basis points, to 5.27 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
In the municipal bond market yields were little changed amid concern that that the combination of slow investor demand and $3 billion in supply of new issues this week could cause dealers to raise interest rates in order to lure buyers into the market.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Regains Some Ground Vs. Mark, Swiss Franc and Yen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar gained against the German mark and the Swiss franc in thin trading yesterday as currency dealers took profits on the two European currencies.
The mark and the Swiss franc surged last week as doubts about the prospects for monetary union spurred a flight to the haven of Europe's two most stable currencies. That flight stalled today, letting the dollar and other currencies recoup some of their losses. 
 "It looks like a softer mark against Europe, and that's helping the dollar," said Dennis Pettit, foreign exchange manager at the Long Term Credit Bank of Japan.
The French franc, Italian lira, British pound and other European currencies also made gains against the mark.
The dollar also benefited from expectations that the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee would leave interest rates unchanged when it meets today. Lower rates tend to hurt the dollar by making United States deposits less attractive.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.4345 marks from 1.4247 marks on Friday and to 1.1565 Swiss francs from 1.1471. The dollar edged up to 100.52 Japanese yen from 100.1 yen. The British pound rose to $1.5702 from $1.5685.
On Thursday, the mark and Swiss franc soared against most other major currencies after senior German officials raised doubts about whether Italy, Sweden and other European countries would be able to meet the stringent economic criteria for monetary union laid out in the Maastricht treaty.
While the prospects for monetary union remain murky, the initial surprise caused by the remarks has largely been priced into exchange rates, traders said.
"There's a clearer picture now of what Germany and France think about E.M.U.," said Belal Khan, chief of foreign exchange sales at Bank of Tokyo referring to European monetary union. Still, Mr. Khan and other traders said they did not expect the mark to give back all its gains any time soon.
The dollar's rebound against the mark helped lift it higher against the yen as well, traders said.
Expectations that the Bundesbank will participate in a coordinated bout of dollar-buying, meantime, were damped by a speech by its president, Hans Tietmeyer. "Only in special situations and with good timing can coordinated interventions" make an impression on the markets, Mr. Tietmeyer said.
He acknowledged that the dollar's recent slump was "exaggerated." But ultimately, he said, the strength of the dollar depends on American efforts to reduce its budget deficit.

HEADLINE: Out of a Crisis, an Opportunity

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: TULTITLAN, Mexico

 BODY:
When Hugh D. Pace, Goodyear's manager here, heard on his car radio last December that the peso had crashed, dragging the nation's economy with it, he immediately met with his managers to assess the damage. Within days, he figured that domestic demand for their tires would plunge more than 20 percent, or 3,000 a day. His choices: lay off workers or find new export markets -- right away, before his warehouse overflowed.
Mr. Pace turned his office into a war room. On his walls, members of what he called Team 3,000 pinned outlines and diagrams of strategies to capture new foreign customers, especially in the United States. 
 Among the goals: sell 120 more truck tires a day to the United States. And 40 to 48 for mobile homes. Plus another 400 a day to a Chrysler plant in Mexico for new Neons headed north. And why not hawk a few tires in Venezuela? Or Switzerland?
His team members, aided by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company headquarters in Akron, Ohio, not only found enough buyers to make up for what turned out to be a 3,500-tire drop in domestic sales. They also found spots to sell 1,600 more, setting an output record at the plant, some 15 miles north of Mexico City. A factory that had imported supplies but exported not a single tire in 1992 now ships away half its production, mostly to the United States but also to South America and Europe. "From one day to another we passed from being an importer company to an exporter company," said Marcel Miota, Mr. Pace's production chief.
Goodyear is just one of many big American companies here that have compensated for the collapse of domestic demand by sending goods abroad, to the United States most of all. As the peso shriveled in value, these companies saw their labor costs, in dollars, fall by more than a third. The resulting flood into the United States of cheaper autos, televisions and other products, including tires, is turning last year's $1.4 billion trade surplus with Mexico into a $15 billion deficit.
The imbalance has revived the debate over whether the United States should have welcomed Mexico into a new North American free trade zone last year. Several Presidential contenders have already featured opposition to free trade with Mexico in their campaigns. Some economists predict that the deficit, reflecting slower Mexican demand for United States goods but mostly higher Mexican exports, will cost more than 100,000 American jobs this year.
Calculating the ultimate effects of Goodyear's turnaround and the wider trade deficit with Mexico is far from simple, though. In trade, unlike football, one side's gains are not always the other side's losses. Increased trade can benefit consumers and create jobs in both countries.
Herminio Blanco, Mexico's Commerce Secretary, noted that although Mexican exports to the United States have risen almost 30 percent this year, United States exports to Mexico are off less than 10 percent. "As soon as this crisis passes, this is going to be an excellent market," he said in an interview. "Mexico is an excellent source of jobs for the United States."
Mr. Blanco believes, however, that this year's export gains will be permanent, even a base for further advances. What is more, Mr. Blanco is pressing American companies to substitute local supplies for American parts at their Mexican plants.
Goodyear says that because its United States factories are already running flat out, it is merely adding production in Mexico. But many other companies have shifted jobs to Mexico this year -- mostly under long-range plans that have, if anything, accelerated since the peso's collapse lowered their labor costs. According to Labor Department records, Allied Signal, Mattel, General Electric and Zenith are some of the companies that have laid off American workers and moved production south. (Even so, Mexico's overall job losses from the economic crisis far exceed the worst projections for the United States' loss.)
Most unions say that Mexico's economic woes and the draining of jobs from the United States bear out their arguments against the trade pact. "Here's one of those situations where I wish we were wrong," said Mark A. Anderson, director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. task force on trade.
For all its new activity, Goodyear's tire plant here, the nation's largest, still seems like a mile-long relic of the industrial past. Outside, 48 years of grime have turned the plant the same color as its products. Inside, the darkness is punctuated by the hissing and clanking of hulking machines and the twinkling lights of small shrines, mounted on columns, to the Virgin of Guadalupe.
Goodyear commands a leading 30 percent of the Mexican tire market. But the plant's plodding ways under a hidebound union long discouraged renovations and ruled out exports.
By 1992, however, Mr. Pace saw how a pending North American Free Trade Agreement would eventually remove the 20 percent tariff that had protected Mexican plants from more efficient American competition. Mr. Pace called in the union to explain that Mexico could be swamped by imports. With grudging union cooperation, he cut more than 500 of the plant's 2,500 workers, who in 1992 produced 12,500 tires a day.
Mr. Pace, a lanky, slouching sloganeer -- "profit is not a dirty word," he lectured his workers, "it's why we're here" -- invited suggestions about improving productivity. Despite the cutbacks, output rose to 13,500 tires a day in 1993 and 14,700 in 1994. In gratitude, Mr. Pace renovated the fetid bathrooms, installing tile floors, marble counters and new showers.
Higher output required higher sales, mostly in the United States. In 1993, the plant began shipping tires north, although only 7 percent of output. Last year, after the trade pact took effect on Jan. 1, removing a 4 percent United States tire tariff, the plant exported about 20 percent of production.
The peso's December collapse threatened all the trust that Mr. Pace had painfully won. He called union leaders into his office for a message he soon repeated in letters to every worker. "We cannot promise you anything," Mr. Pace told the union chiefs. "But we will work 24 hours a day to find export business to substitute for domestic demand."
The United States topped his managers' target list, but Chile, Colombia, Peru, Venezuela, Western Europe, East Asia, even Russia, also came up. In his office, managers translated their discussions into task lists and diagrams at a flip chart on an easel, then pinned the pages to the walls. "The only thing not in the scenario was a square tire," said Mr. Miota, the production chief.
The managers then worked the phones, calling former bosses, colleagues and employees in Goodyear's global organization, reminding them of favors owed. With plants in 30 countries and a crisis always breaking out somewhere, Goodyear has become expert at moving tires to stronger markets, as long as they can be profitably sold.
Mr. Pace, at 43 one of the company's top foreign trouble-shooters, worked on his Goodyear friends from previous assignments in South America. He persuaded them to stock and sell some tire types from Mexico that they did not make themselves and some that they did.
The plant desperately needed molds from headquarters in Akron to make seven new tire models for the United States and more for South America. The reduced labor costs were a clincher. Since December, the peso has lost nearly half its value against the dollar -- tumbling to about 16 cents, from about 29 -- but union wages at this plant and many others have risen just 8 percent. "That devaluation helped us to be competitive," said Pablo M. Ross, Goodyear's logistics director here.
Goodyear will not disclose overall production costs. But Mr. Pace says supply costs are similar in the United States and Mexico. And for every dollar Goodyear spends in the United States on labor, it can get the same output for 62 cents in Mexico -- down from 90 cents before the devaluation.
Tire plants in the United States pay $17 an hour in wages alone. Mr. Miota says workers here average $10.50 an hour in wages and benefits, or more than $15 before the peso's plunge. While they are generally paid well enough to buy cars, own houses and earn the envy of friends and relatives, none of several workers interviewed said they were compensated nearly as well as Mr. Miota said. Nicolas Martinez Martinez, a senior power technician and one of the plant's best-paid workers, earns about 4,000 pesos a month, or roughly $3 an hour. Mr. Pace says that benefits more than double wages.
The workers bemoan the loss of purchasing power from inflation, which this year has run at an annual rate of about 50 percent. Mr. Martinez, used to vacations in Acapulco and other resorts, is staying home this year, citing the higher costs of everything from shoes to gasoline.
Still, employees are glad they work for a company that can export to preserve their jobs. "It's a very strong international company," said Juan Jimenez Salinas, glancing down from his forklift. He earns about $80 a week.
In Mr. Pace's office, export deals for new tires soon found their way from the sheets pinned on the walls to a central tally on the easel.
The Chrysler Corporation, which started using the plant's tires last year, agreed to take another 400 as its own exports rose. Next to the "Mobile Home 40-48 tires a day" entry, Mr. Pace marked "Done. Jan. 13, 1995." He also found new markets north of the border for Unisteel radial truck tires, high-performance Eagle car tires and private label tires. By midyear, exports to the United States more than doubled, to at least 5,200 a day.
The plant got far more help from other markets than managers anticipated. They were soon able to sell 2,600 tires a day to Latin America. Though sales there have slowed, beginning this month they have been selling 900 tires a day to Europe and about 100 a day to Japan.
All told, the plant is turning out 16,300 tires a day, 11 percent more than the year before. Mr. Pace plans to maintain or increase exports even when the local market picks up, as it is just starting to do.
By increasing productivity two-thirds in the last three years, he added, the factory has become a candidate for a major expansion.
In the long run, the plant will stop trying to make every type of tire the Mexican market needs and instead concentrate efficiently, like American plants, on a few models. Just watch what happens to his exports then, Mr. Pace said. "We've got this magnificent opportunity now, and we cannot let go of it," he said.
