HEADLINE: Bessie Delany Dies at 104; Co-Wrote 'Having Our Say'

BYLINE: By CHARISSE JONES 

 BODY:
Annie Elizabeth (Bessie) Delany, the younger of the two sisters whose wisdom and triumphs have been celebrated in a best-selling book and in the Broadway play "Having Our Say," died yesterday at her home in Mt. Vernon, N.Y. She was 104.
"She just took a couple of deep breaths and passed away," said Amy Hill Hearth, co-author of "Having Our Say: The Delany Sisters' First 100 years," the 1993 best-selling oral history. "And it's an important thing she died at home, in her bed, with her sister there. That's all she wanted." 
 Her 106-year-old sister, Sarah, known as Sadie, with whom she had lived for more than 100 years, seemed to handle her sister's death with the same strength that had carried her through a century.
"I'll just do the best I can," Sarah Delany told Ms. Hearth in an interview at her home. "I'll continue right on as if Bessie were here."
She added that for her sister, whose life was filled with many achievements, the last few years had been particularly special. "Bessie lived to be 104, and she lived her life the way she wanted to," she said. "And especially the last couple of years, she has been having a ball. Between the play and books, she has been having the time of her life. And she said you really couldn't ask for anything more."
The two sisters had lived so long and seen so much that to some it seemed they might live forever. Born a generation after the Civil War, they had triumphed over Jim Crow, worked in Harlem during its renaissance, borne witness to the feminist and civil rights movements and in recent years, become national celebrities.
Their award-winning memoir has been on the New York Times best-seller list for 19 months, sold more than 900,000 copies and been translated into four foreign languages. They were co-authors of a second book, "The Delany Sisters' Book of Everyday Wisdom" (Kodansha America, 1994) which has sold 160,000 copies. And in April their Mt. Vernon parlor was re-created on Broadway, in a dramatization that earned three Tony nominations.
Bessie Delany often marveled that the nation would be interested in what two elderly black women had to say. She wanted her life seen not so much as a story of blacks or of women, but of America.
The sisters' lives remained simple despite their celebrity. They rose early to eat a breakfast of oatmeal, went to bed after watching the MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour on a black-and-white television and had no telephone. They relied mostly on each other for comfort and company. In more than a century, they lived apart for only a few months. And Sarah Delany said many times that it was for her baby sister that she had lived so long.
Annie Elizabeth Delany was born on Sept. 3, 1891, in Raleigh, N.C., the third child of a former slave who became the country's first black Episcopal bishop. Raised on the campus of St. Augustine's College, she and her siblings were well-educated, nurtured and sheltered from the harsher edges of American racism.
But she and her sister often spoke of the first time they were told to go to the back of the trolley car. And they remembered how the staff at the drugstore refused to serve them. Still, Bessie Delany was undaunted. Known as the feistier of the sisters, she was once almost lynched for speaking rudely to a "rebby boy." And she often told tales of how as a child she would sneak a sip from the forbidden side of the water fountain. 'I'd just take a drink of the white water," she said. "It didn't taste any different."
She graduated from St. Augustine's in 1911 and worked as a teacher in North Carolina and Georgia to earn the money she needed to continue her education. The few months in 1912 that she and Sadie taught in different parts of the South was the only time they did not live together.
In 1917, the two sisters made their way to New York City. Bessie had planned to become a doctor but ultimately decided to go to dental school. She graduated from Columbia University in 1923 and became the second black woman to work as a dentist in New York.
Known as "Dr. Bessie, Harlem's colored woman dentist," Dr. Delany socialized with Cab Calloway, W. E. B. Du Bois and the doyennes of the Harlem Renaissance. But she treated many of Harlem's poor, and in 27 years of practice never raised her rates. It was $2 for a cleaning and $5 for a silver filling, from 1923 until the day she retired, in 1950.
Like her sister Sarah, the first black home economics teacher in a New York City high school, she never married or had children. They referred to themselves as "Negro maiden ladies" and lived together in a Harlem apartment, in a Bronx cottage and finally in the Mt. Vernon home they bought in 1957.
With the death of their youngest sister, Laura, in 1993, they were the last survivors among their parents' children. When asked in a 1993 interview if she could account for her and her sister's longevity, Dr. Delany replied, "Honey, we never married; we never had husbands to worry us to death." As for mortality, she said, "I haven't been afraid to live, and I won't be afraid to die."
Recently Dr. Delany had become more frail, Ms. Hearth said. And in the time the two women knew each other, she often spoke about death, though with characteristic sass and humor. "She was worried she was too mean to get into heaven," Ms. Hearth remembered, laughing.
A funeral service is to be held on Thursday at 10:30 A.M. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in Manhattan. And before the curtain rises on "Having Our Say" tonight, there will be a brief tribute at the Booth Theater.
In addition to her sister, Dr. Delany is survived by 14 nieces and nephews.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Bessie Delany, right, with her sister and co-author, Sarah, in 1993. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Rock Promoters Vie for Manhattan

BYLINE: By NEIL STRAUSS 

 BODY:
Ron Delsener didn't become king of the rock-concert scene in New York City by accident: it was through a series of strategic moves. By negotiating exclusive contracts to promote concerts at halls like the Academy and Roseland, he encouraged new bands to remain loyal to his company. Thus did Mr. Delsener take over Manhattan several years ago from John Scher, his only significant rival. Mr. Scher continued to promote regularly at other places on the East Coast, including the Meadowlands in East Rutherford, N.J., with an occasional foray into Madison Square Garden with the Grateful Dead or the Beacon with a smaller band. But for rock, Manhattan became essentially a one-promoter game.
Until today, that is, when promoter wars returned.
The crucial pawn was Irving Plaza, at 17 Irving Place, the smallest of Mr. Delsener's holdings. With a capacity of 900, Irving Plaza was the perfect place for Mr. Delsener to start young bands on his club circuit, moving them up to bigger venues: the Academy, Roseland, Jones Beach and, if their popularity continued to grow, Madison Square Garden. But Mr. Delsener didn't count on Irving Plaza's having a mind of its own. 
 "I was making no money, living hand to mouth," said Andrew Rasiej, one of the owners of Irving Plaza, about the club's exclusive contract with Mr. Delsener. Under this deal, which began in 1992, Irving Plaza received $500 a month in rent and was allowed to keep its revenue at the bar. All money made in ticket sales went to Delsener/Slater Enterprises, Mr. Delsener's company, which used it to pay the band and to cover advertising, insurance and other costs.
"When we initially signed on with Delsener/Slater, we were told by them that there were no profits to be made from a club this size, and that the only reason a promoter produces shows of this size is to establish a relationship with a band," Mr. Rasiej said. "But earlier this year we started doing our own research, and we discovered that the economics weren't what we were told they were. Delsener had made $250,000 since the beginning of our relationship, while we had lost exactly that much. We realized that we had to become promoters ourselves in order for the room to survive."
Mr. Delsener and his partner, Mitch Slater, both declined to be interviewed or to comment on Irving Plaza.
In April, when Delsener/Slater approached Irving Plaza about renewing its contract, Mr. Rasiej said, the club tried unsuccessfully to negotiate a deal in which it could cover its costs, thereby breaking even.
In the meantime, Mr. Scher's company, Metropolitan Entertainment, had been looking for just such an opportunity. "In September of 1993, I was given the mission of getting Metropolitan Entertainment back into New York City," said Carl Freed, who is in charge of the company's marketing and special projects. "It soon became clear that it was too difficult to open a new room in New York. The only way we could gain market share was for Ron and Mitch to lose a room. And with that mission, I went to help them do that."
Metropolitan Entertainment offered Irving Plaza a deal in which the club could promote all of its own shows and keep and distribute its box-office receipts, as well as have an equal share in the profits Metropolitan makes if a band that first performs at Irving Plaza moves on to a larger concert hall in the area. Irving Plaza's first concert under its new contract with Metropolitan, by the band Del Amitri, is to take place tonight, followed by 20 more concerts over the next month, ranging from the funk of Maceo Parker to the punk of Mike Watt to the dance music of the Chemical Brothers, a slightly more varied fare than in the past.
Unseating a promoter can have consequences. One concert-industry executive, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that Mr. Delsener and Mr. Slater were "doing everything they can to shut Irving Plaza down."
Mr. Rasiej said: "They maintained a monopoly. I broke the monopoly, and they're upset. I wish them well."
Mr. Scher said he had decided to return to Manhattan because of a change in the musical climate. "We dominated the stepping-stone club level when we ran the uptown and downtown Ritz in the late 1980's," Mr. Scher said. "But, candidly, we found two harsh economic realities: Promoting clubs is a losing proposition and, when we looked back over 10 years of doing clubs, we found that only about three or four artists out of thousands had graduated to the arena level."
With the recent popularity of alternative rock, however, more and more bands are experiencing rapid success, enabling a promoter to shepherd them quickly from a small club to large arenas and big profits. All things equal, a band will generally remain loyal to the promoter who first took a chance on it. Green Day, for example, which performed a Delsener/Slater concert at Irving Plaza in March 1994, became successful enough to perform at the Nassau Coliseum by the end of the year.
For concert audiences, the fallout from battling promoters can be good and bad. "The concertgoer, for the most part, doesn't know or care who the promoters are," said Bob Grossweiner, the New York bureau chief of Performance, a concert-industry magazine. "But the booking agents are going to start aggressively offering their acts to both promoters to see who gives them the highest bids. The result might be that when the promoters are paying more for the acts, there will be a little bit of an increase in ticket prices. On the other hand, in the case of Irving Plaza, at least they're improving the sound system and the lights."
Irving Plaza isn't the only club shifting the balance of power between Mr. Scher and Mr. Delsener. Livent Inc., a Toronto-based company run by Garth Drabinsky, who has produced "Showboat" and "Kiss of the Spider Woman" on Broadway, recently announced that next year it would begin renovating the Academy on West 43d Street, turning it into a Broadway theater and thus depriving Mr. Delsener of the second step on his concert-hall ladder.
Metropolitan Entertainment, in the meantime, has been growing. Mr. Scher, who is producing "Victor/Victoria" on Broadway, said that in the next three or four months he would announce the opening of a new Manhattan concert space that holds 3,000 to 6,000 people. More significantly, Metropolitan Entertainment began a multimillion-dollar joint venture on Sept. 8 with the Ogden Corporation, among other things a concert site operator, which, Mr. Scher said, will enable him to "develop concert halls both large and small in the principle markets we're promoting."
Where promoter wars in Manhattan once meant races for bands, they have now become races for venues as well. It is impossible to promote a concert without a place to hold it, and with rising real estate costs and increasing community-board opposition to clubs, it is getting harder to do that. Mr. Delsener and Mr. Scher have been scrambling for a foot in the door of existing clubs. They both have their first concerts at the Westbeth Theater in Greenwich Village coming up this fall, and Mr. Delsener recently helped promote his first concert at Tramps, in Chelsea. But representatives of Tramps and the Westbeth Theater said they were not considering an exclusive contract with either promoter.
"I've been competing with Ronnie Delsener for a long, long time," Mr. Scher said. "When the Meadowlands first got built, Ronnie took me out to lunch and thought we should be partners on promoting shows there. I said, 'Let's see how much money you made at Madison Square Garden on artists I broke in metropolitan New York, and we'll split that money, then we'll talk.' He looked me in the eye and told me he was sorry he'd have to put me out of business.
"Clearly, he didn't succeed. This is a big enough city for two major promoters, and we're here to stay."

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: Constance C. R. White 

 BODY:

Cussle on Sixth
Young Innovators, a new showcase series planned as a low-cost alternative to Seventh on Sixth in Bryant Park, has found itself locked in battle with Seventh on Sixth organizers.
Darnell Brewster, the producer of Young Innovators, which is to take place Oct. 28 to Nov. 3, said relations had been smooth with Seventh on Sixth and the New York Fashion Calendar, which traditionally acts as a clearinghouse and referee for the scheduling of fashion events, until last week, when Seventh on Sixth learned that the designers Donald Deal and Violeta Villacorta were switching from the tents to Young Innovators. To Seventh on Sixth, the shift means a loss of $27,000. 
 Mr. Brewster said that Seventh on Sixth, in phone conversations and by letter, had tried to dictate when Young Innovator shows could be held, even though times had already been allotted by Ruth Finley, publisher of the calender. Conflicting times can mean press and retailer attention, or lack of it, to a designer.
In a letter to Mr. Brewster, Bruce Rayvid, the producer of Seventh on Sixth, laid out times and dates for Young Innovators shows. A copy of the letter was routed to Swerdlin & Hassid, Seventh on Sixth's lawyers.
Mr. Brewster said that among other things, the times given (on the last day of show week for example) were undesirable. He added that Mr. Rayvid also called designers participating in Young Innovators to pressure them to change their dates.
Charles Short, a producer and publicity agent, said he had recommended that his client Ms. Villacorta participate in Young Innovators.
"It's been very difficult," he said. "Ruth Finley told me something could be worked out." He added that the sense he got from the Council of Fashion Designers of America was "It's our week, we own the time slots."
Mr. Rayvid did not respond to requests for comment left with his office yesterday. Fern Mallis, the executive director of the C.F.D.A. and Seventh on Sixth, said the organization did not endorse strong-arm tactics to elicit cooperation from designers who may not want to show under the tents. She said she could not explain why Mr. Rayvid had routed a copy of his letter to the lawyers.
"It's just not the way we do business," she said. "I have many, many different groups all over town calling me trying to do alternative fashion events and I've said, 'Fine.' We work with everybody."
She admitted that Seventh on Sixth had asked Ms. Finley to hold slots open for undetermined Seventh on Sixth shows because it was financially necessary to fill the tents in every time slot.
As Seventh on Sixth has become established, its hold on the show week calendar has grown. But each season, some designers elect to show elsewhere, whether for economic or creative reasons, and report feeling pressure from the organization.
Last season, Marc Jacobs and his partner Robert Duffy clashed with Seventh on Sixth when they held a Monday night show that coincided with the C.F.D.A.'s press party.
 
Ghost Puts Men in Velvet
After several false starts over the last few years, Tanya Sarne, the British designer who creates under the much-followed Ghost label, has found the perfect moment to inaugurate a men's wear collection. The clothes, which are made from the same soft velvets and stretch fabrics that she uses in her women's line, reflect the new "playboy" element in men's fashion. "I quite like men to wear pretty, frilly clothes," she said. "Throughout history some of the most masculine have -- not just frilly clothes, but makeup, too. It's clothes for rock stars." The clothes will be in stores in December.
 
A Minimalist Collection
Ron Shamask, whose rich, understated designs were emblematic of SoHo's moneyed artists and intellectuals in the 80's, is reintroducing his women's collection for spring 1996. For the first few seasons, the line will be sold exclusively at Barneys New York, which licenses and sells Mr. Shamask's men's wear. "I'm trying to create a collection that's about shape and form," Mr. Shamask said. "It's purity and a Minimalist approach -- but I really didn't dig in the closet to rework the past, though."

HEADLINE: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD;
Why Many Trailblazing Scientists Must Wait Many Years for Awards

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, M.D. 

 BODY:
MANY landmark scientific discoveries win prizes only years, even decades, later. Sometimes the lag reflects the time it takes to verify unorthodox findings or overcome long-held beliefs. Sometimes a discovery is so far ahead of its time that years pass before its significance is understood. In other instances, the delay reflects an establishment's habitual resistance to new ideas and endless foot-dragging by the scientists who nominate and serve on the award juries.
Consider Dr. Barry J. Marshall, who was among the winners of this year's Albert Lasker Awards, which were announced yesterday. Dr. Marshall was honored for finding that a bacterium, not stress, causes inflammation of the stomach and ulcers. The research was partly based on experiments he did on himself in the early 1980's. 
 More recently, other scientists have linked the bacterium, known as Helicobacter pylori, to cancer of the stomach. And scientific reports say that antibiotics appear to cure one rare form of stomach cancer.
Dr. Marshall is a brash Australian whose original findings were dismissed outright by many of the world's leading gastroenterologists and other specialists when they were published in The Medical Journal of Australia and in The Lancet. In 1986, he moved to the University of Virginia in Charlottesville.
It was only last year that a consensus meeting held by the National Institutes of Health said that antibiotics should be added to conventional treatments for ulcers, and the Lasker prize is one of the few awards that Dr. Marshall has received. Why was it so long in coming?
Human nature is one reason, said Dr. Michael E. DeBakey, the heart surgeon from Baylor University in Houston who has served as chairman of the Lasker jury for 30 years.
When scientists come up with a bold new idea, "there is usually a certain amount of reservation," Dr. DeBakey said in an interview. "Almost everybody is against it right away, and it takes a certain amount of time for the new idea to be validated. Then, five years later you cannot find anybody who objected to it!"
Science is inherently cautious. "It is inevitable that a certain amount of time passes before a good idea is recognized by one's peers, and while we may bemoan the length of the gap, there is some protection in having it," Dr. DeBakey said.
Nominations for Lasker Awards are made by officials of medical schools and research institutes and by former winners, independent of the voting jury. Members of the jury are assigned to review the work of nominees in preparation for the discussion that precedes the voting. It is a system similar to that used by the Nobel committee in Stockholm.
A delay of "10 to 15 years is about average," Dr. DeBakey said. "Sometimes it is much longer, and you feel badly about that."
Often there is a delay in recognition after a seminal finding until "people begin to realize that so many current findings are based on an original finding 30 years ago," Dr. DeBakey said.
Dr. Marshall's wait is short compared with some others.
Dr. Peyton Rous waited 48 years to receive his Lasker and 55 years for his Nobel Prize for cancer research. Dr. Joseph Murray waited 36 years before receiving his Nobel Prize after performing a pioneering kidney transplant operation.
Dr. Rosalyn S. Yalow won a Lasker Award in 1976 and a Nobel Prize in 1977, many years after she and Dr. Solomon A. Berson at the Bronx Veterans Administration Hospital developed the radioimmunoassay technique to detect tiny amounts of hormones and other substances. By 1976, Dr. Berson had died, an illustration that prize-worthy scientists need the good fortune to survive until their work is recognized. Posthumous Nobel Prizes and Lasker awards are not given.
Most award juries and sponsors play to safety, in no small part because of the embarrassment many have suffered after the findings that led to an award fell apart.
A Nobel committee, for example, awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1926 to Dr. Johannes Fibiger, a Dane, for the discovery that stomach cancer in rats was caused by a nematode parasite. Committee members believed that a similar parasite might cause stomach cancer in humans.
Though severe doubts soon arose about Dr. Fibiger's research, it was not until 1952 that other researchers could conclusively refute it, in part because Dr. Fibiger used strains of wild rats that others could not obtain.
Despite such errors, some science prize committees do reward scientists for controversial research.
Last year, for example, the Lasker committee gave an award to Dr. Stanley B. Prusiner, a neurologist at the University of California at San Francisco, for his research inferring the existence of a new class of disease agents called prions, even though he has not proved their existence to everyone's satisfaction.
The Nobel awards were created by the will of Alfred Nobel, the Swedish chemist and inventor of dynamite. Yet the prizes almost did not come into being. The King of Sweden and the Prime Minister went to court to fight Nobel's will in part because they believed that his wealth would be scattered around the world, to Sweden's loss.
Despite the Swedish Government's concerns, the Nobels have brought enormous political, economic and cultural benefits to Sweden. The Nobels are now considered the gold standard of scientific prizes, despite richer prizes from other groups.
The Nobels are considered a critical factor in keeping Sweden in the forefront of science. Committee members come from the ranks of that country's leading research centers and universities. They write extensive reports on the nominees' scientific contributions that help keep Swedish researchers continually aware of the cutting edge of science.
The Lasker Awards have often been called the American Nobels, largely because 52 of 275 winners have gone on to win Nobels.
Although the Lasker Awards for medical research are celebrating their 50th anniversary this year, they are nearly a half century younger than the Nobels, which were first awarded in 1901 and are due to be awarded next month.
In his will, Nobel said that the awards should be given for discoveries made the previous year. But Nobel committees have become much more conservative.
One reason that the Lasker and Nobel prizes have had continuing impact is that they are awarded by independent groups that generally have not succumbed to making the type of self-serving awards made by so many industrial or private interest group sponsors.
The Lasker Awards have reflected a mixture of politics and science.
In 1942, Mary W. Lasker, who died at age 93 in 1994, and her husband Albert, an advertising pioneer, created the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation to raise public awareness about major diseases and the need for increased research funding to conquer them. Though substantial, the foundation's $20 million assets are smaller than many others.
Yet Mrs. Lasker's influence was far greater than the amount of money she spent. She recognized that the nature of medicine was changing after World War II from a private system to a public institution. She contributed to the growth of Government support for research and helped direct where those funds would be spent by lobbying Congress and Presidents. Although the research benefited scientists and medical schools, many often resented her efforts as an intrusion on their independence and expertise.
"Her lobbying was even more effective than lobbyists who went with large amounts of money," Dr. DeBakey said. "She went with ideas and with what might be called humanitarian concerns, and it was very difficult to oppose that. After a while she gained the confidence of political leaders, and she was treated like royalty when she visited their office.'
Mrs. Lasker traded on the station that the Lasker awards gave her. "While she was lobbying for science, she was also achieving a certain prestige in science with her awards," Dr. DeBakey said.

HEADLINE: Geochemist Says Oil FieldsMay Be Refilled Naturally

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE 

 BODY:
COULD it be that many of the world's oil fields are refilling themselves at nearly the same rate they are being drained by an energy-hungry world?
A geochemist at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution in Massachusetts says she believes that hitherto undetected gas and oil reservoirs lying at very great depths within the earth's crust could stave off the inevitable oil depletion much longer than many experts have estimated. 
The scientist, Dr. Jean K. Whelan, whose research is part of a $2 million Department of Energy exploration program in the Gulf of Mexico south of New Orleans, has found evidence of differences in the composition of oil over periods of time as it flows from greater to shallower depths. By gauging degradative chemical changes in the oil resulting from action by oil-eating bacteria, she infers that oil is moving in quite rapid spurts from great depths to reservoirs closer to the surface.
Skeptics of Dr. Whelan's hypothesis acknowledge that oil is almost certainly flowing into certain reservoirs from somewhere, but say her explanation remains to be proved, as does the exact extent of the phenomenon.
A site in the gulf of particular interest to the Pennzoil Exploration and Production Company and several independent scientific teams, including Dr. Whelan's group, is Eugene Island Block 330, which is not an island but a patch of sea floor 700 feet beneath the water's surface. Discovered in 1972, an oil reservoir some 6,000 feet beneath Eugene Island 330 is one of the world's most productive oil sources; it has yielded more than one billion barrels, or 42 billion gallons, and is still going strong.
But Eugene Island 330 is remarkable for another reason: Its estimated reserves have declined much less than experts had predicted on the basis of its production rate.
Dr. Whelan's somewhat controversial hypothesis is a possible explanation.
Although the reservoir from which Pennzoil is pumping oil was formed at the time of the Pleistocene epoch less than two million years ago, oil now being recovered from the reservoir has a chemical signature characteristic of the Jurassic period, which ended more than 150 million years ago, Dr. Whelan said. The implication, she believes, is that highly pressurized oil from lower levels of "stacked" reservoirs is frequently breaking through geological barriers and "burping" upward, eventually reaching the reservoir from which oil is being pumped. The source of the pressurized gas Dr. Whelan believes to be powering the process is a bed of Jurassic period "source rocks," more than 30,000 feet deep, which are rich in very hot hydrocarbons.
Oil created during the Jurassic period from the decayed bodies of plants and animals that lived during the age of dinosaurs would initially have been a liquid, but in some cases, geological processes are believed to have gradually dragged oil reservoirs downward to great depths, where pressures are enormous and temperatures are greater than 700 degrees Fahrenheit. Under these conditions, oil is "cooked," decomposing into hydrocarbon gases consisting mainly of methane.
The methane, however, cannot exist in its normal gaseous form at such pressures and temperatures, but is transformed into a "supercritical fluid" -- neither a gas nor a liquid but something in between. Large amounts of oil can be dissolved in supercritical methane, and the oil-and-methane mixture is probably capable of flowing upward from deep reservoirs through faults, cracks and geological "plumbing" to higher reservoirs. At the higher levels where temperatures and pressures are lower, methane can no longer remain in its supercritical state, and the mixture of gas and oil separates into its respective components.
"It could be," Dr. Whelan said, "that at some sites, particularly where there is a lot of faulting in the rock, a reservoir from which oil is being pumped might be a steady-state system -- one that is replenished by deeper reserves as fast as oil is pumped out." Extensive fault systems like those along the California coast might offer such a geological environment, she said.
The discovery that oil seepage is continuous and extensive from many ocean vents lying above fault zones has convinced many scientists that oil is making its way up through the faults from much deeper deposits. Faulting associated with such seepage is common along the Pacific Coast, in parts of the North Sea, and the Gulf of Mexico, among other areas, Dr. Whelan said.
The amounts and types of hydrocarbons lying at great depths are highly uncertain, because oil companies have had little incentive to sink exploratory wells to depths of 20,000 feet or greater. The cost of drilling increases exponentially with depth, and there are still ample supplies of oil in relatively shallow reservoirs.
Dr. K. K. Bissada, a geochemist at Texaco Inc. in Houston, is doubtful that a true steady state exists in reservoirs that seem to be refilling themselves.
"I think we pump oil out much faster than oil can come in," he said. "But from a long-term perspective, I believe that hydrocarbons are coming in from great depths and are filling the newer reservoirs at shallower depths.
"It's impossible to put a number on the rate at which this goes on," Dr. Bissada said, "but I could imagine that this kind of stacked reservoir system, with favorable geologic plumbing between the reservoirs, might refill the upper reservoirs in, say, 10 or 20 years. If we were to go back to some old oil field that had been abandoned 50 years ago, we might drill a test well, and we might find fresh oil. The trouble is that that kind of experiment is too expensive in the present economic climate."
A recent report from the Department of Energy Task Force on Strategic Energy Research and Development concluded from the Woods Hole project that "these new data and interpretations strongly suggest that the oil and gas in the Eugene Island field could be treated as a steady-state rather than a fixed resource."
The report added, "Preliminary analysis also suggests that similar phenomena may be taking place in other producing areas, including the deep-water Gulf of Mexico and the Alaskan North Slope."
Dr. Thomas Ahlbrandt, chief of the United States Geological Survey's Petroleum Geology Branch in Denver, is among many skeptics who believe that the Woods Hole hypothesis has not been demonstrated, although experts appear to agree that an increase in estimated reserves is occurring at many sites.
"I have the impression that although the people who drilled at Eugene Island encountered a fault plane," Dr. Ahlbrandt said, "they did not find oil coming up through it. On the other hand, drilling is a high-risk proposition, and the fact that it didn't produce oil doesn't necessarily make the hypothesis wrong."
There is much evidence that deep reserves of hydrocarbon fuels remain to be tapped. A recent estimate by the Geological Survey of "conventional" oil resources within the 48 states and state waters offshore has doubled America's estimated oil reserves since the last estimate was prepared in 1989. Dr. Ahlbrandt said that the estimate of continental American oil resources was 60 billion barrels, up from 30 billion in 1989.
But Dr. Ahlbrandt hastens to add that this does not mean that prospectors are finding large new oil fields; it means that "people are becoming more clever at finding and extracting hydrocarbons from previously overlooked resources."
This results from a trend oil experts call "field growth."
In some cases, he said, an oil company may discover an oil field, pump it almost dry, and then, using new seismic techniques that produce three-dimensional images of the fine details of deep geological structures, discover that an unsuspected and untapped extension of the field exists in some new direction.
In other cases, Dr. Ahlbrandt said, prospectors may find new reservoirs by drilling beneath old ones, penetrating salt barriers that had obstructed seismic probes. Finally, oil companies sometimes unknowingly drill right through oil-rich deposits on their way to reservoirs they had identified at greater depths. From such drill holes, oil is sometimes discovered simply by piercing the drill casing with a few holes at relatively shallow depths and analyzing the fluid that flows into the pipe.
But petroleum experts agree that no one has more than a vague notion of how much gas and oil remain in the world, or how long it will last.
The Geological Survey recently estimated that the world has about 1.7 trillion barrels of oil from conventional sources, enough for about 75 years at current production rates. However, if the consumption of oil should increase at a modest 3 percent annually, the survey estimates, production could be maintained for only about 31 years.
But Dr. Edward D. Porter, senior economist at the American Petroleum Institute, says that the uncertainties are so large that the implied precision of such calculations should not be taken seriously. "The estimate of world oil resources could be off by as much as 700 billion barrels," he said.
Many past predictions have been wildly inaccurate. One of the better forecasts was made in the early 1970's by M. King Hubbard, a geologist, who predicted a peak in petroleum production in 1972, followed by a slow decline.
"Hubbard was pretty much correct about the trend of United States production, which has been declining during the last two decades," Dr. Ahlbrandt said, "but he extended that forecast to the world, and that was wrong. World production has not yet peaked, although many experts believe it will start declining in about 2015 or 2020."
The United States, he said, "is still the world's leading oil producer, although the Persian Gulf states own about two-thirds of the world's oil supply."
"They just curb their production rate," he added.
Possible improvements in technology could make a big difference, Dr. Porter said. New seismic techniques, in which sound waves are reflected or bent by geological structures, can now be interpreted to reveal very small oil reservoirs and other details of deep geological formations. Three-dimensional seismic technology, as well as measurements of the electrical conductivity of rock and other methods developed during the last decade "are as much better than old methods than is clinical magnetic resonance imaging better than conventional X-rays," he said.
Another imponderable is the future rate of oil and gas consumption, he said.
To some extent, consumption depends on the price of oil, but this, Dr. Porter said, is impossible to predict. Production curbs by oil-producing nations have effects on price that can be easily calculated, he said, but in the absence of such constraints, "the price of oil fluctuates chaotically."
Future prices will affect not only consumption but the willingness of oil companies to invest in the extraction of petroleum products from nonconventional sources -- tar sands, heavy oil and perhaps even shale. Experts estimate that 10 times as much petroleum is tied up in such sources than in conventional reservoirs, but the cost of recovering it is high.
The research needed to develop new sources is also expensive, and oil companies, together with many American industries, are reducing such expenditures.
"Everyone is scaling back research," said Dr. Bissada of Texaco.

HEADLINE: Seeking to Avoid Carter Comparisons, President Refines Comments

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
President Clinton wants to make one thing perfectly clear.
"Malaise is a state of mind," he said today, touching his finger to his tanned temple. "Funk is something you can bounce out of." 
 Worried about the parallels that have been drawn between his promise on Friday night to lead the nation out of its funk and Jimmy Carter's promise to lead America out of malaise, a vow that did much to sour Mr. Carter's re-election campaign, Mr. Clinton took pains today to make sure that his campaign does not get off on a downbeat.
At a press lunch in the White House, he said he had made a poor choice of words, and stressed, over and over again, that he was "very optimistic" and "feeling good" and that the country was not in a funk.
"I think if you were betting on which country is likely to be in the strongest shape 20, 30 years from now in the 21st century," he said, "you'd have to bet on the United States because of the strength and diversity of our economy and our society."
Mr. Clinton told reporters on Air Force One on Friday night that he was trying to lead people away from their "funk," which he described as anger about government, unease with the pace of technological change and fears for their jobs. To do that, he said, he wanted to talk more, explaining that he had not been talking to voters enough about "the big picture."
But after two days of unflattering comparisons in television reports with Mr. Carter, another Southern President, Mr. Clinton wanted to refine his comments a bit. He said he had been talking about how Americans felt in 1994, not 1995.
"I think it would be difficult to convince people that I am advocating a politics of national funk," he said. He warned reporters not to distort his words, while Vice President Al Gore walked behind him, pointed to their notebooks and jokingly spelled: "F-U-N-K."
Mr. Clinton is clearly into his campaign talking mode. He spent more than an hour at the lunch discoursing on Gen. Colin L. Powell, Speaker Newt Gingrich and President George Bush; his mistakes in office; the things that were perceived as mistakes but that he says were not; the things for which he thinks he does not get enough credit, and his "marketing" strategy for 1996.
When his spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, tried to get the President to leave right away for a national security meeting on Bosnia, Mr. Clinton testily brushed him off. He said: "That meeting's at 2:15. That's when I called it for."
Mr. Clinton stayed so much longer to talk that Mr. McCurry desperately tried again, saying, "Let's go, boss." Mr. Clinton, who had moved on to family values, still ignored him.
The President made his remarks at a session of that most peculiar Washington institution: a meal, usually breakfast, arranged between newsmakers and journalists by Godfrey Sperling Jr., a columnist for The Christian Science Monitor.
The White House presented Mr. Sperling, who was celebrating his 80th birthday, with a cake decorated with a replica of one of the high-cholesterol meals served at the breakfasts: coffee, Danish pastries, eggs, bacon and potatoes. Then, as the official White House transcript put it rather drily: "(Happy Birthday is sung to Mr. Sperling.) (Applause.) End. 1:47 P.M. E.D.T."
Like other Presidential candidates, Mr. Clinton at first tried to ignore the issue of Mr. Powell as a potential challenger for the White House. He refused to answer one question about Mr. Powell's strong popularity and deflected another about whether a black man could win the White House.
But he eagerly responded to a question about the "defining differences" between himself and Mr. Powell -- by listing all the things on which he and Mr. Powell agree. As he spoke, it was apparent that Mr. Clinton had studied Mr. Powell's public words in great detail.
"I was grateful for what he said about abortion, that he didn't want to criminalize it but that we should reduce it and emphasize adoption more because that's what I've worked very hard to do," Mr. Clinton said.
He said, "And I was grateful for what he said about affirmative action." He added, "All I can say to you is that on those statements that he has made, I am profoundly appreciative. I think it's helped America to kind of stay in the sensible center."
Mr. Clinton bristled when he was asked about Mr. Gingrich, denouncing the House Speaker's threat to have the Government default on its debts if there is no agreement on other issues like welfare and Medicare. "I'm not going to be blackmailed," he said.
But, for the most part, as he tries to make headway against the Republican domination of Washington, Mr. Clinton was eager to keep the tone positive. He took credit for the new Palestinian-Israeli agreement and progress in Bosnia as "examples of the imperative for United States leadership."
Mr. Clinton said he was determined not to repeat the mistakes of Mr. Bush, on which Mr. Clinton, as a candidate, had pounced so eagerly in 1992. "George Bush never got anyone to associate him with any achievement besides Desert Storm," Mr. Clinton said.
So at the first invitation, he rattled off what he considers his accomplishments. "The economy is in better shape," he said. "We passed the toughest crime bill in American history, and it's plainly playing a role in driving the crime rate down throughout the country. When there was no action on welfare reform, we gave two-thirds of the states, I think more than two-thirds now, the right to pursue their own reforms. And we have lowered the cost and increased the availability of a college education."
Mr. Clinton took exception to the suggestion that he needed to produce fresh ideas to compete with the Republicans in Congress. Echoing the convictions of other incumbent Presidents in trouble, including Mr. Bush, he said he had to do a better job of getting his words across.
"I may have a marketing problem," he said. "I do not have a substantive problem." If George Bush had made smarter choices about buying 30-second spots in 1992, he could have received credit for the Clean Air Act and other achievements, Mr. Clinton said.
The President said he had made mistakes in his first years in office, including "making a lot of people mad" at first. But he insisted that the issue he had made one of his first priorities in office -- allowing gay men and women to serve openly in the military -- had been forced on him by the Republicans.
Mr. Clinton, who has often seemed to enjoy campaigning more than the gritty reality of governing, spoke openly of his eagerness to return to the stump. He even noted with relish that he had lost weight.
"Ten more pounds to go," he said.

HEADLINE: Safety Plan Too Little For Mayor

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
Students at Adlai E. Stevenson High School in the South Bronx call the hallway outside the school cafeteria Belt Alley.
It got that name because students stop there every morning to put their belts back on after removing them so they can walk through the school's new metal detectors. 
 While belt buckles rarely set off metal detectors at airports, they do at Stevenson because the school's detectors are set to ferret out not only guns and knives. They must also find the student weapon of choice: box cutters.
These highly sensitive metal detectors, newly deployed at 34 schools this year, are part of the school system's response to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's repeated calls for a Police Department takeover of the school system's safety division. The Board of Education has begun implementing a range of changes intended to reduce crime and violence in schools and to upgrade a division that the Mayor has targeted with unrelenting criticism.
Mr. Giuliani set his sights on the 3,000-employee school safety division last spring, after a number of incidents involving officers charged with sexually abusing students. The scandal prompted the Mayor to create a commission to investigate school security and to demand that the Police Department be allowed to screen school security applicants, train them at the Police Academy and supervise them on the job.
And despite the changes the school board has made, Mr. Giuliani repeated his attacks on the Board of Education at a news conference yesterday while also offering several initiatives of his own. Although most of them have been in place for some time, he proposed one new program that would increase the presence of undercover police officers outside 40 schools throughout the city. The officers would look for students buying or selling drugs.
Even as he discussed that idea, the Mayor derided the school board's commitment to school safety once again.
"The current situation regarding crime in New York City schools is unacceptable," he said.
But board members insist that school security should remain under their jurisdiction, and they have begun their own safety overhaul.
Stevenson is one of 34 high schools and junior high schools in New York City that were given walk-through metal detectors and X-ray machines for bags this year. The equipment scans everyone who enters a school. Last year, the school system installed walk-through detectors in about 20 schools. Before that, the schools used hand-held metal scanners, which allow guards to conduct random checks of only about 10 to 20 percent of a school's students each day. .
Two weeks after installation, the metal detectors and X-ray conveyor belts have already become a humdrum part of the morning routine for Stevenson's 4,000 students.
"I guess it's good for my safety," Luis A. Sanchez, a junior at Stevenson, said while slipping a leather belt back around his waist.
"They got to get it together, though," he added, complaining that backups at the door, as students took off their belts and got ready to walk through the metal detector, had made him late for his first-period class.
The introduction of the metal detectors is just one of several innovations that Philip Tama, the school safety division's interim director, has introduced this year, these among them:
*The division's borough chiefs make unannounced visits to the schools to increase supervision of the security officers.
*Job candidates will be given psychological tests as part of the standard evaluation.
*New officers will receive 12 weeks of training instead of 10.
*For the next class of safety officers, who will enter the division's training academy in November, the minimum age has been raised to 23 from 21.
*Preference will be given to job candidates with college degrees, military experience and knowledge of a foreign language. Previously, a high school diploma was the only requirement, and other education or experience was not taken into account.
Mr. Tama also is negotiating with union officials to turn 300 senior security officers at high schools and junior high schools into mid-level supervisors by giving them the power to evaluate and discipline other officers in their schools.
"I have to improve the integrity and the perception of professionalism of this division," Mr. Tama said. "Everybody says it's broken and it can't stay the way it is. I hope I can fix enough of it before it disappears."
But despite these recent changes and others that are proposed, Mayor Giuliani has become increasingly impatient with the board's progress. He renewed his criticism of the division when the board recently released statistics showing a 16 percent increase in the number of reported incidents at public schools -- an increase board officials attribute largely to improved reporting.
"The school system has a level of crime that is unacceptable," the Mayor complained last week. "We are perilously close, in some communities, to the schools' being the most dangerous place in the community, and that has to change."
When part-time guards were first placed in schools in the late 1960's, largely in response to disruptions at schools caused by civil rights sit-ins and riots, candidate screening was minimal and many of the guards came from the ranks of the chronically unemployed. But board and safety officials say the force has come a long way since then.
Dressed uniformly in white shirts and gray slacks, safety officers now patrol all but a handful of the city's more than 1,000 schools. Elementary schools usually have an officer who primarily sits at the main entrance to screen visitors. High schools have 10 to 20 regular officers who patrol halls and look for weapons. They all wear the gold badges of "peace officers," a police designation that legally authorizes them to make arrests, confiscate firearms, and conduct warrantless searches. Although they carry handcuffs and radios, they do not carry weapons.
School officials say keeping school guards unarmed is the main reason they oppose having police officers patrol school halls.
"Only a noneducator would suggest having police officers assigned to schools," said Alan Weiner, the principal of Stevenson High School. He said armed officers could easily be jostled and lose their weapons in the controlled chaos that breaks out seven times a day when several hundred teen-agers jam the school's halls during a change in periods.
Having armed officers would also undercut efforts to rid the school of all weapons, he argued. That is a goal that the new metal detectors already seem to have accomplished. In the week since the detectors were installed at Stevenson, guards found only one box cutter, and it was discarded in the school yard. The only other weapons found were carried by parents visiting the school.
"Unfortunately, this is no way to go to school," Stephen P. Kam, a school safety supervisor, said as he pointed to the more than $80,000 in weapons detection equipment at Stevenson and the hundreds of students marching indifferently through the metal detectors."But it's reality," he said. "And at least now they know that while they're in the building, they're safe."

HEADLINE: Global Warming, Unfortunately, Is All Too Real;
Wood Replenishes

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Sept. 10 front-page article on global warming couples burning of wood with burning of coal and oil as the culprits, a mistake repeated in your Sept. 18 front-page article. 
 Burning fossil fuels -- coal, oil and natural gas -- all contribute carbon dioxide to the atmosphere, but wood is constantly being replenished, removing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and replenishing our oxygen supply in the process of photosynthesis, thereby offsetting carbon dioxide production and oxygen depletion in the burning process.
But wood growth and burning are not simply a zero sum if we adopt enlightened social policies and economic incentives to increase tree growth. Aside from the global impact on climate, trees afford enormous local benefits of esthetics, shade, of habitat for wildlife, and of wood for use in our country's 25 million fireplaces.
Woodburning with modern technology can provide a supplement of 125,000 megawatts to the country's power supply. That is the power rating of 12 Grand Coulee dams or of all the nuclear power stations in the country. That supplement can enable fossil-fuel-burning utilities with winter power peaks to shave those peaks, and if tree production is encouraged, can reduce carbon buildup in the atmosphere at no cost to utilities but with substantial fuel savings to them and to customers with a cheap source of wood.
And the benefits are of indefinite duration.
 
LAWRENCE CRANBERG
Austin, Tex., Sept. 18, 1995
The writer is president of Texas Fireframe Company, which produces grates for fireplaces.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
During the 1970's, ANGELA DAVIS, the black power advocate, was imprisoned in California on kidnapping and murder charges in connection with the invasion of a San Rafael, Calif., courthouse to free black prisoners. At that time, social and political advocates in Cuba joined the international movement to secure her release.
Last week, Ms. Davis returned to Cuba for the first time in 20 years, as part of a delegation from the United States-Cuba Medical Project to deliver a $5 million shipment of medicines and medical supplies. It was the single largest donation from the project, said LESLIE CAGEN, its director. 
 "The United States Government's continued embargo against Cuba seems to have no purpose, except that of making a difficult economic situation in Cuba much worse," Ms. Davis said yesterday from Vassar College, where she is a visiting professor of philosophy. "The people of America should know that people are dying as a result of their inability to purchase medicines to heal them."
The delegation, which returned to the United States on Sunday, included ALICE WALKER, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author; PRATIBA PARMA, the British film maker; KATHY ENGEL, the president of Riptide Communications, a New York company active in social causes, and Ms. Cagen. Founded three years ago, the project raises money to send medicines and medical supplies to Cuba.
Ms. Cagen said that Ms. Davis was considered "a bit of a folk hero" in Cuba and that many Cubans recognized Ms. Walker, not by sight but by her work.
"Her books have been translated into Spanish, and 'The Color Purple' has been shown in Cuba," she said.

HEADLINE: Prosecutor Eager to Present Capital Case in Girl's Death

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Sept. 26

 BODY:
Even before the body of a 7-year-old girl was removed from a shallow grave outside Kingston on Monday, the Ulster County District Attorney, E. Michael Kavanaugh, confidently declared that he had the state's first capital case on his hands.
Mr. Kavanaugh, an outspoken supporter of the death penalty, moved quickly to build what he believes is an airtight case. Forensic experts from the F.B.I. were called in. And the prosecutor said the girl had been killed during a kidnapping, a scenario that would meet New York State's narrow definitions of first-degree murder under its new death penalty law. 
 Despite the painstaking groundwork, a capital prosecution of the 25-year-old suspect, Lawrence Whitehurst, will be complicated, lengthy and far from certain in its outcome, as has been the case in other states that have written laws carefully guarding against the misuse of the death penalty, defense lawyers and other legal experts said today.
Indeed, prosecutors across New York say they have come to realize that the state's first death penalty law in more than two decades, which took effect Sept. 1, is written so narrowly that it will be difficult to prosecute even the most shocking of murders as capital cases.
"I think he's going to have his work cut out in this case," said James Catterson, the chairman of the New York Prosecutors Training Institute, which has been providing instruction on the new law.
"He may well not have the facts to support murder in the first," Mr. Catterson added, noting that Mr. Kavanaugh will have to prove that Mr. Whitehurst intended to kill the girl, Rickel Knox, while committing another crime, like rape or kidnapping.
For example, a defense lawyer could argue that there was no kidnapping because the girl knew Mr. Whitehurst and may have entered his car voluntarily, said Norman Siegel, executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union. "Kidnapping will have to be proved beyond a reasonable doubt, and if someone saw her get into his car, that might not be sufficient in and of itself," he said.
Mr. Kavanaugh is apparently satisfied with the evidence that he already has, saying that he plans to ask a grand jury for a first-degree murder indictment next week, even though the law allows prosecutors up to 45 days to present a case before a grand jury and a further 120 days after an indictment to investigateand formally declare that they will seek the death penalty.
This case "clearly qualifies" as a first-degree case, Mr. Kavanaugh said, declining to discuss the evidence beyond saying that he believes Rickel Knox, a second grader, had been kidnapped by Mr. Whitehurst, an unemployed grocery clerk who knew the girl's family in Kingston, a town about 100 miles north of New York City. "This, in my view, is not close," he said.
Rickel disappeared on Thursday afternoon while playing in front of her house. Mr. Whitehurst, who was questioned by investigators for several days, eventually led investigators to a wooded area on the outskirts of Kingston where the girl was buried under a pile of twigs and debris that covered all but a foot.
Mr. Kavanaugh said he won Mr. Whitehurst's cooperation by agreeing to sign a plea bargain that he never felt obligated to uphold. "It's as though someone put a gun to my head and asked me to sign a promissory note," he said. "We knew time was running out and we knew that he knew where she was."
Since his arrest early Sunday, Mr. Whitehurst has tried twice to hang himself in his cell in Ulster County Jail, Police Chief James Riggins of Kingston told The Associated Press. Both times, the police stopped him, Chief Riggins said.
Mr. Kavanaugh's swift decision to seek the death penalty has been criticized by civil liberties lawyers who said that he may have acted prematurely.
Several lawyers noted that the law attempts to avoid hasty conclusions by prosecutors through the provision that gives them 120 days after an indictment to decide whether the evidence supports capital prosecution.
"You would hope that district attorneys would approach these cases as coolly and dispassionately as they can," said Russell Neufeld, director of the New York City Legal Aid Society's Capital Defense Unit.
Mr. Kavanaugh himself acknowledged that he decided that the case was eligible under the new law even before the girl's body had been removed and forensic tests had been completed. But he said the evidence -- including a witness who saw the girl enter Mr. Whitehurst's car -- pointed to kidnapping.
Legal experts also said that another potential problem in the case might be the ruse of a plea-bargain agreement with the suspect. In the agreement, prosecutors offered him a sentence of 10 years to life if Rickel were found alive and 15 years to life if she were found dead, in return for his leading them to her.
But Mr. Kavanaugh said on Monday, after the girl was found dead, that he would have made a deal with anyone as long there was a chance of finding the girl alive.

HEADLINE: PLAN FOR SAVINGS IN SOCIAL SECURITY

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26

 BODY:
Senators from both parties suggested today that the Government could solve some of its budget problems by slowing the growth of Social Security benefits paid to 43 million people.
President Clinton has threatened to veto any bill that carries out Republican plans to help balance the budget by cutting projected spending on Medicare and Medicaid by $452 billion, or 16 percent, in the next seven years. As a possible alternative, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said the Government could reduce the annual cost-of-living adjustment in Social Security benefits. The current formula overstates inflation, he said. 
 Mr. Moynihan's comments came on a day of fast-paced maneuvering on Capitol Hill, as lawmakers said it might be necessary to scale back the tax cut and the Medicare savings initially demanded by Republicans. Some Republican senators expressed doubts about the wisdom of cutting taxes at the same time they were exacting big savings in Medicare and Medicaid.
Senator Moynihan said the Consumer Price Index, now used to compute annual increases in Social Security benefits, invariably overstated the rise in the cost of living. He said the Government could save $281 billion during seven years if the cost-of-living adjustment were based on the Consumer Price Index minus one percentage point, as a panel of economists recommended earlier this month.
"The money is sitting there, asking to be picked up," Mr. Moynihan said in an interview.
Lawmakers from both parties leapt at his suggestion, which may offer a way for them to wriggle out of a confrontation with Mr. Clinton and to reduce the large sums that must otherwise be squeezed from Medicare and Medicaid.
On the other hand, it is a legislative truism that Social Security is a program politicians touch at their peril. Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, said Mr. Clinton must be involved in any effort to change Social Security. "If this is going to work, we've got to be in it together," said Mr. Dole, who hopes to take Mr. Clinton's job after the 1996 Presidential election. "It will happen only if everybody sort of joins hands."
The White House did not dismiss the idea. "Many economists believe that the Consumer Price Index somewhat overstates increases in the cost of living," Gene B. Sperling, deputy assistant to the President for economic policy, said today. "But there is significant disagreement as to the degree of the overestimation." Mr. Clinton's press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said the revision suggested by Mr. Moynihan was "too large."
John C. Rother, chief lobbyist at the American Association of Retired Persons, said: "The effort to make the Consumer Price Index a more accurate measure of inflation is laudable. But a reduction of one percentage point a year -- one-third of the likely cost-of-living adjustment -- probably goes beyond what is truly justified according to Government experts."
Mr. Rother said that it would be hard for elderly people to accept higher Medicare premiums, as proposed by Republicans in Congress, if the purchasing power of their Social Security benefits was going down.
Senator Moynihan did not give details of his proposal. The figure he cited, $281 billion, reflects the amounts that would be saved by altering the cost-of-living formula for several benefit programs, including Social Security, Civil Service retirement and military pensions. It also includes $98 billion of additional tax revenue that would be collected because changes in the Consumer Price Index imply changes in income tax brackets and the personal exemption.
There was much talk of Social Security at today's meeting of the Senate Finance Committee, which was called to deal with Medicare and Medicaid, the health programs for more than 70 million people who are elderly, disabled or poor.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, said that Mr. Moynihan, in proposing to slow the growth of Social Security benefits, "has pointed to something that required some courage, and offers some hope and opportunity" to members of Congress.
Mr. D'Amato, like other senators, seemed to assume that squeezing money out of the giant Social Security program would allow Congress to reduce the amount that must be extracted from Medicare and Medicaid. "The President is going to veto this," he said, referring to Republican proposals as they stand now. "The best effort we make, it's going to be vetoed."
If Republicans can find some of the budget savings they seek in Social Security, Mr. D'Amato said, then states like New York will have some time to cut back their Medicaid programs without forcing a sudden disruption. New York has an unusually generous Medicaid program, he said. But he added: "We can't just stop the stretch limousine, throw out the poor people and replace it with a Volkswagen. We need time for a transition."
On Friday, the House Commerce Committee approved legislation that would dismantle the current Medicaid program and give each state a lump sum, or "block grant," to finance health care for the poor. A private research institute, the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, said that under that bill, New York State would lose $25 billion, or 21 percent, of the money it could expect to receive under current law in the next seven years.
Senators John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming and Don Nickles of Oklahoma, all Republicans, said they supported Mr. Moynihan's proposal to change the formula for computing cost-of-living adjustments in Social Security. (One problem with the Consumer Price Index is that it uses a standard market basket of goods and services that do not change as quickly as people's buying habits. Many people, for example, buy pork or poultry if beef becomes too expensive, but the shift is not immediately reflected in the index.)
Economists have argued for years that the Consumer Price Index exaggerates inflation. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said in January that the Government could save billions by "correcting" this bias. The panel of economists that recommended such changes on Sept. 14 was appointed by Mr. Moynihan and Senator Bob Packwood, the Oregon Republican who was chairman of the Finance Committee but resigned after accusations of official and sexual misconduct.
The targets for Medicare and Medicaid savings were set in a budget blueprint adopted by Congress in June. That document is for the guidance of Congress but is not a law and did not have to be submitted to the President for his signature. By sufficient votes in each chamber, Congress can override parts of the budget resolution.
The Senate Finance Committee has jurisdiction over Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security and could try to reallocate money among those programs. But any change in Social Security would require delicate negotiations, and the Senate would need to waive rules intended to protect the program.
Three Republican Senators -- Mr. Simpson, Mr. D'Amato and Orrin G. Hatch of Utah -- expressed reservations about the Republican plan to cut Federal taxes by $245 billion during seven years. Mr. Hatch tried to inject a note of political realism, saying: "I don't think we're going to have $245 billion in tax cuts. I don't think anybody thinks that."
The Senate Republican whip, Trent Lott of Mississippi, said "we might come down a little bit," toward $200 billion of tax cuts.
The Ways and Means Committee, which is dealing with Medicare legislation on the House side of the Capitol, said today that it would delay its votes on the proposal, originally scheduled to begin on Wednesday. The panel is still trying to work out detailed legislative language and has not received the necessary fiscal analysis of its proposals from the Congressional Budget Office.
The budget office said today that the Senate bill would achieve the goal of saving $270 billion in Medicare over seven years. Beneficiaries would contribute $71 billion through higher premiums and deductibles. Doctors, hospitals and other health care providers would give up $152 billion. And $47.5 billion would be saved through use of health maintenance organizations, "medical savings accounts" and other alternatives to the standard Medicare program, the budget office said.

Mr. Roth, accepting the gavel yesterday from Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, replaced Senator Bob Packwood, the Oregon Republican who resigned after accusations of official and sexual misconduct. (Agence France-Presse)(pg. D22)

HEADLINE: Stocks Slip as the Fed Holds Steady on Interest Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks failed to sustain an advance yesterday and finished mostly lower after news that Federal Reserve policy makers had decided to keep interest rates at current levels.
Although the outcome of the Federal Open Market Committee meeting was expected, some traders had apparently hoped for a pleasant surprise in the form of a rate cut. 
 "You can characterize the session as a day of modest anticipation and modest disappointment surrounding the Fed's meeting," said Charles G. Crane, senior vice president and director of research at Spears, Benzak, Salomon & Farrell Inc. "The reality of that nonaction kindled a little disappointment and profit taking among investors."
Blue chips and the broader market started the session by moving decisively higher but reversed course in the afternoon as bonds temporarily weakened. The Dow Jones industrial average ended at 4,765.60 points after a modest loss of 4.33 points.
Losers nosed past gainers by about 11 to 10 on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume expanded to 363.6 million shares.
Among other popular stock market indicators, the New York Stock Exchange composite index inched 0.06 point higher to 311.82 points while the Standard & Poor's 500 slipped 0.40 point, to 581.41 points. The American Stock Exchange market value index dropped 1.85, to 542.53.
Technology has been one of the sectors hit hardest lately by investors' concerns over profits. That has depressed the Nasdaq stock market, where many semiconductor, software and computer-related issues are listed. Nasdaq's composite index shed 8.10 points to close at 1,038.05.
Wall Street's positive opening was supported by rising markets in Japan and Europe, but that favorable influence faded as traders faced the possibility that interest rates would probably remain at current levels indefinitely.
The BellSouth Corporation rose 1 1/4, to 72 7/8, after raising its quarterly cash dividend by 4 percent, to 72 cents a share, and declaring a 2-for-1 stock split.
The SCOR U.S. Corporation rose 3 7/8 to 15 after its French parent company, SCOR S.A., a large reinsurer, said it was buying the 20 percent of its American unit that it did not already own for $50.6 million.
Micron Technology Inc. lost 3 1/4, to 78 3/4, in Big Board-leading volume of more than 7 million shares. Concerns about quarterly earnings bedeviled certain technology issues. Among other active Big Board stocks, Advanced Micro Devices Inc. fell 1 3/8, to 29 3/4. Active Nasdaq stocks included several technology losers, like the Dell Computer Corporation, which fell 4 3/4, to 82 1/4.
Silicon Graphics Inc., however, rose5/8, to 35 1/2 in heavy New York Stock Exchange volume of more than 3.4 million shares. Investors were encouraged that the company is shipping its new Indigo2 Impact work stations and that it had introduced a new World Wide Web publishing tool.
Shoney's Inc. lost 1 1/4, to 10 5/8, in response to reports that the restaurant operator would be included in an ABC report airing today on unsanitary conditions at food chains.
The Glaxo Wellcome Company was up 1/2, to 23 7/8, in heavy Big Board volume of more than 5 million shares, as investors reacted to reports that a Glaxo Wellcome drug to treat H.I.V. was involved in a promising trial. In other news that supported the stock, a Food and Drug Administration panel recommended approval of Flovent, a dry-powder device for asthma treatment.

HEADLINE: Fed Passes Again on Cutting Short-Term Rates

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve today left short-term interest rates unchanged, apparently believing that the economy was showing adequate growth again after a swoon in the spring.
This was the second straight meeting at which the Federal Open Market Committee, the central bank's main policy arm, passed up a chance to cut rates further since it reversed course in early July and lowered them for the first time since 1992. 
 "The Federal Open Market Committee meeting ended at 1:20 P.M. There is no further announcement," Joseph R. Coyne, the Fed's chief spokesman, said in a statement that has become standard for occasions of no change in monetary policy.
Since only a small minority of analysts had expected the Fed to ease further today, there was little reaction in the bond or stock markets.
The latest deliberations of the committee, which at full strength has 19 members, of whom 12 vote at a given time, leaves the rate for Federal funds at 5.75 percent and the largely symbolic discount rate at the 5.25 percent level to which it was raised in February. The Federal funds rate covers overnight loans that banks make among themselves but that are strongly influenced by the Fed; the discount rate is the rate the Fed offers banks for overnight loans from the Fed's own reserves.
Since decelerating to a 1.1 percent rate of expansion in the second quarter, the economy has revived, although unevenly, with the interest-rate-sensitive housing sector among the most solid performers and industrial output finally posting a significant rise in August.
Inflation, meanwhile, has remained in check. Consumer price inflation in the first eight months of the year was running at a 2.9 percent yearly pace, compared with 2.7 percent for all of 1994.
This favorable combination of stepped-up growth and low inflation prompted an upbeat assessment by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, in an appearance before the Senate Banking Committee on Friday.
"Near-term prospects for the U.S. economy have improved in recent months," he said at that time.
The 52 economists who are polled monthly by Blue Chip Economic Indicators now forecast a growth rate of 2 percent for the quarter that ends Saturday and 2.8 percent for the October-December period.
If achieved, this would be a highly satisfactory result for Fed policy makers, who last winter faced the challenge of restraining an economy surging at an annual pace of 5.1 percent without pushing the economy into recession.
With the Fed continuing a yearlong raising of the Federal funds rate, the economy throttled back to a 2.7 percent growth rate in the first quarter. By midyear, fears grew that the restraint that led to a doubling of the funds rate to 6 percent might be overdone.
Sharing this concern, the Fed cut rates in early July and expectations grew that more reductions would be needed in the second half of the year to sustain renewed growth and bring about the so-called economic soft landing that has so often proved elusive.
But with the recent upticks in various indicators, including in employment in the nation's factories last month after four straight monthly declines, it may be that borrowers -- the prime rate tends to move in step with the Federal funds rate -- will get just the single dose of rate relief.
Opinion today was divided about the prospects for a rate reduction at the committee's remaining 1995 meetings on Nov. 15 and Dec. 19.
Among the optimists was Kathleen Stephansen, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, who had expected a cut today.
"The consumer sector remains very sluggish," she said, contending that the Federal funds rate will need to be trimmed if the Fed policy is to be neutral rather than mildly restrictive.
Indeed, James E. Annable, chief economist at the First National Bank of Chicago, said he and others had begun to wonder whether the Fed had become "too unambitious" for today's restructured economy in which unemployment has declined to about 5.5 percent without putting significant upward pressure on wages.
This, Mr. Annable said, suggested that the Fed had maneuvering room to be "more tolerant of growth" even if it was unwilling to risk leading the way to a higher level.

HEADLINE: To Pay Some Debts, U.N. Will Try Borrowing From World Bank

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 26

 BODY:
The United Nations, facing its most severe financial crisis in half a century, will try for the first time to borrow money from the World Bank to pay some of its debts, the organization's highest-ranking financial officer said today.
Joseph Connor, a former chief executive of Price Waterhouse who is now United Nations Under Secretary General for Administration and Management, said today that a World Bank loan was only one of many ideas being explored "to lift from our shoulders the burden of debt." 
 Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali said in an interview on Saturday that he planned to meet the World Bank president, James D. Wolfensohn, this weekend to discuss the proposal.
In the past, the United Nations has borrowed small amounts for specific development projects, Mr. Connor said, but there is no precedent for a loan of this kind, which would go to paying off some of the organization's growing general indebtedness.
"This crisis cannot be solved unless we can borrow money," the Secretary General said.
The United States, which is at least $1.2 billion in arrears in its dues to the United Nations, is expected to challenge the plan, an American diplomat said.
The American opposition to any new idea for raising money surprised diplomats from Europe and elsewhere, whose governments pay their bills regularly. A Western diplomat said today that with the United States the largest defaulter in assessments, it seemed inexplicable that the Clinton Administration would make things worse behind the scenes.
An American diplomat said today that the Administration had "two basic problems" with the loan plan.
"The United Nations and the Secretary General have no authority to borrow externally," the diplomat said. "And borrowing from the World Bank is restricted to sovereign governments."
The World Bank is technically part of the United Nations system, although the bank and the International Monetary Fund, both based in Washington, operate with considerable independence.
The United Nations, which has no capital base and cannot borrow commercially, is owed $3.4 billion in unpaid assessments, of which the United States owes roughly half.
The organization is $900 million in arrears in payments to countries that have provided peacekeeping troops and $400 million for purchases of various kinds. Half of the tens of millions of dollars awarded in contracts each year go to American companies.
"Our inability to pay is impacting the willingness of countries to participate in peacekeeping," Mr. Connor said. The operation in Bosnia alone is costing nearly $5 million daily, according to the Secretary General.
In a speech today to the General Assembly, the British Foreign Secretary, Malcolm Rifkind, proposed charging interest on late payments as one way of tightening penalties against member nations in arrears. He said 39 nations failed to pay anything at all last year.
In June at the meeting of the Group of Seven major industrial nations, Mr. Boutros-Ghali proposed that the United Nations would take bonds from nations owing money and use them to settle debts with other member countries. That idea was also opposed by the United States.
Mr. Connor said today that the bulk of the money owed by the United Nations for peacekeeping is in debts to Western European nations, Australia, Canada and other countries close to the United States.
