HEADLINE: Panel Backs New Fees on Student Loans

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26

 BODY:
As one Republican stayed away, the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee voted 8 to 7 on party lines today to charge colleges for every loan their students take out as part of a $10.8 billion cut in the Federal student loan program.
The missing Republican, Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont, said later that he would fight the proposal on the Senate floor. Asked why he had stayed away from the committee meeting, where he could have killed the plan, he said he was "steadfast against any cuts in education" but had promised the panel's chairman, Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum of Kansas, that he would not block her efforts to get the proposal to the Senate as part of Republican efforts to balance the budget. 
 Senator Kassebaum, after sharp protests from colleges, last week scaled down her original proposal for a fee of 2 percent on all Federal loans a college's students received. But the opposition remains almost as intense to the plan she proposed Friday and the committee adopted today. It calls for a charge of $85 on every $10,000 of loans, or less than 1 percent of the loan total.
Democrats argued that the charge would fall most heavily on those institutions that had the highest number of students taking out loans. They said that the State University of New York, for example, with student loans of about $470 million in a year, would be charged $4 million under the new fee. Rutgers University, the state university in New Jersey, with $83 million in loans, would be charged $706,000.
They said that the changes would make it harder for low-income students to go to college and that the Republican priorities were wrong. Senator Paul Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota, said the Senate should have attacked corporate tax breaks and excessive arms spending: "I think the students come before the oil companies, the tobacco companies, the pharmaceutical companies and the military contractors."
After students at the hearing applauded, Senator Kassebaum replied, somewhat testily: "The students are not going to be hurt in this. We care just as deeply as anybody else about education."
Mr. Jeffords, who earlier had voted for an amendment that would have imposed $4.4 billion in new charges on lenders and no charges for the five million student borrowers, was the only one of the committee's nine Republicans who did not vote, though some who were absent left proxies for the fee proposal. All seven Democrats voted against it.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, the committee's senior Democrat, denounced the proposal as a "student loan tax," saying Republicans wanted "to raid $10.8 billion from student aid to pay for tax cuts for the wealthy."
Senator Kassebaum denied that the fee was a tax. She said it was a reasonable charge to impose on "institutions which clearly benefit from the availability of Federal student loan programs," and argued that the charges would not necessarily be passed on to students. "There is room for postsecondary institutions to take a hard look at their own costs," she said, "just as we are asking everyone else to do."
The House Educational and Economic Opportunities Committee will meet on Thursday to vote on a different plan to cut the loan program by $1.8 billion. Its plan cannot be amended on the House floor. Amendments will be allowed in the Senate, but will be hard to pass as Republicans stand behind the overall plan.
The fee would raise $2 billion over seven years. These are other elements of the Kassebaum package:
*Require $4 billion in added charges and cut payments to lenders and guarantee agencies.
*End the six-month post-graduation grace period during which no interest is charged on loans, saving $2.7 billion.
*Raise interest rates on the PLUS program of subsidized loans to parents, saving $694 million.
*Reduce direct Government loans to colleges and universities to no more than 20 percent of loan volume, down from a current total of nearly 30 percent. Banks that get Federal guarantees would see their share of loans grow instead of declining as they have been. Under new accounting rules adopted by the Republicans this year, $1.5 billion would be saved.
Senator Kassebaum's plan did not say how the Administration was to choose which institutions could continue on the direct loan program, which most who use it say is more efficient than the guaranteed bank loan program. Senator Paul Simon, the Illinois Democrat who was an early advocate of direct loans, demanded, "Are we in the business of helping banks and guarantee agencies, or are we in the business of helping students?"
Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, tried to amend the Kassebaum proposal to allow colleges to choose between direct or bank loans, instead of having the committee set any limit. He lost on an 8-to-7 party-line vote with Mr. Jeffords absent.
Mr. Dodd also attacked the plan as "the largest cut in the history of higher education."
Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Indiana, scoffed at the Kassebaum assertion that the cuts were small and would not have much impact. He said six of the last seven reconciliation bills had also reduced student loans, leading to "death by a thousand small cuts."
Senator Kassebaum said the committee had a duty to come up with the $10.8 billion in cuts set out in the budget resolution passed this summer, even though "it is undoubtedly easier to vote in favor of a balanced budget than to support the steps necessary to achieve it."

HEADLINE: Nuns to Leave Cloister for Papal Visit

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Sept. 25

 BODY:
The white-robed nuns of the Monastery of St. Dominic arise in the darkness of their simple cells to begin their daily ritual of devotion to God and prayer for His world. Voices echoing in choral prayer or eyes closed in private meditations, they reflect on the lives that lie just beyond their thick, stone walls: people desperately ill, unemployed or lonely.
In the tradition of mystics and monks, the 21 cloistered Dominican nuns have set themselves apart from the world, which in their case is a down-at-the-heels neighborhood where young men spend hours standing on corners and where stolen cars speed crazily through the night. But on Oct. 4, these nuns and some 100 other cloistered religious will be allowed to venture into the city and pray with Pope John Paul II at Sacred Heart Cathedral. 
 The chance to pray with the Pope is a special occasion for any Roman Catholic, but it is especially sweet, and rare, for the nuns of St. Dominic's, who leave their cloister only for medical visits and annual meetings of their order and with the approval of Newark's Archbishop, Theodore McCarrick. Even in death, they remain with their sisters, buried in plain wooden coffins in a crypt beneath the chapel.
The nuns see the prayer service as an exciting reaffirmation of their decision to embrace a radical life style removed from the comforts and routines that others take for granted.
"This is a milestone for us," said Sister Marie of the Incarnation. "Our life is something that is always seeking a depth and rootedness in the fact that I gave my life to Christ. It never wears out, but it needs to be renewed. God provides times of renewal."
Like with many moments in their spiritual journey, the nuns think of the papal visit as a gift bestowed on those who have given totally of themselves.
"It's a love gift from our Lord," said Sister Mary Mannis. "He said He would give a hundredfold to those who left their mother and father for Him."
When the Newark monastery was founded in 1880 by members of a French religious order, it was one of the few places in the United States where women led monastic lives of contemplation. The stone buildings, whose street-side windows are frosted, are built around grassy courtyards decorated with flowers and religious statues. By tradition, the nuns pray seven times a day as a group, spending the other hours in meditation, reading and household chores.
They are self-supporting, relying on donations and the income from the sale of memorial cards and a small business they run packaging and distributing altar breads.
"There is an intensity in our constant striving to focus on God," said Sister Catherine Mary, the group's prioress. "To live in His presence. That's the purpose of our life, the rhythms, the sameness and uncomplicated work. Our spirits are free to be for the Lord."
Guided by their vows of chastity, poverty and obedience, they talk of their daily routine with ease and happiness, enjoying a relaxed spirit of community.
"I could walk out the door any time I want," said Sister Mary Joseph. "I'm not locked in. There is a freedom to our life."
Now there is a bit more joy as they anticipate the papal visit. One nun posted a daily countdown near the door to their community room.
"It's a real privilege" said Sister Mary St. John. "He is a representative of Christ to us. It's like our Lord Himself visited us in person."
Their daily conversations are filled with questions and talk about their much traveled spiritual leader. They know he has affection for their way of life, noting how he established a contemplative community on the Vatican grounds.
"You see him on TV -- we don't usually see TV -- and you feel acquainted with him," said Sister Mary Magdalen. "The gifts of the man are just awesome. His personal rapport. His gift of touching and empathizing with all sorts of people. His whole life has prepared him for this."
Sister Mary Joseph, who keeps tabs on the group's bills and donations, said she was pleasantly surprised by the Pope's choice of Newark, an archdiocese overshadowed by its neighbors.
"Newark is considered an inner city," she said. "It's not terribly famous like New York."
And though the nuns live behind walls, they are aware of what city life means, for better and for worse.
"In the early hours of the morning, you can hear all kinds of sounds in the city," said Sister Mary Christine, whose first contact with the monastery came as a teen-ager when she attended a party across the street. A few years later, in 1964, she converted and strode through the gate whose arch inscription reads in Latin, "Come Let Us Adore Him."
"Maybe someone's sick, a stolen car with its squealing tires," she said. "You lift those people up in prayer. But you also hear the good side. On Sunday morning, singing across the street. You know they're going to worship. They know God is still here."
Sister Catherine Mary said she and the other nuns see opportunities for prayer and understanding even in their infrequent trips into the city. It's a chance to see the world with different eyes.
"You can see in people's faces the burden or the loneliness they experience," she said. "If we're in a traffic jam, we see how many people have to live every day in a traffic jam just to go to work. How many women have to get their children home. It's really trying to bring the Lord into these situations, which is where I think He'd want to be."

HEADLINE: Save West Point Prep

 BODY:
Congressional plans for scaling back or eliminating the prep school that supplies many of the Army's minority officers are wrongheaded. The U.S. Military Academy Preparatory School at Fort Monmouth, N.J., is doing a yeoman job integrating the officer corps, making the Army more representative of America -- and a model of how an integrated enterprise ought to work. Tampering could undo two decades of progress and destroy a vital source of opportunity for minority youths.
The prep schools were created in 1916, when Congress authorized the Army to nominate enlisted men as cadets for West Point. The Air Force and Navy have the schools as well, but the Army's has clearly been the most successful. In recent years the Army prep school became a finishing program for West Point applicants who barely missed getting in. A favorable evaluation of its efforts appears in the forthcoming Twentieth Century Fund book "Overcoming Race: Army Lessons for American Society," by Charles Moskos and John S. Butler. 
 The 10-month Army prep school is grueling, and nearly a third of those who enter drop out. Those who complete the program show dramatic improvement. S.A.T. scores rise by an average of 100 points for whites and 120 points for blacks. About 40 percent of blacks who attend West Point enter through the prep program. Without it, minority enrollment at West Point would be lower still than its current, dismal 6 percent.
True, the prep school costs are steep -- between $40,000 and $60,000 per student, depending on who does the calculation. But repairing the damage done by a ghastly education is inevitably costly. A better way to evaluate the Army school is in terms of social costs and benefits. The dramatic increases in S.A.T. scores achieved by the prep school show what can be accomplished if sufficient resources are put into educating disadvantaged youths. Given that young black men are five times as likely as whites to be unemployed -- and many more times as likely to be incarcerated -- the prep school trade-off seems more than cost-effective.
Plans for scaling back the prep schools and farming out the students to private military academies will very likely result in the best students being admitted and the riskiest students left out. Congress is right to cut costs, economize and eliminate abuses, such as the alleged focus at the Air Force Academy's prep school on preparing athletes for admission. But keep the prep schools. They pay for themselves many times over.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar's Value Rises Broadly Amid Profit Taking on the Mark

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar ended slightly higher against most leading currencies yesterday as traders sold German marks to take profits after a run-up last week.
"We started to see some unwinding of long mark positions Monday, and we're continuing to see more of the same," said Dave Glowacki, senior trader at NBD Bank in Detroit. 
 In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar edged up to 1.4373 marks from 1.4345 marks on Monday. It rose to 1.1625 Swiss francs from 1.1565 francs and to 100.90 Japanese yen from 100.52 yen. The British pound fell to $1.5665 from $1.5702.
The dollar declined last week as the mark and the Swiss franc surged as concern about the future of Europe's drive toward monetary union prompted flight into the two currencies. The mark and the Swiss franc are considered safe-haven currencies in times of uncertainty.
But battered European currencies, including the Italian lira and the Swedish krona, recouped some of their losses against the mark yesterday, indirectly bolstering the dollar.
"The French franc and the lira are clawing back territory versus the mark," said Amy Smith, senior currency strategist at IDEA Inc. "That has given the dollar strength."
Further lending support to the dollar was the Federal Reserve's expected decision to leave interest rates unchanged amid signs that the economy was recovering from a second-quarter slump, traders said.
Though the dollar had a muted response to the news, traders said the currency was likely to remain buoyant as American interest rates remained higher than those in Germany and Japan. "There was a slight risk that the Fed was going to cut rates, but their decision to hold rates steady maintains the interest-rate differential, and that's good news for the dollar," said Ron Leven, currency analyst at J. P. Morgan.
Though the dollar has recovered somewhat, traders wonder if central banks will again buy dollars in a concerted effort to push the dollar's value higher. "The dollar needs some kind of an impetus to push it higher," said Jim Blackwelder of National Westminster Bank.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices End Mixed As Fed Holds Line on Rates

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, after the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee left interest rates unchanged at its policy meeting.
Bonds were initially higher in early trading after the Conference Board reported its consumer confidence reading had fallen in September to 97.4, below the average trade forecast of 100. In August it was 102.4. Analysts said the report suggested signs of waning consumer optimism that could restrain growth. People buy things when they feel confident; when they do not, manufacturing slows and inventories rise. 
 The 30-year Treasury issue gained 2/32 of a percentage point, to 103 30/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, slipped to 6.57 percent, from 6.58 percent on Monday. But shorter-maturity bills, because they are more sensitive to monetary policy, were down sharply. The rate for a three-month bill was up 10 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 5.27 percent.
Anthony Dwyer, chief market strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said he was sure that some of the early price gains were tied to the hopes of some who still believed that there was an outside chance the Fed would ease rates. "But those hopes did not come to fruition, and bonds relinquished those gains," he said.
"I expect the bond market to remain in a narrow trading range over the short term until more evidence regarding the strength of the economy comes forth," Mr. Dwyer continued. "Longer-term bond yields should continue to stay stable to lower over the longer term. It's my opinion that given the favorable inflation outlook, bonds will retain their long-term appeal."
Mr. Dwyer said yesterday's Treasury auction of two-year notes did not go as well as it might have, but that it should not affect the favorable long-term outlook for bonds, as the inflation picture remains the fundamental key to rates.
Nor did the disclosure that Daiwa Bank had lost $1.1 billion because of unauthorized bond trading in its New York office have any impact on the market yesterday because the bank has had a month since the executive involved turned himself in to bank officials to correct any imbalances.
Anthony Chan, chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors, Columbus, Ohio, said he thought the Fed acted according to plan by leaving interest rates unchanged.
"Although F.O.M.C. participants had enough time to digest a plunging level of consumer confidence, as proxied by the Conference Board's latest reading, it was apparent that in the end they paid more attention to the marked turnaround in the housing and manufacturing sectors," Mr. Chan said.
"We believe that the Fed adopted a directive with a bias toward easing. It appears that Nov. 15 is likely to be the last chance for the Fed to act this year. If they acted, it would be with the intention of stimulating retail sales activity in 1995. And given the fact that most stores record close to 50 percent of all retail sales during the Christmas season, one can see why an easing at the last F.O.M.C. meeting of the year on Dec. 19 is certain to fall short of having much effect."
Mr. Chan said the uncertainty of the Fed committee's meeting caused yesterday's two-year note auction to suffer from lack of interests as the bid-to-cover ratio -- the number of bids to actual sales -- came in at 2.04 to 1, which is considerably below its average historical level of 2.65.
The high yield at auction yesterday was 5.86 percent, down from 6.08 percent in August and the lowest since June 27, when it was 5.69 percent.
Today, the Treasury will auction a new five-year note. Yesterday in when-issued trading the new notes were offered at a price to yield 6.09 percent, up from 6.06 percent on Monday.
Some economists said that market participants came away with the feeling that the balance of data remained in a state that was weighing more heavily in favor of moderate to firmer growth. "Nonetheless," Mr. Chan said, "it is clear that market players are now likely to shift their attention to watching movements in the labor market, especially the weekly unemployment claims prior to next month's nonfarm payroll employment report, to see if the Fed will finally pull the trigger next month."
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new two-year notes:

POLITICAL FIGHT LOOMS OVER CHANCELLOR

ARE THE 'NICE PANTS' ADS A MORALITY TEST?
 In a new advertising campaign promoting Dockers brand pants, Levi Strauss hung khakis usually priced up to $55 under plastic shields in 40 Manhattan bus shelters. Any New Yorker might expect that covetous vandals would pry open or shatter the shields and make off with the pants. Levi Strauss expected it, too: When the pants were stolen, an outline of them would remain, along with a message: "Apparently they were very nice pants." [A1.]

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

S.E.C. Seeks to Assure Investors of Benefits
The S.E.C., 20 years after Congress mandated competition in securities markets, is seeking to make it work for investors' benefit. The commission would require that stock markets give investors a reasonable chance of getting better prices than they often have.
One aim is to make sure that orders can be seen by other investors who might want to take the other side. With today's fragmented markets that does not always happen. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [Page D8.]
 
Time Warner to Shed Rap Label
Time Warner will sell its 50 percent stake in Interscope Records, the Los Angeles label whose violent and sexually degrading gangsta rap lyrics have stirred political controversy. But executives said the company expected to recoup its $100 million investment. [D20.]
 
Court to Hear Copyright Case
Accepting a case with important implications for the software industry, the Supreme Court agreed to decide whether Lotus Development had a valid copyright for the commands used in its Lotus 1-2-3 spreadsheet program. [D4.]
 
Japan May Form Loan Agency
The Japanese Government moved toward establishing an institution similar to the Resolution Trust Corporation to dispose of bad debts held by mortgage companies. [D6.]
 
Daiwa's Delay and the Regulators
By waiting nearly two months to tell regulators about a $1.1 billion loss from unauthorized trading, Daiwa Bank apparently violated Federal and New York State regulations, banking lawyers say. [D6.]
 
Durable Goods Orders Rise 4.9%
Durable goods orders jumped 4.9 percent in August, the largest increase in a year, as some auto plants resumed production after a shutdown to retool for 1996 models. [D4.]
 
Pact Keeps the Government Open
Leaders from the Republican-controlled Congress agreed with the White House on a plan to keep the Government from shutting down for lack of money next week. [A1.]
 
End Seen for AT&T Requirement
The Federal Communications Commission plans to free AT&T from the last vestiges of price regulation, officials said. [D21]
 
Heavy Lobbying by Drug Makers
Several drug companies are lobbying Congress, trying to head off a budget amendment that would reverse a change in the new world trade agreement extending prescription drug patents. [B12.]
 
I.B.M. Consolidates OS/2 Work
I.B.M. will relocate 1,100 software developers and other personnel from Boca Raton, Fla., to Austin, Tex., consolidating OS/2 development in a single location. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Shift at Top: Du Pont Gets A New Chief

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
The Du Pont Company said yesterday that John A. Krol will become its chief executive at the end of the year, replacing Edgar S. Woolard Jr., who will remain as chairman.
Mr. Woolard, 61, said he was stepping down as chief executive because he had fulfilled his goals of revamping E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the nation's largest chemical concern, and because he felt the time was right to pass the baton to Mr. Krol, who is 58 and has been vice chairman for three years. Mr. Woolard said his health was fine and had nothing to do with his decision. 
 Because the two executives have worked together closely and have known each other for more than 20 years, the company "will not skip a beat," Mr. Krol said. The only difference between the two executives, Mr. Woolard added, is that Mr. Krol is the better golfer.
Analysts said the transition had not been expected for another year or so. William R. Young, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said that Mr. Krol "is really going to follow in Ed's footsteps," adding that they shared a penchant for controlling costs and improving productivity while Du Pont pursued growth in new markets.
Mr. Woolard said his role as chairman would be a part-time job in which he helped shape strategy and pondered long-range goals for Du Pont.
Analysts credit Mr. Woolard, who has been chief executive since 1989, with making the $40 billion company leaner and more responsive to customers and new markets while shedding its historical culture, which tended to be stodgy and, at times, arrogant. He had ordered division heads to meet profitability targets, and they, in turn, had laid off thousands of workers to meet those goals. The company now employs 107,000 worldwide.
"He has turned the Titanic around," said James F. Hickman, an analyst at CS First Boston.
Mr. Krol, a native of Massachusetts, joined Du Pont in 1963 as a chemist in Wilmington, Del., and held various marketing, manufacturing and management positions in its fibers and agricultural products divisions until 1992, when he was named vice chairman.
In the most recent quarter, Du Pont reported net income of $938 million on revenue of $11.3 billion. The results, a 15 percent increase over the comparable quarter in the previous year, reflected higher prices in its plastics, fibers and chemicals business. In addition, the company cited strong growth in Europe and Asia for the rise.
However, the company warned that its automotive and construction-related sales were showing signs of a softening economy in the United States.

HEADLINE: Threat Is Seen in Pension Shift

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27

 BODY:
Escalating its opposition to a Republican plan to allow companies to use money from pension plans that have a minimum cushion of funds, the Clinton Administration contended today that passage of the measure would reduce the retirement security of millions of Americans, endanger the economy and inspire predatory corporate takeovers.
"We are going to see raids on pension assets that will make the train robberies during the days of Jesse James pale in comparison," said Robert B. Reich, the Labor Secretary who also serves as chairman of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, insurer of 58,000 private-sector pension plans. 
 Mr. Reich was joined at a news conference by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, the other members of the pension agency board, to announce adoption today of a resolution urging Congress to reject liberalization of the law governing pension assets.
The Republican-dominated House Ways and Means Committee approved a measure last week to let companies transfer an estimated $30 billion to $40 billion from their pension plans over the next five years and use the money for other purposes.
Proponents contend this would raise more than $10 billion in tax revenue and free underutilized capital for investment while preserving an adequate cushion for meeting obligations to retirees. To be tapped, a fund would be required to have at least 25 percent more assets than needed to meet current liabilities.
In July 1996, a 6.5 percent excise tax would apply to removals.
In denouncing the idea, the three Cabinet members cited a study the pension agency published today stating that many plans could be left with "insufficient resources" to protect retirees. Among other things, it said that funds deemed more than sufficient now "can quickly become underfunded" with a market shift of as little as a one percentage point reduction in interest rates combined with a 10 percent decline in asset values.
The officials also raised the specter of pension assets as a lure, as Mr. Brown put it, "for corporate raiders to use reversions to finance takeovers." He said pension funds were used in two-thirds of the largest buyouts of the 1980's. Beginning in 1986, the Government sought to curb pension reversions by imposing a series of taxes that eventually ranged as high as 50 percent.
Republicans immediately responded to the Administration attack.
"The Administration's attempt today to mislead and scare people is deeply regrettable and extremely misguided," the Ways and Means Committee said a statement. "The real culprit when it comes to protecting pensions is the Administration's ongoing effort to compel public pension funds to invest in so-called economically targeted investments."

HEADLINE: Stock Prices Take a Wild Ride Down but Rebound at Close

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Led by technology issues, stock prices tumbled sharply enough yesterday to set off the New York Stock Exchange's 50-point "circuit breaker" rule, but bounced back before the close.
Nevertheless, the three major market indicators all finished on the downside. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 3.25 points, to 4,762.35; the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 0.37 point, to 581.04, and the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index declined 11.51 points, to 1,026.54. 
 The stock and bond markets dropped at the opening in response to a Commerce Department report that August durable goods orders soared almost 5 percent -- the largest advance in a year. Later in the day, the Dow fell as much as 53.11 points, which set off the Big Board's circuit breakers. The 50-point collar, established after the 1987 market crash, is meant to curb excess market volatility from computer-guided sales and purchases. In a down market, once the circuit breaker is set off, a stock may only be sold when its price is unchanged or rising slightly.
After the Treasury's $11.5 billion five-year note auction went better than expected, bonds and stocks turned away from their lows. The trend of both markets was positive when trading concluded. Thus the 30-year Treasury bond -- which at one point was down a full percentage point -- fell just 1/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, was unchanged at 6.57 percent.
"Bonds led stocks down and then bonds led stocks up," said Edwin D. Walczak, chief investment officer of Vontobel U.S.A. "The day ended uneventfully."
Declining issues exceeded advancers on the Big Board by 1,469 to 842. Volume was heavy, with 411.3 million shares changing hands, compared with 363.6 million shares on Tuesday and the three-month daily average of 340 million shares.
Technology stocks, which have had one of the most powerful upward runs in the market this year, were most vulnerable yesterday to the currently clouded outlook for third-quarter earnings. Cisco Systems dropped 1 5/8, to 68; 3Com fell 1 1/4, to 44 1/4; Bay Networks slid 2 3/8, to 52, and Intel declined 7/16 , to 595/16 .
Some capital-goods stocks also declined, following a decision Tuesday by Federal Reserve policy makers not to lower interest rates. Caterpillar closed at 56 1/8, down 2; Harnischfeger finished at 33 3/8, down 3/8, and Boeing ended at 67 3/4, down 7/8.
In contrast to the overall market, the high-dividend utility sector was strong yesterday and the Dow Jones utility index gained 1.19 points, to 212.50 -- its highest level in more than a year and a half. Duke Power rose 1/8, to 42 3/4; Wisconsin Energy gained 1/8, to 28; Southern Company climbed 1/2, to 23, and Houston Industries rose 1/4, to 44 1/2.
Banking issues advanced on traders' expectations that profit margins would not narrow in the months ahead. Chemical Banking increased 1, to 60; Citicorp jumped 2, to 70 7/8; BankAmerica gained 3/4, to 59 1/2, and J. P. Morgan rose 3/8, to 77 1/8.
Among other gainers, Hayes Wheels soared 5 5/8, to 26 1/2, after Varity agreed to acquire the 54 percent of the company it does not already own for $25 a share. And Morrison Restaurants advanced 2 1/2, to 20 1/4, after announcing that it will split into three separate companies.
Among the declining issues was Egghead, which said late Tuesday that it expected a wider loss in its second fiscal quarter than it had in the comparable period last year; its share price slipped 1 3/8, to 7 7/8. Midland Financial, which projected a loss for the third quarter, plummeted 8 1/4, to 10 1/2.

HEADLINE: Midpriced Hotels Look Abroad

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
For decades, American luxury hotel chains like Hilton and Hyatt have been familiar sights in foreign capitals and resorts, homes away from home for top business executives and well-heeled travelers.
But now, a second foreign invasion by American hotel and motel chains is under way, carrying decidedly middle-brow names like Comfort Inn, Days Inn and Holiday Inn Express -- and with prices that are midrange or even lower. 
 The new chains, often found in smaller cities and away from traditional downtowns, are aimed at local business travelers and regional tourists who value comfort and familiarity but are willing to do without frills. And while the original beachhead was the capitals and provinces of Europe, the new invaders have lately been going farther and farther off the beaten path, to virtually all corners of the developing world.
From Argentina to Zimbabwe, hundreds of new hotels bearing American chain names have been built in the last year or two, and a couple of thousand more are scheduled to rise in such countries as China, Costa Rica, India, Indonesia, Mexico, Panama and Thailand.
In Chile, for example, a Holiday Inn Express opened in January in Temuco, a commercial and agricultural center some 300 miles south of Santiago, the capital. It is the first of eight hotels in the Express chain -- which offer fewer services and amenities than regular Holiday Inns -- that are planned for Chile over the next three years. There are also plans to build 10 Howard Johnson hotels in the country.
A prime motivation for the relentless push abroad is the dim outlook for hotel growth in the United States, which is largely a mature market. By contrast, the Asia-Pacific region alone will need 1.2 million more rooms by 2005, according to a recent estimate by the Economist magazine's Intelligence Unit.
The larger world stage clearly is where the action is. "The difference between operating successfully in the United States and in the world economy is the difference between operating successfully in Minnesota and in the United States economy," said Curtis Nelson, president of the Minneapolis-based Country Hospitality Corporation, a unit of the Carlson Companies.
Last fall, Mr. Nelson's Country Inns agreed with local partners to develop about 20 hotels in Malaysia over the next 10 years -- part of the 60 it expects to have throughout Asia by 2000. This year it agreed to develop 37 hotels in India and 5 in Panama.
The American invasion has been made easier by a number of big changes abroad.
The fall of Communism removed many restrictions on travel and investment. That change, together with the spread of democracy, has resulted in a world on the move, with new highways and airports spurring the need for more hotels.
And thanks to the widespread availability of the latest technology, hoteliers in the undeveloped world are hardly in the hinterlands when it comes to day-to-day operations. To book reservations, for example, "Bombay talks to Phoenix in its computer, not New Delhi," said Werner Braum, director of international development of the Phoenix-based Best Western chain.
To be sure, American chains do not have the midpriced field entirely to themselves. In Europe and the Pacific, for example, they face formidable competition from Accor, the giant French chain that owns Motel 6, Sofitel and Novotel.
But the Americans are far ahead in many places, proliferating with much the same frequency as American fast-food companies did in recent years. And the approach is similar, whether the Americans are going into Europe or Asia: develop a big presence in the core markets, then fan out into the provinces once the economies of scale are in place.
"In the past, Hilton or Sheraton would put a hotel in Paris, then say they've done Paris," said Gerald Petitt, co-chairman of Choice Hotels International of Silver Spring, Md., parent of Comfort Inns and Quality Inns. "We have 33 Quality or Comfort Inns in and around Paris and more than 150 throughout France."
With some 300 foreign properties already, and a recent agreement to develop 210 hotels in Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay, Choice plans on having more than 3,000 properties abroad in 10 years.
The need for all these new economy and midpriced hotels in the developing world parallels the growth of the middle class there -- business and leisure travelers unwilling or unable to pay top dollar for a luxury hotel yet no longer content to stay in the fleabags or guest homes that were often their only other options.
Now, even budget hotels usually offer continental breakfast, television, air-conditioning and wake-up calls. Some new properties are resorts complete with swimming pools and other amenities, but with prices for rooms and local fare geared to attract middle-class guests.
"It took me a while to get used to the local food night after night, but after all, this is an Indonesian hotel," said Marty Busbee, in a recent telephone interview from the Quality Inn resort in Mambruk, Indonesia.
A native of Tyler, Tex., Mrs. Busbee, whose husband works in the oil industry in Indonesia, said she had been apprehensive about staying at a midrange, or three-star, hotel. "But the staff is gracious and the property is lovely," she said.
Rates at the midpriced chains vary widely. There are some real bargains, compared with prices in the United States. The Quality Inn properties in India, for example, average $15 a night in smaller cities and $30 in the big markets. But the rule of thumb, according to Best Western's Mr. Braum, is that rates in comparable South American properties are the same as in the United States, are 20 percent higher in Japan and at least 60 percent higher in Western Europe.
In Mexico, a large and growing class of middle and upper-middle managers is willing to pay a premium for the new hotels. At the recently opened Holiday Inn Express in Leon, an agricultural city in the country's center, rates average about $60, $10 or so more than at a Holiday Inn Express in the United States. (While the 43-year-old Holiday Inn chain has been owned since 1990 by Bass P.L.C., the British brewer, it is based in Atlanta and is still widely regarded as an American company.)
In 14 years of plying the backroads of Mexico, Jorge Fernandez de Miguel says he has been in almost every city in the country. What many have in common, said Mr. Fernandez, director of a training center in Mexico City that is a joint venture between Coca-Cola and its Mexican bottlers, are inadequate hotels. Some are overpriced, some are hovels, some are both, he said. And, of course, there are the guest houses, whose level of comfort and sanitation reflect the owner's whim.
"Now when I travel I often stay in a Holiday Inn Express, a Comfort Inn or some other chain hotel," Mr. Fernandez said. "They're clean, comfortable, air-conditioned and everything functions as it should."
Except for Best Western, which is an association of member hotels, the expanding midpriced chains are franchise operations. The "hotel company" owns few if any hotels. Instead, it franchises its name and reservations network, and provides training for the franchisees' employees, in return for about 7 percent of gross room revenue.
"The fast-food companies helped hotel chains all over the world by doing a good job of explaining the concept and value of franchising," said Ed Ansbro, vice president of development for Latin America for the Promus Company's Hampton Inns and Suites. Hampton properties are currently going up in Chile, Costa Rica and Mexico, and the company eventually is looking to have 150 properties in Latin America.
Most franchisors align themselves with a builder or hotel management company, which in Latin America is often family run. A "master franchise" is given exclusively in a country or region, usually for 10 to 15 years, although the franchisor still has the right to approve development plans and to impose standards of service.
"The absolutely critical key is to align with a partner with hospitality experience and with good ties to the government," said John Russell, president of Days Inn. Days Inn, a unit of Hospitality Franchise Systems, is in nine countries, including India, where it recently signed an agreement to build about 60 inns. It expects to add at least two countries a year -- including Malaysia, South Africa and Thailand -- for the next 10 years.
But not every franchisor is anxious to jump in. Marriott, for example, has no immediate plans to franchise its lower-priced operations, including Courtyard and Fairfield.
"We are just in the process of establishing our four- and five-star brands in key cities outside the U.S.," said June Farrell, a company spokeswoman. "Once we establish who we are there, we'll probably go into the secondary and tertiary markets with three-star properties."
And expansion already has been a mixed blessing for some. Many American mid-priced operations in Europe reportedly have not yet turned a profit, and Mexico's peso problems have proved disastrous for hotels along with other industries.
"It will be 6 to 12 months before hotels get back to break-even, and maybe three years before they get back to profitability," said Howard Willis, head of Holiday Inn's operations in Latin America, including Mexico, where the chain has 28 hotels.
But those putting down roots abroad say there are long-term benefits that outweigh the uncertainties. For hotel operators, they say, all roads eventually lead to home.
"Expanding abroad is a big help to our business in the U.S.," said Mr. Russell of Days Inn. "More than 20 percent of our business in America is coming from abroad, and we need to know how to service them better, so by the year 2000 we'll have 50 percent of our guests coming from abroad."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Sells Off With Bonds, But Regains Some of Its Losses

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most leading currencies yesterday, dragged down by an early selloff in the United States bond market.
The dollar was also weakened by continued monetary uncertainty in Europe. 
 Bonds fell early in the day after a report showing a greater-than-expected rise of 4.9 percent in durable-goods orders for August, which revived concerns that the American economy might be robust enough to accelerate inflation.
"After durable goods, bonds went considerably lower and the dollar linked up with them," said Kevin Lawrie, foreign exchange manager at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
Bonds later rebounded, buoyed by better-than-expected demand at the Treasury's auction for five-year notes. That helped the dollar pare its losses, traders said.
After falling as low as 97.75 Japanese yen, the dollar recovered to settle in New York at 100.45 yen, down from 100.90 yen on Tuesday. The dollar was quoted at 1.4253 German marks, down from 1.4373 marks, but up from its intraday low of 1.4200 marks. The dollar fell to 1.1530 Swiss francs from 1.1625 Swiss francs. The British pound rose to $1.5755 from $1.5665.
Contributing to the dollar's fall against the mark were doubts about the prospects for the European monetary union, which prompted investors to sell the currencies of some countries, like Italy, for marks.
Although many of those trades can be done directly, traders sometimes sell Italian lire and other currencies for dollars first, then sell the dollars for marks, traders said. As a result, the dollar often suffers when economic or political turmoil in Europe leads investors to seek the security of Europe's most stable currencies, the mark and Swiss franc.
"The on-again, off-again turmoil in Europe over the E.M.U. is a negative for the dollar," said Steve Flanagan, currency trader at Credit Agricole in New York. "The mark rebounded sharply overnight."
The shift to marks and Swiss francs began last Thursday after senior German officials questioned whether Italy, France and other European countries would be able to meet the strict economic criteria for monetary union laid out in the Maastricht treaty. The dollar fell 2.6 percent versus the mark that day.
"The dollar's going to have a tough time going up until they resolve the E.M.U. situation," said Earl Johnson, foreign exchange adviser at the Bank of Montreal/Harris Bank in Chicago.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Panel Urges Reform Of Nation's Bank System

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 27

 BODY:
In an effort to clear up the bad-loan problem that is threatening Japan's financial system, the Government moved today toward establishing an institution similar to the Resolution Trust Corporation, which was used to deal with the savings and loan crisis in the United States.
The recommendation to form an institution to take over and dispose of the bad debts held by home mortgage companies was contained in a blueprint for reform of Japan's banking system that was released today by an advisory committee to the Ministry of Finance. The committee also recommended the use of public money to help shore up the financial system in limited cases. 
 Today's report is an interim one that is expected to be finished by the end of the year. If the Ministry of Finance adopts the recommendations, as is expected, legislation would be introduced next year to put the plan into effect. Today, the Finance Ministry said it would seriously consider many of the proposals.
The Financial System Stabilization Committee, however, offered virtually no details about how a new debt-disposal institution would be structured. Indeed, analysts criticized the blueprint for being too vague and for failing to address the most pressing problem -- disposal of the bad loans of the home mortgage companies that are now virtually insolvent.
The report's significance is that it "is clearly showing the direction of the policy," said Mineko Sasaki-Smith, senior economist for Morgan Stanley & Company in Tokyo. "But specificity still has to wait." She added that the Government was "reluctant to take an extremely aggressive, surgical approach to the problem" of bad-loan disposal.
The report came only a day after Japan's financial system was jolted anew by the announcement that Daiwa Bank, a major commercial bank, had suffered a loss of $1.1 billion from unauthorized bond trading by an employee in its New York branch. The release of the banking reform proposals today was planned long ago and was not in response to the Daiwa incident.
The report represents another step toward building a consensus to use taxpayer money to pay for some of the bad-loan disposal, as was done in the United States. Many analysts say public financing is needed to resolve the problem and therefore help end Japan's economic slump. But the public is thought to be opposed to bailing out shady operators of failed credit unions.
The report says that for five years some public money might be needed to pay depositors after an institution fails. The report also says that taxpayer money might be needed to help dispose of bad loans but it notes that there is still opposition to this idea on the committee.
The Finance Ministry says Japanese financial institutions are carrying about $400 billion in bad loans, largely because of the collapse of real estate prices in recent years. Independent analysts say the figure is probably twice as high. Using the official figures, the ratio of nonperforming loans to total outstanding loans in Japan is about the same as it was in the United States at the peak of its bad-loan problem in 1991, the committee report says.
The document partly blames mismanagement at the Finance Ministry for the current problems..
The report recommends several regulatory changes to strengthen the financial system in the long run. These are among the proposals:
*Revamping the deposit insurance system and replenishing the insurance fund by raising the premiums banks must pay. The fund, analogous to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in the United States, was wiped out by the recent failures of a bank and two large credit unions.
*Increasing inspections so that regulators can shut down ailing financial institutions more rapidly.
*Shifting more regulatory responsibility for credit unions, four of which have failed in the last year, to the Finance Ministry and away from prefectural governments, which lack the necessary expertise.
*Requiring banks to disclose their bad-loan situation more completely. With better disclosure, depositors would be expected to exercise their own responsibility in choosing where to put their money. That way, the Government would not feel obligated to reimburse every depositor if a bank failed.
But on the most pressing issue, that of the home mortgage companies, the report basically punts, other than to call for the formation of an organization like the Resolution Trust Corporation to take over problem loans.
The eight home mortgage companies, known in Japanese as jusen, together have about $84 billion in bad loans, of which up to $63 billion is unrecoverable. The jusen issue has become "symbolic" of Japan's bad-loan situation and therefore should be "urgently addressed," the committee says.
The jusen were set up in the 1970's by large banks and other financial companies to provide loans for home purchases, a business the big banks did not want to be in themselves. But in the 1980's, the banks changed their minds and muscled their way into the home mortgage business.
"By the mid-80's the jusen got their legs cut off by the city banks," said David Threadgold, analyst with BZW Securities in Tokyo. Searching for new business, the jusen began lending heavily to real estate developers. Big banks "introduced clients to the jusen, especially people they didn't want to lend to directly because they were too shady," Mr. Threadgold said.
Now, most of the jusen are expected to be liquidated. The problem is who will swallow such huge losses -- the larger banks that created them, the agriculture cooperatives, which lent money to the jusen, or the Government. The issue is likely to be discussed in Parliament, where farmers have far greater support than banks.
The advisory committee report does not decide this issue. It merely calls on all parties to try to reach a consensus on a bad-debt disposal plan by the end of this year.
 
Putting Japan's Finances in Order
The Finance Ministry released a plan to aid troubled banks and to help restore confidence in the banking system. It is the first plan to propose using tax money to ball out failing financial institutions.
 
What the plan recommends
 
-- Use public funds to finance losses from failed banks.
 
-- Use public funds to stabilize banks before they fail.
 
-- Give authorities power to force the closure of financially troubled banks as soon as they become insolvent.
 
-- Replenish the depleted deposit insurance system through higher premiums and greater borrowing authority.
 
-- Encourage thrifts to become commercial banks.
 
-- Prohibit executives at thrifts from holding senior posts elsewhere.
 
-- Step up supervision of banks; require disclosure of bad loans; require independent review of credit cooperative' books.
 
-- Establish a temporary institution to take over failed thrifts, much like the Resolution Trust Corporation in the United States.
(Source: Bloomberg Business News)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Are Steadied By a Strong Note Auction

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices recovered in late trading yesterday, paring losses after an auction of new five-year notes turned out better than expected.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond slipped 1/32 , to 10329/32 , leaving its yield unchanged at 6.57 percent. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, had risen as high as 6.64 percent in trading yesterday. 
 Treasury securities initially stumbled after the Commerce Department reported yesterday that orders for durable goods jumped 4.9 percent in August, the largest increase in a year.
The increase was larger than what the market had expected, suggesting that spending on big-ticket items would pick up and reviving fears that inflation might start to accelerate.
Ken McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, a market research and analysis firm, said that "the increase in durable goods orders signals healthy, steady growth for the balance of 1995."
But Mr. McCarthy and other analysts noted that the sharp increase in August was largely a result of two developments: auto plants reopened in August after shutdowns in July and the Microsoft Corporation introducted its Windows 95 operating system for personal computers.
"When auto plants shut in July, orders plunge, and when they're re-opened in August, orders increase," Mr. McCarthy said. In addition the introduction of Windows 95, he said, "caused a 4.6 percent jump in orders for nonelectrical machinery, the third increase in the past four months."
"Given the distortion in this data -- a fact the Fed is well aware of -- the key question for the financial markets is, does this increase represent the start of a new upward trend, or is it an anomaly in an otherwise flat trend?" he said. "I think it's an upward trend but a moderate one."
Mr. McCarthy said that he expected a steady increase in durable-good orders -- that is, orders for goods from washing machines to aircraft -- would not keep the Federal Reserve from lowering short-term interest rates this year.
Treasury prices were also under pressure from weakness in the dollar yesterday. A weaker dollar makes imports more expensive, raising prices and inflation pressures as a result.
But a well-subscribed note auction helped bring buyers back into the market. The Treasury auctioned $11.5 billion of new five-year notes yesterday at a high yield of 6.141 percent, down from 6.370 percent last month and the lowest auction yield since June 28, when it was 5.905 percent.
Matthew F. Alexy, the chief market strategist at the CS First Boston Corporation, said the difference between the better-than-expected auction yesterday and the disappointing two-year note auction on Tuesday was that the two-year had been priced in a great deal of uncertainty. "It was coming on the day the Federal Open Market Committee was meeting," he said, referring to the Fed committee that sets short-term interest rates, "and in front of the durable-goods data."
Additionally, the price of the five-year notes was more attractive "and investors felt it had finally reached a price that even they thought was a fair value for the amount of current risk," Mr. Alexy said. "Much of the premium that had been built into the price on expectations that the Fed will cut rates was removed," he added.
Debt futures ended the session lower, with the December bond futures contract dipping early to the low of 11131/32 , before finishing at 11230/32 in the afternoon, one tick off the high set near the close.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
The S.E.C. tries to insure that investors get better stock prices.

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
TWENTY years after Congress mandated competition among securities markets, the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday made its most determined effort yet to make that competition work to the benefit of investors.
The S.E.C. voted to issue a proposal to require that the various markets that trade stocks in this country act to assure that investors have a reasonable chance of getting better prices than they have often gotten. A principal aim is to make sure that orders from investors can be seen by other investors who might want to take the other side. 
 "The issue is how do you make sure all buying and selling interest is reflected in the market," said Brandon Becker, the director of the S.E.C.'s division of market regulation.
A few decades ago, that goal would have seemed absurd. Nearly all major stocks were traded on the New York Stock Exchange, and for all practical purposes nowhere else. But the Congressional mandate for competition led to the revival of regional exchanges and the growth of other markets. And the Nasdaq market, which was in its infancy 20 years ago, grew to become a major market using competing market makers.
That competition has served to force down the costs of executing a trade, but at the cost of fragmenting markets. An order to sell a stock at a given price ought to meet an order to buy at the same price, but that does not always happen.
"Part of this is to address the fragmentation of the markets without forcing them together," said Richard R. Lindsay, the commission's chief economist. While commission rules have long required brokers to seek "best execution" for all customers, in practice that execution has not been very good, something the S.E.C. hopes to change.
The S.E.C. proposal, which had been leaked last week, calls for all markets to take the following steps:
*Assure that limit orders -- that is orders to buy or sell at a specified price -- are advertised to the market, so that someone willing to take the opposite side can be found.
*Require that brokers who quote prices on stocks quote the same price in all markets. Currently, brokers sometimes quote better prices on Instinet, a proprietary system used by many institutions, than they do on Nasdaq.
*Require that all orders to buy or sell at the market be given a chance for improvement. In practice, it appears that would include only stocks with a spread between the bid and asked prices of at least 25 cents. The bid price is the price at which someone stands ready to buy the stock; the asked price is the price at which someone is willing to sell it. For many liquid stocks, the spread is only 12.5 cents -- one-eighth of a dollar -- and the S.E.C. is unsure what to do in such cases.
*Require that any market maker who accounts for a significant part of trading volume in a stock maintain a published quote in the stock.
Arthur Levitt Jr., the commission chairman, said the rules would "represent a kind of culture change" for markets, but added that the S.E.C. hoped to begin a dialogue with markets and brokerage firms.
The S.E.C. action was taken by Mr. Levitt and Stephen M. H. Wallman, the only other sitting commissioner. Three seats are now vacant, although two nominations are pending.
That actual proposal is vague in many areas, with "hundreds of questions" that brokerage firms and others are asked to comment on, Mr. Wallman said. Details of the proposal will not be disclosed until later this week.
Although it appears that the Nasdaq market would be most affected, the rule is likely to have implications for all markets, including the stock exchanges and the so-called third-market traders who trade away from the primary markets.
Reaction from markets was generally restrained. Spokesmen for both Nasdaq and the New York Stock Exchange said they needed more details to comment, but added that their markets already met many of the criteria. On Monday, Nasdaq formally introduced its own plan, called Naqcess, to get better prices for traders.
Bernard L. Madoff, whose firm is one of the oldest of the third-market traders, praised the commission's action as "a major step in the right direction." It would, he added, not affect his company's operations.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
An argument that big ego is behind a lot of mergers.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
FIRST they put them together and then, most notably in the cases of ITT, Sears and AT&T, they take them apart. Is there more behind the recent frenzy of corporate coupling and uncoupling than the restless ambition of managers and their investment bankers?
That's what Mathew L.A. Hayward and Donald C. Hambrick of Columbia University seem to think. They argue that simple megalomania is a common disease in the executive suite. In a recent paper presented to the Academy of Management, they found statistical evidence that the premiums paid above market price to acquire new companies were tied to what the two researchers labeled the hubris of the bosses. 
 The conventional wisdom sees the situation differently. Corporate restructuring in the 1980's -- mostly leveraged buyouts -- was initially the result of the stock market's low valuation of corporate assets and Wall Street's new-found ability to peddle junk bonds to banks and insurance companies. By the same token, the current merger mania is apparently driven by an urge to do something -- anything -- to reduce risk or to exploit opportunities in a very rapidly changing business environment.
With profits squeezed in traditional areas of lending, banks have responded by seeking economies of scale. With both Washington and big employers howling to cut medical costs, pharmaceutical makers sought to guarantee market share by swallowing health care providers. With technology breaking the lock on delivering information and entertainment, the big purveyors are covering their bets by purchasing everything in sight. If General Motors and I.B.M. could fall, the thinking goes, why not us?
"They're confronting a profound level of ignorance" about how to adapt old companies to new environments, suggests Oliver E. Williamson of the University of California at Berkeley. And while Mr. Williamson thinks that growth through mergers "is the organizational form of last resort" because it tends to undermine market efficiency and adds to the costs of bureaucracy, he is basically sympathetic with the impulse.
Lawrence J. White, an economist at New York University's Stern School of Business, agrees. He sees a common motive in the spate of mergers in banking, medical care, information processing, electric utilities, telecommunications and entertainment. "All are responding to radical changes in technology or public policy," he says. In banking, Mr. White notes, roughly half the mergers seem to have increased efficiency while the other half decreased it. That's pretty much a wash. "These guys aren't as smart as they think they are," he concludes, but they all know they are vulnerable and see mergers and acquisitions as a way to stay ahead of the curve.
Still, means may easily be confused with ends, especially if the boss knows deep in his heart that the cure for what ails the corporation is more of his own august leadership. Executive hubris, Mr. Hayward and Mr. Hambrick argue, leads acquiring companies to pay too much.
They tested the idea by identifying various measures of hubris, among them an index of media praise for the acquiring company's chief executive and the sense of his own self-importance as measured by the ratio of the chief executive's pay to that of his second in command. And they found that the higher on the scale the chief executive happened to be, the larger the premium he was likely to pay over the pre-merger market value. In the 106 mergers in which the target company was bought for more than $100 million in the years 1989 and 1992, both measures were statistically linked to the price paid for the target company. Statisically, each highly favorable article about a chief executive in the national press added 5.4 percent to the premium over market price.
Jaundiced views of corporate mergers are nothing new. In fact, this research leads to a more forgiving perspective than the cynic's presumption that the real motive for most mergers is to generate fees for the investment bankers who do the matchmaking, or simply to give the chief executive a bigger jet to play with or to increase his invitations to White House dinners.
Whether the offending chief executives fall into the fool or knave category, shouldn't someone do something about it? That sentiment stirs memories of the 1960's, when big was equated with bad and the prevailing theory of antitrust put the burden of proof on corporations wishing to merge. Odd though it seems today, Washington spent a decade trying to cut I.B.M. down to size before Apple, Intel and Microsoft showed how fleeting power really was in the computer industry.
The issue for public policy is not whether corporate managers are overdoing the merger thing, but whether somebody is in a position to second-guess them with much hope of success. That somebody is more likely to be the shareholders than a government official. "All we can do," Mr. White concludes, "is try to get the managers' egos aligned with the stockholders' interests."

HEADLINE: Religious Differences Aside, 2 Men Await Pope's Soup Kitchen Visit

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, Sept. 27

 BODY:
For two years now, they have eaten breakfast together each morning at Our Daily Bread, this city's largest soup kitchen, and most days, the hour passes with only the mildest of chitchat. Once in a while, though, Douglas Tillery and his friend Alphonso Alvarez Jr. start talking religion. Then look out.
Mr. Alvarez is a Buddhist, Mr. Tillery a Baptist who would like to convert him. 
 "Buddha's nothing but a statue," Mr. Tillery said this morning, as they went at it again.
Mr. Alvarez laughed and said, "It's a wonderful thing."
"It's all bunk," Mr. Tillery huffed.
"Got to be yourself," Mr. Alvarez replied.
It has become their endless conversation, and they talked on for another few minutes today with the usual result of Mr. Alvarez promising to consider change and Mr. Tillery doubting his sincerity.
But recently, their debate has taken a new and, for them, quite unexpected turn. Of the hundreds of men and women who eat each day at the soup kitchen, Mr. Alvarez and Mr. Tillery are among 20 participants in local Roman Catholic charity programs invited to join Pope John Paul II and William Cardinal Keeler of Baltimore for lunch at the soup kitchen on Oct. 8.
The Pope's five-day trip to the United States, which includes four busy days in Newark and New York, is scheduled to end with a 10-hour visit to Baltimore.
With huge crowds expected at highlight events of the trip, Masses at Giants Stadium, Aqueduct Racetrack, Central Park and Oriole Park at Camden Yards here, the soup kitchen lunch of chicken-and-rice casserole and chocolate cake is one of the few small-scale events on the Pope's schedule. But it underscores a major theme of his visits to wealthier countries, that more should be done to help the poor and homeless.
By choosing Our Daily Bread, a 14-year-old institution on the same downtown block as the Basilica of the Assumption, the oldest Catholic cathedral in the country, the visit highlights not only the Pope's concerns but also the local archdiocese's.
"Being right there on that site shows our commitment to helping those less fortunate than we," said Bill Blaul, a spokesman for the Pope's Baltimore visit. "People are not stuffed away into some corner somewhere."
Vatican officials and archdiocese representatives have been planning the soup kitchen lunch for more than a year, to follow the stadium Mass and an afternoon parade from the stadium to the Basilica.
But the lunch guests, who include a mother with three children in a Head Start program and a couple who adopted two children from South Korea, were invited only last week, after officials from the charity programs settled on candidates whose lives had stabilized as a result of the services offered. Meals at Our Daily Bread are offered to elderly and disabled people of any religion.
Both Mr. Alvarez, 57, an employee of Goodwill Industries who has been disabled most of his life because of polio, and Mr. Tillery, a 45-year-old unemployed and disabled former marine and police officer, said in an interview after breakfast that they were surprised to learn they were selected. But only Mr. Alvarez, the more talkative of the two, could imagine what he might say to the Pope if given the chance to speak freely.
"With all the dope and drugs and people robbing people, I'd talk about trying to help other people the best you know how," said Mr. Alvarez, who was robbed but unhurt just last week in an incident near his downtown apartment.
Mr. Tillery said he would "try to be quiet and let the Holy Spirit speak to me and see what He has to say."
Mr. Tillery, who describes himself as a "spiritual Christian," said that anything he might say to John Paul would also come from the Holy Spirit.
But Mr. Tillery needed no apparent guidance in advising Mr. Alvarez to temper his enthusiasm for Buddhism, at least on Oct. 8.
"Don't tell the Pope," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alphonso Alvarez Jr., left, and Douglas Tillery have been chosen to dine with Pope John Paul II during his Oct. 8 visit to Our Daily Bread, a Baltimore soup kitchen where the two men meet daily. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Clampdown at Border Is Hailed as Success

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 23

 BODY:
Border Patrol agents call it squeezing the balloon. For the past year, aided by a big infusion of Federal money, manpower and technology, they have been squeezing as never before, choking off illegal crossings from Mexico at the busiest section of the border.
The immediate effects are unmistakable at the five-mile Imperial Beach section of the border that has historically been the scene of one-quarter of all illegal land entries into the United States and a symbol of the nation's difficulties in controlling its frontiers. 
 Once the nights were filled with chaos and violence, as both immigrants and the bandits who preyed on them clashed with American border guards. Now an ugly 10-foot-high welded-steel wall snakes up hillsides and down ravines, bathed in the orange glare of high-intensity stadium lights. Scores of Border Patrol agents keep watch from newly purchased vans, their work made easier by new night-vision scopes, ground motion sensors and computers.
This new equipment has given the agents the edge, but has not ended their cat-and-mouse game with border-crossers. As soon as the steel barricade was erected, replacing a sagging and torn chicken-wire fence, immigrants began tunneling beneath it, working holes into it and building ramps on the southern side to help them leap across. In response, agents began reinforcing the wall struts, anchoring its base in concrete and extending the sheeting as much as 10 feet underground in some areas.
The battle along the border here, part of a $500 million immigration initiative begun last year by the Clinton Administration, has as its target not only illegal aliens but also political opponents. Next August, the Republicans, who have made a campaign issue of illegal immigration, will hold their national convention here in San Diego, within a 15-minute drive of the border.
The one-year anniversary of the crackdown, Operation Gatekeeper, falls on Sunday. Academics who monitor the border say it is too soon to conclude whether this experiment in intensive border enforcement has been effective and worth its expense. But the Administration claims a measure of initial success.
The Immigration and Naturalization Service puts the cost for the first year of Operation Gatekeeper at $46 million, covering fencing, lights, vehicles, equipment, new agents and overtime.
"It is wonderful progress in an area where, frankly, most of us never really believed that government intervention like this would work," said Robert Bach, the top policy and planning official for the immigration agency, which oversees the Border Patrol. "This is historic. These are routes of travel that Mexicans have been using for decades. We have broken that up."
Along the Imperial Beach section of the border, which runs from the surf of the Pacific Ocean to the checkpoint in San Diego's San Ysidro section, the initial results were startling: apprehensions of illegal border-crossers, the main yardstick used to determine success, were reduced by 40 percent, to 114,460, over the past year. The Imperial Beach section covers the first 5 miles of a 24-mile wall along what is known as the San Diego Sector. The wall is in three sections, built where crossings have been most prevalent.
But as Border Patrol agents and planners like Mr. Bach have learned from long experience, when the balloon is squeezed in one place, it bulges in another. While apprehensions have dropped along the Imperial Beach section, they have skyrocketed farther east. Indeed, the total number of apprehensions along the San Diego Sector have actually risen by 14 percent over the past year, to 512,000.
Mr. Bach and other officials say they were prepared for the eastern bulge, calling it proof of their rapid success to the west, and insist that it is only a matter of time before these sections are also brought under control. Their plan is to push illegal border-crossers still farther to the east where they will face the obstacles of mountains and deserts and be forced to travel farther to reach the sanctuaries of cities.
But after a year of the most expensive and determined effort ever mounted by the Federal Government to bring the Mexican border under control, the fundamental question remains open: Is it possible to squeeze the entire balloon and to halt illegal immigration by force?
Is it possible, in the words of Johnny N. Williams, chief patrol agent of the San Diego Sector, to send the message to people in the poor villages of Mexico: "Stay home. If you try to cross over, you are going to get caught."
Wayne Cornelius, director of the Center for United States-Mexican Studies at the University of California at San Diego, said his visits to such villages suggested that the impetus of poverty was stronger than the deterrent effect of a more difficult border crossing.
"There is no evidence," Mr. Cornelius said, "that pushing illegal migrants into areas where there are more physical obstacles to crossing will deter more than a small minority from trying repeatedly to gain entry until they succeed.
"When you consider the economic return from even a short period of employment in the United States, the cost-benefit ratio still strongly favors illegal entry."
Thus, while Operation Gatekeeper sharply reduced the number of apprehensions in the Imperial Beach section, those along all other areas of the San Diego Sector rose. They were the Chula Vista area, up 27 percent, to 133,710; Brown Field, up 90 percent, to 129,326; El Cajon, up 439 percent, to 46,089; Campo, up 1,752 percent, to 24,111, and the Boulevard area, up 889 percent to 10,361.
"The movement eastward has occurred faster than I had predicted," Mr. Bach said, "and our ability to respond to that traffic in the east has strained our resources."
But he said the people crossing to the east, with a longer and more difficult trip to the cities, would be easier to apprehend once the Border Patrol increased its resources there.
And he said the immigration service was augmenting its border enforcement with other deterrents, including expedited deportation of criminal aliens and tighter enforcement of sanctions against employers who hire undocumented workers.
The Gatekeeper crackdown is part of a $540 million immigration initiative announced by Attorney General Janet Reno in February 1994. Since then, the Administration has nearly doubled the size of the Border Patrol, to more than 4,500 agents. It has asked Congress to approve the addition of hundreds more agents each year, with the goal of fielding about 7,000 agents by the end of 1998.
Statistics on apprehensions are notoriously difficult to analyze because they can be interpreted to reflect either improved enforcement or a surge in immigration. Mr. Williams, the San Diego Sector's chief patrol agent, said several factors complicated the current picture.
One is Mexico's economic crisis, after the devaluation of the peso last December, which most analysts believe has increased the number of Mexicans seeking employment in the United States. "They turned on the faucet," Mr. Williams said. "Absent Gatekeeper, we would have had a tidal wave."
A second is the phenomenon of repeat efforts to cross. Once a would-be migrant reaches the frontier from the interior of Mexico, is caught and sent back across the border, studies have shown, he or she is likely to try again and again rather than return home.
"We are apprehending fewer people more often," Mr. Williams said. "We have more fishermen in the sea, if you will."
