HEADLINE: Pataki, a Son of Hungary, Is Embraced as Its Rich Uncle

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, Sept. 27

 BODY:
The Prime Minister suggested on Monday that the Governor could help create an American Marshall Plan for Hungary. The Interior Minister asked him on Tuesday to help the nation fight organized crime. The mayor of one small town asked him for help in getting an airport, while the mayor of another thought Mr. Pataki might drum up investors for a riverside resort project.
Gov. George E. Pataki spent the final hours of his visit to the country of his ancestors today much the way he spent the previous four days: listening to petitioners. 
 A college official asked him to prevent the Hungarian Government from cutting his school's budget -- not realizing, perhaps, that Mr. Pataki himself cut spending on New York State colleges earlier this year. Business leaders implored him to open a Budapest trade office. And human-rights activists urged him to speak out on the treatment of Hungarians overseas.
So it has gone for much of the Governor's Hungarian trip, which ended today as Mr. Pataki flew to Italy for a five-day visit. Having come here to help New York's economy by building commerce with Hungary, Mr. Pataki instead found himself inundated with appeals to help Hungary first.
"He's like the rich American uncle," said Bulcsu Veress, a Hungarian-American who has been accompanying Mr. Pataki for much of the trip.
The tenor of the trip has raised questions about just what Mr. Pataki can achieve here to help New York's economy, and whether, if his aim was to help the state, he would have been better off staying home to fight proposed Federal spending cuts that could devastate New York's budget.
Mr. Pataki has answered by saying that he will lobby hard in Washington against budget cuts as soon as he returns home next week. And he argued that the trip would benefit New York's economy in the long run by pushing the state faster into an emerging Central and Eastern European market.
"If I.B.M. is successful in marketing computers in Eastern Europe, where there should be an exploding market over the course of the next decade, it should allow us to create chip-manufacturing jobs in the Hudson Valley," Mr. Pataki explained to reporters today. "I think to the extent we can see better market penetration by New York companies, it can only help us."
But greater market penetration did not seem to be much on the minds of Hungarian officials the Governor met.
Asked if Hungarians expected more of him than he could possibly deliver, Mr. Pataki said: "I don't think there is any great belief that the visit of the Governor of New York is going to change the economic circumstances of Hungary. I think there is the hope that I will take back the message that these vast potential markets on the new global marketplace exist."
But among Hungarians, Mr. Pataki is clearly viewed as a walking promotion for Hungarians, and his trip is seen as a public-relations coup for the entire country.
"Every Hungarian thinks that George Pataki can raise awareness about Hungary in America," said George Lang, the New York restaurateur who is co-owner of Gundel Restaurant in Budapest. "The fact that he did this trip already is a kind of public relations wave you couldn't buy for any amount of money."
Laszlo R. Czirjak, general manager of Bankers Trust's Hungary office, said Mr. Pataki could help convince American investors that Hungary, despite its large debt, high inflation rate and fitful attempts to privatize state industries, can be a safe haven for American investments.
"Hungary suffers from an image problem," he said. "The Governor has access to a lot of people and in informal meetings with companies he can say, 'Hey, look at Hungary instead of the Far East.' "
American-based companies with operations in Hungary also seem to think that Mr. Pataki will help them deal with Hungarian Government officials, even after he returns to New York.
Amid the high expectations of him, Mr. Pataki has already disappointed on one front. Many Hungarian business leaders hoped that he would announce the opening of a state trade office in Budapest. But Mr. Pataki, who has closed four of the state's overseas offices as part of budget cuts this year, today said no.
Instead, he said that the state's last remaining European trade office, in London, would create a Central and Eastern European desk to find business opportunities for New York State companies.
Some East European experts said that the high expectations of Mr. Pataki are sure to lead to more disappointments.
"Unfortunately, I think they expect too much from this trip," said Ronald P. Oppen, director of the State University of New York's international programs for Eastern Europe. "It's because their needs are so great."

HEADLINE: Reform of the U.N. Is Overdue

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who can be diplomatic to a fault, cut quickly to the point in his address before the 50th anniversary session of the United Nations General Assembly this week. To win back the ebbing trust and support of Americans, he told the delegates, the U.N. must reform its financial ways.
Mr. Christopher urged the U.N. to eliminate outdated or duplicative agencies and programs, streamline its patronage-swollen headquarters bureaucracy and subject all parts of the organization to the scrutiny of inspectors general with the authority to end financial waste. 
 Dozens of agencies, he pointed out, now share overlapping responsibilities in the areas of economic development, emergency relief and statistical reporting. Some of the functions of the venerable U.N. Conference on Trade and Development may more appropriately belong to the new World Trade Organization. Despite some modestly successful efforts at improved financial oversight in recent years, the U.N. has been repeatedly embarrassed by procurement scandals, excessive personnel costs and the waste of scarce resources.
Mr. Christopher called, as President Clinton did last year, for a far more selective approach to peacekeeping operations and a reapportionment of contributions to reduce the American share and to reflect the rise of new economic powers like Japan.
The United States is asked to contribute 31 percent of the peacekeeping budget in addition to valuable support in equipment and people. That is only partly offset by U.N. contracts for peacekeeping purchases that go to American companies.
Mr. Christopher was right on every point. The U.N., despite its many shortcomings as an international forum, can play an important role in making the world safer and more secure, but it badly needs to fix its internal problems and funding inequities. There is little chance Congress will provide more than $1 billion in overdue assessments until it does.
In other areas, Mr. Christopher rightly reiterated American support for making Germany and Japan permanent members of the Security Council, although he failed to address how this could be accomplished without further increasing the disproportionate power already exercised by the developed world or making the council unwieldy. The U.N. cannot dodge these questions any longer.
Mr. Christopher has provided the U.N. with a timely and necessary program of reform that it would be wise to act on promptly.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Essay;
New Evil Empire

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Security will be especially tight at the House Judiciary Committee's hearing room tomorrow morning, as a former Chicago mobster testifies about the penetration of organized crime into the booming world of "legitimate" gambling.
William Jahoda, under Federal protection, will get the camera attention, but the story will be the Federal Government's first step toward focusing the nation's attention on gambling, the new evil empire 
 Gambling is a $40-billion-a-year industry that is inherently immoral, corrupting public officials, enriching criminals, addicting and impoverishing the young and vulnerable.
But the gambling racket -- whether in state-licensed casinos, state-sponsored lotteries or on glitzy reservations of phony Indian tribes -- has been promoted by public officials as a great way of painlessly raising revenues, with state voters acting as suckers. As a result, officially endorsed and government-advertised gambling now has America by the throat.
Last week in this space, I wrote about a bill presented by Representative Frank Wolf, Republican of Virginia, to establish a national commission to investigate gambling's economic and social effects. The word was that the bill would get a hearing and then be shelved
But a phenomenon is under way. Senator Richard Lugar challenged the Christian Coalition and other family-values groups to get behind the movement to root out this state-sponsored immorality.
They did. "We'll have a couple of representatives present at the hearing," Ralph Reed of the Coalition tells me, "and we'll underwrite the work of a full-time lobbyist." He joined a half-dozen family groups warning, in a letter to Speaker Newt Gingrich, that "teenagers are gambling in record numbers."
Reed notes how the alliance worked in defeating gambling in Virginia: "The combination of black preachers and white family groups can be a powerful force in politics. They freeze the Democrats, we freeze the Republicans."
Meanwhile, Tom Grey, a Methodist minister from Galena, Ill., who heads the grass-roots National Coalition Against Legalized Gambling, got busy with his fax machine. At the hearing, Mr. Grey will fade the bet of Frank Fahrenkopf, the former Republican National Committee Chairman hired by the gamblers.
A member of the House Republican leadership called me in wonderment: "There's more mustard on this issue than I thought." He now expects Judiciary will mark up the bill and make it available for a floor vote next month.
Who stands for the forces of darkness at the House hearing? Representative Barbara Vucanovich, Republican of Nevada, says: "This bill is the nose under the tent of Federal interference with the right of states to regulate gambling." She admits that "gaming is kind of wasting your money" and is "not something the people of Nevada do," but clings to that decentralizing principle.
As a card-carrying devolutionary, I'm for providing states with national information to help them make local decisions. This is a national nose we have to get under the state tents in a hurry, as gambling on riverboats and Indian lands undermines jurisdictions, and as on-line gambling turns computers into interstate casinos.
Gamblers like Steve Wynn of Las Vegas, who just raised $500,000 for Bob Dole at a lunch, think they have the Senate majority leader in their pocket; they may be surprised.
For the first time in years of wailing in the wilderness, I see hope for turning the gambling trend around. We need no laws against a friendly poker game or church fund-raising by Bingo; we do need the facts that will disabuse local voters of the notion that skimming gambling profits helps local education. That's a hoax: the truth is that lottery proceeds soon substitute for, and do not augment, education funds.
"We've been taking them on and beating them," reports Tom Grey, who claims 16 state victories against 2 defeats in two years, on next to no money. His group (1-800-664-2680, E-mail ncalgwave.park.wy.us) meets with like-minded moralists in Orlando, Fla., on Oct. 27 for a national strategy session.
Odds are this bill to investigate gambling will pass. And the truth will make us free.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%);

HEADLINE: Hidden Change in Foreign Aid Bill Sets G.O.P. Against G.O.P.

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27

 BODY:
A disagreement has broken out among Senate Republicans over an amendment quietly stuck into the foreign aid bill that would withdraw most-favored-nation trading status to any country that does not back sanctions against the Burmese military Government.
While floor managers of bills often insert amendments that have unanimous support, several lawmakers criticized Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican who managed the foreign aid bill, for inserting an amendment, without unanimous backing, that could have huge repercussions. 
 Several lawmakers said the bill could, for instance, cut off China's most-favored trade status because Beijing does not honor sanctions against Myanmar, formerly Burma.
As the flap heated up, Senator McConnell said he would withdraw the amendment.
After the Senate approved the bill last Thursday, John McCain of Arizona, a Republican leader on foreign policy, took to the Senate floor to attack the way the amendment on Myanmar was inserted.
"I was quite upset about it and thought it was highly inappropriate to do it," Mr. McCain said in an interview. "I have a special concern about Burma -- 60 percent of the heroin coming to the United States comes through Burma -- and if there was an amendment on the issue, I wanted to be involved in the debate."
Joining this unusual intraparty feud, Senator William Roth, the Delaware Republican who is chairman of the Finance Committee, wrote a letter to Mr. McConnell expressing great disappointment with the amendment. He complained not only that the provision involved matters that were the jurisdiction of his committee, but also that its call for withdrawing most-favored-nation trade status would violate treaties.
In an interview today, Mr. McConnell said he inserted the amendment without a vote to apply some quick pressure on the Burmese military dictatorship. The foreign aid bill, approved 91 to 9, would cut overseas assistance by 10 percent.
Mr. McConnell's amendment also calls for banning travel to Myanmar, barring Burmese imports and withholding money to the International Monetary Fund if it provides aid to Myanmar.
"I do think there is some urgency about this," Mr. McConnell said. "The situation there is quite terrible. I thought it would be helpful to the situation in Burma to have some language in the bill."
He called Senator McCain late today to say he would move to delete the amendment when House and Senate lawmakers meet to rework the bill in conference. Nonetheless, Mr. McConnell vowed to continue trying to pressure Myanmar and "fight this another day and soon."
Several Republican Senate aides said they had been reassured by Robin Cleveland, a top aide to Mr. McConnell, that no Myanmar amendment would be put into the foreign aid bill. Several Republican aides said they were stunned to learn that a Myanmar amendment had been inserted into the overall bill, especially since several senators had expressed reservations about a bill on Myanmar that Mr. McConnell had been floating for several months.
Mr. McConnell defended his decision to insert the amendment. Speaking about Senator McCain, he said, "What was unusual was that John wanted to clear every amendment we handled," he said. "That's just not possible. You can't manage a bill that way."
But a senior Republican aide said, "It violates all Senate rules of tradition and comity to surreptitiously insert an important amendment that does not have unanimous consent."

HEADLINE: China Cancels A Sale to Iran, Pleasing U.S.

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 27

 BODY:
In a move that is likely to speed up the recovery in the troubled relationship between Washington and Beijing, China told the United States today that it had decided to cancel its contract to sell two nuclear power reactors to Iran.
Foreign Minister Qian Qichen told Secretary of State Warren Christopher of his Government's decision during a nearly two-hour meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, a senior Administration official told reporters after the meeting. 
 Just five months ago, in a similar meeting in New York, Mr. Qian told Mr. Christopher that despite fierce objections by the United States, which wants to keep nuclear technologies out of the hands of the militant Iranian Government, his country intended to go forward with the deal.
But also today, in a clear rebuff to the United States, the Chinese declined an invitation from President Clinton for President Jiang Zemin to come to Washington for a meeting next month.
The unwillingness to accept the invitation was based not on any substantive disagreement, but on China's insistence that Mr. Jiang deserved a formal state visit -- complete with an arrival ceremony with 21-gun salute, dozens of Chinese flags flying along Pennsylvania Avenue and a formal dinner at the White House, other senior Administration officials said.
Mr. Christopher and his team had expected Mr. Qian to accept eagerly -- and express gratitude for -- an invitation to the White House, and the American side had been expected to announce a summit meeting after the session.
Senior Administration officials do not rule out the possibility of a summit meeting in Washington, and Chinese and American officials will continue talks on how to make it happen in the days after the two leaders address the General Assembly next month during ceremonies marking the 50th anniversary of the United Nations.
But a formal state visit may be more problematic. Mr. Clinton has said he does not like state visits and he has presided over only seven -- for the leaders of Japan, South Africa, Ukraine, Russia, Brazil, South Korea and Morocco. President Jacques Chirac of France has been invited for a state visit in November.
In addition, elevating a meeting with the Chinese President to a state visit might open Mr. Clinton to criticism from conservative Republican lawmakers on Capitol Hill that he is being too nice to Beijing, particularly since only weeks ago the United States-China relationship was in the worst state since China crushed its democracy movement in 1989.
"A summit remains a goal of both sides," said the official. But he added that in the current Administration, "It's still very rare to have official state visits."
In recent weeks a number of events have helped pull both countries back from the brink: the release by Beijing of Harry Wu, the American human rights advocate convicted of stealing state secrets; the visit by Hillary Rodham Clinton to Beijing to address the international women's conference; the decision of the Chinese to return their Ambassador to Washington and approve an American Ambassador for Beijing, and an easing of Capitol Hill's China-bashing.
In another sign of China's determination to get the relationship back on track, the thorny issue of Taiwan was barely discussed in today's meeting, and Mr. Qian did not repeat his country's persistent demand that the United States pledge never again to allow a Taiwanese leader to visit the United States.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Jiang, who is Secretary General of the Communist Party and Commander in Chief of China's three-million-member Army, have met twice before: in Seattle in 1993 and in Jakarta, Indonesia, last year. Although Mr. Clinton has a gift for disarming his guests, the two men have never hit it off.
But the Chinese rejection of the summit meeting invitation could not obscure the much more important development involving Iran.
A senior Administration official suggested China did not make the decision in deference to Washington but for its own internal reasons.
"The Secretary raised our well-known concerns," he said, but added, "It was their own unilateral decision."
The head of Iran's nuclear agency, Reza Amrollahi, said in an interview last May that he had signed a formal contract last year and had made a down payment on two 300-megawatt pressurized water reactors to be built in southern Iran. But China is believed to have become increasingly resigned to the fact that the deal would fail, both because of Iran's increasingly difficult economic situation and its nuclear cooperation with Russia, which has begun a $780 million project to complete a much-larger reactor at Bushehr on the Persian Gulf.
In addition, the United States had doubts that China could build the reactors on its own because the original model included parts from Germany and Japan.
Today's meeting between Mr. Christopher and Mr. Qian also went a long way to setting aside the thorny issue of Taiwan, which China considers a renegade province.
The relationship between the two countries has been deteriorating since the beginning of the year, but it worsened considerably last spring, after the United States decided to change 16 years of official policy and allow President Lee Deng Hui of Taiwan to visit the United States.
After months of trying, the Administration has apparently convinced Beijing that it has no intention of abandoning its one-China policy, although it has refused to pledge never to allow future visits by Taiwanese officials.
In remarks to reporters before today's meeting, Mr. Qian seemed to accept that, saying the United States has "stated that it fully understands the seriousness and sensitivity of the question of the visit to the United States by Tawian leaders." He added, "The U.S. side will handle this question with great prudence in the future."
For his part, Mr. Christopher also sounded a conciliatory note, saying before the meeting: "Sometimes we've had differences, Sometimes we've had quite profound disagreements on issues like human rights. But both of our countries accept that the best way to address those problems is through positive and regular dialogue."

Clinton and Yeltsin to Meet
 WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia agreed today to get together of an abbreviated meeting on Oct. 23 in Hyde Park, N.Y., the White House announced today.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin spoke for 20 minutes today, discussing the coming meeting -- to be held in conjunction with the United Nations session in New York -- and recent peace developments in Bosnia, a White House spokesman, Mike McCurry, said.
Mr. McCurry said Hyde Park, the home of Franklin D. Roosevelt, was chosen as the site because "that would evoke the spirit of cooperation between the United States and Russia that existed during World War II."

HEADLINE: Orders for Durable Goods Surged by 4.9% in August

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27

 BODY:
Orders for big-ticket manufactured goods jumped 4.9 percent in August, the largest increase in a year, as some auto plants resumed production after a shutdown to retool for 1996 models, the Commerce Department said today.
"It's a strong number," said Carl Palash, chief economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York. "It's a good-sized gain despite the monthly volatility. It points to better manufacturing ahead." 
 August's increase in orders for durable goods -- among the most volatile of the monthly economic indicators -- was the first since May. The Commerce Department also revised July's decline to show a drop of 1.8 percent, smaller than the 2.7 percent originally reported.
The August increase was well above analysts' forecasts, which had ranged from about 2.4 percent to 3.1 percent. It brought fears that inflation might accelerate and investors concluded that the latest data would give the Federal Reserve little need to cut interest rates soon.
"There's no risk of a recession in 1995," said Anthony Chan, chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation, in Columbus, Ohio. "The economy will probably hum along" at an annual rate of 2.5 percent to 3 percent, he said.
August's increase in orders was broad. Excluding orders for transportation equipment, durable goods orders rose 2 percent. Excluding military hardware, orders rose 3.8 percent.
The breadth of August's increase suggests that the gain was not a fluke, Mr. Chan said.
Over all, "the risks of recession have receded since early this summer," analysts at the Nationsbank Corporation wrote before the release of today's report, citing a surge in housing sales and construction.
Still, analysts took note of the data's volatility, which stems from an erratic pattern of orders for aircraft and military hardware. The seasonal shutdown of auto plants in July added more volatility to orders this summer, analysts said.
If August's surge in manufacturing orders does prove to be an aberration, continued sluggishness on the industrial side of the economy could give the Federal Reserve reason to lower interest rates.
Unfilled orders, a gauge of pent-up demand, rose two-tenths of 1 percent in August, the ninth increase in the last year. Shipments, a gauge of current demand, increased 4.7 percent, the third gain in four months.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 3, 1995, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article by Bloomberg Business News in Business Day on Thursday about a Commerce Department report on orders for durable goods in August misstated the previously reported decline in orders in July. It was 2.1 percent, not 2.7 percent.

HEADLINE: In Schools Crisis, Union's Opportunity

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
Sandra Feldman, the canny and powerful president of the New York City teachers' union, has been complaining more than usual this fall: about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's epic battle with the Board of Education over the choice of a new chancellor, about overcrowded classrooms, about having to negotiate a teachers' contract during the worst education budget cuts since 1975.
"This is a horrible, horrible situation," she said. 
 In truth, this may be Ms. Feldman's season of triumph. While Mr. Giuliani and Carol A. Gresser, the president of the Board of Education, have warred for months about hegemony over the school system, Ms. Feldman has quietly maneuvered herself into a position in which the union will have considerable say in how that system is run.
"She is using this dysfunctional situation to her advantage," Mrs. Gresser said.
Last week, in conversations with board members, Ms. Feldman spoke warmly of the Mayor's latest choice for chancellor, Leon M. Goldstein, the president of Kingsborough Community College. Mr. Goldstein is opposed by Mrs. Gresser, and has been criticized for his close ties to the Brooklyn Democratic machine. "I think his political savvy is a plus," said Ms. Feldman, echoing the Mayor.
Next month, Ms. Feldman will try to finish negotiating a new union contract with City Hall, which pays the teachers, and the school board and the new chancellor, who set policy. Ms. Feldman wants higher salaries, and also a sweeping transfer of power in budget and hiring decisions from the Board of Education to individual schools -- and teachers. If the chancellor is Mr. Goldstein, both he and Mr. Giuliani will owe favors to Ms. Feldman at an opportune time.
"What we're watching here is a superb union leader and tactician coming in for the kill," said Edward I. Koch, the former Mayor, who said he only recently forgave Ms. Feldman for supporting his successful opponent, David N. Dinkins, six years ago.
Two weeks ago, working with Mr. Giuliani, her new ally, Ms. Feldman used her political leverage over the Board of Education to secure a promise of no teacher layoffs. City Hall was impressed. "She's got an incredible political and legislative lobbying organization over there," said Randy Levine, the Mayor's chief labor negotiator.
Ms. Feldman has long been one of the most important power brokers in the city, a union boss with the votes and influence from her 120,000-member United Federation of Teachers to make or break candidates for mayor, City Council, borough president and the Legislature. She is unapologetic about her maneuverings.
"I think if I were not looked upon as a formidable political force," she said, "I would not be doing my job."
Sandra Feldman is 55, a tall, angular, well-dressed worrier who wakes up in the middle of the night and makes lists. Friends say she does lighten up -- she has a good torch-singer voice after a glass of wine -- but it takes time.
"If you walk up to Sandy in a social setting and ask, 'Did you have a good summer?' " said Richard I. Beattie, a lawyer and founder of the Fund for New York City Public Education, "she'll say, 'Oh, things have been terrible, the Mayor's been fighting with the Board of Ed.' And you have to say, 'No, no, Sandy, did you have a good vacation?' "
Ms. Feldman, who has no children and spent only three years as a classroom teacher, has always looked upon the teachers' union as her personal cause and the New York City public school system as her salvation. In a conversation with a teacher at New Dorp High School in Staten Island the other day, she recalled how her first home economics class in junior high school had made a small, but important, change in her life.
"It was the first time I understood there was a difference between a kitchen dish towel and a regular towel," she said, smiling. "I learned something about how to live in the world that I wouldn't have known."
Ms. Feldman grew up in the back three rooms of a condemned house on Neptune Avenue in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn, the unhappy daughter of a milkman and a mother who was so often ill that Ms. Feldman, the eldest, was left to care for her two younger siblings. "What we both got at home was no comfort and not much love and no recognition for our intelligence," said Ms. Feldman's friend, Rachelle Horowitz, a consultant to the American Federation of Teachers.
Public School 188 in Coney Island and a beloved second-grade teacher, Miss Bezman, opened her life. "I had no idea this world existed," said Ms. Feldman, who has spoken time and again of Miss Bezman as a kind of guardian angel. "There were paints and pictures and books and musical instruments. I loved school."
Ms. Feldman still gets misty-eyed during visits to schools like P.S. 19 in Corona, Queens, which immigration in recent years has swelled to 2,500 pupils with 25 languages from 47 countries. The students include some fifth graders who had never been in a classroom before. Ms. Feldman, whose grandparents arrived in Brooklyn from Eastern Europe during the great wave of immigration at the turn of the century, finds in schools the memories of the best days of her youth.
"This looks just like the school I went to," she said. "You know, they made those cookie-cutter buildings," she added, with feeling in her eyes, looking at the hopeful new paint in the P.S. 19 auditorium.
Ms. Feldman's background is also that of a traditional union organizer, schooled as she was by the civil rights leader Bayard Rustin and her even more powerful predecessor at the union, Albert Shanker. Her political education began in the late 1950's as a student at Brooklyn College, where Ms. Feldman fell comfortably into the socialist politics of a small group of campus bohemians. "We all came from working class, emotionally deprived backgrounds," said Ms. Horowitz, who became friends with Ms. Feldman when the two began passing notes complaining of a professor's "simple behavioral stuff" in a psychology course.
"Partly we were interested in psychology for selfish reasons," Ms. Horowitz said. "You know, 'When will we be happy?' So a lot of that was channeled into our activism. We had this belief that our personal happiness would come from making the world better."
Ms. Feldman was married after her freshman year to Paul Feldman, whom she met on the literary magazine. "We were both drawn to tortured men," Ms. Horowitz said. The couple were divorced 17 years later, and Ms. Feldman is now married to Arthur Barnes, the former president of the New York Urban Coalition.
Two of Ms. Feldman's proudest moments were her arrest for trying to integrate restaurants on Route 40 in Maryland in 1963, and her work in Harlem helping with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s march on Washington in August of that year. That fall, she began her only regular job as a teacher at P.S. 34 on the Lower East Side, where she taught first and fourth grades and was one of only two members of the union.
Within a year, Ms. Feldman had helped organize the entire teaching staff. By 1966, on the recommendation of Mr. Rustin, Mr. Shanker hired her as a full-time field representative.
"I said to myself, 'Well, I can always go back to teaching,' " Ms. Feldman said. She laughed. "Here I am."
Ms. Feldman became president of the union in 1986, and has been re-elected five times by increasing majorities. Mr. Shanker, now president of the American Federation of Teachers in Washington, has recently cast less of a shadow over her life. "As the years went on I got more and more confident," Ms. Feldman said. "But it was very difficult."
One of the more absorbing developments of the chancellor battle has been Ms. Feldman's newfound relationship with Mr. Giuliani. "Personally, he's different from the way he comes across," Ms. Feldman said. "He's very charming. He's funny. He's nice. And there are things I agree with him about. He really cares about the schools."
The Mayor and the largely Democratic teachers' union found common purpose this summer, when Ms. Feldman made a deal, as part of a citywide agreement, with Mr. Giuliani: no layoffs in exchange for the union's forfeiture of $160 million in health and pension benefits. The Board of Education then announced it was not a party to the deal, and all summer threatened to defy the Mayor with layoffs. By the time school started, 1,000 unassigned teachers did not know if they could keep their jobs, but under pressure from City Hall and Ms. Feldman, the board agreed to keep the teachers for now.
Given the circumstances, Ms. Feldman said it is not surprising she has sided with the Mayor, but denied that she made a deal with him to remain neutral, or even support him, in the next election. (The union was neutral in 1993, which helped Mr. Giuliani defeat Mr. Dinkins.)
"The mayor is the mayor," said Ms. Feldman. "The mayor holds the purse strings. And when it's time to enter the political fray, if that's helpful to my members, I've never been shy about it. I've been in it, and I will be in it, when I need to be."
She said she does not favor giving Mr. Giuliani line-by-line control of the school budget, as he wants, but that "if he had confidence in the person running the budget end of things, that might not be the issue that it is."
Few things make Ms. Feldman angrier than critics who say that her union, with its seniority rules, opposition to merit pay and restrictions on dismissing teachers for incompetence, is not only inconsistent with her goals for children but also an impediment to improving schools. "There is nothing I have ever done as a union leader which has not been good for kids," Ms. Feldman said, adding that the union, "despite popular myth, does not want incompetent teachers in the classroom."
In contract talks, Ms. Feldman is asking for salaries that will be more competitive with surrounding districts. Top pay in New York City is $60,000, compared with $74,000 in White Plains and more than $80,000 in some districts on Long Island. Ms. Feldman makes $156,963 a year.
She says she will have to be "in an oxygen tent" before she gives up a much-criticized benefit, the $20 million a year spent on sabbaticals, available to teachers after 14 years at up to 70 percent pay.
"Having teachers with high morale who have self-respect and dignity is good for kids," Ms. Feldman said. "Just because kids are poor, and maybe come from uneducated parents, and live in an urban setting, doesn't mean they shouldn't have teachers who are paid as well, and whose lives are as comfortable professionally, as teachers from the richest suburbs. It is so emotionally and intellectually exhausting teaching in the classrooms of New York City. You have to be mother and father and social worker and psychologist and baby sitter."
Ms. Feldman says passionately that a child can get "the best education in the country" at some New York City public schools, and that if she had children she would never consider private school.
"I mean, I would want my child to grow up to be something like me," she said, laughing. "They'd have to go to public school. They wouldn't get to be me in private school."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Market Jumps on Gains In Technology Stocks
The stock market rose on a surge in technology stocks, as buyers returned after Wednesday's early sell-off and late rebound.
The Dow industrials jumped 25.29 points, to 4,787.64, and the technology-heavy Nasdaq index soared 20.51 points to 1,047.05. The S.& P. index rose 4.83 points to 585.87. [Page D6.]
 
The dollar fell against most leading currencies, dropping to 99.22 Japanese yen, from 100.45 yen on Wednesday, and to 1.4200 German marks, from 1.4253 marks. [D13.]
 
Competing Bids for British Utility
Houston Industries and Central and South West, seeking a stake in Britain's consolidating electric-power industry, announced an agreement to acquire Norweb P.L.C. for $2.7 billion. But a British water utility quickly topped their offer. [D3.]
 
Caremark to Buy Cigna Clinics
Caremark agreed to acquire the Cigna Medical Group, which operates 29 clinics in Los Angeles, from Cigna Health Care of California. The transaction is expected to increase Caremark's 1996 revenue from management of physicians' practices to almost $1 billion nationwide, including about $600 million in Southern California alone. Financial terms were not disclosed. [D5.]
 
News on Loan Lifts Mexican Stocks
The stock market in Mexico rebounded 1.64 percent after Government officials said that President Zedillo would tell President Clinton in Washington on Oct. 11 that Mexico would repay its $12.5 billion loan on schedule. [D3.]
 
Anadarko Plans to Drill in Red Sea
Anadarko said it would begin searching for oil in the Red Sea, using technology it developed in the Gulf of Mexico to find oil below salt formations. It will invest $28.5 million in Eritrea in the next seven years. [D2.]
 
Seven Settle Insider Trading Case
Seven men settled charges by the S.E.C. that they had illegally traded on insider information before the March 1994 announcement of a takeover offer by Martin Marietta for Grumman. [D6.]
 
AT&T Tries to Calm Employees
Robert E. Allen, the chairman of AT&T, held a video teleconference with employees and discounted reports that AT&T planned to cut 20,000 employees, saying that the company had not begun to make any decisions. [D5.]
 
Concession on Superfund Debate
House Republican leaders backed away from earlier plans to relieve big corporate polluters of the obligation, under the Superfund environmental law, to help pay for cleaning up old toxic waste dumps, but they would exempt many small businesses and municipal landfills from paying for clean-ups. [A28.]
 
Commerce Official Heading to Yale
Jeffrey E. Garten, the Under Secretary of Commerce for international trade and a chief architect of the Administration's focus on emerging markets, said he was resigning to become dean of Yale's School of Management. Mr. Garten had spearheaded the Administration's strategy to support American efforts to win contracts and business opportunities abroad. [D2.]
 
China Sentences Australian
James Peng, an Australian businessman who had textile and property interests in China, was sentenced in China on corruption and embezzlement charges to 18 years in prison and deportation. Mr. Peng's case has raised concern among business people working in China over the arbitrary nature of Chinese law and the dangers of crossing politically powerful officials. [D4.]

HEADLINE: New Toll Road Offers Glimpse at Future

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: STERLING, Va., Sept. 28

 BODY:
After a gala celebration on Friday, the first privately financed toll road built in this century will open on Saturday here in northern Virginia, offering commuters a speedier link between rural surburbs and Washington.
But the new highway, the 14.1-mile Dulles Greenway, is viewed as more than a quicker alternative to a stuttering trip through a dozen traffic lights along nearby state roads. It is, government officials and transportation experts say, a prime example of the way big public construction projects will be built in the future. 
 Those experts say that with fewer tax dollars available, with a reluctance by elected officials to impose new taxes and with increasing demands on existing structures, capital improvements and new projects may be possible only with at least some private financing.
"The continuum of traditional, purely public involvement, the way the Interstate highway system was built, has swung to the other end with the Dulles Greenway," said Stephen Martin, director of financial development for the United States Department of Transportation. "But there is a lot going on in between."
Indeed, as many as a dozen states are either considering or already building projects with significant private investment. One, expected to open later this year, is a 10-mile toll road built between existing lanes of Interstate 91 in Southern California, from the densely populated areas of Anaheim in Orange County eastward to Riverside County.
"The public sector is just tapped out," said Gerald Pfeffer, senior vice president of United Infrastructure, the Chicago company building the California project. "Increasingly, public facilities that deliver a service, even arenas, are going to be built through public-private partnerships."
Charles E. Williams, the chief operating officer of the Dulles Greenway and a former general in the Army Corps of Engineers, said representatives of at least six states and a dozen countries had visited him to learn the advantages of private financing.. Those benefits, he said, include fewer bureaucratic hurdles, simpler financing schemes and smaller administrative staffs.
Mr. Williams also said the project had won the support of local environmental groups. Two of the largest environmental problems were solved by a one-for-one tree replacement program and by creating 150 acres of wetlands elsewhere to replace the 64 acres of federally protected wetlands needed for the project.
Indeed, since Virginia enacted legislation in 1988 allowing a private company to build the road, only a few voices have been raised in protest here in Loudoun County.
"It's a win-win situation," Mr. Williams said, referring to benefits for both motorists and the state, which will inherit ownership of the road in 42 1/2 years.
The new road offers motorists the ease of nonstop toll collection through an electronic system that deducts the amount from a driver's account -- up to $1.75 per trip for now, $2 after Jan. 1.
"It's a great benefit to us out here," said Christine Wilde, a worker at a day care center in nearby Leesburg, echoing the prevailing view. "Most people I've talked to are pretty pleased. It's going to reduce a lot of the headaches of traffic and open up a lot of retail opportunities."
Private toll roads are hardly new to the American landscape. The first, opened in 1794, was in Pennsylvania, a 62-mile link between Philadelphia and Lancaster that was financed in part by the sale of stock. As the country grew, so did enthusiasm for more private roads.
But as the railroads expanded, offering travelers a faster route to distant points, private roads began going out of business, and they had virtually passed into obsolescence by the early years of this century. When the popularity of automobiles led to a new wave of toll-road construction in the 1940's, the roads were built by state authorities with public money.
Interest in rapid automotive links between Washington and distant suburbs began in the early 1980's, when construction started on a Virginia toll road in Fairfax County. That road connected Dulles International Airport with highways leading downtown, and high-technology companies began putting new offices along it.
Officials in Loudoun County, which had grown steadily as a bedroom community, were eager for the kind of economic development that Fairfax enjoyed.
So in 1993 the state granted a group of investors, the Toll Road Investors Partnership II, authority to build the private road for $326 million. Construction was completed this month, six months ahead of schedule.

HEADLINE: With Congress Slowed to a Crawl, G.O.P. Pushes Stopgap Spending

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28

 BODY:
Conceding that the last four weeks have reflected a slower legislative pace than the hectic early days of the 104th Congress, Republicans hurried today to push stopgap spending into place so the lawmakers could leave for a 10-day recess.
The House passed the temporary spending bill without even a roll-call vote this morning. There was no visible opposition anticipated in the Senate. But the Senate leaders kept the bill on the shelf, waiting for a Friday vote. They wanted to keep the senators in Washington to work on other legislation. 
 The temporary measure will cut the Government's spending significantly below this year's level. But it would also keep programs that Republicans want to kill from being shut down, at least for the first six weeks of the fiscal year that begins on Sunday.
Republicans acknowledged the diminished rate of lawmaking in the four weeks since Congress returned from its August break. Representative Robert L. Livingston, the Louisiana Republican who is chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, said he had known all along that the early focus on the Contract With America carried with it a "built-in delay of four to five weeks" that was now being felt.
"We have talked a better game of dramatically changing the American Government than we have practiced," said Senator Phil Gramm, a Texas Republican seeking his party's Presidential nomination.
The most visible delay is that only two of the 13 basic spending bills that pay for everything from space shuttle fuel to combat boots and salaries for press spokesmen have been sent to President Clinton to sign or veto. And one of them, which finances Congress itself, was ready in August but was held back to deny the President a chance for a showy veto. Last year, when action was unusually fast, all 13 bills had reached his desk before the fiscal year began.
Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, said Congress was still working hard but its work was just "less visible." There was some delay, he acknowledged, but he said that was because the new Congress was cutting spending, and "the toughest thing to do in Washington is to cut spending."
Some of the legislation is tied up less by disputes over money than by arguments over Republican attempts to use spending bills to make policy, such as trying to bar recipients of Federal grants from lobbying Congress. Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, said that tendency was the real cause of delay.
"Very little has been done, and I think in part it is because the extreme right has dominated the agenda in the Republican caucus," Senator Daschle said. "Progress has almost been at a standstill on a number of pieces of legislation because of the pressure put on the Republican caucus by the extreme right wing."
The recess, expected to begin on Friday and last until Oct. 10, is occasioned by the Jewish holy day of Yom Kippur, and extends through Columbus Day. But even without these days, Congress needed time off so that the Congressional Budget Office could have a little time to analyze the pieces of the massive budget reconciliation bill that will cut such programs as Medicare, Medicaid and student loans.
On the biggest of those issues, Medicare, both houses of Congress are well behind schedule. The Senate Finance Committee has more than 100 amendments before it, and the House Ways and Means Committee does not yet even have a printed bill to consider. The Finance Committee may finish this week, but the Ways and Means Committee will not even begin voting before Oct. 10. The first deadline for both committees was last Friday, and then this Friday.
The most serious deadlock is over the measure that provides for the Department of Labor and the Department of Health and Human Services. A dispute over a provision designed to undo Mr. Clinton's order prohibiting the Federal Government from doing business with companies that use permanent replacements for strikers prevented the Senate from debating it today.
This bill is the biggest of all the domestic spending bills, with $62.8 billion in the Senate version and $61 billion in the bill the House passed last month.
But there is a dispute of almost equal passion surrounding efforts by Representative Ernest J. Istook Jr., Republican of Oklahoma, to bar lobbying by recipients of government grants. That provision has tied up the $23.2 billion bill financing the Treasury Department, the Postal Service and various other agencies, including the White House. Some Senate Republican conferees have joined Democrats in opposing this effort as unconstitutional.
Other bills are in various stages of consideration. Some have yet to go into House-Senate conferences, including the bills covering energy and water development and the one for the Department of Veterans Affairs, the Department of Housing and Urban Development and other agencies.
Three bills are nearly ready; they pay for the Department of Defense, the Department of the Interior and the Department of Agriculture, and have been approved by House-Senate conferences but have not been voted on in either house.
A continuing air of unreality hung over much of the debate today. Senator Arlen Specter, the Pennsylvania Republican who heads the subcommittee that deals with Labor and Health and Human Services spending, acknowledged that even if the bill was passed by the Senate, agreed on in conference and then passed again by both houses, it would face a certain veto. "This is all Confederate money," he said.
But if the Senate was relaxed, the House was caustic. Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, said that passing only 2 of 13 spending bills was equivalent to batting .154. "A .154 batting average for the champs is pretty weak," he said. "But if they could reduce the deficit to be as low as their batting average, they could really claim victory."
His ridicule was mild in comparison to the anger of Representative Randy (Duke) Cunningham, Republican of California. In a meeting of the House Committee on Economic and Educational Opportunities dealing with cuts in student loans, Mr. Cunningham said his party was really fighting "the Socialist tendencies of the Democrats, including "Communist supporters" like Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich.
"He goes along with Karl Marx in many of his writings," Mr. Cunningham said of Secretary Reich.
"There you have it!" yelled Representative Pat Williams, Democrat of Montana. "If you think the far right is now running this joint, there you have it!"
After Mr. Williams was gaveled into silence by Representative Bill Goodling, the Pennsylvania Republican who is chairman of the committee, the panel voted to eliminate the program of direct Federal student loans that was adopted two years ago.
Then it voted to charge higher fees to the banks and other lenders who will profit from the elimination of their competition. It also voted to eliminate the six-month interest-free grace period that loan recipients now have after finishing college.
 
PRIMER
The Budget: What Remains
 
APPROPRIATIONS
 
There are thirteen individual spending bills setting the amount of money agencies and programs will get for the coming fiscal year.
 
Individual houses: Senate and House (13 versions in each)
House-Senate Conference: Must make versions agree.
President: Many bills face vetoes. Absent compromise, Federal offices could run out of money in six weeks.
 
Where it stands today: The House has passed 12 of 13 bills; the Senate has approved 11. Final versions of two bills have been sent to the President, who has yet to sign ot veto them. Congress may pass two more final versions on Friday.
 
TAXES AND ENTITLEMENTS
 
Individual houses: Welfare, Tax rates and Medicare and Medicaid
House-Senate Conference: Republicans in both houses will struggle to enact curbs on health and welfare beneifts, along with deep tax cuts. If they succeed, a veto seems certain.
President: A veto would maintain current benefit levels until the two sides reach a compromise. But Republicans could force the issue by attaching their proposals to vital legislation that allows the Government to borrow more money.
 
Where it stands today: The House has approved major tax cuts and sweeping changes in welfare and Medicaid. The Senate is working on similar curbs on Medicaid but has passed only modest changes on welfare. It is working on a tax cut. Neither has enacted promised curbs on Medicare.

HEADLINE: Commerce Official to Head Yale Management School

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
Jeffrey E. Garten, the Under Secretary of Commerce for international trade and one of the chief architects of the Clinton Administration's strategy on emerging markets, said yesterday that he was resigning to become dean of Yale University's School of Management.
In two years in his post, Mr. Garten spearheaded the Administration's effort to use the country's political power to support American efforts to win contracts and business opportunities abroad. 
 Down the hall from his office, the Commerce Department built what came to be known as "the war room," where more than 150 major contracts around the world are tracked daily. From that room, Mr. Garten and other Commerce officials called on American officials from President Clinton to ambassadors to promote the business interests of the United States, much the way Japanese and German officials have done for their nations.
The agency that Mr. Garten directed, the International Trade Administration, has been at the center of the debate over the role of commercial considerations in foreign policy -- and he is leaving before that argument is over.
It is unclear whether he will be replaced: The Republican-dominated Congress is considering several plans to break up the Commerce Department, and some would relegate the department's trade operations to a proposed United States Trade Administration.
Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown has fought those efforts but Mr. Garten's departure removes the leader of one of the department's most successful operations.
"What I hope we began is a shifting in weight of our commercial interests to the center of our national interests abroad," Mr. Garten said yesterday.
"We have weighed in -- not always successfully -- arguing for more and more consideration of commercial considerations in the development of our foreign policy. But it will be a number of years before the balance is right."
Achieving that balance has often put the Commerce Department at odds with other Government agencies, particularly when trade disputes affected broader military and political relationships with allies.
Mr. Garten was active in negotiations with Japan and was one of the two lead negotiators in the automobile dispute that ended in an accord in Geneva in June.
But Mr. Garten concentrated on encouraging both Washington and American business executives to switch their focus from traditional markets to faster-growing economies like China, India, Brazil and the countries that make up the Association of South East Asian Nations.
Mr. Garten said in a telephone interview that he was leaving primarily to be closer to his wife, Ida, who runs the Barefoot Contessa, a gourmet food store and caterer in East Hampton, L.I. But he also said that the chance to direct the Yale School of Management was "a very rare opportunity." The school, since its founding, has had trouble balancing its dual objectives of turning out managers for both the public and private sector.
"Jeffrey Garten brings outstanding ideas and achievements, an exceptional breadth of top-level experience in both business and government, and a global perspective to the leadership of Yale's School of Management," Richard C. Levin, the president of Yale, said yesterday. "He personifies the school's management ideal."
Before joining the Administration, Mr. Garten was an investment banker at both Shearson Lehman Brothers and at the Blackstone Group. He worked for Henry A. Kissinger in the Nixon Administration and is the author of "A Cold Peace: America, Japan, Germany and the Struggle for Supremacy." He is a graduate of Dartmouth College and holds a Ph.D. from the School of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University.
Mr. Garten said that he hoped to turn Yale's management school into an equivalent of Yale's law school, "a small place that produces leaders with a sense of business but also with a sense of society."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jeffrey E. Garten, the Commerce Department's top international trade official, is the next dean of Yale University's School of Management. (David Scull/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: College Fees And Tuition Increase 6%

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
College tuition and fees have risen by about 6 percent in this school year, according to an annual survey released yesterday by the College Board. As a result, the annual cost at elite colleges and universities is approaching $30,000.
"When taken together with the expectation that Congress will reduce student grant and loan programs, many young people in our society face a deeply mortgaged future," said Donald M. Stewart, president of the College Board, a nonprofit association of 3,000 schools, colleges and universities. 
 Undergraduates must pay about 6 percent more this year than last for tuition and fees at four-year institutions, and 4 percent to 6 percent more at two-year institutions. The cost of room and board is also rising 2 percent to 4 percent, the survey says.
"Despite these increases, the fact remains that college is still affordable for most students," Mr. Stewart said. "Students and families must keep college costs in perspective and not focus on the relatively small number of high-priced institutions."
That view was seconded by Terry Hartle, a vice president of the American Council on Education, a research and lobbying association.
"I don't want to say that college costs aren't a tremendous strain for many people," Mr. Hartle said, "but we should remember that in 1993-94, 61 percent of all American college students spent less than $3,000 in tuition and fees. There are some tremendous bargains out there."
In fact, Mr. Hartle said, college costs have averaged two percentage points above inflation throughout this century. "It was an aberration when college costs were less than that rate during the 70's and when they were higher than that rate in the 80's. What we're seeing today is a growth rate that's back to normal."
Among the colleges that Mr. Hartle singled out as relative bargains is the University of Texas system, which enrolls 118,000 students and charges $1,623 for tuition and fees.
Another example, he said, is the State University of New York system, which enrolls 156,000 students in its four-year colleges. SUNY increased its tuition this year by $750, but an in-state student could still pay, on average, $3,900 for tuition and fees.
Among private institutions, he cited Rice University, where the full tuition is $17,013, but various discounts are offered; the average Rice student pays $9,855. In contrast, tuition and fees this year at Yale University can total nearly $28,000, without financial assistance.
Experts point to several reasons for the inexorable rise of college costs.
The first is what economists call the productivity problem. Although the salaries of professors and administrators continue to rise, the number of students does not.
Second, advanced laboratories and scholarly materials that many students need have become surprisingly costly. A subscription to Chemical Abstracts, for example, would cost a college $16,800 a year, and it is not uncommon for other journals to cost $3,000 annually.
Third, as state legislatures cut their budgets and devote more of their resources to building prisons and coping with the steady increase in the cost of programs like Medicaid, they reduce their contributions to higher education -- which mostly go to public institutions -- and pass an ever-larger share of college costs on to students and their families.
Finally, in pursuit of an increasingly diverse student body, colleges are devoting more resources to student aid based on need.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Market Rally Eases Gloom Of Mexicans

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 28

 BODY:
Mexico's peso and stock market rebounded slightly today after a four-day slide, but investors remained worried, expecting low third-quarter company earnings and fearing social unrest.
The main stock index here closed at 2,381.49, up 38.43 points, or 1.64 percent. The peso held steady at 6.385 to the dollar, making one peso worth 15.66 cents. 
 In the four sessions before today, the market dropped 8.4 percent, its biggest decline since some of the dismal days of the Mexican economic crisis in February. Analysts said the dip was based on edginess, mainly among Mexican investors who worry that a recent spate of minor political events could signal an onset of turmoil.
Fidel Velazquez, the powerful 95-year-old leader of the principal labor federation, had indicated on Sunday that he might break with the terms of an anti-inflation pact arranged by the Government and seek substantial wage increases. At the National Autonomous University, Mexico's largest, several hundred students have occupied the rector's office since last Friday to demand an increase in admissions.
A job fair by a private small-business association turned into a street melee on Tuesday between white-collar job seekers and the police when only a handful of companies showed up to offer employment to more than 60,000 applicants.
The same day, a rise in interest rates on bellwether short-term Treasury bonds raised fear that economic recovery would take longer than the Government has predicted. President Ernesto Zedillo had said that the economy might stop shrinking before the end of this year.
"There's a feeling that something is bound to happen," said Jaime Campbell, a broker for CBI Securities in Mexico City. "We're going through turbulence, but I don't think we have a change of course."
Analysts said the peso had weakened in part because companies with foreign debts were buying dollars to make quarterly interest payments and avoid foreign-exchange losses. Third-quarter earnings are expected to show dismal results for most companies except export producers.
Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz said today that Mexico was suffering an "outbreak of nervousness and market volatility," which he hoped would be brief.
The market rally came after officials said that when President Zedillo meets with President Clinton in Washington on Oct. 11, he will confirm that Mexico would repay a $12.5 billion American loan on schedule. Mexico is considering making its first payment on the financial-aid package by returning some unused reserve funds in coming weeks. But no decisions have been made, Government officials said.
The Clinton Administration provided the loans to shore up the Mexican economy after a botched December 1994 peso devaluation unleashed crippling recession in this country. The Zedillo Government in time adopted a tough fiscal package to replenish foreign reserves and limit inflation. Until now, there has been surprisingly little popular unrest despite widespread unemployment and other hardship.

HEADLINE: Buenos Aires Journal;
Will Tofu Replace the T-Bone as a National Dish?

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 28

 BODY:
It is lunchtime at the downtown Yin Yang restaurant, and the owner, Perla Palacci de Jacobowitz, is carrying trays of microbiotic salads with tofu, vegetable-stuffed empanadas and fruit-sweetened breads to the tables of dozens of hungry customers.
"Opening a natural foods restaurant in a country of meat-eaters did not seem like the wisest thing to do, but it will pay off," Mrs. Palacci said. "People are more health-conscious these days, so there are more people coming in the doors." 
 Across town at Parrilla Parana, a traditional outdoor barbecue, the pungent smoke of roasting beef billows from open grills, eliciting smiles from passersby. But the restaurant's tables and counter stools remain empty, waiting for the throng of patrons who once occupied them.
On Corrientes Avenue, a main thoroughfare, construction crews can be seen eating sandwiches and salads, when several years ago the typical laborer's lunch was beef cooked on a makeshift grill.
Could this be the same land where people once considered it almost a national duty to eat a thick steak, grilled sweetbreads and spicy sausages at least once a day?
Argentina, known the world over for its beef, is eating less red meat these days and more poultry, pasta, and salads.
Concerned about their health and beset by a stubborn recession and record unemployment, Argentines are exercising more and eating lighter and cheaper. For the first time in recent memory the price of chicken, driven by cheap imports, has dropped below the price of beef in Argentina: a two-pound broiler costs about $2, or 30 percent less than two pounds of beef.
To meet the new demand, a growing number of inexpensive vegetarian restaurants, natural food markets and salad bars have opened. As Argentines try new foods, the national palate, traditionally very bland, is expanding, and ethnic restaurants are opening in large numbers for the first time in Buenos Aires, which now has Chinese, Thai, Japanese, Indian and African eateries.
To be sure, vegetarians are still considered odd in Argentina. "It's difficult to live here as a vegetarian," said Carlos Figoli, a 40-year-old cab driver, who parked to eat his meatless pasta lunch. "Most of my friends look at me funny and think I'm crazy. They always question why I don't eat meat in Argentina, the country with the best meat in the world."
Argentines still eat more beef than people in any other country, and most families continue to have a weekend asado, a mixture of beef cuts and innards grilled over charcoal. But they are eating beef less often than they used to.
According to statistics released by the Ministry of Agriculture, beef consumption in Argentina fell 12.3 percent to 140 pounds a person in 1994 from 157 pounds a person in 1990.
By comparison, beef consumption in the United States was 67.5 pounds per person in 1994, virtually unchanged from 67.8 pounds in 1990, according to United States Department of Agriculture statistics.
Felipe Sola, Secretary of the Department of Agriculture, Livestock, and Fishing, said that while beef remains a source of national pride in Argentina, the country's eating habits are changing.
"We held out for a long time," Mr. Sola said. "But as a nation we have become more concerned about our health and that has meant rethinking our diet."
Mr. Sola said that he believes the slump in the economy has also played a role in Argentina's declining beef consumption. Hit hard by a sudden recession last December and a record 18.6 percent unemployment, Argentines have less money to spend eating in steak houses, a favorite pastime.
Of course, Argentina is not allowing beef -- a $4 billion industry as well as an important national symbol -- to fade away silently. President Carlos Saul Menem recently urged Argentines to eat even more red meat, vowing, "the green fad is on the way out." And the Rural Society of Argentina has promised an advertising campaign to promote the "unique" virtues of Argentine beef.
Luciano Miguens, vice president of the Rural Society of Argentina, said that Argentine beef is leaner and lower in cholesterol because it comes from cattle that are grass fed. Grain forms a large part of the diet of most beef cattle in the United States and Europe.
Mr. Miguens said that beef producers had not been hurt by the decline in local consumption because they are selling more beef abroad, especially now that Argentina has undertaken a vaccination program to eliminate hoof-and-mouth disease.
Meanwhile, Sara Hueyo, a 69-year-old anthropologist, who says she eats meat maybe once a month, lamented the decline of the wonderful smells of grilling steak that used to permeate the streets of Buenos Aires coming from the entrances to construction sites.
"It would catch you mid-step, and you would say, 'How delicious, that smell,' " she said. "I guess this is a sign that Argentina is changing."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Construction workers in Buenos Aires chow down on sandwiches and salad instead of the traditional lunch of beef barbecued on an outdoor grill. Argentines are weaning themselves from a steady diet of red meat. (Pablo Garcia Corradi for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Rockefeller Center Trust Gets New Plan

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
Gotham Partners L.P., an investment firm that holds a 5.6 percent stake in Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., proposed a plan yesterday to recapitalize the real estate investment trust as it prepares to take ownership of Rockefeller Center.
Gotham's proposal, which has the support of several of the trust's other large shareholders, would use a rights offering to raise at least $105 million and combine that with a senior loan of at least $350 million to replace some of the trust's high-cost debt and give it the financial wherewithal to operate the property. 
 The Gotham proposal is competing with a deal the REIT has already signed with an investor group led by Sam Zell, the Chicago financier, which includes the General Electric Company and the Walt Disney Company. Under that deal, the Zell group would pay $5.50 a share, or $250 million, for a 50 percent stake in a company that would own Rockefeller Center jointly with the REIT's existing shareholders.
The Leucadia National Corporation, an insurance and real estate company that owns more than 7 percent of the REIT's shares; Goodman & Company, a Canadian investment manager that owns a 5 percent stake, and O Hill Partners, a real estate firm that holds 2 percent of the REIT's stock and owns $50 million of its bonds, all support a rights offering. Such an offering essentially gives shareholders an option to buy additional shares at a discount.
"We believe this proposal is the most equitable and least expensive way to recapitalize the REIT," said William A. Ackman, a principal of Gotham, which manages money for, among others, the Ziff family, which has dismantled its publishing empire. "It raises the money the REIT needs without diluting its existing shareholders, many of whom have already seen the value of their investments fall."
Joseph S. Steinberg, president of Leucadia, said, "It's a very constructive proposal."
The REIT's shares rose 12.5 cents yesterday to close at $7.50 before the deal was announced.
Several large shareholders, including Gotham, have vowed to vote down the Zell deal because it would dilute the existing shareholders' stake in the company by 50 percent. They also say that in exchange for G.E.'s participation, the REIT would have to grant NBC a sharp reduction in its rent, and therefore the REIT's income would fall. The television network is owned by G.E. and is the center's largest tenant.
These shareholders have repeatedly suggested that before allowing outsiders like Mr. Zell and his investors to buy into the REIT at a discount to the stock's market price, the REIT should allow its shareholders to find a way to raise money. "I welcome this proposal because I have believed all along that the shareholders should have first crack at investing on very favorable terms," said Tom Tisch, whose family owns a stake in the REIT.
A spokesman for the Zell group declined to comment, saying the group had not had time to review the proposal.
Stephanie Leggett-Young, a spokeswoman for the REIT, said the board would consider Gotham's proposal "in due course."
The REIT is preparing a joint plan of reorganization with the owners of Rockefeller Center, the Mitsubishi Estate Company and the Rockefeller family trusts, that will bring Rockefeller Center out of bankruptcy protection by handing over ownership to the REIT, which holds the $1.3 billion mortgage on the property. The plan is scheduled to be presented in bankruptcy court on Tuesday.
In the rights offering that Gotham has proposed, shareholders would receive rights on a pro rata basis to buy additional shares in the REIT at $5.50 a share, for a total of $105 million. If they chose not to exercise those rights, they could sell them in the open market.
Arnold Kastenbaum, an analyst who follows the REIT at M. J. Whitman Inc., valued the deal at $8 to $9 a share. He estimated that the rights would immediately be worth 80 cents a share in the open market.
The REIT, with Gotham's assistance, would obtain at least $350 million more from a lender like a bank or insurance company, which would be used to repay $116 million it owes to the Goldman Sachs Mortgage Company, an affiliate of Goldman, Sachs & Company, and buy back $213 million of convertible bonds.
The proposal asks for two concessions from Goldman, which previously made a bid for control of the REIT that the board rejected. Gotham wants Goldman's Whitehall Street Real Estate L.P. to exercise warrants and rights that entitle it to buy a 19.9 percent stake in the REIT at $5 a share, which would raise an additional $47.5 million.
Whitehall would then be able to participate on a pro rata basis in the rights offering.
And Gotham wants to subordinate a $75 million loan that the REIT took from Whitehall last year to the new $350 million loan it plans. As part of its own bid for control of the REIT, Whitehall suggested that it would be willing to subordinate that loan, which carries an expensive 14 percent interest rate.
If it agreed to subordinate its loan, Whitehall would stand in line to be repaid after the new lender and the holders of the REIT's zero-coupon bonds.
A person involved in the Zell deal raised several questions about Gotham's proposal. He said that leaving the $75 million loan in place would raise the price of the new financing the REIT would seek under the Gotham proposal. He also questioned whether the rights offering would raise enough money for the REIT. And he noted that his group had previously tried to work out a subordination agreement with Goldman.
"We spent three weeks talking about it, and ultimately their definition of subordination would have left the REIT with an economically inferior deal," the person said. "Ackman is falling victim to the same thing."
But in its letter to the REIT's board yesterday, Gotham, which is represented by Leonard Rosen, a lawyer at Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, hinted that it could get around Goldman if need be. "We would welcome the participation of Whitehall and Goldman, Sachs & Company in our transaction on the terms described above," the letter said. "However, if Goldman's consent it not obtained, we believe an alternative structure exists" that would "enable the transaction to be consummated without the consent of Goldman and without breaching their contractual arrangements."
A spokesman for Goldman and Whitehall declined comment.
Gotham may be contemplating a strategy -- similar to one the Zell group has planned to use -- for reducing Goldman's influence in the situation, obtained as part of the terms of its loans. Both Gotham and the Zell group contend that although Whitehall's loan says it cannot be prepaid before 2000, a provision in the loan requiring the REIT to hand over to Whitehall all cash it does not need for operations creates a loophole that would permit prepayment.
Once that loan is prepaid, its prohibition against the REIT's merging into a new company, which is part of Gotham's proposal, would no longer be in force.
But Goldman contends that there is no loophole. It has hired Arthur L. Liman, the noted defense lawyer and a partner in Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, to represent it should anyone challenge its rights under the loan agreement.
