HEADLINE: Could This Be You?

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
In the business of selling life insurance, death is making a comeback.
Since the 1980's, when talk about mortality was supplanted by charts showing high interest rates, insurers have focused their sales pitches on the value of policies as an investment that can grow without being taxed. 
 But as they packaged policies primarily as investments, some insurers fell into bad sales habits, including overstating returns, that eventually led to a deluge of customer complaints and lawsuits and a falloff in sales. Now, agents and some large insurers have joined to spend millions on an advertising campaign to repair their image. The linchpin is a return to the simple, old-fashioned way of selling insurance: pushing the death benefit.
The advertisements, to appear in newspapers and on radio and perhaps on television, range from a stark warning -- "It's 1998. You're Dead" -- to more gentle reminders of mortality, including "Before you see the light . . . see the light."
Other proposed ads are aimed at women, a market that many insurance executives say they have not served as well as they should. One ad, picturing five women at various stages of life, will advise: "All the women who won't outlive their husbands don't need to read any further."
But with the campaign not even begun -- there was a test run two weeks ago but there is no formal start-up date -- the grumbling can already be heard.
Some insurance executives see the program as only an exercise to make the industry feel good about itself. They say the campaign does nothing to address the key problem, which is an outmoded product.
And others say the campaign is at odds with demographic trends. People are living longer, they say, and consumers' concerns have shifted from death at a young age to death at such an old age that savings might be exhausted. Thus sales of annuities, which promise a stream of future payments as long as you live, are growing rapidly while sales of new life policies with an investment feature are stagnant.
"The objective is good, but the industry is still trying to make an old product look more attractive than it really is," said Robert W. MacDonald, chief executive at Life USA, a Minneapolis-based insurer specializing in annuities. The campaign is relying on some old industry favorites -- guilt and fear -- to spur sales, he added.
But the campaign's backers say they are on the right track.
"The death benefit is what makes life insurance unique," said David Woods, an agent in Springfield, Mass., for the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company and the president of the agents' group that organized the new campaign. Insurers paid about $30 billion in death benefits last year.
That focus got lost in the go-go 1980's, he said, when the sales gurus of the industry decided that most people were put off by talk about their own deaths -- and were more likely to buy life insurance if it was described as a way to accumulate money for their continued life in retirement.
"We can all blame ourselves for kicking away our birthright," said Mr. Woods, who recalls that as a new agent, 30 years ago, "part of our training was to hand-deliver death benefit checks to widows." It was, he says, "a way for agents to learn an appreciation of the best that life insurance can do."
Last year, to remind consumers about the death benefit -- and the usefulness of life insurance agents in financial planning -- Mr. Woods and other agents created the Life and Health Insurance Foundation for Education, with the convenient acronym of LIFE.
The group received $1.5 million of seed money from organizations representing 165,000 agents, including the Million Dollar Round Table, an organization for the most successful agents. It then turned to a New York public relations firm, Robinson Lake Sawyer Miller. With a combination of advertising, seminars and training materials for agents, executives at Robinson Lake hope to "move the needle" on public opinion of life insurance, in much the same way that they succeeded with earlier efforts to promote milk and pork.
"We are running this along the lines of a political-style campaign," said Carter A. Eskew, head of Bozell/Eskew, the advertising arm of Robinson Lake.
The strongest financial support for the campaign, which has raised $14 million so far, comes from companies that have suffered steep declines in sales recently, and have faced the most complaints from regulators and customers:
*The Prudential Insurance Company, whose $2 million contribution was the first by an insurer and was a catalyst for others. Prudential's sales practices are being investigated by regulators from 27 states. The company also faces many lawsuits by customers.
*The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, which was fined $20 million last year by a different multistate task force and spent over $80 million more in payments to customers and legal fees. It has contributed $1 million to the campaign.
*New York Life, which earlier this year agreed to settle class-action suits by offering added benefits to three million clients who bought policies from 1982 to 1994, costing the company $65 million. It has given $1 million to the campaign.
Other contributors, like Guardian in New York, Northwestern Mutual in Milwaukee and Principal Financial in Des Moines, avoided the worst sales mistakes but recognize that they, too, are being harmed by the industry's image.
"The industry has definitely suffered from the public's negative feelings," said Ted Athanassiades, the second-ranking executive at Met Life. "This idea came from the agents themselves, and it was important to us to support their effort."
Agents have become increasingly restless lately as their incomes have fallen. At Met Life, for example, the number of agents has dropped to about 8,700 from 14,000 several years ago, while Prudential is down to 14,000, from 20,000.
In the best of times, selling insurance is a tough business, with fewer than one of every five agents still active after four years. Now that commissions on new sales have also dropped, companies have become worried about losing their most experienced agents, either to another insurer or another line of work.
Agents attending a conference in Minneapolis two weeks ago got a taste of the campaign when the first full-page ads appeared in a local newspaper. "You could almost hear the sigh of relief," Mr. Woods said.
For more than 20 years, he said, the industry spent millions annually on trade groups that would lobby in the political arena, "but we did not have any group whose only objective was to educate the public about the value of life insurance."
Barry M. Roth, head of Roth Associates, a New York sales agency that represents Equitable Life Assurance, said he favored any effort to "improve the public's perception of the average agent." But, he added, he is unsure how much can be gained by emphasizing the death benefit and de-emphasizing policies' investment component.
"Life insurance does not sell as easily these days when all you are selling is the death benefit," he said, adding that "life insurance as a long-term investment plan is still a great product."
Mr. Woods and others handling the program say that in stressing death benefits, the campaign will not favor one product or company over others.
Despite that goal of neutrality, the campaign's emphasis on the death benefit as a key element in a financial plan could turn up the heat on a long-simmering industry dispute -- whether a client is better off buying low-cost term insurance than whole-life or some other investment-related policy. Term policies, now a fast-growing type of life insurance, have no investment component.
Consumers who are convinced by the ads that the death benefit is important will find that term insurance is the cheapest way to go, assuming their insurance needs decline in their later years, when the cost of a term policy rises sharply.
Unfortunately for agents, the low premiums on term insurance produce commissions that are only a small fraction of those earned on policies with an investment feature. That financial incentive, many say, is the root cause of many of the improper sales practices that have hurt the industry in recent years.
Traditional life insurance, with or withoutinvestment features, "was a great product for the past 100 years, when the greatest fear was of dying young," said Mr. MacDonald of Life USA. Now that people are living longer, though, there are more two-income families and there is a sharper awareness of investment choices, he said. That has led to a greater need to develop products promising more income during retirement.
"Most of the old companies are slow to do that," he added, "for fear that their customers will want to replace their existing products with something new."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST ACCORD;
From Clinton, Arafat and Rabin: Hope, Dreams and Now Peace

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from remarks by President Bill Clinton; Yasir Arafat, Chairman of the Palestinian Liberation Organization, and Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel at the signing of the peace accord at the White House, as transcribed by The Associated Press:
 
PRESIDENT CLINTON
The agreement that now will be signed means that Israel's mothers and fathers need no longer worry that their sons will face the dangers of patrolling Nablus or confronting the hostile streets of Ramallah. And it means that Palestinians will be able to decide for themselves what their schools teach, how their houses should be built, and who they will choose to govern. . . . . 
 Mr. Prime Minister and Mr. Chairman, you are showing that it is not by weapons but by will and by word that dreams best become reality. Your achievement shines as an inspiration to others all around this world who seek to overcome their own conflicts and to secure for themselves the blessings of peace.
Chapter by chapter Jews and Arabs are writing a new history for their ancient lands. Camp David, the declaration of principles signed here two years ago, the peace last year between Jordan and Israel: with each of these the truth of this book has become clear to the world as courageous leaders step beyond the bounds of convention.
They build for their peoples a new world of hope and peace. Now, as this new chapter begins, it is fitting that we are joined by so many from the camp of peace.
 
YASIR ARAFAT
We are gathered today under the sponsorship of President Clinton, who has generously offered to host the signing of this agreement.
It has been two years since we met at the White House to sign the Declaration of Principles, to which we and our Israeli partners have agreed to in Oslo. We meet again today to make new headway in giving hope to this historic process, the process of realizing a credible peace, reconciliation, and coexistence between the Palestinian and Israeli peoples, and the peace of the brave, which we achieved on Egyptian land at Taba, under President Mubarak's auspices.
A significant portion of Palestinian national rights reverts today to the Palestinian people through their control of the cities, villages, and populated areas. Recovery of this portion is a step in the implementation of the interim agreement, which we are gathered here to witness its signing.
There is also a step which paves the way to free and democratic Palestinian elections, capping thereby the political components required for the establishment of an independent Palestinian national entity on the Palestinian territories. . . .
The permanent status negotiations will deal with such issues as settlements, the delineation of the borders, the rights of Palestinian refugees as determined by the international legitimacy, and the fundamental issue concerning the status of Jerusalem, which our people, irrespective of their faith -- Moslems, Christians or Jews -- consider Jerusalem to be the heart and soul of their entity and the center of their cultural, spiritual and economic life.
I would say that the sanctity of Jerusalem for us all dictates that we make it the joint cornerstone and the capital of peace between the Palestinian and the Israeli peoples inasmuch as it is a beacon for believers all over the world.
We urge you all to recognize the importance of this historic interim step that demonstrates the irreversibility of the peace process. Its distinct significance lies in the verdict passed by history, the international community, and human civilization at the turn of the century; that a just and comprehensive peace be established on this sacred land whereby the Israeli and Palestinian peoples would coexist on the basis of mutual recognition of the rights, while enjoying equality and self-determination without occupation or repeated wars, and without terrorism.
At this point, I must tell our Israeli partners, from this solemn rostrum, and in the presence of our brethren and friends who have come here from the region and from all of the world, particularly those who contributed to the realization of this agreement, that our past experience underscores the need to be more credible and committed to our steps in the future.
And the commitment should be precise, honest, and mutual.
For our part, we will honor our commitments. That's why the continuation and expansion of the settlement drive, as the situation in the city of Hebron and elsewhere shows, lead to the persistence of tensions. Likewise, continued qualms about a new independent Palestinian birth convey to each and every Palestinian the feeling that his or her life shall remain in jeopardy.
Today, standing before you, I tell you with courage and a sense of responsibility that our participation in the great peace process means that we are betting everything on the future.
Therefore we must condemn and foreswear violence totally, not only because the use of violence is morally reprehensible, but because it undermines Palestinian aspirations to the realization of peace, the exercise of our political and national options, and the achievement of economic and cultural progress in Palestine and in the region.
From this day on we do not want to see any waste of or threat to any innocent Palestinian life or any innocent Israeli life. Enough killing and enough killing of innocent people. . . .
For us to succeed on both fronts, we are bound to base the emerging Palestinian political system on the principles of liberty, democracy, separation of powers, freedom of expression, and national initiative. We are also bound to continue building Palestinian institutions and the Palestinian national economy.
But this enterprise is still in its early stages and our institutions have yet to mature. The road ahead remains long, indeed. We look forward to your continued support of our people, and we thank all friendly and brotherly donors for their assistance.
 
YITZHAK RABIN
The sight you see -- you see before you at this moment was impossible, was unthinkable just two years ago. Only poets dreamt of it. And to our great pain, soldier and civilians went to their death to make this moment possible. Here we stand before you, men who fate and history have sent on a mission of peace to end once and for all 100 years of bloodshed.
Our dream is also your dream, King Hussein, President Mubarak, Chairman Arafat, all the others, and above, assisting us, President Bill Clinton, a president who is working in the service of peace. We all love the same children, weep the same tears, hate the same enmity, and pray for reconciliation. Peace has no borders.
Yes, I know; our speeches are already repeating themselves. Perhaps this picture has already become routine. The handshakes no longer set your pulse racing. Your loving hearts no longer pound with emotion as they did then. . . .
We have matured in the two years since we first shook hands here. The handshake: that was the sign and symbol of the start of reconciliation. Today we are more sober. We are gladdened by the potential for reconciliation, but we are also wary of the dangers that lurk on every side.
The enemies of yesterday share a common enemy of today and in the future: the terrorism that sows death in our homes and on the busses that ply the streets. The sounds of celebration here cannot drown out the cries of innocent citizens who traveled those buses to their death.
And new eyes shining here cannot erase for a single moment of the sight of the lifeless eyes of the students who were going to their classes and housewives who were on their way to market when hatred struck them down. We are pained by their death and remember them with love.
I want to say to you, Chairman Arafat, the leader of the Palestinians, together we should not let the land that flows with milk and honey become a land flowing with blood and tears. Don't let it happen. If all the partners to the peace making do not unite against the evil angels of death by terrorism, all that will remain of this ceremony are color snapshots, empty momentos.
Rivers of hatred will overflow again and swamp the Middle East.
We, gentlemen, will not permit terrorism to defeat peace. We will not allow it. If we don't have partners in this bitter, difficult war we will fight it alone. We know how to fight, and we know how to win.
My brother Jews speak through the media to you. Thousands of years of exile and the dream of generations have returned us to our historic home in the land of Israel, the land of the prophets. Etched on every vineyard, every field, every olive tree, every flower is the deep imprint of the Jewish history, of the Book of the Books that we have bequeathed to the entire world, of the values of morality and of justice. Every place in the land of the prophets, every name is an integral part of our heritage, of thousands of years, neighbor.
Ladies and gentlemen, this week the Jewish people in its thousands of places of dispersion has marked a new year, and in their Holy Day prayers, Jews everywhere are saying -- May we -- I'm translating it to the best of my capability.
May we be remembered and inscribed before you in the Book of Life and of blessing and peace and prosperity, of deliverance and comfort and opportunity, we and all who people the House of Israel, for a good life and peace. These are my wishes to all the Jewish people. These are my wishes to all the citizens of Israel: a good life and a peace. These are also our wishes to our neighbors, to all the world peoples: a good life and peace.
Ladies and gentlemen, look at us again. Look at the scene on the stage, here in the White House. You are not excited anymore. You have grown up accustomed to it. But in order for peace to be completed, in order for this picture to be completed and for the Middle East to become a jewel in the world crown, it still lacks two people -- the president of Syria and the president of Lebanon. I call upon them to come and join us, to come to the platform of peace.

HEADLINE: Stocks Gain, With Dow Up by 25.29

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market leaped forward yesterday, as buyers returned in force after Wednesday's early selloff and late rebound.
"Institutions did some end-of-the-quarter portfolio adjusting, and there was some program trading at the close," said Robert Ritter, chief technical analyst of Ladenburg Thalmann & Company. "That led to gains almost across the board." 
The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 25.29 points to close at 4,787.64, its high for the session. Among the broader indicators, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 4.83 points, to 585.87, and the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index soared 20.51 points, to 1,047.05.
After the Labor Department reported a sign of economic vigor in a larger-than-expected drop in the number of workers filing first-time jobless claims last week, the market opened on the upside, and it remained there for most of the day. The 30-year Treasury bond fell 5/32 and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, increased to 6.59 percent from 6.57 percent.
Advances far exceeded declines on the New York Stock Exchange, with 1,467 issues rising and 806 falling. Big Board volume eased to 367.8 million shares, from 411.3 million shares on Wednesday.
Technology stocks were once more the day's standout, as bargain hunters continued to search for depressed values in issues that they believed to be oversold. Hewlett-Packard rose 2 7/8, to 85 5/8; Micron gained 4 1/8, to 82 5/8; Microsoft increased 2 7/8, to 91 1/2; Intel advanced 2 9/16, to 61 7/8, and Cisco Systems spurted 2 7/8, to 70 7/8. After a recommendation from Bear, Stearns, Compaq broke out of its recent trading range and its price at the bell was 49 5/8, up 3 1/8.
Insurance issues were up in the wake of an unconfirmed report from Sanford C. Bernstein & Company that Aetna Life and Casualty would spin off its troubled property and casualty unit. Aetna itself closed at a 52-week high of 74 3/8, up 2 3/8; Allstate closed at 35 5/8, up 1 3/8; American International Group closed at 86 1/2, up 2 1/8; Cigna closed at 105 7/8, up 6 1/8, and Chubb closed at 96 7/8, up 1 3/8. Caremark International Inc. agreed to acquire the Cigna Medical Group, which operates 29 clinics in Los Angeles, from Cigna Health Care of California, a managed health care subsidiary of Cigna.
The Dow Jones utilities average, which has been rising all week, increased 2.24 points, to 214.74. Consolidated Edison increased3/8, to 30 1/2; Delmarva rose 1/8, to 22 7/8; Detroit Edison advanced 5/8, to 32 1/4, and Duke Power spurted 1, to 43 3/4.
Defensive stocks retreated in keeping with yesterday's renewed optimism regarding economic growth. For example, major drug issues closing on the downside included Schering-Plough, off 5/8, to 51 7/8; Merck, off 1/2, to 56 3/8, and Bristol-Myers, off 7/8, to 72 3/8.
Similarly, food stocks also slipped. Campbell Soup closed at 50 5/8, down 1/2; General Mills wound up at 55 3/4, down 1; Kellogg finished at 72 3/8, down 5/8, and Sara Lee ended at 29 7/8, down 1/8.
Nashua dropped 2 3/8, to 15 1/4, after stating that it expects a third-quarter loss of $300,000 to $1 million. And the American depository receipts of Alcatel Alsthom declined 3 1/8, to 17 3/8, after the company announced a first-half loss.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off Again on Uncertainty Over European Monetary Union

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell further against most leading currencies yesterday as continued uncertainty about European monetary union strengthened the German mark and the Swiss franc.
The dollar was held to a small loss against the mark as traders awaited a weekend European summit meeting aimed at resolving doubts about the future of a single currency. 
 Japanese investors, meanwhile, faced a weekend of reconciling the quarter's books and had little reason to buy dollars, allowing the dollar to slip.
In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 99.22 Japanese yen, from 100.45 yen on Wednesday. It also fell to 1.4200 German marks from 1.4253 marks and to 1.1433 Swiss francs from 1.1530 Swiss francs. The British pound rose to $1.5792 from $1.5755.
In European and Asian trading, the dollar dropped against European currencies, but recovered toward the end of European trading and into the session in New York. Against the yen, it was a slow slide from the start of Asian trading.
"It was more of a day where the news was predominantly European and less focused on domestic issues in the United States," said Wayne Grigull, director of foreign exchange sales at Merrill Lynch & Company.
In Europe, investors moved to the mark from the Italian lira partly because of disappointment with Italy's budget, which fell short of requirements for a common European currency.
The Italian budget called for a deficit that amounted to 5.8 percent of the country's gross domestic product. The maximum deficit under rules for attaining monetary union by 1999 is 3 percent of G.D.P.
While some traders sold lire and bought marks, others moved into Swiss bonds and francs.
The attention to Italy's budget follows remarks last week by German monetary officials who said Italy and France were among the countries that might not meet the criteria for a single currency.
The remarks caused an uproar in currency markets and the dollar has seesawed since then as politicians have tried to right the foundering ship of monetary union.
The European finance ministers and central bankers meet this weekend to map out their plans for the single currency,
"We are riding a lot on the seriousness building in Europe," said Dan Ascani, editor and publisher of Global Market Strategist, an advisory firm in Gainesville, Ga. "If the solution is not accepted by the market, the magnitude of the crisis developing in Europe would increase dramatically,"

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Jobless Data Push Down Bond Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday, following a report that suggests the labor market is improving and provides more evidence that the Federal Reserve need not cut interest rates.
Weekly first-time jobless claims were down 31,000, to 335,000, from 366,000 the previous week. The decline was much stronger than the expected drop of 7,000, to 358,000. The four-week average, which is considered a better gauge, subject to less volatility, fell to 351,750 from a revised 355,000. 
 Cautious trading was the rule yesterday, some market participants said, as sellers and buyers engaged in a tug-of-war, with prices whipsawing throughout the session.
The 30-year bellwether issue was down 5/32 in the cash market to a price of 10324/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.59 percent, from 6.57 percent on Wednesday.
Carl Palash, chief economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York, said: "Today's numbers provided more evidence that the economy has picked up steam as the third quarter is ending. In particular, the initial claims data and Conference Board's help-wanted index show that the labor market is still in good shape." Mr. Palash expects an increase of 175,000 in next week's nonfarm payroll numbers.
In bond futures trading, which affects trading in the cash market, "prices were range-bound," Robin Mesch, fixed-income analyst at Thomson Research in Portland, Ore., said. "The market is in a period of equilibrium betweeen buyers and sellers," she added, "as the price of the December bond contract moves between 11218/32 and 1139/32 ."
She said that as the market comes into the end of a month and the end of a quarter, traders are a bit jittery trying to position themselves. "We think next quarter is going to play the role of a transitional quarter," Ms. Mesch said, "from a strong uptrend to a period of consolidation."
Ms. Mesch said that would translate to a market range of 114 to 116 at the top, and 10821/32 on the downside, which would be a retest of last quarter's low. Yesterday the December bond contract hit a high of 1139/32 , with a low of 11218/32 , to finish at 113.
"Which end the market is going to put in first is what all this choppy trading has been about for the last three days," she said.
The market today will be subjected to another dose of strong economic data, with the key number being the September Chicago Purchasing Managers index.
"I think the risk is that if it jumps to about 55 percent, from 49.3 in August, this will put it in the range that signals a significant improvement in manfacturing," Mr. Palash said. That, he added, "raises the specter of stronger growth in the fourth quarter and along with it increasing fears about inflation accelerating and little or no chance of a Fed increase this year."
Data on August new-home sales today are likely to show an increase, and that in turn helps explain why the manufacturing sector is doing better.
"Basically, the market is going to be weighed down by strong economic numbers going into next week," Mr. Palash said.
James Hale, a fixed-income analyst at MMS International, said the market had not been giving the economy the credit it deserved. "The market has been underestimating its strength, and we are finally starting to get proof of that from recent data," he said. "Today's examples were the initial claims report and a couple of regional manufacturing surveys."
Traders had been pricing a premium into bonds in the conviction that the Fed would cut rates. Now, that premium "is being priced out as the strong data continues to mount," Mr. Hale said.

HEADLINE: The Missing Man

 BODY:
With one conspicuous exception, the key players in the long, painful search for peace in the Middle East gathered yesterday in the White House East Room to celebrate the biggest and boldest step so far toward coexistence between Israel and the Palestinians.
This historic assemblage included President Clinton and, flanking him, Yitzhak Rabin, the Israeli Prime Minister; Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman; President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, and King Hussein of Jordan. They were the most prominent witnesses to the signing of a new agreement transferring essential military and political control over most Arab residents of the West Bank into Palestinian hands. If this agreement works, it will lay the foundation for a settlement between the two peoples at the heart of the Middle East conflict. 
 But as Mr. Rabin noted in his remarks, one vitally important leader was not on hand -- President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, who controls Lebanon's foreign policy too. Syria and Lebanon, alone among Israel's neighbors, stand aloof from the growing regional dynamic of peace. Though formally committed to a negotiated solution, Mr. Assad resists the kind of compromises that make agreements possible. Yet until he accepts Mr. Rabin's invitation to "come to the platform of peace," the Middle East's promising diplomatic and economic transformation will not be complete.
That situation should concern Syria at least as much as it does Israel. Through their peace agreements with Egypt, Jordan and the P.L.O., Israeli leaders have dramatically improved Israel's prospects for security and prosperity. Syria is doing well enough on both counts for the time being. But it cannot afford to isolate itself too much longer from a region increasingly turning its attention to economic development and cross-border cooperation.
Mr. Assad's priorities right now are maintaining political dominance at home, preparing the way for a loyal successor and guarding against any adverse consequences for Syria should Saddam Hussein finally lose his grip over Iraq. Making peace with Israel ranks well behind those concerns.
Mr. Assad does just enough to keep peace talks alive. But he prefers to deal with Israel through low-level intermediaries or America rather than engage his own prestige in the process. Progress therefore has been glacial and intermittent. Talks between military officials on both sides, broken off in recent months, may now be about to resume.
But Israel and Syria remain far apart on the extent and timing of any Israeli military withdrawal from the Golan Heights, monitoring arrangements and the quality of diplomatic normalization Syria is willing to offer in exchange for Israeli withdrawal.
Israel hints at flexibility on all these issues if Syria will engage in high-level direct talks, insisting only on assuring the security of its citizens in northern border areas and continued access to local water resources. But with a momentous West Bank agreement to digest, Israel can wait a bit for Syria to come around. Even if the opposition Likud Party comes to power in next year's Israeli elections, talks with Syria will continue.
At the signing ceremony President Clinton reaffirmed America's commitment to keeping up its diplomatic efforts "until the circle of peace is closed" around all of Israel's borders. How long that may take hinges largely on the choices of yesterday's missing man.

PUB-DATE: September 29, 1995

SECTION: Section A; Page 31; Column 2; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 685 words

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
On Another Planet?

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Do the members of the Republican majority in Congress want to swim at beaches polluted by raw sewage? Do they want to live in a country with forests stripped bare, birds disappearing, trout and salmon gone? Do they want toxic wastes draining into sources of the water they drink?
Those would be some of the results of environmental legislation that the Republicans are pressing toward enactment. And one has to wonder why they want to do such things to themselves. For in this area, unlike others, they would be among the victims of their own policy -- unless they plan to live on another planet. 
 They are not likely to be affected by other revolutionary changes they are trying to make in our society. They will not have to go without health care because of changes in Medicaid or Medicare. Their children will not be deprived of welfare. They are not among the working poor whose taxes will rise.
But they breathe the same air as the rest of us, profit from the same beauty and serenity of nature, rely on the same protections against environmental hazards. As Shakespeare might have said, hath not a Congressman senses? If you poison him, does he not die?
The House, under Speaker Newt Gingrich's leadership, voted to cut the Environmental Protection Agency's spending by a third. But the two Houses and their committees have gone far beyond that, writing dozens of ripper provisions into pending appropriation bills. The effect would be to gut our environmental laws.
These are some of the things the bills would do:
* Open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska, which may be America's greatest unspoiled ecosystem, to oil and gas drilling.
* Prevent the E.P.A. from keeping possibly toxic fill out of lakes and harbors.
* Deprive the E.P.A. of funds to keep raw sewage out of rivers and away from beaches.
* Prohibit for a year the listing of new endangered species for protection and kill most of the funding to carry out the Endangered Species Act.
* Cut by two-thirds, from 300,000 to 100,000 acres, the wetlands to be bought from farmers by the Agriculture Department for a reserve.
* Increase logging in the Tongass National Forest, a remarkable rain forest in Alaska.
"Congress has set up a virtual environmental exemption bazaar," Gov. John Kitzhaber of Oregon said the other day, "granting special interest after special interest exemption." Serving those special interests must matter more to the Republicans in Congress than the integrity of the environment in which they, too, will live.
The way the Republicans are carrying out their Operation Plunder is revealing. They are making policy in riders attached to appropriation bills, usually without hearings, without debate or votes on the floor, or indeed sometimes in defiance of floor votes.
Last week, for example, the House rejected by a vote of 231 to 180 a bill creating a commission to consider privatizing the management of some national parks. Later the same day the defeated provision was attached to a spending bill.
Several of the exemptions from environmental law are attached to the giant budget reconciliation bill. One of those is the provision for drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.
Legislation destroying our established and increasingly effective system of protecting the environment is far more important, I think, than the revolutionary changes being made in welfare, Medicaid and other such programs. Particular economic arrangements can always be changed, but the environment is forever. When oil has polluted the Arctic refuge, all the king's horses and all the king's men cannot put it back together again.
Most Americans understand that. They would not be for pollution and the degradation of nature if the issues were put squarely to them. No doubt that is why the Congressional Republicans are trying to slip their ripper provisions through in silence.
President Clinton has said he will veto legislation damaging to the environment, even the budget reconciliation bill. If he keeps that promise, and explains what is at stake, the public will support him.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

SECTION: Section A; Page 31; Column 6; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 730 words

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Listening To Arafat

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
The first time Yasir Arafat went to Washington to sign an agreement with Israel he made two speeches. The first was the formal address, heard around the world. The second was to the Palestinian people, broadcast through Jordanian TV and neither heard nor noted in the West.
In that second speech, he said that the Oslo declaration of peace principles, signed a few hours earlier, was the first step "in the 1974" plan. Every Arab in the Mideast knew what that meant. The Arab strategy drawn up in 1974 called for the "phased" destruction of Israel. 
 But two years later, Mr. Arafat and Israel have signed an even more important agreement -- not a declaration of principle but the actual institution of Israeli withdrawal and Palestinian self-government on the West Bank. That changes the Mideast picture politically and militarily, and is meant to do so irrevocably.
This should be said: Mr. Arafat has become one of the most successful modern leaders of national movements, certainly in the Arab Mideast. He turned the Palestine Liberation Organization from a running feud into a near-state, acknowledged as such around the world. And he did it with the help of the Israeli Government and the U.S., once his designated Satans.
When he is addressed as Mr. President, nobody smirks. He has won from the Israelis most of the conditions of independence: control over territory, an armed force, a legislature, the power of taxation, passports, courts.
Now it is a matter of time before an independent Palestine is recognized. Even foreigners afraid that such a state would be a threat to Israel will find it difficult to make a rational case against independence since the Israeli Government itself created the conditions for it.
Mr. Arafat was near the political end when Oslo was signed. He has given up virtually nothing for the gains he won for Palestinians. But the Israeli Government has profited too. It would be destructive and deceptive to deny that -- particularly by those of us who still worry that the accords can weaken Israeli security.
Jordan and Israel are officially at peace. Near-peace exists with other Arab nations in the Mideast. That means a great deal to every human being -- to begin to feel at home in your own neighborhood.
If Likud wins the next election it will strengthen security controls but is not likely to scrap the accords. Done is done.
Why do so many Israelis fear these agreements, enough to threaten the Labor Government? Some Israelis oppose them for religious reasons. The Rabin Government and its foreign supporters make a political and ethical mistake by treating these Israelis as fanatical idiots. If Israel's security is compromised, there will be no way to tell the difference between the blood of religious or non-observant Jews, or between Labor's and Likud's.
Most Israelis who oppose the agreements are driven not by religion but fear about the area where they believe Israel is losing -- the safety of their nation. That's not strange; the agreements involve land transfers that Labor as well as Likud once said could destroy Israeli security.
That takes us back to the "phases" speech of Mr. Arafat in 1993. It was not an exception then -- nor is it now.
On my desk is a pile of transcripts, tapes and intelligent material about passages of Arafat speeches in the two years since Oslo: jihad, jihad via death, via sacrifices, the "weapons" of jihad and martyrdom. They are violations of his promises to end incitement and hostile propaganda.
Israelis know too well that holy war propaganda brings wars, one after another. How can they trust a man who used it against them when he was on the fringe of power and uses it now that he has achieved it?
The U.S. and Israel have consistently played down jihad rhetoric by Mr. Arafat and the P.L.O. His use of international funds for political purposes and the P.L.O.'s slippery attitude about terrorism are also ignored, covered up or rationalized. Israel and the U.S. became not simply his negotiating partner but his shield.
The time for that should be over. Mr. Arafat must be held politically and economically accountable for holy war incitements to violence. Unless his promises are fulfilled, away from the microphones and cameras, there will be no trust. The accords and their fruit can become not a garden in the desert but one more patch of sand.
